HEADLINE: EVENING HOURS;
May's Parties And Pace Pick Up

 BODY:
Celebrating causes, from Russian genealogy to wildlife for children.

GRAPHIC: Photo: May 14, 7:40 P.M.: A children's party at the Central Park Wildlife Center raised $60,000 for the Wildlife Conservation Society. Nearly 1,000 parents and children attended. May 16, 10:35 P.M.: The New York City Ballet held a benefit dinner-dance at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center following a performance. More than 900 guests dined and danced on the promenade. The evening raised more than $1 million for the dance company. Among the benefit chairwomen were MICHELE HERBERT and ELIZABETH TILBERIS. The evening's highlights included the performance of "Jazz (Six Syncopated Movements)," choreographed by Peter Martins to music by Wynton Marsalis, who made a guest appearance with his orchestra. May 16, 7:30 P.M.: The Catholic Big Sisters, an organization that provides individual and group counseling, mentoring and educational programs on the Lower East Side, held an awards dinner-dance and auction at the Plaza. It raised $175,000. The guest of honor was the investor PETER S. LYNCH, who received the organization's Distinguished Service Award. He was there with his wife, CAROLYN. May 16, 8:30 P.M.: The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center celebrated its 50th anniversary with a dinner-dance at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center. The 600 guests entered the atrium by way of the striking crescent stairway. The event raised $900,000. In the half century of its existence, the society has raised $85 million for cancer care. CULLMAN was one of 960 guests. Many viewed the exhibition "Amber: Window to the Past" before dinner. May 15, 7 P.M.: The South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, which seeks to bring businesses to its neighborhood, held an awards dinner at the Sheraton New York. The event raised more than $200,000. Among the honored guests was JOHN PATTERSON JR. its president emeritus. LEWIS RUDIN and DORRETT ABRAHAMS joined him. May 13, 8:10 P.M.: The Foundation Fighting Blindness, which finances research on retinal diseases, raised $850,000 at a dinner at the Plaza. Seated, GORDON GUND, the group's chairman, with HARRIET, MICHAEL and JULI FINKELSTEIN. The guest of honor, FRITZ GERBER, the chairman of F. Hoffmann-La Roche, with AGNES GUND, Mr. Gund's sister. HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
And in the Long Run We Should Win

BYLINE: By RICHARD H. KOPPES; Richard H. Koppes is deputy executive officer and general counsel of the California Public Employees Retirement System, the nation's largest public employee pension fund with $98.5 billion in assets.

 BODY:
LAST Thursday, President Clinton put the spotlight on excessive corporate profits and exorbitant layoffs by holding a party at the White House to congratulate those companies that "do well" by their employees and their shareholders.
The Administration, however, may want to take to the woodshed the real culprits of corporate greed: the boards of directors that have allowed "the hollowing out" of America's corporations to obtain short-term increases in stock prices. 
 That statement may be surprising, coming from the nation's largest public pension fund and one of this country's strongest advocates for good performance. But contrary to assumptions being made in some board rooms of the United States, Calpers, the California Public Employees Retirement System, is not pushing to bump up short-term stock prices. We are a company's long-term patient capital and are troubled when companies sell out to short-term Wall Street traders.
So let me set the record straight: Calpers opposes layoffs to lift stock prices in the near term. This is wrong and will not work to create wealth over the long run. One public pension fund official put it best recently when he said, "You can shrink your way to profitability in the short term, but it isn't the road to greatness in the long run."
Calpers doesn't condone what's going on. We won't participate in that kind of greed. And we intend to be a constructive voice to change it, by demanding high-quality, independent directors.
How did America's corporations get to this point? To understand, we need only examine the evolution of the balance of corporate power over the last decade.
When investors began to zero in on corporate governance issues in the early 1980's, management held most of the power that might rightfully have belonged to the company's directors and its share owners.
As corporate governance activism grew, share owners, from the short-term Wall Street traders to the long-term investors like Calpers, became increasingly influential, and managers began to heed their share owners' bidding. Some managements overresponded to the point that they were willing to slash human assets to improve stock prices.
Either way, the balance of power is out of whack, this time having swung too far toward share owners. Institutional investors recognize it is not their role to govern the company. That is the responsibility of the board. Only the directors can insure that neither management nor share owners hold an unequal share of the power.
How do they do that? They can learn a lot from the Chrysler Corporation and what transpired when Kirk Kerkorian vigorously sought to distribute more of Chrysler's $7.5 billion in cash to shareholders last year.
Chrysler is led by a strong, independent board that is strategically focused and knows the business. It could resist Mr. Kerkorian's proposal because it engaged its directors, managers and investors in debating what was best for the company. "None of our institutional owners asked us to change directions," Chrysler's chairman, Robert J. Eaton, said in a recent speech to the Economic Club of Detroit. "Not one of them told us to compromise the future for the sake of today." In the last five years, Chrysler has added more than 15,000 hourly workers while creating impressive share-owner value. At its own pace, it has moved to give share owners more money, including another dividend increase last week.

THE approach taken by Chrysler's board thus serves as a model for how to remedy the needless "hollowing out" of the corporation. Strong, independent boards must be formed with directors who will individually and collectively ask questions about proposed layoffs to satisfy themselves that the layoffs are motivated by a strategic plan for long-term growth, not a desire to increase the stock price.
What critics of public pension fund investors do not realize is that we don't care about next quarter's stock price or even this year's stock price. As the company's patient capital, we hold our positions for a decade or longer.
Therein lies Calpers's next stage of corporate governance activism. We will be looking for measures of performance that are based not simply on quarterly earnings and the most recent rise in the stock price.
We will be examining how a corporation is positioned for the long term. Part of that screen will be an evaluation, for example, of whether executive compensation is rewarding short-termism and whether the company has placed true value on its workers.
Calpers will continue its focus on board structural issues with an expansion into board performance, evaluating directors individually and collectively. Among the key questions it will ask is whether the position of board chairman or chairwoman is separate from that of the chief executive. If the positions are combined, is there an independent director as lead outside director to act as a counterbalance to the power of the chief executive? We will also want to know if directors own enough stock to make themselves meaningful owners.
When we meet with directors, we'll be asking them what they have done to add value to their company. We will look at issues that affect their own objectivity and their ability to devote sufficient time to board work: the number of boards they serve on and whether they represent cross-directorships, for example.
We shouldn't let the underperformers with bloated payrolls off the hook. But Calpers and many other institutional investors will continue to advocate real long-term growth and recognize, as Mr. Clinton did on Thursday, those who resist short-termism. We will listen to quality boards that commit to actively pursue long-term growth.
With this structure in place, America will see an end to what's been called the "looting of corporate America's human capital." It can't happen soon enough.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Inflation Bonds: Now Is Not The Time

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Indexing bonds to inflation is, to hear the advocates tell it, a win-win situation for everybody. The buyers of bonds get inflation protection, while the sellers -- the Government -- get lower financing costs and a needed incentive to hold down inflation.
Don't bet on it. The chances are that such bonds, which Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin says will be issued by the Government, will prove a better deal for the buyers than for the Government, which will benefit in the short term, but suffer later. 
 There should be nothing surprising about that. Individuals are concerned with what happens 10 or 20 years out. That is why you save for retirement; if you don't, you'll be the one who suffers. But mayors, governors and presidents come and go. They do care about long-term issues, but they are primarily concerned with the current budget and the next election.
That helps to explain why Governments of all levels are in such fiscal trouble. Decades ago, mayors and governors across the land cut deals that saved money on salaries then by inflating pension benefits later. As the bills come in now, those mayors and governors have long since retired. Similarly, the Reagan fiscal excesses now constrain the Federal Government.
Here's what might happen after inflation-indexed bonds are introduced: First, the Treasury's apparent borrowing costs will fall. That is because the bonds will have a stated interest rate of 3 or 4 percent. The coupon payments will rise over time, but it will be years -- and administrations -- before they start to bite. That will free up a little space in near-term budgets.
At the same time, investors given protection against inflation may be less bothered by it. Not everyone is really against inflation. It benefits borrowers (at fixed rates) and those who own assets that are appreciating, like real estate in the 1970's. It hurts those living on fixed incomes. But not if those incomes are no longer fixed.
Then there is the impact on the stock market. It has risen with the flood of money from baby boomers worrying about retirement. They could be attracted by the promise of assured purchasing power without the risks of a speculative stock market.
Mr. Rubin argues that these bonds have an added value -- inflation protection -- for which buyers will pay. "We are offering a unique and very valuable investment vehicle," he said when asked if a future Treasury Secretary might rue the day such bonds were issued. "We should get a price that lowers our cost of capital." On average and over time, he has a good point.
But averages can deceive, and this may be the worst possible time to introduce these bonds. In 1981, when Britain took the step, inflation fears were high and interest rates were soaring. It was a clever move for the British Government, which saved a lot of money as inflation fell.
Now, however, inflation is low. "That makes it a good time for the Government to show confidence, because the confidence will be justified," says Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary. More likely, it will be seen as an indication of overconfidence near the bottom of the inflation cycle.
That said, this does not have to be too damaging to the Government, even if the bonds do prove to be great investments for the buyers. If the Government issues them as alternatives to short-term borrowing (whose rates will rise with inflation anyway), the fiscal harm will not be great.
But it is still bad timing.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
A Bear on Stocks Who's Outrunning the Bulls

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
ONE week, inflation fears grab the stock market by the throat. The next week, they all but dissipate.
Amid the jolts, stock investors keep scoring solid gains. But a select group of investors, those most concerned about rising prices, have done extraordinarily well this year. They have flocked to precious metals, commodities and natural resources. Such assets, they say, represent the best opportunity because inflationary pressures are building in the economy. 
 Whether prices really soar in coming months -- something much in dispute -- money managers who espouse this theory are enjoying at least a short stay in the sun.
One of them is Richard H. Fontaine, who started a group of funds under his own name after many years at T. Rowe Price, the fund company in Baltimore. After five lean years, the bounty is sweet.
A superstar at the helm of T. Rowe Price Capital Appreciation fund in the late 1980's, Mr. Fontaine anticipated the 1987 market crash and bought aggressively afterward, delivering average annual returns of nearly 40 percent.
But his record cooled shortly after he opened his own company in Towson, Md., in 1989. He contended that equities were experiencing a speculative bubble, though the stock market persistently defied him by rising ever higher. He acknowledges that he was at least five years early. "Let's face it," Mr. Fontaine said recently, "I'm a bear."
Because of lackluster returns, his total assets under management have shriveled to $100 million from four times that amount at their peak. His three no-load funds remain far too small to be listed in most newspapers and magazines. The best of his funds this year has been Fontaine Global Growth, also the smallest, with a gain approaching 50 percent through May 7. Fontaine Capital Appreciation, the biggest and the only one listed on Nasdaq, has gained nearly 30 percent this year, and Fontaine Global Income is up nearly 20 percent (800 247-1550).
One thing is for sure: Mr. Fontaine puts his own money behind his predictions. As of April 1, he and his wife owned 44.6 percent of Fontaine Global Growth. The fund had only $1.3 million in assets on May 6 but has since swelled to $1.8 million.
Since its inception, the fund has an annualized return of 13.31 percent, compared with 11.62 percent for world stock funds on average. In truth, though, it is less a global fund than a natural resources fund. Mr. Fontaine, 44, continues to believe that financial assets like stocks and bonds are grossly overvalued and concentrates on defensive positions in gold mining and similar stocks.
"I've long thought that if things went the way I expected, the last thing to go up before the market goes down is inflation-related stocks, especially gold," he said. "If you inflation adjusted the price of gold back to 1934, the current price should be about $470 to $490 an ounce, and I believe it will go to that level and beyond." Despite a run-up this year, gold is trading at less than $400.
Chuck Zender, managing director of the Leuthold Group, an institutional research firm in Minneapolis, says Mr. Fontaine has been quite consistent in his outlook and that the market has simply come around to him.
Right now, about 65 percent of the global fund's assets are invested in mining and exploration companies, and 5 percent are in international oil companies. Rounding out the portfolio is a handful of retailers, insurers and others with depressed prices -- all favorites of the value-oriented stock picker. In terms of foreign exposure, more than half the fund's assets are in Canadian mining and exploration companies, with just 25 percent in the United States. Cash has risen to 15 percent because of new money.
The fund has an extremely permissive charter, meaning it can concentrate on a few stocks, a few countries or even cash if the manager desires. "Have I left myself a lot of latitude?" Mr. Fontaine asked. "Yeah. I've been doing this a long time, and the last thing you want to do is get caught up in your own restrictions."
Still, to meet the requirements for diversified stock funds, Fontaine Global cannot have more than 25 percent of its assets in one industry. For that reason, Mr. Fontaine has had to reduce some positions recently. Last week, he said, he finished selling his stake in Black Swan, a Vancouver-based mining company with interests in Australia. He bought the stock, traded in Toronto, for 24 cents a share and sold on Thursday for about $1.40. Stocks like that hint at the fund's risk level.
Much of the fund's return this year can be attributed to Golden Star Resources, a gold and diamond exploration company based in Denver. Golden Star's shares, traded on the American Stock Exchange, represent about 12 percent of the fund.
Even though the stock soared last week to $17, from the $5 Mr. Fontaine paid last year, Golden Star remains much more promise than reality. It has negligible earnings and operates in the Indiana Jones end of the gold business. Its geologists slash their way through rain forests from Africa to South America in search of a big deposit. When they find it, they negotiate mineral rights with local governments and then sell interests to mining companies, who put up the capital for development but share up to half of the profits with Golden Star.
The company's shares plunged last year after cyanide-laced water spilled in an accident at the Omai gold mine, the largest in Guyana, of which Golden Star owns 30 percent, Mr. Fontaine said.
The stock's price has risen sharply this year because of a discovery of diamonds in nearby French Guiana. Though Mr. Fontaine puts the chance of successful development at less than 20 percent -- it can take years to determine if diamond deposits are dense enough, and of sufficient quality, to make mining profitable -- he said the mine's value could be billions of dollars.
At the other end of the mining spectrum is Inco Limited, a Toronto company traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Inco, one of the Fontaine fund's biggest holdings, is a producer rather than an explorer and specializes in base metals rather than precious metals. It is the largest producer of nickel, used in stainless steel.
Late this month, Inco is scheduled to acquire Diamond Fields, which burst onto the scene a year and a half ago with the discovery of a spectacular deposit of nickel in Newfoundland. The ore is unusually pure, located near the surface and easily accessible to ocean-going vessels.
The acquisition will greatly dilute earnings for Inco shareholders, and the stock price has suffered. The shares traded at $33.125 on Friday, compared with more than $40 last year.
Mr. Fontaine continues to add to his Inco position, however, and supports the company's management. "I think they will use cash flow to buy back a lot of the shares issued to buy Diamond Fields," he said, "Here is a big blue chip that will probably be a 50 percent performer over the next year or two. So even if you think the market is overvalued, as I do, this company is not."
Companies out of favor are manna for value investors, and Mr. Fontaine has a few plays outside the mining world. One favorite is Wal-Mart, the retailer whose stock is trading at half its $42 peak three years ago.
While examining mining properties in Brazil recently, Mr. Fontaine noticed that the chief topic of local conversation was the opening of a Wal-Mart. "They were talking like they did in New England three or four years ago," he said.
In just a few years, foreign sales have risen from nothing to 4 percent of Wal-Mart's total. "We expect that they'll be able to double that percentage over the next five years," Mr. Fontaine said.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Lessons of Flying in a Free Market

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
HOURS after the Valujet crash last weekend, the airline's president and the Transportation Secretary closed ranks, guarding each other's backs from an onslaught of questions about the safety of Valujet and other airlines overseen by the Federal Aviation Administration.
"The F.A.A. has been highly complimentary of the steps that we have taken," said Lewis H. Jordan, Valujet's president. Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena repeated time and again that Valujet and other start-up airlines were safe: "They have been responsive. They have been very cooperative. Valujet is a safe airline, as is our entire aviation system." 
 The script had played out in previous crashes involving other airlines. But it did not work so well this time.
Aviation experts found ready audiences for their concerns about Valujet and other budget airlines. The Transportation Department's inspector general, Mary F. Schiavo, embarked on dawn-to-dusk tours of news programs to suggest that the F.A.A. was to blame for the crash because of holes in its safety net. Travelers canceled bookings not only on Valujet, but also on other airlines with less familiar pedigrees.
The public response was not unjustified. The F.A.A. released an internal report on Friday that showed it had had ongoing concerns about Valujet's safety and its own ability to oversee the airline.
But consumers' sharp reaction also illustrated a paradox: The critics scolding Valujet and the F.A.A. were, in a broad sense, the same travelers whose demands for low fares and less government have prodded the airline and the agency to strain to be all things to all people.
Before Flight 592, from Miami to Atlanta, crashed into the Everglades last Saturday killing all 110 people aboard, Valujet and the F.A.A. appeared, in many respects, to be succeeding.
In fact, Valujet's rapid rise has been unequaled in modern aviation. When it started almost three years ago, it made a splash as a fun airline, with a cartoon plane painted on the side of its aircraft. Its double-digit fares earned the airline even more free publicity than the games its flight attendants used to entertain passengers -- win a prize if you guess the number of sheets of toilet paper rolled out along the aisle!
Valujet had the formula for economy: It bought used DC-9's, with an average age of 26 years, from airlines around the world. With each new plane, its stock soared higher in anticipation of even more profitable growth. Cities on the East Coast and in the South wooed the airline with offers of marketing dollars. Its DC-9's were filled with bargain hunters; a Miami-to-Atlanta ticket that cost at least $200 on larger airlines, for example, could be had for $59 on Valujet.
Signs of trouble caused no great alarm; an accident last June, when a plane caught fire on a runway in Atlanta, injuring four passengers, did little damage to business.
But amid the second-guessing of last week, doubts about the Valujet formula suddenly abounded. Questions piled on about whether the inexpensive fleet was in fact a liability.
"Was it responsible of you to grow this airline at such a remarkable rate?" Mr. Jordan was asked at a news conference. "We never grew the airline faster than we could be sure that we were operating safely and reliably," he replied.
But rapid growth takes its toll in the airline business, said Bob Iverson, a founder and former chairman of Kiwi Airlines. "The faster you grow," Mr. Iverson said, "the more difficult it is to keep up with managing the ever-expanding problems."
In hindsight, he said, increasing Kiwi's fleet to 15 planes in two years now seems too fast. In a little more than two and a half years, Valujet's fleet grew to 51 planes.
Those planes added to the F.A.A.'s mushrooming portfolio of responsibilities, which include certifying pilots and the private planes and jets they fly, airlines, repair stations, and pilot training and maintenance schools. The effects of industry deregulation in 1978 are still being felt, with new airlines starting all the time. Worldwide passenger traffic climbs every year, and the F.A.A. is increasingly playing the role of watchdog over its counterparts in foreign countries to insure that their aviation systems are safe for Americans.
 
 
 
Baked-In Problems
 The agency has at times been hampered by some baked-in management problems -- like a lack of accountability among its 2,600 front-line inspectors -- that have been described by Government oversight agencies and news reports, as well as in recent Congressional hearings. But the F.A.A., in taking its share of broad Federal budget cuts, has been left with antiquated technology. When it has had money to invest in new equipment, arcane Government procurement rules have contributed to misguided investments.
On most days, the constraints do not appear to anyone outside the organization as a problem. Flying, after all, is statistically the safest form of transportation, and the F.A.A. regularly takes some credit for that fact. So the agency never complains publicly that its resources are stretched too thin, which would suggest that it can't do its job.
But what is its job? Very often, top managers spend more time on public relations than much else, explaining to the media, politicians and oversight agencies what its statistics and regulations mean, why something is not as troubling as it might appear, and why it cannot simply shut down an airline unless it has a reason that it can defend in a court of law.
"Who in the F.A.A.'s senior management has time for improving safety?" said Clark Onstad, a former F.A.A. chief counsel.
The F.A.A. was defending itself last week against criticisms about the safety of Valujet and other airlines. It had a similar week only last month, when it tried to explain why it was not partly to blame for allowing 7-year-old Jessica Dubroff to fly the plane in which she was trying to cross the country when she crashed, along with her father and an instructor. In the F.A.A.'s eyes, Jessica was not technically piloting the aircraft, since the agency had not licensed her to be a pilot.
The logic was difficult to get across, and an angry public was not satisfied. So the F.A.A. once again pledged to review its rules.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A young and fun airline did have some problems. Last June, a fire burned the fuselage of a Valujet DC-9 on the ground in Atlanta. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

TREASURY BONDS
 
Inflation? Let It Rain
When the Treasury announced those inflation-proof bonds last week, it voiced a lofty goal: to get Americans, notorious spendthrifts, to save more. Well, O.K. But it surely also had its eye on that juicy $675 billion sitting in 401(k) plans -- money that, given inflation fears, rarely finds its way into Treasury bonds. It would love a chunk of that to help with its own spendthrift ways. And what of the impact on inflation? It's a proven fact that if you take an umbrella, it won't rain. But could it be that the opposite is true here? Say you take out that umbrella, buying bonds that give you peace of mind, inflation or not. But then, with people less worried about inflation, there might be less pressure to fight it, allowing inflation to creep in more easily.
 
HEALTH CARE
 
Doctors Strike Back
Today's episode of the health care mini-series is called "The Doctors Strike Back." Doctors haven't been happy about all this new managed-care stuff, this H.M.O. stuff, this cost-cutting stuff -- because, of course, it's their income that's being squeezed. When these changes started emerging, doctors were scattered about, alone, clinging to their independence. But gradually they started to band together, often by selling their practices to emerging companies that manage their affairs -- and, more to the point, beef up their bargaining power. That trend reached the big time last week as one such company, Medpartners/Mullikin, agreed to buy another, Caremark, in a $2.3 billion deal. The result: a giant among doctor-office managers, strength in numbers for doctors.
 
AUTO MAKERS
 
G.M.'s Hometown Bet
Busy times in Detroit last week. General Motors, in a stroke, tilted the city's map by buying the 73-story Renaissance Center, planning to move its base camp there. The landmark, built in 1977 at a cost of $350 million, had since plummeted in value in a shaky city, but G.M.'s move sent hopes soaring for a revitalized downtown. An added bonus: whenever any rude person rubs G.M.'s nose in how well Ford is doing, G.M. can respond: "Ford? Oh, that's just one of our tenants." Ford, you see, occupies one tower at the center. And the third Detroit heavyweight was also in the news, as Chrysler -- feeling peppy with its wallet full and its stock price high -- spread the wealth a bit, splitting its stock and lifting its dividend.
 
TOBACCO WARS
 
Advertise No Evil?
Philip Morris and U.S. Tobacco said last week that to reduce teen-age smoking they wanted legislation to ban vending-machine sales, giveaways and sports advertising. Their condition: that the F.D.A. back off from more stringent regulations, which among other things would make alluring figures like the Marlboro Man and Joe Camel far less visible. That's a free-speech issue, they say. So, should the Government try to shield people from things that, though legal, are bad for them? As it happens, the Supreme Court just gave a strong hint of its thinking. "The First Amendment directs us to be especially skeptical" of such limits, Justice John Paul Stevens said as the Court struck down a Rhode Island ban on advertising liquor prices -- a ban aimed at reducing consumption by discouraging price wars.
 
CAMPAIGN CASH
 
Mr. Dole's Thin Wallet
Some ungenerous souls have been known to suggest that money buys votes. Shocking, yes, but if it's true, Bob Dole won't be able to go on much of a shopping spree for voters until the Republican Convention. Federal rules say you can spend only $37 million before being nominated, and Senator Dole has gone through nearly all that, while Bill Clinton has more than $20 million to go. As a Senator, of course, Bob Dole makes news just by coughing, and he can use things like the Capitol steps or Newt Gingrich as photo props. But part of his gamble last week -- to downsize himself to mere Mr. Dole -- is that he's giving up all that nice free coverage. And he's doing it just when the Government -- the Government he's distancing himself from -- is keeping him from paying to get his message out.
 
GAMES KIDS PLAY
 
Did Nintendo Get Devoured?
Remember Nintendo? Not long ago, if preteen-agers were sitting in front of a screen playing games, it was a good bet that Nintendo was there. But while Nintendo was slow to get out spiffed-up machines, computers have been learning all sorts of new tricks. So when it previewed its latest game machine last week -- well behind schedule -- it ran the real risk of being a year late and a modem short. The coming thing, analysts say, is multiplayer games over the Internet. So "progress" continues: from children playing with friends in the backyard, to having a solitary basement game staring at a TV screen, to playing, say, Command and Control with some faceless person in Montana.
 
ACCIDENTS
 
Plane Safety: The Age Issue
Plane crashes, like the gallows, tend to focus the mind -- and the media. True, more people probably died in car accidents the day 109 people were killed in the Valujet crash. But the 109 died all at once, and they died on a fledgling airline, so safety was instantly a big topic. There may have been risky cargo, but what about the age of planes? A lot of airlines fly old planes -- and experts say age is no handicap as long as they're maintained properly. But the fact remains that Valujet has, on average, the oldest fleet in the air. And the doomed plane had been forced to return to airports seven times in the last two years for safety problems.
 
GLITZ
 
Times Square Tunes Out
What price civilization? As Times Square paints its porch, tidies up its flower bed and clears the garbage off its front lawn, one can't help wondering if the place will still feel like home -- home sweet garish home. Will New Yorkers be deprived of such basics as that giant TV screen shouting its images at the passing throng? Well, for now, yes. Sony is turning off the Jumbotron on June 1, when its six-year lease expires. But don't despair. Though Sony said it was a cost-cutting move, the true reason might be that the technology for these huge screens has leaped ahead since 1990, as technologies tend to do. Maybe something bigger and better and sharper is on the way. Maybe they can even get cable.
 
MUTUAL FUNDS
 
Magellan's Detour
Fidelity Magellan. The very name used to make other mutual funds tremble. Magellan's spectacular returns drew so many investors that it came to dominate the fund landscape. This year the giant has stumbled, though, with returns far behind the curve. Why? Because Jeffrey Vinik, Magellan's manager, got nervous late last year and put a lot of fund money into bonds and cash. And in Magellan's annual report, just out, Mr. Vinik goes public about his thinking, saying he saw mounting speculation in the vast sums flowing into funds. While he expects no crash, he called stocks "expensive" and said he was "cautious." So if stocks fall, he's a hero; if they don't, he's a nervous Nellie. It's a fickle world.

HEADLINE: The World;
This One Just Might Be a Real Trade War

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE UNITED STATES took on China over a pirating of America's intellectual property for the first time in 1903, when trademarked foreign products first started flowing out of Chinese factories. The Chinese figured that if they signed an agreement and ignored it, Washington would soon forget about the whole thing. They were right.
Ninety-two years later China's leaders signed another accord, this time promising to keep their hands off Winnie-the-Pooh videotapes and Windows 95 CD-ROM's. Then, figuring that some strategies work as well at the end of the century as they did in the beginning, they permitted all but a few of their illicit factories to keep generating hundreds of millions of dollars in profits for provincial officials, the military and the entrepreneurial elite. This time, they miscalculated. 
 In a nutshell, that's how the United States and China descended into another tape-for-tat trade war last week, with Washington threatening billions of dollars in sanctions against China's state-owned industries -- mostly clothing, silk and electronics -- and China shooting back that it will meet tariff with tariff.
It sounds like a lot of bravado, and by the time the two countries hit a June 17 deadline to strike a deal or invoke the sanctions, that's all it may prove to be. But behind the make-my-day threats are two very different calculations of national economic power.
America figures that it is still too big to mess with and that China -- faced with the choice of closing plants or finding their products locked out of Walmart -- will fold. In Beijing, the guess is that American industry is far more divided than President Clinton would like to admit -- and that Hollywood can be pitted against Boeing (which sends one in seven planes to China) and that Microsoft will be arm-wrestling Ford and G.M., which are in delicate talks over joint-venture factories.
Those divisions in American industry are very real and help explain why China's back seems to stiffen a bit more with each annual cycle of American threats and counter-threats. Every year, China gets a little richer, a little more nationalistic, and a little better equipped to resist America's seemingly endless demands. And it's getting better at the divide-and-conquer techniques that its longtime Asian rival, Japan, has used so effectively to stiff-arm the whining barbarians across the Pacific.
 
 
 
Learning From Japan
 "China learned a lot watching the Japanese handle American trade negotiators," said William P. Alford, a Harvard law professor and author of "To Steal a Book Is an Elegant Offense," (Stanford University Press, 1995), a study of Chinese views of intellectual property. And Washington's standard technique -- draft a highly specific agreement, then demand enforcement -- "doesn't translate so well in a country like China that doesn't have much of a legal infrastructure and views this all as deal-making," he added.
Clinton Administration officials say their case is straightforward: Last year, under the threat of $1 billion in sanctions, Beijing agreed to a tight schedule for closing its pirate factories or turning them into legitimate operations. But illegal production has surged.
"We're not asking to negotiate new agreements," Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States Trade Representative, said. "We have the agreements. They are clear. The question is one of enforcement. And that is a question of political will, not ability."
Ms. Barshefsky is, at first glance, in an admirable negotiating position. United States-China trade accounts for more than 8 percent of China's gross national product, but less than 1 percent of America's. So China has a lot more to lose in a trade war.
Beijing's strategy centers not only on its economic power, but on the political advantage that comes from playing competing American and other Western interests off against each other. So when America steamed the Seventh Fleet off Taiwan this year, Li Peng, China's Premier, ostentatiously used a trip to Paris to sign a few contracts with Airbus Industries that Boeing had desperately wanted. And when China published its "counter-retaliation list" 20 minutes after Ms. Barshefsky left the podium on Wednesday, Beijing said it would not hesitate to suspend American investment in its market.
 
 
 
Rattling Ford's Cage
 That's probably a bluff. But it rattled a few cages in Detroit: Ford Motor Company turned out a statement declaring that while "the protection of intellectual property rights is a key to open and successful trade and trust between trading partners, we do not believe that unilateral sanctions by either country are constructive or likely to lead to a solution of the problem." Many other companies, from electronics makers to oil companies, turned out equally fence-straddling statements.
America's allies, especially Japan, the Philippines and others who live in China's shadow, were a lot clearer: Conduct exercises with the Seventh Fleet wherever you want, but don't start messing with trade weapons; someone could get hurt.
Much as the Chinese enjoy hearing such a chorus, they know -- or Ms. Barshefsky thinks they know -- that there are risks in overplaying their hand. Congress is about to begin the annual ritual of debating whether to withdraw China's overall trade benefits, a step so drastic Congress has always shrunk from it before. So far, President Clinton and Bob Dole have both favored renewal, giving China a good chance to squeak through again. If a real trade war starts in mid-June, though, all bets are off.

HEADLINE: Who'll Win Russia?;
For America, Uncertainty Wraps the Riddle

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN divining the Clinton Administration's thinking about the presidential election in Russia next month, consider this: Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott's first draft of a major analysis of Russia policy last January omitted any discussion of what to expect if the Communists won. Only after colleagues drew the omission to Mr. Talbott's attention did he insert a "what if" section in the final version.
The possibility that the Communists will win is the West's worst foreign policy nightmare, and why Mr. Talbott initially left it out is unclear. Some of his colleagues say he simply preferred not to speculate about it -- on the premise that any suggestion from official Washington that President Boris N. Yeltsin could lose would only hurt his chances. Others point to Mr. Talbott's inclination to look on the bright side when it comes to Russia. Mr. Talbott himself isn't talking. 
 But the omission underscores just how little is known in Washington about what will happen in the Russian election next month -- and, more important, how that uncertainty limits the Administration's ability to plan for the outcome. Despite a flood of analytical reporting from the American Embassy in Moscow, no one in the Clinton Administration is willing to be predictive. Even the Central Intelligence Agency, which Administration officials say was betting two months ago that there was no way Mr. Yeltsin could win, is now giving him an even chance of pulling it out.
"Nobody -- believe me, nobody -- can tell you what is going to happen in this vote," said James F. Collins, the State Department's special adviser on the former Soviet countries. "Nobody knows what Russian voters are going to do," he added. "It's an imponderable."
Who will be the victor is not the only imponderable. If the Communist challenger, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, wins, there is the issue of just what sort of Communists he will put in his Cabinet and how soon and how much they will change things. No matter who wins, there is the future course of the endlessly brutal war in Chechnya. Above all, there is the anxiety of the people and the pessimism of the military.
Which makes it particularly hard to identify specific new threats and challenges that may confront the United States after the election -- how the vote might affect Russia's attitude toward democracy, the rule of law, economic integration with the West, stability around Russia and its place in the world.
 
 
 
What to Do
 So with the course of events in Russia beyond prediction, how does a policy maker respond? The quandary is reminiscent of other moments when events of enormous sweep unfolded too rapidly for the United States to be more than a bystander: the revolution in Iran, the fall of the Berlin Wall, the collapse of the Soviet state after the failed coup of 1991.
In such a situation, of course, good policy makers try to make decisions that will help produce favorable outcomes. But when it comes to another country's elections, meddling too blatantly is never a good way to do it. Planning for the worst, hoping for the best and doing no harm may be the only prudent course of action.
Thus the importance of the Talbott paper. Those officials who read it say it was less remarkable for what it said than for what it did to energize the bureaucratic process: It helped prompt President Clinton to call his first (and so far only) formal National Security Council meeting on Russia, in February. And that produced a clear redefinition of America's two overriding national interests in dealing with Russia: promoting American national security and pushing the continued integration of Russia into the social, political and economic life of the West. Not that the Administration changed its view of the national interests; rather, this wasan opportunity to spell out what was most important in a way that wouldn't leave the United States trapped if the Communists won.
 
 
 
What to Say
 Just as important, the Administration also came up with a way to talk about the Russian election publicly: first, to say that the United States does not have a vote in it and therefore has no candidate (even though every senior official from the President on down is rooting for Mr. Yeltsin); second, to stick to fixed talking points to avoid the impression that the United States is panicking.
"We leave it to the Russian people to judge him in his capacity for re-election," Mr. Talbott said of Mr. Yeltsin in a speech at Amherst College three weeks ago.
That doesn't mean there have been no missteps. During last month's summit meeting in Moscow, Mr. Clinton cast Mr. Yeltsin as a Slavic version of Abraham Lincoln, equating Russia's war to subdue the Chechens to the Great Emancipator's battle against slavery. Even Mr. Clinton's aides were appalled by the off-the-cuff remark, in which Mr. Clinton broke one of the cardinal rules of diplomacy: never make comparisons to America's history.
And other officials seem unable to resist saying just how much they want the Communists to lose. "These people are not benign Euro-Communists," said Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman and a Russia specialist. "Their policies, if they are implemented, would roll back the economic and political reforms of the last four and a half years."
Even if Mr. Zyuganov wins, what is important for the United States is what he does and how fast he does it. The last time the Communists held the keys to the Kremlin, they were free to do things like arbitrarily fix the value of the ruble and weed out budding capitalists. Russia now seems firmly established in the international marketplace, and the Communists may have only limited room to maneuver in it.
 
 
 
What to Care About
 If the United States has drawn up a list of what it will not tolerate from a Communist regime, it is not saying what those acts are. Privately, however, Secretary of Defense William Perry has said that the only critical national interest in Russia is American security, and that this begins with strict adherence to arms control agreements. How far Washington would be willing to go to punish a Russia that reneged on those pledges is another matter.
Other issues are even more murky. Just about every internal Government analysis agrees that Russia's military, which is too poor to pay even its electric bills, is unlikely to directly threaten the United States. But how far would America be willing to go if a President Zyuganov used his military to put pressure on a neighbor?
Paradoxically, Administration officials feel they know more about what the reaction to a Communist victory would be in Washington than in Moscow. Officials are predicting that the Republicans would immediately seize on it to blame the Democrats for Mr. Yeltsin's defeat, push through funding for a "Star Wars" space-based missile defense and back away from the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential candidate, has criticized the Administration for embracing Mr. Yeltsin too tightly, but has yet to articulate his own strategy for dealing with a Communist President. His first Russia speech could be one in which he accuses Mr. Clinton of having lost Russia.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 906 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Germany's Anguish: History, Identity and Shopping

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
IT'S early evening and you forgot to buy the milk, so what do you do? In New York or London, you go to the corner store. If it's Rome and not too late, you try the local alimentari or the neighborhood bar.
In Germany, you keep the refrigerator well stocked.
Among the wealthy lands of the West, Germany has the stingiest shopping hours of all. Stores, nearly all stores, close most nights at 6:30 P.M., and on most Saturdays at 2 P.M. Sundays, they are closed all day -- as they are, for that matter, between 1 P.M. and 2:30 P.M. on any weekday afternoon. 
 The reason? Germany has regulated shopping hours to suit the store owners' associations, not the customers. According to the newspaper commentator Josef Joffe, Germans have become "slaves to a culture of guilds and brotherhoods," not to mention a "curiosity" to the world.
"The whole world is laughing at us," said Gunter Rexrodt, the Economics Minister.
Now, though, the once-unthinkable is happening: in Parliament this month, Chancellor Helmut Kohl introduced legislation to permit stores to remain open later, until 8 P.M. on weekdays and part of Saturday afternoons, and -- heaven forbid -- to allow bakers to sell fresh bread for three hours on Sundays. The current laws only permit, but do not oblige, storekeepers to stay open later on Thursdays (until 8:30 P.M.) and on the first Saturday of each month (until 4 P.M., or 6 P.M. in the summer).
Mr. Kohl has not won friends in the process. As a measure of the furor he caused, some 50,000 people -- a big crowd by any standards -- gathered in Bonn last month to oppose the idea of changing the current rules.
To be sure, Germany is not alone in regulating shopping hours, which are laid out by laws that strike Americans as bizarre.
 
 
 
No Clothes on Monday
 In Rome, clothing stores close on Monday mornings and food stores don't do business on Thursday afternoons. In Greece, the charts that decree pharmacy hours resemble those of a medieval astrologer. In Italy, France, Britain and elsewhere, Sunday shopping -- now permitted in Britain and creeping into Italy -- has been debated, heatedly, for years.
Here, though, the issue is not so much the hours themselves as their meaning: what Chancellor Kohl is suggesting, his critics assert, is an assault on the very essence of modern German-ness with its twin totems of capitalist gain and socialist security.
Scrap the shopping hours, the labor unions maintain, and you open the door to part-time workers deprived of full social security rights, who, in turn, threaten the position of full-time workers and their hefty packages of pensions, health and job security benefits.
 
 
 
Fear of Mammon
 Liberalize trading hours, the argument runs, and watch the mom-and-pop corner stores fall easy prey to the Mammon-driven super-stores. "Only the big businesses will profit from this," said Margareta Wolf from the opposition Greens, who are lining up with the opposition Social Democrats against the changes.
Open up the stores to late trading, opponents say, and watch the traditional German family go under: no more Saturday afternoon strolls in the park, because everyone will be at the mall; no more family dinners, at least for storekeepers, because Mom and Pop will be glued to the cash register.
Restrictive shopping hours do, in fact, condition much of the way Germans live.
Families really do take to the parks to stroll and bicycle on Sunday, their urge to consume held lawfully in check, in a way that many other countries have forgotten.
Moreover, many women stay home to tend Kinder, Kuche and Kirche (children, kitchen and church), which allows family shopping on a schedule that accommodates the shopkeepers, not to mention school hours that end sometimes at 12:30 P.M.
Millions of German women do work, of course, which increases the pressure for longer shopping hours; gone are the days, said Mr. Joffe, the commentator, "when Mom strolled through the market every day, buying a little wurst here, three pounds of apples there." But a recent survey said 73 percent of German women are still wholly or partly economically dependent on husbands or social security checks.
The shopping rules, first formulated in 1956, reflect a hankering for cartels and protective regulations that has deepened with the growth of postwar wealth. At the same time, though, things have changed. The last few years in particular have brought the upheavals of German reunification, ingrained unemployment, and, most of all, new economic challenges from distant lands where people are prepared to work late and spend late.
Jobs are moving out of the country because of high labor costs. And what Germany now needs, Chancellor Kohl insists, is a dose of the same flexibility that distinguishes its global competition.
Liberalized shopping hours, by this argument, will mean not only more jobs and more profits -- and an injection of nocturnal life into moribund city centers -- but also a shift in the attitudes that breed perilous complacency.
The shopkeepers may demur, but the challenge facing them is not only from Mr. Kohl.
Germany's gas stations, for example, operating under more liberal regulations, already stay open till all hours, and many of them now sell bread, coffee, cigarettes, soft drinks, beer and candies -- just about everything, in fact, that you might need when you forget to stock the refrigerator.

HEADLINE: What If?;
An Election-Year Forecast: Surprise, Surprise.

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF he accomplished anything last week in his extraordinary decision to quit the Senate, Bob Dole jolted the capital, and maybe even the great electorate beyond, with a reminder that, yes, there is a Presidential race this year, and a lot still can happen between now and the Election Day so far off.
White House naysayers contend that Mr. Dole's announcement will give him a shortlived lift in the polls that won't last much past Memorial Day, and a lot of people would be inclined to agree with them if Mr. Dole were to do nothing further to galvanize his campaign. It could be that the conventional wisdom and the polls are right, that President Clinton will win re-election as Republicans hang on to the House and Senate. 
 But as Mr. Dole's maneuver last week underscored, unpredictability and quantum shifts have been defining characteristics of American politics in recent years. Only a few months ago the Republican national chairman was bragging that the Democrats were "running from Bill Clinton like scalded dogs." Now it is the Republicans who are running -- from Speaker Newt Gingrich. In this spirit of volatility, consider some permutations for how it could all shake out on Nov. 5:
 
 
 
Scenario 1: the Status Quo
 Despite the reincarnation of Bob Dole as Every-American rather than frustrated Senate Majority Leader, Mr. Clinton could solidify his comfortable lead in the polls to the point where not even Colin L. Powell's presence on the Republican ticket could erode it.
Under this scenario, the House would stay Republican, if for no other reason than there is no groundswell for another upheaval. The Republicans have done exceedingly well in fund-raising; they have recruited a batch of aggressive candidates for seats being vacated by incumbents, and have far fewer such seats to defend than the Democrats (19 as opposed to the Democrats' 28). The Senate, where Republicans have a six seat edge, appears even more difficult for Democrats to reclaim because of numerous Democratic retirements and because many of those races are in states that are disposed to Republicans.
If voters grant Mr. Clinton a second term, it might not be out of fondness for him, but because they see him as countering extreme elements of the Republican Congress. That equation could change if voters turn on the Republicans in Congress.
"There's a trap here," said former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York. "As the Democrats become more likely winners in the House or the Senate, you have this curious perverse effect. What I'm afraid will happen is when people perceive that the Congress might become more Democratic, they might want Clinton less."
But for now, Mr. Clinton has so positioned himself as a moderate that it may be a breeze for him to win over independents and some Republicans on issues like welfare and the budget. In a nod to conservatives, he has said he would oppose gay marriages. All the while, though, Mr. Clinton has tended to his base with pronouncements on health care, education and the environment.
Besides grabbing Republican issues, the Democrats are already stoking the Republican ferment on abortion, as well as concerns that at 72 Mr. Dole is too old. They also hope that Ross Perot will enter the fray with his third party and siphon votes from Mr. Dole.
Because Mr. Clinton seems to be behaving almost as a Republican, it may be too much for Democratic Congressional candidates to expect him to do them much good. "You just don't see a lot of coattails," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster.
 
 
 
Scenario 2: G.O.P. Sweeps
 Charles E. Cooke Jr., a non-partisan analyst, said if the election were held today, Mr. Clinton would draw 290 electoral votes (270 are needed to get elected) because polls show he has leads of 20 points of more in nearly every large state except Ohio, Florida and Texas. The biggest prize of all, California, is leaning so much toward Mr. Clinton that many Republicans feared that Mr. Dole would abandon them.
Despite those intimidating statistics, Republicans can take solace in their party's traditional advantage in the Electoral College. An analysis by Richard Bond, a former Republican national chairman, shows that 12 states, with 73 electoral votes, went for the Republican in the last 7 elections. Another 12 states, with 165 electoral votes, did so in 6 of the last 7 elections.
Many Democrats concede that they are not likely to win many states in the Rocky Mountains or the South, and those regions -- with a few other traditionally Republican strongholds -- make it possible for a truly reinvigorated Dole campaign to lay claim to nearly 200 electoral votes with little effort.
Mr. Dole's aides said they recently conducted surveys of focus groups that found that most voters know very little about the Republican candidate, and were surprisingly clueless that he was a wounded veteran of World War II. The campaign plans to make much of Mr. Dole's biography as it hits hard on the character issue against Mr. Clinton.
"For Dole to win, he has to create a contrast of ideology and of character," said John McLaughlin, a Republican pollster. "He has to flip that age factor into an integrity factor. And then he has to go out and get some Democrat votes."
Mr. Dole's biggest advantage may be that he is not Bill Clinton; Presidential elections often become referendums on the sitting President. "Clinton has an opportunity to lose in a variety of ways," said Alan Secrest, a Democratic pollster. "Let's say something of a smoking-gun nature emerges out of one of these hearings or trials." Another sure-fire spoiler for a President, of course, is a downturn in the economy.
 
 
 
Scenario 3: All Democrat
 Not even the most optimistic Democrats predict that their party will capture the White House and both houses of Congress. They are particularly doubtful about the Senate. The House offers greater opportunities because the Republicans' 39-seat advantage is the narrowest any party has held since 1958.
But given Mr. Clinton's high poll numbers -- and nationwide surveys showing people are more inclined to vote for Democratic members of Congress than Republicans -- some Democrats paint a scenario in which the Republicans will be so villified that Democrats will sweep the elections much like the Republicans seized Congress in 1994. The party could be helped along by newly enacted "motor voter" laws which make it easier for people to register.
 
 
 
Switcheroo No. 1
 For all the conventional wisdom that the Presidential contest drives the races down the line, there is the prospect, however remote now, that Mr. Clinton will be ousted even as Democrats reclaim the House or the Senate or both.
Two separate dynamics would have to be at play: one is that Mr. Clinton's support would be devastated by an unknown huge scandal that would make Whitewater as we now know it look like child's play, or by the bungling of a major national or international crisis (like, for argument's sake, one that develops in Russia after its presidential election). At the same time, Democrats in Congress could prevail by distancing themselves from Mr. Clinton and turning their own elections into a referendum on Mr. Gingrich.
"It would have to be a pretty severe personal setback for Clinton for that to happen," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. "The fact of the matter is that chances for a Democratic takeover of Congress depends on Clinton doing well."
 
 
 
Switcheroo No. 2
 In his zeal to put distance between himself and the Capitol, where he has worked for 35 years, perhaps Mr. Dole will go too far for his former colleagues' liking. Negativity about the Gingrich Congress could become so strong that moderate Republican defectors vote moderate or conservative Democrats into the House while installing Mr. Dole in the Oval Office to keep his eye on the things.
"I could argue arithmetically that the Democrats could take over the House while the President loses by one point," said Mark A. Siegel, a former executive director of the Democratic Party.
But while he said he has been "programmed by the White House" to dampen expectations and predict a close race, Mr. Siegel said he was confident about Mr. Clinton's chances. "The margin of victory could be around 10 points," he said, "which I'm not supposed to say!"

HEADLINE: May 12-18;
The New Slogan: Buy Inflation-Buster Bonds!

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
In announcing that it would issue a new type of Government bond -- an "inflation-indexed" bond -- the United States Treasury last week moved to accomplish a lot of goals: protect the savings of ordinary Americans from inflation, encourage Americans to save more and cut the Government's borrowing costs.
The new bonds -- whose returns would be pegged to inflation, though the exact terms haven't been worked out -- are meant to give the Government a chance to compete for the huge amounts of money flowing into 401(k) plans, the self-directed retirement accounts that now have $675 billion in assets. Since they would have the inflation hedge, the bonds are to be issued at rates lower than those of the fixed-rate bonds that the Government now sells -- a provision intended to save the Government money. 
 For consumers, the appeal would be added security for retirement plans from bonds backed by the "full faith and credit" of the Government.
"This is a good example of a common-sense approach to better serve citizens," said Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, himself a former bond salesman on Wall Street, "and to bring down the cost of capital for the Government." LESLIE WAYNE

HEADLINE: A Breakthrough in Bonds

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's decision to issue indexed bonds -- Government bonds that protect the purchaser from inflation -- is welcome news for investors, taxpayers and the overall health of the economy. The Administration deserves credit for overcoming obstacles that have blocked this good idea for years.
Indexed bonds would, in effect, pay an investor a fixed rate of return, probably around 3 percent, above the rate of inflation. As obligations of the Federal Government, they would not carry the risk of default. Held to maturity, these bonds would be a risk-free way for investors to save for retirement. The bonds will be especially attractive to unsophisticated investors who wish to avoid buying stocks. 
 Taxpayers would gain from indexed bonds because Government borrowing costs, and therefore the need to raise taxes, would likely fall. The Government now pays owners of non-indexed bonds an interest rate that compensates them for the risk that future inflation will erode the value of the principal and interest payments. With indexed bonds, bondholder risk is eliminated and the Government can pay lower interest rates.
Indexed bonds will make it easier for the Federal Reserve Board to control the economy by giving it a good barometer of investor expectations about inflation. If, for example, investors begin expecting higher inflation rates, the Fed might want to counter with a tighter monetary policy. The Fed now has no reliable way to measure those expectations, and may adjust monetary policy based on mistaken assumptions. The difference in interest rates on indexed and non-indexed Government bonds will show how high investors expect inflation to be. Indexed bonds will also give the Government added impetus to control inflation. Otherwise, it would be required to funnel extra payments to bondholders.
Bureaucratic inertia and opposition by Wall Street dealers have blocked the issuance of indexed bonds in the past. The dealers fear, with some justification, that purchasers are likely to hold onto these bonds rather than continually trade them, reducing commissions for bond sellers. It took a former investment banker, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, to blow the whistle on his former colleagues. Indexed bonds are a victory for good government.

HEADLINE: The Keys to the Spy Kingdom

 BODY:
The management of America's intelligence agencies has long suffered from an awkward power-sharing arrangement between the Director of Central Intelligence and the Secretary of Defense. The director is nominally in charge, but the Secretary of Defense actually controls most of the agencies, people and money. Over the years the two have sometimes tripped over each other, resulting in lax management and a shortage of accountability.
The latest example is $4 billion that was lost and then found by the National Reconnaissance Office, a Pentagon agency that operates spy satellites. Because no one was clearly accountable for running the agency, the office, through incompetent bookkeeping and obsessive secrecy, lost track of enough money to run a small country before the Director of Central Intelligence and Secretary of Defense realized there was a problem. 
 Arlen Specter and Bob Kerrey, the chairman and vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, have proposed a reasonable remedy. They would give the Director of Central Intelligence an enhanced role in selecting the chiefs of the intelligence services within the Pentagon and greater authority in managing their budgets and operations.
Under the current system, which evolved without a coherent blueprint during the cold war, the Director of Central Intelligence is the country's top spy official. But he possesses final operational and financial authority over just one organization -- the Central Intelligence Agency. The rest of the Government's main espionage agencies reside within the Department of Defense, including the Reconnaissance Office and the National Security Agency, which monitors international communications. Further, while the director helps set spending goals for all the spy agencies, he directly controls only about $3 billion of the $26 billion annual intelligence budget, and employs only a fraction of the work force.
Real power over the Pentagon spy agencies resides mainly with the Deputy Secretary of Defense. But in the vast universe of Pentagon activities and spending that pivot around this post, the work of the spy agencies can easily be overlooked.
The Pentagon agencies produce two broad categories of intelligence information. One, known as national intelligence, consists largely of information on political, arms control and economic issues that goes to the White House, State Department and civilian leadership at the Pentagon. The other category is military intelligence, including data on foreign forces, weapons and tactics. This information flows primarily to the armed forces and is especially vital in wartime.
The Senate plan would provide more exacting management by giving the Director of Central Intelligence greater control over the national-intelligence operations of the Pentagon spy agencies. Those activities properly belong under the director, who is supposed to guide national intelligence programs. It would leave the Pentagon responsible for running the military intelligence side of the same agencies, which is appropriate.
John Deutch, the Director of Central Intelligence, seems content to leave operational and budget matters unchanged, but does endorse a greater role for himself in the selection of spy agency heads. Yet as a former Deputy Secretary of Defense, he well knows that the Pentagon cannot provide the close oversight needed to keep an organization like the Reconnaissance Office in line.
The Senate Armed Services Committee, reflecting the Pentagon's opposition, has blocked the Specter-Kerrey bill. The two Senators have retaliated by delaying approval of the defense budget. With the House already moving toward reform, Congress will squander an opportunity to put the intelligence services under tighter control if the committee does not budge. Does another $4 billion have to be misplaced before Congress acts?

HEADLINE: Military Strives to Reduce a Relatively Low Suicide Rate

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Navy's highest-ranking officer, took his life this week at a time when the military is striving, with considerable success, to reduce suicide in the ranks.
Despite some spectacular instances -- in 1994, a Marine drill sergeant shot himself in front of 40 recruits at boot camp at Parris Island, S.C. -- military personnel have committed suicide far less frequently than civilians of the same age and sex, Government statisticians say. In addition, the Navy has the lowest suicide rate of the armed services. 
 In recent years, the Pentagon has been trying to prevent suicide by identifying service members who are at risk of killing themselves and providing them help. Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for health affairs, said in an interview that a major thrust of the campaign had been to emphasize that seeking help for mental illness is not a sign of weakness.
"We pay a great deal of attention to making sure people are aware that it's O.K. to look for help," Dr. Joseph said. "It's O.K. to seek support and not keep your problems within yourself." He said commanders were instructed to make clear that nobody would suffer professionally by seeking help, a message that he acknowledged ran counter to a centuries-old military culture in which strength is prized and anything that could be perceived as weakness is concealed.
Dr. Joseph said particular attention was paid to situations of great potential stress, like combat. But there are a variety of other factors that can lead to depression and suicide among military people. The invasion of Haiti in 1994 was virtually free of combat, but within one week three American servicemen there took their lives.
Dr. Joseph would not comment on Admiral Boorda's death or how it might affect the message of encouraging requests for help. But the Boorda suicide is not a typical one for the military. The overwhelming majority of military suicides, officials say, involve young men who are depressed because of a number of problems, such as being rejected by a girlfriend when things are going badly on the job.
As in the civilian population, men in uniform commit suicide far more frequently than their female counterparts. The suicide rate is also far higher among low-ranking service members than among officers.
Although news accounts about military personnel who kill themselves may leave the impression that the stress and the occasional isolation of military life produce a higher rate of suicides than among civilians, the opposite is true. A young man in the military, for example, is only about 60 percent as likely to take his life as a young man in the civilian population, said Dr. Joseph Rothberg, who has studied suicide in the military for more than two decades.
Dr. Rothberg, a civilian employee of the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Washington, said that in recent years there had been little statistical difference between the military and civilian populations in the crude rate of suicide. That rate, which does not account for age, race or sex, has ranged from about 10 suicides per 100,000 people to 14 per 100,000.
But a detailed report of a study by Dr. Rothberg and others, published by The Journal of the American Medical Association in 1990, showed that when age, race and sex were taken into account, the rate of suicide in the military was significantly lower than in the civilian population. Dr. Rothberg said in an interview that this disparity had remained in recent years.
"The reasons for this are fairly simple," he said. "Among those in the civilian community who commit suicide, there are some typical features: the person may be unemployed, have health problems and lack a meaningful religion or philosophy, all of which may lead to depression."
In the military, he said, a person is employed, usually in good health and almost certainly drug-free because of mandatory testing, and has the structure of the military to serve as a belief system.
Dr. Rothberg said that while it was difficult to generalize about suicide in the military, there were two common patterns. The far more frequent one involves a young man for whom the breakup with a girlfriend is the last of a series of setbacks. Dr. Rothberg said the suicide of such a man typically occurred after a bout of heavy drinking.
The other pattern, he said, typically occurs among men who have served 15 to 20 years and who find they are not advancing and may be forced out of the service.
Prof. Douglas G. Jacobs of Harvard Medical School, an authority on suicide, said in an interview that it often occurred after a sudden drop in self-esteem. While Dr. Jacobs, the executive director of the National Mental Illness Screening Project, would not comment directly on Admiral Boorda's suicide, he said failure might create an extraordinary psychological burden for a public person.
"Everyone has failures," he said, "but the stakes rise the more one is in the public eye."
Admiral Boorda shot himself on Thursday after learning that journalists were preparing an article suggesting that he was not entitled to two combat decorations that he had worn until last year. Such a public humiliation would be felt more keenly by a military person than a civilian, Dr. Jacobs said.
"In the Navy," he said, "if you lose your honor, I don't know if you can recover it."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Silly Season

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I have a confession to make: Even before the old Bob Dole became the new Bob Dole, our family station wagon wasn't exactly plastered with his bumper stickers. But last week I returned from an overseas trip to find that Mr. Dole was proposing to repeal the 4.3-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, and I've changed my mind about the old guy. Yes, sir, scrapping the gasoline tax. That's the sort of leadership America needs; that's the sort of spirit of sacrifice the country's been missing: a President who's ready to sacrifice the budget, to sacrifice the environment, to sacrifice energy conservation, to sacrifice oil reserves in order to save the American people 4.3 cents a gallon. And when Mr. Dole's sidekick Dick Armey, the House majority leader, suggested that we consider cutting the education budget to make up for the lost gas-tax revenue, well, then and there I knew I was a Dole man. I mean, cutting education to save Americans a few pennies a gallon at a time when their gas is already the cheapest in the world -- that's the kind of thinking that will keep us the world's most competitive nation in the 21st century. I sure hope the Japanese don't get that idea.
Are we out of our minds? Raising the gas tax has been one of the few smart things we've done in recent years. It promotes energy conservation, it helps protect the air, it encourages development of alternative energies, it promotes national security by reducing U.S. dependence on foreign oil supplies -- and it reduces the budget deficit. That 4.3-cent-a-gallon tax raises $5 billion a year. It is one of the reasons the deficit has been cut in half since 1993. 
 Any proposal to repeal the gas tax should be hooted out of Congress with scorn. Unfortunately, that's not what President Clinton did. Instead he's trying to trade his support for this idiotic gas-tax repeal for a Republican endorsement of his proposal to raise the minimum wage -- the worst sort of election-year poker. Mr. Clinton is saying to Mr. Dole: "I see your foolishness and I raise you one."
It is hard to believe that the Dole proposal for repeal of the gas tax is effective even as political pandering. How many people are really going to change their votes from Clinton to Dole over 4.3 cents a gallon? Moreover, how can Republicans argue that a balanced budget and deficit reduction are the two most urgent priorities in American politics and then, when gas prices go up a bit due to seasonal factors, simply discard the gas tax without regard for the long-term budget implications? "It only makes sense politically if it is part of a broader Dole strategy for lowering taxes," says Bill Kristol, editor of the conservative Weekly Standard. And then for Mr. Armey to even hint that we might pay for this giveaway by cutting education -- that takes your breath away. For a cheap political high with the shelf life of a dead fish, a House Republican leader is ready to cut $5 billion a year from education? How could such a thought even cross Mr. Armey's mind? Forget about what a Dole Presidency would be like; if this keeps up I'm not sure we can afford a Dole candidacy.
The truth is we shouldn't be lowering our gas taxes. We should be raising them. Gasoline is probably the best bargain commodity in the U.S. marketplace. The latest blip aside, the real price of gasoline in the U.S. has been falling for 15 years (and if the Iraqi oil sanctions are eased by the U.N. soon, gas prices in the U.S. will likely resume that downward trend). In France and Italy, gas goes for $4.50 a gallon; in Japan it costs $3.75. Most of the difference between their prices and ours is taxes that those Governments use to finance public services. We could put a 50-cent-a-gallon tax on U.S. gasoline, get rid of the deficit and still have a huge competitive edge over the Europeans and Japanese. "This is one of the easiest and most attractive ways of raising tax revenue, and we're just giving it away," says the oil economist Vahan Zanoyan, of the Petroleum Finance Company.
In his speech announcing his resignation from the Senate, Mr. Dole insisted that: "My campaign for the President is not merely about obtaining office. It's about fundamental things, consequential things, things that are real. My campaign is about telling the truth, it's about doing what is right."
If that's true, then I can't wait for the Dole campaign to begin.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

INDUSTRY: NAICS 213112 OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (88%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (94%);
