HEADLINE: Out of the Cradle and Right Into the N.B.A. Draft

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
Spencer Haywood has seen some of the faces on television, young faces of nervous college players as they carefully read or recited that awkward phrase, declaring their intention to apply for the National Basketball Association draft. A quarter-century ago, after an extended and highly publicized legal struggle that took place long before Kobe Bryant was born, Haywood won the right to play in the N.B.A. before his college class graduated. Now, as Bryant and two other high school players, as well as three college freshmen and nine sophomores, wait for the moment their names may or may not be called on draft day, Haywood is one of many voices questioning a system his legal victory helped create.
"I see a very big danger coming on the horizon," Haywood said. "It's not working the way it should be working. When I go to speak at junior high schools and elementary schools, everyone is so focused on the dream, the basketball dream. It's, 'I want to be a basketball player, and if I'm not a basketball player I want to be a rap star.' " 
 The growing exodus of young, high-profile players to professional basketball has led the N.B.A. Players Association to seek a meeting with league and National Collegiate Athletic Association officials in the next month. "We want it to be a nonpolitical meeting," said Alex English, the acting executive director of the players association. "We should all sit down and think about the welfare of the kids, and then think about what is happening to the college game and the N.B.A. game."
Leading college officials, who have long been criticized for a structure that was called "almost prehistoric" by Georgetown Coach John Thompson, have shown a willingness to consider a dramatic liberalization of their current system.
"Do we need to rethink some of these rules relative to amateurism, the way the Olympics have?" said Dr. William E. Kirwan, president of the University of Maryland and chairman of the N.C.A.A. committee on agents and amateurism. "Do we want to make some adjustments in our own thinking? There is really no consensus yet on the committee. But there is a determination to do something. We do not want this to end with a bland recommendation. The problem is real and harmful."
By the deadline last Sunday, 42 players -- more than double the previous high total of early candidates -- had applied to the league for an early entry. More than one-third of them are college sophomores and freshmen and high school students.
"I'm waiting for the day when 9th or 10th graders are considering it," Kentucky Coach Rick Pitino said with a laugh. This year's list ranges from Marcus Camby of Massachusetts, the consensus national player of the year, to obscure players from small schools.
The number of early entrants may eventually shrink because the N.C.A.A. allows players who do not hire agents to change their minds and regain their college eligibility up to 30 days after the draft. Other measures at the pro and college levels have also addressed the departure of underclassmen, including the introduction of three-year contracts with dramatically reduced salaries linked to draft positions for first-round choices.
Still, younger players continue to leave college early. Their aspirations have been supported by the successful progress of Kevin Garnett of the Minnesota Timberwolves, drafted in1995 out of high school.
College teams face difficult personnel decisions as the top players consider leaving even as potential replacements reach the end of the high school recruiting process. Pro teams must now consider making substantial investments in athletes whose physical and emotional skills may be far from fully developed.
"We probably wouldn't draft one of them," said Phil Jackson, the coach of the Chicago Bulls, of the younger players. "I don't think I want a 20-year-old on this team. Eighteen? Out of the question."
Haywood, who works in real estate and oversees a foundation in Detroit, plans to complete his degree requirements at the University of Detroit next spring, 28 years after he signed with the Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association. When Haywood entered school, the N.B.A. operated under what was called the "four-year rule," in which a player could not be drafted until his class was graduating. By the time Haywood's class at Detroit was leaving school, he had signed three contracts with two teams in two leagues. His decision to join the Seattle SuperSonics in December 1970 was then considered the N.B.A.'s most serious internal conflict in its history.
Haywood is not critical of players' leaving school early if their ability has become apparent before their senior season -- as his was on the 1968 United States Olympic team and at Detroit -- or if their decisions have to do with serious economic problems at home, a central factor in Haywood's legal struggle.
Haywood's concern, one he shares with N.B.A and N.C.A.A. officials, has more to do with inexperienced players, unrealistic expectations and an increased emphasis on earning N.B.A. dollars at a younger and younger age.
"For the African-American community, it may look like it's a dream," Haywood said, "but that's going to hurt us like rap music has hurt us."
Few agree where the problems are most severe.
"I don't think this is a big business problem for the N.B.A.," said Russ Granik, the league's deputy commissioner. "To me the real issue is kids coming out of high school or after one year of college who really don't know how good a player they are -- and no one else does either -- and aren't ready to go through the social rigors of the N.B.A. If you get two or three players in that category each year, we'll find a way to deal with them positively.
"But you're going to have several players who make a big mistake and are going to fail. That is my concern. I think Kevin Garnett is going to prove to be an exception."
Cedric Dempsey, executive director of the N.C.A.A., believes the pro teams will feel more of the consequences when they are forced to deal with unfinished projects. "The concern I personally have is for the athletes who may or may not be ready to take that jump," Dempsey said. "It should be a strong concern of the N.B.A. College programs have served as a developmental system, and I don't mean only physical development. There's a social and emotional development."
Several players cited economic needs of their families as a reason for exiting early. John Calipari, Camby's coach, remembered telling the junior that in each of the eight years he has stayed at UMass he declined offers of more money. "He came right back with, 'You make a lot of money,' " Calipari said. "Basically, he has nothing."
Colleges are discussing changes that would have to be based on a new model of amateurism. But N.C.A.A. legislation to ease such an economic burden would conflict with two basic principles of the association's structure and the recent reforms of college presidents: a need to limit costs and the philosophy that players should not receive extra benefits based on their athletic ability.
The N.C.A.A. recently increased athletes' access to a special assistance fund covering costs not included in scholarships such as medical and emergency expenses. The association also increased the budgets of programs designed to help former college athletes gain their undergraduate degrees and receive post-graduate scholarships.
Legislation at the N.C.A.A. convention next January may include more radical proposals. Kirwan has asked members of his committee on agents and amateurism to consider two models, one that would tighten existing rules and another that would liberalize them while creating more severe punishments. One approach could be a loan structure, possibly offered through the N.C.A.A., that could make it less tempting for players to accept payments from agents.
"Suppose a student athlete could borrow some money," Kirwan said. "Five thousand. Ten thousand. That would be so small in comparison with signing a contract. Would it really make any difference? Is it really an incentive to stay in school? The committee is trying to grapple with, what do we do now?"

HEADLINE: A POLITICAL LIFE: The Kansas Years;
On the Kansas Prairie, the Window to Dole

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

DATELINE: RUSSELL, Kan.

 BODY:
Harry Truman had Independence, Bill Clinton had Hope, and Jimmy Carter had the almost too-folksy town of Plains. All traded on their small-town origins, much as politicians of a previous era used to campaign on the basis of being born in a log cabin.
Rarely, though, has a campaign paid so much homage to a small town as Bob Dole's pays to his hometown of Russell. 
 To an unusual extent, Mr. Dole is running for President on the strength of his biography. The hopes of his candidacy are built less on a bright vision of the future, or on any soaring rhetoric of the present, than on the character-defining events of his own past. And it is in Russell, an unlovely town flat in the center of Kansas, that most of these events took place.
It is here that Mr. Dole grew up, poor but determined, during the Dust Bowl. It is here that he returned after being grievously injured and almost left for dead in Italy. It is here that, with the help of local women who dubbed themselves "Dolls for Dole," he launched his political career.
Mr. Dole frequently insists on the primacy of his years in Russell, referring to the town half as memory, half metaphor. "I have never forgotten where I came from," he likes to say. "Or where I go home to."
Russell certainly returns the favor. Even though he has not really lived here since the 1960's, people have never forgotten Bob Dole. And how could they? He has been running for national office off and on for the last 20 years, and every time he embarks on a new campaign, he returns here, national reporters in tow.
Those who are still left in Russell from Mr. Dole's youth -- and every year the number dwindles -- remember him, to a significant extent, as he remembers himself. They remember a serious boy from a hardworking family, a shy teen-ager who loved sports, a wounded veteran whose fierce resolve prompted the entire town to rally around him.
But people also remember aspects of his early years that are, understandably, left out of Mr. Dole's official biography. They recall a competitive young man who became a fiercely partisan politician. They recall a campaigner who ran what were, by the standards of the place and time, some memorably rough races. And they recall a man who from his earliest campaigns, was already relying heavily on his biography.

Russell, Kan.
Future Senator Born in a Boomtown
If things had turned out differently and Bob Dole were still living in this town of 4,700 people, odds are one could find him at 8 A.M. sipping watery coffee at the Mecca Mall downtown, or at 10 A.M. sipping equally watery coffee at Meridy's over on the highway, or at 3 P.M. at the Russell's Inn. Russell has three all-male kaffeeklatsches that meet religiously for an hour or so of gossip and ribbing to break up the day.
There are not that many new stories in Russell to go around, so old stories tend to get a lot of play. The crowd at Meridy's is still talking, for example, about the time, years ago, when some of its members went to what they delicately refer to as a "girlie show." Everett Dumler was mistakenly hailed as "Emmett" by one of the women, and every now and then he is still called "Emmett," just for the fun of it. At the end of the hour, the men settle the tab according to an elaborate guessing game over the serial numbers on a dollar bill.
The daily kaffeeklatsch is just one of the many rituals that make up social life in Russell. Practically every noontime some function is on the calendar -- a Kiwanis Club meeting, or a men's church luncheon. And if you are, say, a reporter looking for the retired editor of the local paper, people in town can advise you what lunch (Rotary) he regularly attends.
According to Mr. Dole's old friends, this is how Russell has always been except, of course, for the Prohibition years, when there was a lot more liquor. If anything has changed, it is that the town has grown sleepier, and perhaps shabbier. Certainly the yellow stone building where Mr. Dole's father worked weighing wheat is still there, and one can still find the sidewalk where decades ago, in a childish hand, young Bob mischievously etched his name in wet cement. (Mr. Dumler, the former head of Russell's Chamber of Commerce, claims it is the "worst thing" Bob Dole ever did.) Even the old Dole house on Maple Street is still standing -- Mr. Dole, in fact, owns it -- but it has been added to and faced with brick since he left home.
When Bob Dole says he still thinks of himself as a Russell boy, he is implicitly laying claim to the stability, order and community spirit that small-town America is supposed to represent. And these are indeed important qualities of Russell, even if the town is canny enough to play up its heartland simplicity for reporters. (At Dole homecomings, Russell folks have been known to set up the barbecue grills strategically upwind from the out-of-town press.)
But Russell is not a town that could, by any stretch of the imagination, be said to represent America's future, nor is it even a town that most Americans would probably feel comfortable inhabiting.
It is strikingly homogenous -- virtually all white, very largely Protestant and solidly Republican. It lies almost 200 miles from the nearest mid-sized city, in a region so treeless and flat that an Easterner can find it downright unnerving. Its small town-ness, while quaint, is also deeply anachronistic.
Like much of the rural Midwest, Russell has, in fact, been losing population steadily since about the time Mr. Dole graduated from high school; all of Russell County now has fewer than 8,000 residents, just a little more than half as many as it had in 1940.
In retrospect, it is clear that the years Mr. Dole lived in Russell were as close as the town has ever come to enjoying a boom. The same year Mr. Dole was born -- 1923 -- oil was discovered out in the wheat fields. The oil made a small group of local residents, known as "the Lucky Seven," very rich, and they built themselves incongruously oversized houses in the midst of Russell's modest one-story homes.
Oil is still an important part of the local economy, and pumping jacks still rhythmically peck at the wheat fields. But with the price of oil so low, no one in Russell calls himself lucky anymore. Years ago, when the price of oil was higher, the stakes of the morning guessing game were also higher, and covered the cost of an entire breakfast.

The Early Years
Back From War, A Turn to Politics
In his eulogy for Richard Nixon, Mr. Dole described the former President as "a boy who heard the train whistle in the night and dreamed of all the distant places at the end of the track." The line was widely interpreted as a reference to himself, too.
But if Mr. Dole had dreams of distant places as a boy, no one in Russell, or at least no one who is left, seems to have heard about them. Indeed, there isn't much out-of-the-ordinary that is remembered about Bob Dole until his dramatic return as a war veteran with a ruined right arm.
Mr. Dole grew up on the north side of Russell, quite literally the wrong side of the tracks, in a little white house with two bedrooms. For years, the four Dole children shared one bedroom until as teen-agers Mr. Dole and his younger brother, Kenny, fixed up a room for themselves in the basement. The family had to struggle to make ends meet, but, so, it seems, did most everyone in Russell during the Depression.
"Everybody was poor," said G. B. (Bub) Dawson, whose father ran the drugstore where Mr. Dole worked as a soda jerk. "We didn't know any better."
Schoolmates of Mr. Dole remember him as a handsome and popular young man, but not one who seemed destined for leadership. He was, by all accounts, a responsible student, but not a brilliant one, a devoted and competitive athlete, but not a naturally gifted one. Ralph Resley, a retired postal worker who went to high school with Mr. Dole, has kept a copy of the school paper from their graduation; in the Class of 1941's last will and testament, Mr. Dole is noted mainly for his shyness around girls.
Nor is there any trace of an early interest in politics. Mr. Dole's sisters, Gloria Nelson and Norma Jean Steele, who both live in Russell, say that politics was not a big topic of conversation in the Dole house while they were growing up, nor were Mr. Dole's parents politically active. They were registered as Democrats, out of friendship, Mrs. Nelson said, for a local Democratic politician.
The Bob Dole who is sharply remembered in Russell -- and whom townspeople recall as something of a hero -- is the emaciated, nearly paralyzed soldier who returned here in 1945, his right arm locked at a 45-degree angle. Russell, according to his old friends, adopted Mr. Dole at that point, rallying around him during his long convalescence.
Some of the boys who had gone off to war from the town had not come back at all, including Mr. Dole's good friend Bud Smith. But of those who survived he was the most gravely injured, and he spent three years in and out of hospitals, twice suffering infections that nearly killed him. When he was away, townspeople would follow his progress. And when he was home, they would stop by to play cards; someone had rigged up a cardholder so that he could play with one hand.
Mr. Dawson recalled that it was his brother, Chet, who started the collection in a cigar box down at the family drugstore when Mr. Dole went off to have surgery in Chicago. Pretty soon, others started collections, and eventually the town raised $1,800, a significant sum in 1947. The operations -- there were three of them -- did allow the arm, at last, to hang straight by his side. But it became clear that he would never regain its use, and Mr. Dole, who had dreamed of becoming a doctor, decided to go to law school instead.
Many in Russell see Mr. Dole's injury and his rise as a politician as inseparable. They recall his successful first campaign for County Attorney, when he ran in a primary against another young lawyer and World War II veteran, Dean Ostrum. No one can remember any real issues in that campaign, except that Mr. Ostrum came from a relatively prosperous family, and Mr. Dole was partly disabled. The race became a contest not so much over who would do the job best as who needed it most. And Mr. Dole, some people say, did his best to encourage that kind of thinking.
"He's always been able to get great mileage out of his injury," said John Woelk, a Russell lawyer who helped get Mr. Dole started in Republican politics. "He learned to do a very good job of drawing sympathy."
 
The 6th District
Candidate Shaped By Constituency
When Mr. Dole got started in politics, Russell was part of Kansas's Sixth Congressional District, which stretched across the state's sparsely populated northwest quarter. Even in staunchly conservative Kansas, the Sixth District's conservatism stood out. When Kansas Republicans gathered, for example, to pick delegates to the national convention in 1952, the year Mr. Dole became County Attorney, the other five districts backed Kansas's favorite son, Dwight D. Eisenhower. But Eisenhower was too moderate for the Sixth District, which instead backed Robert A. Taft.
In those days, the Sixth District's conservatism was the traditional, agrarian sort founded on a belief in local self-determination and an almost instinctive opposition to government intervention. And to a large extent this is still the case, though the Sixth District is now part of a much larger district, known here as the Big First. As a new strain of social conservatism has come to dominate the national Republican Party, western Kansas has continued to cling to its own brand of libertarian politics. These politics are now considered somewhat out-of-date even in Kansas, where the state Republican Party is currently controlled by members of the Christian right.
People who knew Mr. Dole in his early years say they are not sure how his own political philosophy was formed. Mr. Dole met his first wife, nee Phyllis Holden, in 1948 during one of his hospital stays; she was an occupational therapist in the psychiatric ward. Now remarried and living in Topeka, Phyllis Macey said that she can recall warning Mr. Dole to make sure voters knew that he was never one of her "psych" patients. But she cannot recall talking to him about his political beliefs.
"We didn't talk about politics," she said simply.
Mr. Woelk, the Russell lawyer who first approached Mr. Dole about running for office, recalled that in their first discussions not even Mr. Dole's party affiliation was clear. Mr. Woelk says he urged Mr. Dole to register as a Republican, using the argument: "If you want to get anywhere in politics in Kansas, you better be a Republican." Mr. Dole, he said, appeared convinced.
But whatever its origins, Mr. Dole's political thinking eventually developed very much in line with his constituents'.
Norbert Dreiling, a lawyer from the neighboring town of Hays who is the former chairman of the Kansas Democratic Party and a contemporary of Mr. Dole's, said: "I think Bob Dole reflects his constituency. When he's County Attorney of Russell County, he takes care of the county people. When he gets to Congress, he represents the west half of Kansas. It's a rural, provincial area, heavily anti-Communist -- they saw Communists under every rock. When he gets to be a Senator, then he begins to moderate. While he's still conservative, he isn't ultra-conservative."
Mr. Dreiling added: "I don't think you could ever describe him as embedded with an ideology he'll live and die with. If his constituency changes, he'll change."
 
Out of Russell
Washington Bound, Rooted in Kansas
Mr. Dole served as Russell County Attorney for eight years. People involved in local politics at the time, though, say it was clear from early on that he had larger ambitions.
He became active in a half-dozen local organizations -- Kiwanis, Elks, V.F.W. -- and became friendly with the Sixth District's Congressman, Wint Smith. He also earned local notoriety through a case he took to the Kansas Supreme Court challenging a severance tax on oil production on a technicality. (As people here remember it, Mr. Dole argued there was something wrong with the tax's title.) He won the case, and with it, the gratitude of the western Kansas oil industry, which would later become a major source of campaign contributions for him.
Mr. Smith's decision to retire in 1960 provided Mr. Dole with his first chance to move up the ladder. Of all Mr. Dole's many political campaigns, it is this first run for Congress that people in Russell recall most vividly. It is also this race that, in some quarters at least, first earned him a reputation as a tough, do-whatever-it-takes sort of campaigner.
Because the district was so heavily Republican, the primary was the race that counted. Friends recall that Mr. Dole campaigned tirelessly for the nomination and, swept along by his energy, they did, too. Morris Krug, a Russell rancher who worked on the campaign, remembers one weekend when he and Kenny Dole drove around the district, nailing posters to telephone poles for 24 hours straight. At 2 A.M., the pair was nearly arrested for making a racket in Bird City, a town near the Colorado border some 200 miles away.
Mr. Dole's main opponent in the primary was a State Senator, Keith Sebelius. But there was another opponent, too, Phil Doyle, who posed a problem because of his name. Someone in the Dole camp came up with the idea of handing out Dole pineapple juice as a mnemonic device. Someone else came up with the idea of "Dolls for Dole." Mr. Dole's wife sewed red felt skirts for them, with applique elephants holding "Dole for Congress" signs in their trunks.
She also designed a little card listing Mr. Dole's qualifications, which were, in effect, his biography. The card showed a picture of a wheel and the slogan "Roll with Dole"; along the spokes were phrases like "Russell native" and "Twice wounded Vet."
Publicly, the race seems to have proceeded amicably enough; once again, no one seems to be able to remember any significant political differences among the candidates. But privately, people here recall, the word was being spread that Mr. Sebelius had a drinking problem, and a letter was even sent out to this effect, bearing a Washington State postmark. The accusation was particularly explosive in Kansas, which was still dry until 1948 and still had a Prohibition Party in 1960. ("Beer taverns, as well as liquor stores, are a disgrace to the STATE," the party platform that year read.)
Mr. Dole has always denied any ties to those spreading the rumor, but to this day, many people in the district still hold him at least indirectly responsible.
"That was a mean campaign," Mr. Dreiling said. "You can't put your finger on it directly, but the Dole people were putting out the word. Dole in his younger years fought and fought hard."
Mr. Dole beat Mr. Sebelius and went on to face William A. Davis, a self-described "dirt farmer," in the general election. Mr. Davis, too, complained about Mr. Dole's campaign tactics; Mr. Dole, his opponent argued in late October, was "trying to scare the daylights out of the Sixth District voters" with "the same old pitch that no one but his gang is sufficiently patriotic to stave off Communism." But Mr. Davis's complaints apparently had little impact on the Republican electorate, and Mr. Dole defeated him handily in November. At the same time, Kansas voted overwhelmingly for Richard M. Nixon over John F. Kennedy.
In the winter of 1961, Mr. Dole and his wife and young daughter, Robin, moved to Washington. For several years after that, they returned to Russell every summer, making the long drive in a car crammed with luggage and pets. (Mr. Dole's former wife, Mrs. Macey, recalls that during one of these dusty trips, the family dog died from the heat.)
Then in the late 1960's the ties to Russell began to attenuate. Mr. Dole was running for the Senate -- Mr. Sebelius would eventually win the House seat he was vacating -- and he needed to campaign in the eastern half of Kansas, where most of the state's voters live. His trips to Kansas tended toward Wichita, or Kansas City, rather than to Russell.
Nowadays, Mr. Dole's visits to his hometown are almost always in the context of a national election. He returned last year to announce his candidacy for the Presidency, and then again this spring once he had clinched the nomination.
After the rallies and speeches are over, he usually goes back to the old family house on Maple Street. The little house is just the way his mother left it when she died 13 years ago. There he comes back, literally, to an image of himself as his campaign would have him portrayed; there are "Dolls for Dole" skirts hanging in the closet, his varsity letters tucked into a drawer and up on the bedroom wall a big framed photograph of a serious young man wearing a military uniform, his dark eyes staring seemingly full of purpose.
 
A Political Life
 In the months leading up to the election, articles in this series will look at the life and political career of Bob Dole.

HEADLINE: His Art Trashed, He Sues City Hall

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
For two and a half years Jan R. Martin spent his weekends and vacations building a dream, an abstract outdoor sculpture here in his hometown.
"I thought it would be something that would be good for the city," said Mr. Martin, who moved back to Indianapolis to join the family business after a stint as a shivering, starving artist in the TriBeCa neighborhood of lower Manhattan. He erected the sculpture in 1987 on land next to the family business in a rundown neighborhood northwest of downtown. 
 But the city bought the land in 1993, and, without telling Mr. Martin, had the sculpture torn down last July, with an eye toward sprucing up the area. Ten months after the removal, the only additions to the spot where the sculpture had stood are dandelions and fresh spring grass. The site remains a vacant lot.
The artist has sued the city, contending that Indianapolis violated a Federal law, passed in 1990, that is intended to prevent the desecration or destruction of art. The Visual Artists Rights Act was meant to clear up confusion about who decides the fate of public art.
Had it passed earlier, it might have prevented the removals of two prominent sculptures in New York City, an aluminum rhomboid by Isamu Noguchi, which was dismembered in 1980, and a steel work, "Tilted Arc," by Richard Serra, which was carted from the Federal Plaza in 1989.
Mr. Martin's suit is one of a handful under the statute. Lawyers who specialize in art law said it was perhaps the strongest challenge so far.
"The City of Indianapolis better have insurance," said Daniel H. Weiner, a partner specializing in art law at the New York firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed.
Other artists were appalled to hear of the sculpture's fate. "Morally or esthetically, the art belongs always to the artist," said Christo, who with his wife and partner, Jeanne-Claude, is known for his large-scale works that have included wrapping the Reichstag in Berlin in fabric last year. Jeanne-Claude added, "We find it outrageous that some people can destroy art."
Mr. Martin, 48, is a part-time artist. He is an executive and part-owner of the Tarpenning-LaFollete Company here, a manufacturer of ornamental and industrial metal objects -- from toilets on Amtrak trains to stainless-steel skylight frames for the new World Bank building in Washington.
He studied fine arts at Purdue University and earned a master's from the Art Institute of Chicago. Mr. Martin most often works in the same metals that he uses at Tarpenning-LaFollete, and has created metal murals with abstract designs, whimsical, cast-bronze frogs for a fountain and a 15-foot-tall sculpture with undulating steel leaves that decorates the front of a hospital.
But in his eyes, the 45-foot-long sculpture of stainless steel, "Symphony #1," was his masterpiece. It had columns, each about 14 feet tall, representing the movements of a symphony. Cables connected its irregularly shaped slabs of steel, recalling the strings of a violin. The work weighed 8,500 pounds, and the materials cost $23,000.
In an interview Mayor Steve Goldsmith said he was unaware that the sculpture had been destroyed. Mr. Goldsmith then called the city's top litigator, Mary Ann Oldham and asked, "What did we do?"
The Mayor listened and then looked dismayed. Apparently having been told that his city had indeed demolished the sculpture, he let Ms. Oldham speak. She insisted that the city had notified Mr. Martin that it was buying the land under the sculpture and offered him the chance to move it.
"He was very definitely told that," Ms. Oldham said. "And if he wanted it he could remove it."
But Mr. Martin's lawyer, Scott Hodes, a senior partner at the firm of Ross & Hardies in Chicago, said, "We wouldn't be in dispute with them if they would have acted in a reasonable manner and just given him a chance to take the piece away."
Asked why the sculpture had been torn down, Ms. Oldham said, "They had to move it to do whatever we needed to do" at the site.
The artist said he believed that he knew its disposition. "I think they sold it for scrap," Mr. Martin said. Scrap steel sells for 28 cents a pound.
Mr. Martin said that he knew of the sale of the land but that he had never been told that the city was planning to destroy the sculpture. He said he would have moved it had he known about that decision.
Brian W. Welch, a partner at the Indianapolis law firm McHale, Cook & Welch, which the city hired to defend itself in the case, said he did not know whether Mr. Martin had been notified that the sculpture would be torn down. Mr. Welch added that in the lengthy discussions about the land sale "the city was real clear about its lack of a need for the sculpture or desire to keep it."
The misunderstanding seems to stem from the city's view that after buying the land, it had the right to do what it wanted with anything on it.
A prominent art dealer in New York, Richard L. Feigen, said he believed that art should not be used to prevent development. But he sided with Mr. Martin, saying, "Certainly, an artist ought to be given time to remove a work of art" before it is destroyed.
Mr. Goldsmith said he wished that the city had searched for a better solution. He pointed to the fate of "Snowplow" by Mark di Suvero as evidence that the city supports the arts.
When the city needed to move Mr. di Suvero's outdoor sculpture, it arranged an innovative deal with the Indianapolis Museum of Art. The museum paid the city $200,000 for the right to move the work to an honored spot near the museum entrance. Indianapolis promised to use the proceeds to support public art created by local artists.
Mr. Martin has sued for at least $100,000. But whatever the outcome of the case, he said, he knows that it will not bring back his vision. He comforts himself with reminders of other important elements in his life. "I've still got my children," Mr. Martin said. "I've still got my family."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: URBAN PARALYSIS -- A special report.;
While a Dying City Languishes, A State Battles to Take Control

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
On a recent Friday morning, the Mayor of this remnant of a city summoned local officials, supporters and members of news organizations to City Hall to inform them that he was declaring war. "Enough is enough," began Arnold W. Webster, pounding his fist on a lectern in the city's scuffed-up Council chambers. "We're going to fight back."
The battle that Mr. Webster vowed to take on has nothing to do with the drug dealers who have seized control of more than 100 street corners in this city in southwestern New Jersey. Nor is it connected with the city's dubious reputation as the murder capital of the Northeast, a reputation that seems to have eclipsed the image of Camden as the home to Campbell's Soup. 
 Instead, the targets of the Mayor's salvos are economic development groups and the state government -- the very entities trying to assist Camden, one of the nation's most downtrodden cities. Since the first of the year, state officials have issued a scathing audit, accusing the city of mismanagement. They have threatened to seize control of $21 million in Federal money intended to spur economic development.
[On May 17, the state appointed a full-time monitor to oversee all Camden's municipal spending.]
At the same time, the Cooper's Ferry Development Association, a nonprofit corporation that for 12 years has led efforts to develop the city's waterfront, is battling Mr. Webster for control of major projects. "Look around you; your enemy is not hard to find," Mr. Webster told the group. "Everyone who claims they are our friends really are not."
Camden is a city that could use a few friends. Once a proud symbol of American industrial might, it has unraveled economically over the last three decades, as companies shut down, jobs departed by the tens of thousands, and despair moved in. Several plans to revitalize the city have been offered. But a struggle among local, state and business leaders has paralyzed Camden and left its 87,000 residents languishing.
As Mr. Webster conceded in an interview: "We have enough problems ourselves with the violence and the unemployment, and then you compound that with the confusion over who's running the shop and it looks like complete chaos. Nobody suffers more than the community."
Although Philadelphia and Camden are separated only by the Delaware River, the two seem worlds apart. There are so few jobs here that a rush hour is hardly detectable. Neighborhood parks are buried in weeds, mud and trash, and in some yards chickens peck at garbage piled outside ragged houses. Every movie theater, restaurant, hotel and department store closed down years ago, and with only one remaining supermarket, most residents must travel out of the city or depend on small corner stores for food.
Camden is 56 percent black and 31 percent Hispanic. Half the city's population is under age 25, and by most estimates the unemployment rate is about 20 percent, three times the state average and nearly four times the national rate. The per capita income for residents is less than $7,500 annually, according to a state study. More than half receive some form of government assistance, and the infant mortality rate among black residents -- 27 deaths for every 1,000 births -- is as high as that of many developing nations.
"Camden is a much more difficult case than any other city," said Mark M. Murphy, executive director of the Fund for New Jersey, a private Ford Foundation initiative that is financing community development in the city. "It has every urban ill and the level of intensity is such that the issues are much more stark."
The desperation in Camden often plays out through lawlessness. While most other cities have shown a drop in crime over the last few years, Camden's trend continues upward. Violent crimes, like murder, rape and robbery, increased 8.8 percent in Camden from 1994 to 1995, according to Federal Bureau of Investigation data. In the same period, the nationwide rate dropped 4 percent. Officials in Pennsauken, just northeast of Camden, became so fearful that they recently set up police checkpoints to monitor the flow of Camden residents into their township. But it was halted several months ago after irate Camden officials complained.
Illegal drugs easily exact the biggest human toll. According to the police, one dominant street gang that has controlled much of the city's cocaine and heroin trade made it a requirement for new members to murder someone -- anyone -- as part of its initiation.
"These young folks involved in the killings don't have jobs, so the drug dealers give them jobs and they give them a Glock to protect the job," said Albert S. Driggins, a longtime Camden resident. "That's their way of creating economic development."
The city's homicide rate is one of the highest in the country, and the 60 murders last year were a city record. There are 140 reported crimes per 1,000 residents in Camden each year, the highest rate in New Jersey, according to state police figures. And the city's police force of about 335 officers is so outmanned that the state was forced to assign troopers to assist in patrolling the city.
The homicide rate has dropped this year and arrests have increased since the state troopers arrived, the Camden police say. But two weeks after the troopers arrived on the scene in January, one was murdered.
"It's tragedy after tragedy after tragedy," said Kevin G. Halpern, who is Cooper's Ferry's chairman as well as chief executive at the city's largest health care provider, Cooper Hospital and University Medical Center. "The place is like an armed camp," he added. "There's an underworld that has taken over."
This is all light years removed from the Camden that helped shape the prose of its most famous resident, Walt Whitman. Like many of Whitman's poems, this city was once a metaphor for a young, muscular nation.
Just nine square miles, Camden was once known as "the biggest little city in the world." From the Navy ships that were built at its bustling waterfront, to the development of recorded sound at the Victor Talking Machine Company (later known as RCA) and the creation of condensed canned soup at the Campbell's Soup Company, Camden spawned industries that had an impact on the world. Mr. Driggins said, "This was a place where you could get fired or quit a job at 10 in the morning, and have a new job by noon."
But the shipyard closed in the late 1950's, and both RCA's surviving operations, now a unit of Martin Marietta, and Campbell's have only small administrative offices in Camden. Many of the two companies' manufacturing buildings are abandoned, and the neighborhoods where their employees once lived are daunting, skeletal remains.
The Terrace, one neighborhood near the old shipyard in South Camden, is now just four narrow, trash-strewn streets of dilapidated houses -- some abandoned, some occupied by squatters. On a recent day in the Terrace, young men sat on porches and stood in doorways without doors, holding cellular telephones to their ears and gazing warily at each car that passed.
"I get so angry when I see what's happened to this beautiful city," said Mario J. Ferrari, a retired chief of police in Camden. Mr. Ferrari, 66, was born and reared in Camden, and as a police officer he says he "walked every beat" in the city. "What this city used to be and what it has become makes me sick to my stomach," he said. "And now some people are fighting over how to resurrect it."
 
Local Politics
A Patronage Pie For County Leaders
To understand these tumultuous times in Camden, one must understand the city's political underpinnings. The affluent suburban communities in Camden County have built a powerful Democratic machine under leaders like former Gov. Jim Florio and the county's chief Democratic fund raiser, George E. Norcross 3d. As the suburbs prospered and the city declined, county political leaders were able to dominate city jobs, services and contracts.
Because the city qualified for a range of grants for the needy, the patronage machine grew stronger. "We meet every criteria for poverty, so we always received grants," explained Rosemary Jackson, the president of Camden's school board. "All it did was create a social service organization bigger than any Fortune 500 company. The money never trickled down to the people. It just created a bureaucracy and allowed the party bosses to control this plantation."
Ms. Jackson is a member of Young Leadership for Change, a new coalition of black and Hispanic Democratic politicians seeking to upend the old Democratic machine. They have already scored a string of election upsets. "We're challenging the old way things have been done," Ms. Jackson said. After she became head of the school board last year, one of the first things she did was cancel a $1 million insurance contract with a company owned by Mr. Norcross.
In its audit of the city, the state's departments of the Treasury and Community Affairs reported that many of the city's 1,400 workers were beholden to politicians who helped them get their jobs and that a large number of them were inexperienced or unqualified. The report cited numerous instances of mismanagement, including shoddy purchasing practices, improper contract bidding and unethical business relationships between current and former city and county officials.
The report urged city officials to take action "before the city falls into a further state of decay from which it cannot recover," adding, "It is dangerously close to that now."
[As a result of the audit, the state hired a certified public accountant on May 17 and appointed him a full-time monitor of Camden's fiscal affairs. It is also requiring Mr. Webster and the entire City Council to take courses on purchasing procedures and internal controls.]
In the last two years, the state has seized control of the city's parking authority and housing authority. Both were being used to dole out patronage jobs, state officials charged. The parking authority, which in most cities is self-sustaining and earns a profit for the city's coffers, was losing over $1 million annually, mainly, the state said, because of poor management.
 
The State's Role
Trying to Watch Where the Aid Goes
While some city officials say the state is being heavy-handed in its dealings with Camden, state officials say that the amount of money they send into Camden gives them the right to control city affairs, when necessary.
The city hardly fends for itself. Camden's tax base is so small that only $25 million is collected through municipal taxes. To balance an annual budget of $96 million, city officials count on the state for an additional $50 million. The rest comes from fees and grants.
Mr. Webster initially welcomed the state audit because he believed it would add weight to some of his own criticism of the city government, since many of the problems began long before he took office. But he says he now believes that the state has used the audit to "scandalize" the city. "It was used to address a political agenda instead of addressing the hard-core problems of the city," Mr. Webster said.
Moreover, the Mayor has grown even more incensed with the state for refusing to hand over Camden's share of Federal Empowerment Zone dollars. Under the program, which is President Clinton's main urban initiative, Camden and Philadelphia are jointly one of six nationwide zones designated to receive $100 million each over a 10-year period. Camden's share is $21 million.
State officials say that before they release the money to Camden, they want to be sure that mechanisms for accountability are in place and that the money is properly used to stimulate development.
"Based on our experience in Camden, we're not comfortable with this yet," said Robert W. Friant, public information officer for the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs. "We don't want to see this $21 million wasted."
In the meantime, businesses interested in moving into the empowerment zone and taking advantage of the tax incentives it offers are losing their patience. Sylvia's, the renowned Harlem soul food restaurant, had been planning to open a new restaurant in the zone, providing 50 to 75 jobs. But after a frustrating year of unsuccessfully trying to secure various approvals from city boards, the restaurant has put off its plans to move to Camden.
"The incentives were attractive, and people in Camden said they really wanted us," recalled Van Woods, chief executive of the family-owned restaurant. "So we announced that we were going to open up in Camden. We figured it would happen in about two weeks. That was in January '95."
 
Control
An Obstinate Mayor And a Silent Partner
Many people blame the city's stalled progress solely on Mr. Webster. A former superintendent of Camden's public schools, Mr. Webster has become notorious, since he came into office two years ago, for moving slowly on city business and being obstinate in negotiations over development projects. Among business executives, stories of unanswered telephone calls and letters to the Mayor abound.
Often the only way to communicate with Mr. Webster is through his closest confidant, James Ricks, who has no official role or title but is universally described as having Rasputin-like control over the Mayor's affairs.
In its audit report, the state expressed concern about Mr. Ricks.
"The person who appears to function as a special assistant, according to widespread allegations, wields considerable authority and control over city operations," the report stated. Although he receives no salary from the city, Mr. Ricks has "at least at one time, had an interest in a variety of corporations that have done or are doing business with the city in violation of the city's conflict of interest policy," the report went on to note.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has seen, first hand, the power entrusted to Mr. Ricks. Last year, when the Governor convened a meeting to discuss Camden's future with Mayor Webster and other officials at the State House in Trenton, Mr. Webster did not show up. He sent Mr. Ricks instead.
There was "total shock" in the Governor's office, Mr. Friant of the Department of Community Affairs recalled. "Here's a guy who has no official standing in the state showing up for the Mayor," he said. "To say it was unprofessional is the understatement of the century."
Mr. Ricks, a social service entrepreneur who has been involved in city affairs for many years and has been a consultant to previous mayors, refused to comment on his current role. Mr. Webster, however, defended his relationship with Mr. Ricks.
"I desire to have him here," the Mayor said during an interview in his office, where Mr. Ricks stood silently by his side. "He has more institutional knowledge of what has gone on in this city than anybody I know."
In its audit, the state asked the city to clarify Mr. Ricks's role.
Although Mr. Webster was elected with the backing of the county Democratic machine, he has said he wants to dethrone the city's traditional power brokers. This desire, the Mayor asserted, has led to his current struggle with Cooper's Ferry, which has close ties to Democratic Party leaders. Established by the major landowners on Camden's waterfront -- RCA, Campbell's and the city -- Cooper's Ferry over the last decade has assembled public and private dollars and built a new state aquarium, a music and entertainment center and a ferry pier along the river.
Although some of the projects have struggled financially, they were necessary to jump-start development, said Thomas P. Corcoran, the Cooper's Ferry chief executive. "This waterfront development is not a panacea, but it's a critical element," he said.
But Mr. Webster criticizes the projects, contending that they have created only seasonal, minimum-wage jobs and that the tax breaks that Cooper's Ferry offers private companies are too lucrative.
The Mayor has dug in his heels over a Cooper's Ferry plan to build a 175-room waterfront hotel and conference center. Instead, Mr. Webster announced a competing plan in May 1995 to build a hotel, and has brought in his own developer. The plan, which would bring small businesses to inner-city neighborhoods away from the waterfront, has barely budged forward a year later.
Undeterred, Mr. Webster says he plans more aggressive responses to unfavorable publicity like that generated by the state audit. The Mayor conceded that he also needed to reorganize his own office. "Does the responsibility for some of this stuff rest on my shoulders?" he said. "Absolutely."
And for those who have resigned themselves to just waiting out the remaining two years of Mr. Webster's term, the Mayor has already announced his plans to seek re-election.
Despite the turmoil, there are signs of hope in the city, like the handful of community development groups that have started to stabilize small pockets of their neighborhoods. So far this year, the murder rate is down slightly.
And during a snowstorm this winter, it became clear just how much the people of Camden want to work.
Instead of hiring a professional plow service to clear the snow from Camden's school grounds, Ms. Jackson, the school board president, put the word out for people interested in working to report to City Hall. The next morning, she saw a picture that was like a contemporary version of "American Gothic."
"There were 500 men and women of all ages standing there with shovels in their hands," she recalled. "Tears came to my eyes. These people want to work and need to work."

HEADLINE: H.M.O.'s Cope With a Backlash on Cost Cutting

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
With much of the country shifting to managed care, a backlash of criticism by doctors, nurses and consumers -- and the legislative response -- is forcing health plans to abandon a range of cost-cutting practices that reward doctors and hospitals for limiting care.
Over the last 18 months, at least 34 states have outlawed or curtailed methods that many health maintenance organizations have used to shorten some types of hospital stays, discipline physicians or keep patients in the dark about the incentives and ground rules of managed care. 
 Fueled by horror stories of care denied and physicians' rancor at losing their freedom to treat patients without second-guessing, 400 bills affecting managed-care practices have been introduced in state legislatures this year, according to the National Conference of State Legislators.
In Congress, meanwhile, members of both parties are also pushing managed-care legislation, though business groups have in the past deflected such assaults.
Now that so many people have experience with managed care -- 53 million in H.M.O.'s and at least 70 million in other types of plans -- the nation's attention appears to have shifted from concern about getting runaway costs under control to questions about whether managed care has gone too far.
"We believe the whole concept of managed care is spurious," said Dr. Carl Weber, a surgeon in White Plains who heads a group of doctors pressing the State Department of Health to take a tougher stance on industry practices. "It is predicated on financial incentives to restrict care and access to care."
In California, "we see the human wreckage every day," added Kit Costello, a Sacramento nurse who heads the state nurses association, which has collected more than 800,000 signatures to put an initiative on the November ballot that would restrict the use of financial incentives for denying or delaying appropriate care.
The managed-care industry discounts the flurry of legislation and grass-roots protest, though state and national trade groups have lobbied furiously against many of the changes.
They are the product of "individuals who have a vested interest in maintaining the old style of health care," said Karen M. Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, a trade group based in Washington.
Ms. Ignagni said that managed care plans had grown rapidly and that few members had been dissatisfied enough to leave them. "People are voting with their feet," she said, adding that a number of independent studies have found that H.M.O.'s match or exceed traditional fee-for-service medicine in the quality of several kinds of care.
Critics of managed care, on the other hand, say employers -- even as they increasingly demand independent appraisals of health organization quality -- often make it difficult for workers to change health plans. And many force employees to pay more of the costs to see doctors outside the managed-care network.
The most sweeping attacks on managed care have been aimed at the array of economic incentives and penalties that the industry directs at doctors, aiming to reverse what the industry says has been a tradition of excessive testing and referral to specialists.
For example, reacting to complaints that some health maintenance organizations exclude or expel doctors for ordering tests or consultations the health plans deem unnecessary, half a dozen states -- including Illinois and Georgia -- have required them to include any physician who has the appropriate credentials.
Maryland has been one of the most active states in regulating managed care. Last year it prohibited "withholds" -- the H.M.O. practice of holding back a portion of a physician's annual pay until the end of the year as an incentive to keep costs below certain targets. Last week Maryland extended the ban to physicians in fee-for-service discount networks. But the state continues to allow health organizations to pay doctors much of their income in the form of bonuses for keeping costs down -- an example of how managed-care companies, through alliances with consumer and physician groups, have been able to sustain their cost-cutting impetus.
Groups in several states are taking aim at "capitation," the practice of paying physicians a set amount -- the so-called capitation fee -- for each health-plan member who enrolls as their patient. Under many health-organization contracts, the cost of tests or specialist treatment comes out of the primary physician's fee.
While the earliest H.M.O.'s were essentially clinics with salaried doctors, most H.M.O.'s now are networks of physicians who follow a set of rules and typically get a monthly per-person payment. Some of the most respected H.M.O.'s pay bonuses to reward good medical results.
About half of the nation's 560 H.M.O.'s have capitation contracts with primary-care physicians, according to Interstudy, a Minnesota managed-care research center. And specialist groups, especially cardiologists, radiologists and psychiatrists, are also increasingly paid this way, said Marsha R. Gold, a senior fellow with Mathematica Policy Research, which recently studied capitation for Congress.
Although managed-care companies insist that capitation is not designed to deny medically necessary care, the practice stirs strong emotions. In Oregon, Dr. Gordon Miller, a Salem ophthalmologist, is gathering signatures for a voter initiative seeking to outlaw capitation.
The backlash against capitation also has reached the New York region. Physicians Health Services, a health maintenance organization based in Trumbull, Conn., is eliminating capitation fees for individual physicians and resuming fee-for-service payments. "We did not want to deal with the perception of an inducement to withhold necessary care," said Michael E. Herbert, the company's president.
But Physicians Health Services continues to give its doctors an incentive to control costs. The health group has "always tucked away 20 percent of what we paid doctors into a risk pool," Mr. Herbert said. "They get it back at the end of the year if they stay within budget," he added -- and they almost always do so.
Two groups of New York physicians, meanwhile, are fighting a shift to capitation by Aetna Health Plans. In March the doctors sued in Manhattan Supreme Court, contending that Aetna's payment systems give doctors an economic incentive to deny patient care.
An Aetna spokesman, Tom Greaney, said the lawsuit was "without merit."
"Aetna," he said, "is paying a fair level of compensation, and the payments are perfectly legal."
In California, most big medical groups seek to take on the risks created by capitation, hoping to pocket any profits from slashing costs. In that climate, the California Nurses Association has tiptoed around the issue in its initiative drive, which would ban bonuses and incentives for denying or delaying care, but not prohibit capitation.
On another front, at least 27 states recently enacted laws limiting managed-care practices that second-guess doctors or withhold payment for certain types of care.
Addressing one of the most politically charged issues, at least 18 states have banned so-called drive-through maternity care, in which hospitals send mothers home less than 48 hours after they give birth. They include New York and New Jersey, and Gov. John G. Rowland is expected to sign a recently passed measure in Connecticut.
But managed-care lobbyists persuaded 12 states, including New York and Connecticut (but not New Jersey), to add a loophole that removes the 48-hour requirement -- if the mother and her doctor give their consent and the health plan sends a nurse to visit the infant at home.
In Congress, the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee also passed a 48-hours bill last month over opposition from the managed-care industry and business lobbyists. Calling on Congress to pass the measure, President Clinton said recently, "No insurance company should be free to make the final judgment about what is medically best for newborns and their mothers."
Only action at the Federal level could affect the thousands of self-insured employers that are exempt from state insurance laws.
Meanwhile, 14 states have barred insurers from refusing to pay for what turn out to be "unnecessary" emergency room visits, when chest pains, for example, are traced to heartburn, not a life-threatening heart attack. And 12 states guarantee a patient's right to go directly to certain types of specialists without first getting approval from a primary care physician, who insurers call a "gatekeeper."
Finally, a number of states are requiring managed-care companies and their doctors to tell patients about financial incentives and rules that may affect their care.
At least six states have outlawed gag rules under which some health maintenance organizations threaten to dismiss doctors if they inform patients about alternative care that might add to costs. Gov. George E. Pataki of New York included a gag-rule prohibition in a recent proposal that would seek to protect patients and physicians from abuses by managed-care organizations. Similarly, in California, the State Assembly unanimously approved a gag-rule ban last Monday.
The California Nurses Association's ballot proposal and a separate initiative sponsored by the Service Employees International Union would prohibit rules that prevent doctors from criticizing health maintenance organizations.
And in an action that officials said should set a standard for the entire health care industry, the Federal Government in March announced rules requiring managed health plans under Medicare and Medicaid to disclose financial arrangements for physicians to the Government and patients.
 Two other maps with the article, reflecting the prevalence of other types of restriction, erroneously omitted Georgia. The state prohibits health plans from restricting what doctors can tell patients about care choices; it also requires disclosure of financial incentives that health plans offer practitioners.

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article last Sunday, about efforts by states to restrict health plans' cost-cutting practices, referred incorrectly to such laws in Georgia. And a map with the article, summarizing such restrictions nationwide, reflected the error. Georgia's requirement that health plans accept any physician with appropriate credentials applies only to insurer-based "preferred provider" organizations; it does not apply to all health networks.

HEADLINE: Big Government by Popular Demand

BYLINE: By Mathew Miller; Matthew Miller is a syndicated columnist and the economics editor of The New Republic.

 BODY:

THE GOOD SOCIETY
 The Humane Agenda.
 By John Kenneth Galbraith.
 152 pp. Boston:
 Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.
Newt Gingrich and company say they're on the side of history. John Kenneth Galbraith is here to tell the right they're wrong. Anyone who knows the difference between a propagandist and a professor won't be surprised to learn that Mr. Galbraith, a longtime eminence of the economics department at Harvard, wins the argument. In articulating his ideal of "the good society," though, his slim new volume -- synthesizing decades of reflection -- displays both the best and the worst of modern liberalism. It's one thing to assert government's indispensable role in helping give every citizen "access to a rewarding life"; it's another to pretend the bromides of the left aren't themselves ripe for rethinking. 
 The fundamental error made by Republicans out to roll back the welfare state, Mr. Galbraith contends, is that they think politicians and their actions drive history. In fact, he argues persuasively, it's the reverse. Liberals didn't create big government; history did. The social upheavals attending our shift from an agrarian economy to urban industrialization and mass production called forth popular demands for Social Security, medical and unemployment insurance, workplace and product safety regulation and more.
Liberals may have led government's accommodation to these larger trends, but they didn't cause them. Nor, rhetoric aside, can they be substantially reversed, as Newt Gingrich is learning the hard way, just as Ronald Reagan learned before him.
Still, if the welfare state is destined to be with us, Mr. Galbraith says, it could stand much improvement. His charge that America is a "democracy of the fortunate" is hard to dispute. The poor, who don't vote, have little voice. Even Democrats seem poised to end minimal guarantees of health and income support for the needy while leaving subsidies for the well-off untouched. Worse, as Mr. Galbraith shrewdly observes, since the affluent are typically hurt more by inflation than by unemployment, there's a perverse but powerful constituency for economic policies that dampen growth but preserve wealth.
For Mr. Galbraith, the guiding principle is that the good society not deny citizens, merely by accident of birth, the opportunity to rise as far as talent and temperament can take them. Against the current tide, this translates into urgent action on behalf of America's 15 million poor children, especially to improve the dismal education most get today.
In addition, Mr. Galbraith urges further cuts in military spending in the wake of the cold war's demise, to free up money for pressing domestic needs as well as for aid to fledgling East European democracies, in whose success he believes we have a huge stake. This isn't just a liberal's lament. With both parties agreed that the Pentagon should get 90 percent of its average cold-war funding a decade after the Russians' defense spending has dropped by two-thirds, Mr. Galbraith is right that people of all stripes should be asking questions.
As you might expect, "The Good Society" reprises a host of Mr. Galbraith's vintage cultural complaints. He denounces the equation of wealth with intelligence; the role of advertising in ginning up consumer desire; the injustice of private affluence alongside public squalor (why such expensively produced children's television, he asks, and such shoddy public schools?); and, of course, the perils of bureaucracy.
The only fault Mr. Galbraith seems to find with today's liberals is that they're occasionally not liberal enough. He thus lends regrettable authority to their complacency on budget deficits, and to Democrats' related reluctance to control costs in Medicare and Social Security, which as the baby boom nears retirement will gobble up resources for all the other public purposes liberals like Mr. Galbraith claim to cherish.
These blind spots aside, however, we're not likely to find as elegant a little restatement of the liberal creed, or its call to conscience.

HEADLINE: How to Succeed in Business (for Women)

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
ARE female business owners different from male owners?
No and yes. 
 All owners take risks, meet payrolls, worry about the bottom line and, yes, female owners also have to be good jugglers.
"Juggling home, family and business is what most of us do," said Valerie Maitland-Smith, president of the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners.
The association, which began 17 years ago as a forum and support group, has more than 200 members, including new entrepreneurs and longtime businesswomen.
"All we ask is that members be bona fide women business owners, which we define as a sole proprietor, working partner or nonsalaried agent, broker, contractor or any other individual whose earnings are derived principally from her work,"Ms. Maitland-Smith said. "I'm always amazed at the range of businesses our members are involved in.
"Our directory lists every occupation from accounting to topography. Although the majority of us run small businesses, 10 percent of our members run businesses that generate well over $1 million in sales annually, and two of us have megabusinesses, in the $50 million category."
Ms. Maitland-Smith, formerly a member of a KLM management team, left the airline to strike out on her own 25 years and five businesses ago.
"I've always harbored an adventuresome entrepreneurial streak," she said. "I came to the United States as a tourist and I liked it so much that I changed my visa and stayed on and became a citizen. I've started five businesses of my own since then. Only the first, a tour-operating company sending groups to Israel, begun just before the Six-Day War, was a disaster. The others have been successful."
Ms. Maitland-Smith is now president of the Success Connection in Pound Ridge, a consultant company that specializes in business and management development.
"I joined the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners, which we call Wawbo, on the advice of a friend," she said, "and it was wonderful for me. Not only was I struck by the feeling of camaraderie and support and the opportunity for networking at meetings but the programs were of a practical nature that helped me in my business."
Two years ago, for its 15th anniversary, the association started a fund to provide female owners with educational opportunities to improve their skills.
The director of the fund, Donna Goldman, said: "I.B.M. gave us the seed money, and with other corporate donations from Chase Manhattan, Smith Barney and the proceeds from our dinner-dance the education fund has grown to $40,000. We're using some of it to sponsor Wawbo's first conference ever, Women in Charge, which will be held on Friday, May 31, at the Crowne Plaza Hotel in White Plains. Pepsico paid for our mailing.
"It's an all-day event open to all women, 10 hours packed with information, exhibits, seminars, round-table chats and a dozen breakout sessions focused on showing women how to make it in the business world."
Ms. Goldman, a vice president at the Smith Barney branch in Mount Kisco and a certified financial adviser, said subjects of the 14 seminars at the conference had been chosen after a membership survey.
"Seminars totally reflect what our members deem most important," she said, adding that the topics would include starting a business and evaluating opportunities, understanding financial statements, retirement planning, marketing and sales plans, identifying techniques for specific businesses, computers, hardware and software and transition management, which entails how businesses grow.
"We feel we have something of value for everyone," she said.
Eileen Fisher, a fashion designer who in 12 years expanded her business from a $35 investment to one with 1996 projected sales of more than $50 million, will be the keynote speaker at a luncheon, Ms. Goldman said, adding that the morning keynote speaker will be District Attorney Jeanine Pirro.
"And Rich All, manager of Internet services for I.B.M., will be speaking about the Internet," she said. "There'll even be job opportunities at the conference. I know Smith Barney, for one, is hiring now, and they are willing to talk to anyone who might be looking for a career change."
Another member of the association, Joan Goodman, president of Glatzer Industries in New Rochelle, manufacturer of Emergency Beacon search and rescue products for the aviation industry, will conduct a round-table session. "My subject is Building a $1 Million Business, which I have managed to do with my company," Ms. Goodman said.
She had been special assistant to the president of the company, her husband, Stephen, who founded the company in 1968. "When my husband died in 1988," Ms. Goodman said, "I moved into the presidency. It was fortunate that I knew the business. Our products are marketed to private aircraft owners of small recreational planes and owners of business planes, and the recession was taking its toll. One of the first things I had to do was install a computer system and redo our marketing material and reorganize the finances of the company.
"I managed to accomplish it all without losing a customer. But I felt isolated and pretty much alone, because when it comes to business, men and women really do have different styles."
Three years ago Ms. Goodman read about the women's group and became a member. "As president of my company I was lonely at the top. I needed someone to talk to, to share experiences with," she said. "When I joined the club I immediately connected with other business owners. They were easy to talk to and they understood where I was coming from. We had the same frame of reference."
Ms. Goodman said another advantage is that members buy goods and services from one another.
"When I wanted to buy health insurance for my employees," she recounted, "I got a better understanding of what was needed and better service from a fellow member than I ever received from an outside insurance agent."
Women own 18 percent of businesses in the county, Ms. Maitland-Smith, and that number is growing. "What has happened is that women, as well as men, have become veterans of corporate downsizing," she said. "Many of those who have been terminated are exploring ways to start their own businesses. Women need two incomes today. We hope to see many of them at our Women in Charge conference."
The fees for the conference are $85 for members and $110 for nonmembers. Additional information is at 682-2113.
 
Membership Profile
 Fifty-seven percent of the more than 200 members of the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners work from home. They have owned their businesses for an average of six years and have 12.2 years' experience.
The association says the average sales are $130,000 a year, with 10 percent exceeding $1 million. Fifty-one percent operate service businesses, and 18 percent are consultants. Seventy-five percent run their businesses full time, averaging 36 hours a week. Seventy-seven percent are married. The average age of members is 43.
The areas of most interest to members are promotional and marketing techniques, business planning and expansion and customer service.
The dues are $95 a year. Business people who do not own their own businesses may join as associate members. PENNY SINGER
 The article also referred imprecisely to Donna Goldman of the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners Education Fund. She is its president; it has two directors besides her.
