HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Reporter's Eye on Militant Islam

BYLINE: By DAVID SCHOENBAUM; David Schoenbaum teaches history at the University of Iowa. He is the author of "The United States and the State of Israel."

 BODY:

GOD HAS NINETY-NINE NAMES
Reporting From a Militant Middle East
By Judith Miller
574 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30.
On the eve of the heady 1960's, the sociologist Daniel Bell pointed to "the end of ideology." In watershed 1989, which brought the end of the cold war, the political scientist Francis Fukuyama foresaw "the end of history." Yet, in ways neither Mr. Bell nor Mr. Fukuyama ever imagined, the odd product of history and ideology we have learned to call religious fundamentalism may yet turn out to be the real measure of our times. 
 In fact, from St. Petersburg, Fla., to St. Petersburg, Russia, and Tripoli, Iowa, to Tripoli, Libya, and Lebanon, the new political religion -- or religious politics -- has now taken root nearly everywhere but Western Europe and the surviving Communist states. Judith Miller, a 19-year veteran of The New York Times and the paper's former Cairo bureau chief, prefers to call its predominant Middle Eastern form "Islamism." Whatever its name, the phenomenon has flourished like kudzu among the ruins and crevices left by liberalism, socialism, nationalism and the crash of rising expectations.
 But the Islamic Middle East seems to be its happy hunting ground. In Lebanon, Ms. Miller has watched 5-year-olds march under the burning eyes of bearded kindergarten teachers who get their lessons from Iran. In Egypt, one of her sources, a columnist and critic of the militants, was gunned down after reporting that senior clerics promised martyrs an eternity of blissful pederasty. Such things can make life difficult for people in the region. But the bombs and bombers they inspire are also at least a potential threat to the rest of us.
"The Middle East is not the Middle West," the Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens once observed. Under most other circumstances, the dour Mr. Arens is probably not Ms. Miller's kind of guy. But on this, at least, she is all but certain to agree. What distinguishes her from Mr. Arens is her determination to understand as well as to master the differences, and to make sure we understand them too.
"I am not a scholar and this is not a scholarly book," she declares preemptively before she even reaches Chapter I. This is true. While generally accurate, Ms. Miller's history comes out of the can. She openly acknowledges her reliance on translators. Like most smart journalists, Ms. Miller piggybacks on scholars, in this case including such familiar suspects as Fouad Ajami, Bernard Lewis, Ghassam Salameh and Emmanuel Sivan.
But her reporting is its own reward. Like such now-forgotten giants of the correspondent's art as Dorothy Thompson, John Gunther and Vincent Sheehan, Ms. Miller is at her best at point-blank range: the interview, the street scene, the face in the crowd, which distinguish a place and a moment from all others. An amateur in the best sense, she is equally good at explaining why the Middle East has captured her imagination since she was a student at Barnard in 1971.
Her subsequent adventures are the kind that make an editor's day. En route with the author through 10 countries and a very big book, the reader visits Lebanese Baalbek in jeans and a T-shirt and an Iranian Persepolis covered from head to toe, attends a Sudanese execution and an Israeli interrogation, just barely escapes a pass by Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi of Libya, enjoys a lift and repeated dinner invitations from King Hussein of Jordan, is issued a Saudi affidavit certifying that the bearer is not a prostitute and watches Iran's theocracy fray and corrode like the Shah's regime 20 years ago.
Along the way, there are the conversations with the men in charge and the man on the street that all good reporters exist to report. But at every stop, there are also the conversations with decent, smart, tough and troubled women that only a good female reporter can deliver.
Fair-minded to her fingertips, Ms. Miller offers sensible thoughts and afterthoughts on a part of the world Americans find intermittently fascinating, sometimes scary, but invariably baffling. No reader of Ms. Miller is ever again likely to think that Arabs are closer to one another, let alone Iranians, than Sicilians are to Finns.
But her real comparative advantages are focus and nuance. The former allows her to note evenhandedly how the people she so plausibly likes have consistently been their own worst enemy, while Americans and Israelis too have done their part to create the golems that now haunt them. Her sense of nuance not only allows her to see such unexpected change as an American-financed birth control clinic in Egypt that actually works. It even allows a feminist case for what the author herself sees as the inhibiting and discriminatory conventions of Islamic modesty. The veil, Ms. Miller observes, can also be a social buffer. It can express generational revolt. It can be a passport to hitherto inaccessible jobs, a cultural analgesic, even a way to save on cosmetics. The argument would not occur to most men.
Ms. Miller's bad news is that Middle Easterners suffer from what is arguably the world's highest ratio of discontent to civilization. As recently as the early 1960's, the seven most prosperous Arab states were no poorer, even slightly richer, than their Asian rim counterparts. Today the same countries are already lengths behind the Asian tigers, not to mention Israel.
In a globalized economy where markets vote daily with their software, 58 percent of foreign investment now goes to Asia, 3 percent to the Middle East. From Algeria to the Sudan, from Syria to Saudi Arabia, rampaging population growth has left economic development in the dust. Yet the region buys half of all arms sold to what we still call the third world, and several Islamic sources not only confirm but volunteer that the Koran is no barrier to nuclear fantasies.
Ms. Miller's good news, if relative, is that Islamists are not inevitable winners, that they can be as pragmatic as anyone else and that Israel, Lebanon and Jordan have all had some success containing and domesticating them. Their own contentiousness is a natural obstacle to any "Khomeintern." They can be a threat to individual states, to the regional status quo, perhaps to economic stability and certainly to our own sense of security. But they are not Nazi Germany or the Soviet Union.
Her argument stops here. But what it suggests about the appropriateness, likely efficacy, even rationality of our current national energy habits, defense priorities, special relationships and cultural blind spots, already demands another book. With luck, Ms. Miller herself is now working on the sequel. If not, we should at least hope someone else is.

A book review yesterday about "God Has Ninety-Nine Names" by Judith Miller misspelled the surname of a journalist hailed as a great foreign correspondent of the past. He was Vincent Sheean, not Sheehan.

HEADLINE: Pataki Needs to Rethink Plan on Juvenile Crime

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The May 9 Metro Matters column calls attention to a troubling conundrum -- how to prevent as well as punish juvenile crime -- that needs to be addressed by Gov. George E. Pataki's budget proposal now before both houses in Albany. 
 Proven preventive services and constructive community development projects are more effective and economical than mandatory sentencing and more prisons.
While appropriate sentences should be meted out to offenders, even those as young as 16, when the crime and the criminal deserve it, mandatory sentencing and the wholesale transfer of high school kids to adult prisons are not the answer.
Effective legislation must also preserve judicial discretion so that each young person will be responded to individually and appropriately.
 
BARBARA PAUL ROBINSON
President, Association of the Bar of the City of New York
New York, May 16, 1996

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Reporter's Eye on Militant Islam

BYLINE: By DAVID SCHOENBAUM; David Schoenbaum teaches history at the University of Iowa. He is the author of "The United States and the State of Israel."

 BODY:

GOD HAS NINETY-NINE NAMES
Reporting From a Militant Middle East
By Judith Miller
574 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30.
On the eve of the heady 1960's, the sociologist Daniel Bell pointed to "the end of ideology." In watershed 1989, which brought the end of the cold war, the political scientist Francis Fukuyama foresaw "the end of history." Yet, in ways neither Mr. Bell nor Mr. Fukuyama ever imagined, the odd product of history and ideology we have learned to call religious fundamentalism may yet turn out to be the real measure of our times. 
 In fact, from St. Petersburg, Fla., to St. Petersburg, Russia, and Tripoli, Iowa, to Tripoli, Libya, and Lebanon, the new political religion -- or religious politics -- has now taken root nearly everywhere but Western Europe and the surviving Communist states. Judith Miller, a 19-year veteran of The New York Times and the paper's former Cairo bureau chief, prefers to call its predominant Middle Eastern form "Islamism." Whatever its name, the phenomenon has flourished like kudzu among the ruins and crevices left by liberalism, socialism, nationalism and the crash of rising expectations.
 But the Islamic Middle East seems to be its happy hunting ground. In Lebanon, Ms. Miller has watched 5-year-olds march under the burning eyes of bearded kindergarten teachers who get their lessons from Iran. In Egypt, one of her sources, a columnist and critic of the militants, was gunned down after reporting that senior clerics promised martyrs an eternity of blissful pederasty. Such things can make life difficult for people in the region. But the bombs and bombers they inspire are also at least a potential threat to the rest of us.
"The Middle East is not the Middle West," the Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens once observed. Under most other circumstances, the dour Mr. Arens is probably not Ms. Miller's kind of guy. But on this, at least, she is all but certain to agree. What distinguishes her from Mr. Arens is her determination to understand as well as to master the differences, and to make sure we understand them too.
"I am not a scholar and this is not a scholarly book," she declares preemptively before she even reaches Chapter I. This is true. While generally accurate, Ms. Miller's history comes out of the can. She openly acknowledges her reliance on translators. Like most smart journalists, Ms. Miller piggybacks on scholars, in this case including such familiar suspects as Fouad Ajami, Bernard Lewis, Ghassam Salameh and Emmanuel Sivan.
But her reporting is its own reward. Like such now-forgotten giants of the correspondent's art as Dorothy Thompson, John Gunther and Vincent Sheehan, Ms. Miller is at her best at point-blank range: the interview, the street scene, the face in the crowd, which distinguish a place and a moment from all others. An amateur in the best sense, she is equally good at explaining why the Middle East has captured her imagination since she was a student at Barnard in 1971.
Her subsequent adventures are the kind that make an editor's day. En route with the author through 10 countries and a very big book, the reader visits Lebanese Baalbek in jeans and a T-shirt and an Iranian Persepolis covered from head to toe, attends a Sudanese execution and an Israeli interrogation, just barely escapes a pass by Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi of Libya, enjoys a lift and repeated dinner invitations from King Hussein of Jordan, is issued a Saudi affidavit certifying that the bearer is not a prostitute and watches Iran's theocracy fray and corrode like the Shah's regime 20 years ago.
Along the way, there are the conversations with the men in charge and the man on the street that all good reporters exist to report. But at every stop, there are also the conversations with decent, smart, tough and troubled women that only a good female reporter can deliver.
Fair-minded to her fingertips, Ms. Miller offers sensible thoughts and afterthoughts on a part of the world Americans find intermittently fascinating, sometimes scary, but invariably baffling. No reader of Ms. Miller is ever again likely to think that Arabs are closer to one another, let alone Iranians, than Sicilians are to Finns.
But her real comparative advantages are focus and nuance. The former allows her to note evenhandedly how the people she so plausibly likes have consistently been their own worst enemy, while Americans and Israelis too have done their part to create the golems that now haunt them. Her sense of nuance not only allows her to see such unexpected change as an American-financed birth control clinic in Egypt that actually works. It even allows a feminist case for what the author herself sees as the inhibiting and discriminatory conventions of Islamic modesty. The veil, Ms. Miller observes, can also be a social buffer. It can express generational revolt. It can be a passport to hitherto inaccessible jobs, a cultural analgesic, even a way to save on cosmetics. The argument would not occur to most men.
Ms. Miller's bad news is that Middle Easterners suffer from what is arguably the world's highest ratio of discontent to civilization. As recently as the early 1960's, the seven most prosperous Arab states were no poorer, even slightly richer, than their Asian rim counterparts. Today the same countries are already lengths behind the Asian tigers, not to mention Israel.
In a globalized economy where markets vote daily with their software, 58 percent of foreign investment now goes to Asia, 3 percent to the Middle East. From Algeria to the Sudan, from Syria to Saudi Arabia, rampaging population growth has left economic development in the dust. Yet the region buys half of all arms sold to what we still call the third world, and several Islamic sources not only confirm but volunteer that the Koran is no barrier to nuclear fantasies.
Ms. Miller's good news, if relative, is that Islamists are not inevitable winners, that they can be as pragmatic as anyone else and that Israel, Lebanon and Jordan have all had some success containing and domesticating them. Their own contentiousness is a natural obstacle to any "Khomeintern." They can be a threat to individual states, to the regional status quo, perhaps to economic stability and certainly to our own sense of security. But they are not Nazi Germany or the Soviet Union.
Her argument stops here. But what it suggests about the appropriateness, likely efficacy, even rationality of our current national energy habits, defense priorities, special relationships and cultural blind spots, already demands another book. With luck, Ms. Miller herself is now working on the sequel. If not, we should at least hope someone else is.

HEADLINE: In South Africa, Bringing Theaters to the Townships

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: VOSLOORUS TOWNSHIP, South Africa

 BODY:
Hollywood's future in Africa may rest on the shoulders of people like Jerry Phadima.
Until two years ago, Mr. Phadima ran a spaza bioscope. (A spaza, in black township lingo, is an informal shop run in a living room. Bioscope, a turn-of-the-century word for movies, is still in use here.) Toting a 16-millimeter projector, Mr. Phadima showed old films in churches, schools, abandoned buildings -- anywhere he could get a crowd and charge 2 rand -- about 40 cents -- a head. 
 "I sometimes had 500 people," he says. "There was no air-conditioning in these unhealthy places. Often they sat on the floor. But people in the townships were crying for cinemas."
Now he is a franchisee for Maxi Movies, a new South African company that is trying to do for the consumption of movies what Colonel Sanders did for the consumption of chicken: make it cheap and easily available. Since the company deliberately seeks black franchisees, it is also in the forefront of creating black business here. While large South African companies are promoting some black managers, franchise companies, in everything from hamburgers to hair products, are doing more to help blacks own their own businesses.
"I'm from the street," Mr. Phadima says. "But my aim was always to see myself as a big-business man. And today, you see -- I'm wearing a tie."
Whatever the virtues of franchising when it comes to economic empowerment, it also has tangible benefits for Hollywood. From the entertainment industry's point of view, Africa is a great hole into which its products disappear without returning a bit of income. Its films are popular. (Asked their favorite film stars, African teen-agers will often answer "Americans! Jean-Claude Van Damme! Arnold Schwarzenegger!").
But while there are 51 countries in Africa, only 3 -- Egypt, South Africa and Zimbabwe -- have theater chains that show films legally and pay royalties. Almost everything else is pirated. Sometimes the quality is so bad that it is clear the tape was shot in a movie theater with a video camera. In rural areas, spaza operators nail sheets to baobab trees and run their projectors off car batteries.
That is the market Maxi Movies is ultimately aiming at, with the intention of paying royalties back to Hollywood. It has nine theaters now -- six in South Africa, two in Swaziland and one in Namibia -- and deals in the works for 10 more, everywhere from Mozambique to Uganda.
But the black neighborhoods of South Africa are a huge untapped market. Only about two million of South Africa's 41 million people go to the movies regularly. Because of economics and apartheid, nearly all of South Africa's 650 movie screens are in downtown areas or white suburbs. Before 1990, blacks were not allowed to go into those theaters.
So by some estimates, 30 million South Africans -- 75 percent of the population -- do not live within walking or driving distance of a theater. And it is not as if they are all home watching videos, either. Only half the homes in South Africa have electricity, and only 250,000 black homes have videocassette recorders.
But neither can most South Africans afford movies in the theaters that whites patronize. A couple on a date taking a taxi from Vosloorus to downtown Johannesburg would pay 52 rand in taxi fare plus 40 rand for two tickets -- a total of $22. Not much for an American, perhaps, but serious money to a laborer who is lucky to earn 50 rand -- $12 -- a day.
Two Maxi Movie tickets will cost 14 rand for a double feature, and splurging on a township taxi instead of walking will add 4 rand -- for a total of about $4.25
Maxi Movies keeps costs low by projecting video instead of film, and designing theaters so efficiently that they can be run by two people.
The video projectors, like those used on airplanes and in sports bars, cost a third of what the 35-millimeter film projectors used in conventional theaters do, and do not need a projectionist to run them. Also, a distributor like Mr. Nothard has to pay Hollywood far less for the right to show a video three months after the motion picture is released.
Each 96-seat theater -- small enough to retain "big screen" picture quality even in video -- has a normal staff of four, but can be run by two: the ticket-seller can also sell popcorn by simply swivelling her stool around and the manager on the phone lining up new films can load the videocassette and start the projector from inside his office.
Maxi Movies was started by Sven Nothard, the white former chief executive of Numetro, one of the two chains that own nearly all the theaters in the country. For about $500,000, he sold 60 percent to Ster-Kinekor, the other major chain, and Thebe Investments, a black-run investment house connected to the African National Congress.
Before 1990, Mr. Nothard said, Numetro and Ster-Kinekor could not build theaters in black areas. "You weren't given license by the Government," he said. "But it didn't take a degree from Harvard to put two and two together and see how big the market was." That is, if movies could be made affordable.
Mr. Phadima runs his theater -- as comfortable as its American counterparts, though cleaner -- with his wife, daughter and a part-time janitor. His monthly receipts amount to 40,000 rand, or $9,500, against expenses of 26,000 rand, or $6,200. The personal touch is crucial to his success -- a new notion in South Africa, where indifference to the consumer is the norm. When he's not in the lobby asking customers what films they want, Mr. Phadima is visiting churches and schools drumming up new customers.
"Our franchisees must live in the community and be known in it," Mr. Nothard said. He would not, for example, sell a franchise in far-off rural Ladysmith to someone from Soweto, the huge township near Johannesburg. "You have to be behind the counter."
Knowing one's audience takes other forms. In Vosloorus during apartheid, he said, "People were burning each other, shooting each other, putting 'necklaces' around each other," Mr. Phadima says. "You must know your township. Here, they want karate and action movies." He is showing "Goldeneye," a James Bond movie, and "Tough and Deadly," an obscure police thriller.
By contrast, the Maxi Movie in Mbabane, the capital of Swaziland, an independent kingdom inside South Africa, will show "Sense and Sensibility" and "Mr. Holland's Opus" next month.
The biggest problem for the franchisees is time lag. New movies are released in South Africa anywhere from a month to six months after their American premieres. Six months after that, Hollywood studios ship a videotape version to home video-rental shops in South Africa. "That's the trigger for piracy all over Africa," Mr. Nothard said.
He wants to get videotapes for his theaters three months before the stores do, but he wants them encrypted so they cannot be copied. Some studios go along. Others, unhappy with the crude anti-piracy system he uses, refuse. He has hired a European company to develop a sophisticated tape-encryption system that would give each projector a decoder.
Each franchise costs 350,000 rand, about $80,000. For that, Maxi Movies provides the theater and training. It also arranges financing, which is crucial. Mr. Phadima said he was nearly penniless when he enlisted as a franchisee. Ster-Kinekor, one of Maxi Movies's parent companies, is controlled by the Old Mutual and Sanlam Insurance companies, which have combined assets of $50 billion, so financing is hardly impossible
Of the nine initial franchises, Mr. Nothard said, one failed; the franchisee was replaced by a company employee. Now, he said, "six have outstanding results, two are battling, and one is below break-even."
"Africans do not have the cinema-going habit," said Amos Zwane, a Maxi franchisee in Kasigo, a black township near an industrial suburb of Johannesburg. "We still have to build it. But it's a very, very good business proposition."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jerry Phadima, who owns the franchise for Maxi Movies in Vosloorus, South Africa, says theater owners must know their markets. His town was very violent under apartheid so he shows karate and action movies. (Graeme Williams for The New York Times)

COMPANY: MAXI MOVIES MAXI MOVIES (71%);

PERSON: MCNEIL, DONALD G JR ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER (59%);

LENGTH: 1695 words

HEADLINE: KENNEDY AIRPORT IN BIG REVAMPING AFTER LONG DELAY

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
In the confident 1950's, New Yorkers would travel to the airport, not to fly but to dine in a glass-enclosed restaurant as airliners lifted into the twilight. The image is almost fantastic now, as harried travelers flee Kennedy International Airport's sagging terminals to fight their way home through the endless traffic on the Van Wyck Expressway.
But after 20 years with almost no improvement, New York's primary airport is undergoing a profound transformation. In the next five years, the airport's managers and private developers are expected to spend more than $3 billion to replace two aging terminals, rebuild airport roads and parking lots and build a rail line that will ease travel between Kennedy's terminals as well as connect the airport to Manhattan. 
 In part, the plan is notable simply for its scale: $3 billion is triple what it cost to build the World Trade Center. But also remarkable is that the four projects are moving forward after years, or decades, of inaction. There has been no new terminal construction at the airport in 25 years, and the plan to build a rail connection has been under study for three decades.
Why now? The money is available, both from fees tacked onto airline tickets and from private developers. And the political will is there, with both city and state officials agreeing that the poor condition of the airport, which was ranked third worst in the world in a survey of international passengers this year, has made Kennedy an embarrassment to New York. Particularly galling to many New York politicians has been the Port Authority's recent investments in the more modern Newark International Airport, which has threatened to eclipse Kennedy as the New York region's premier airport.
As Charles A. Gargano, director of economic development for New York State and vice chairman of the Port Authority board, tells it, Gov. George E. Pataki gathered his appointees to the authority board shortly after his election in 1994 and told them that the rebuilding of Kennedy should be a top priority.
"It was a question of saying, 'Enough of talk and plans and studies,' " Mr. Gargano said. "Kennedy is in dire need of improvement."
The airport, Mr. Gargano went on, "was a disgrace to New York City and to New York State."
Still, city officials are critical of several aspects of the Port Authority's plans. John S. Dyson, chairman of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's council of economic advisers, said the $1.5 billion cost of the new terminals could make Kennedy more expensive for airlines and travelers.
And city officials contend that the authority's rail plan is unworkable because travelers from Manhattan would have to switch trains in Queens to get to the airport. The Mayor is expected to release his own rail access plan this week.
For all of Kennedy's problems, its old terminals and the shortage of shops and restaurants, the central problem for travelers has long been the incredible difficulty of reaching the airport. It is a long and grinding trip as drivers fight the traffic on the Van Wyck Expressway, only to find themselves negotiating a confusing airport road system seemingly always under minor construction. The trip can also be expensive. A cab ride to Manhattan from Kennedy now costs $30.
While airport managers cannot control the traffic problems outside Kennedy, they promise to make driving inside the airport easier. They plan to couple ongoing road improvements with a $1 billion rail line to Manhattan. Both projects are scheduled for completion by 2001, although elements of each will be operating before then.
The $540 million road project, started in 1989, involves a complete rebuilding of the underground utilities as well as the roads and parking areas at the airport. About half the project, including a large section of the utility work, is complete.
The reconstruction of about 32 miles of airport roadway is expected to eliminate 25 intersections and traffic bottlenecks that have plagued Kennedy for years. The new road system will divide the central terminal area into four sections. Barry Abramowitz, who is managing the road project for the authority, said the new road system would channel drivers directly to their terminals, rather than forcing them to circle the airport.
Port Authority directors acknowledge that the road rebuilding project will not solve the congestion problem at the airport, where 100,000 people on average flood the roads every day. They believe the new railway will draw enough passengers to reduce traffic tie-ups.
The rail plan calls for a small train to circle the central terminal area and transport passengers between terminals. The train would also connect the airport to the Long Island Rail Road at its Jamaica Station and the city subway at the Howard Beach stop. Travelers who wanted to reach Kennedy Airport from Manhattan would board an L.I.R.R. train at Pennsylvania Station and transfer at Jamaica. The airport train would run along an elevated track on the median of the Van Wyck Expressway.
Critics, including city officials, have said the plan will not work because travelers will refuse to transfer between the L.I.R.R. and the airport train. But Governor Pataki, the Port Authority, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the L.I.R.R. have all approved the plan, maintaining that the transfer at Jamaica will be seamless, particularly for passengers with baggage. Officials managing the project have not worked out the the transfer details.
Port Authority officials, as well as transit experts from the Regional Plan Association, have also said it is not possible to run an L.I.R.R. train from Manhattan directly to the airport because the big trains could not handle the turns between the terminals and because there is not enough track space to handle the additional trains. Authority officials have said they plan to begin construction before the end of the year and have the railroad operating by 2001.
Lewis M. Eisenberg, the authority chairman, has agreed that the railway might not be the perfect solution to reaching Kennedy Airport, but he said it was the best solution using available technology. Mr. Eisenberg also said it was a practical solution, unlike many past proposals, which were either too expensive or politically unfeasible.
"One of the standards we use to measure what can be done is, in a reasonable time, can we put a shovel in the ground, can we achieve our goals," he said. "I have seen plans that could never have been accomplished, even if there could have been an agreement."
Mr. Eisenberg said a direct connection to Manhattan could be added in the future, if the track space and technology become available. "We are leaving our options open," he said. "But we also want to have plans that can be worked."
The International Arrivals Building, the center of New York's primary gateway, has been described as an old terminal from a small, Midwestern city. The largest and busiest of Kennedy's nine terminals, it has 1.3 million square feet of space and handles 6 million passengers each year.
When it was completed in 1954, the building was hailed by both aviation experts and architecture critics. But with no major improvements in 40 years, it has become worn and congested. It is the only terminal at Kennedy that is managed by the Port Authority, but that is expected to change by the end of the year when the authority transfers ownership to a private development group. The group, headed by a Dutch airport management company, Schiphol, will spent $1 billion to redesign and renovate the terminal.
The developers say construction will proceed in stages, with the arrivals building staying open throughout the project. The main terminal is expected to be finished by 2000, and the final sections the following year. According to the company that will handle the construction, LCOR Inc., the new terminal will have a centralized customs processing area and better shops and restaurants.
About 70 percent of the cost of the new building is expected to be raised from fees charged to airlines using the terminal. The rest is from a percentage of retail sales from the new food court and shopping mall. Schiphol is expected to pay rent to the Port Authority for the terminal -- figures from $15 million and $40 million a year have been reported -- but both parties have declined to say how much until talks are completed.
City officials have questioned whether the new management will have to raise airline fees to recoup the money spent on the terminal. They are concerned that an increase in fees would make Kennedy, already the most expensive airport in the country, less competitive. But Schiphol and LCOR say that they will be able to make enough money without an across-the-board fee increase, largely by changing the way the airlines are billed and increasing terminal efficiency.
The larger airlines that use the terminal are either reserving judgment until the details of the deal are released or are welcoming the improvements to the terminal.
"The feeling is that finally something is happening at Kennedy," said Marta-Marie Lotti, spokeswoman for Alitalia Airlines. "We are just happy and eager to see it finalized."
While work on the International Arrivals Building is not expected to start until next year, the steel frame of the airport's second new terminal, Terminal One, should be taking shape within the next few months. Terminal One is a half the size of the International Arrivals Building and half the price, $425 million.
The terminal is being built by four of Kennedy's largest foreign airlines, Lufthansa, JAL, Air France and Korea Air Lines. "There are no tax dollars involved in this project," said Charles Croce, a spokesman for Lufthansa. "We share the risks and we share the profits."
The combination of private and public funds is necessary to draw the money and expertise needed to rebuild Kennedy, Mr. Eisenberg said.
"Nothing could be more important than returning Kennedy Airport to the prominence it once enjoyed," he added. "We could not possibly do that without making a major investment in the airport infrastructure."

HEADLINE: Hundreds Line Up to Apply for Casino Jobs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MONTVILLE, Conn., May 19

 BODY:
Hundreds of job seekers are taking a gamble on the Mohegan Sun Resort -- scheduled to be the state's second Indian casino.
About 300 applicants stood in line on Saturday, hoping for a shot at one of the mostly entry-level positions at the casino, which is to open in October. People arrived two hours before doors opened at 10 A.M. 
 "People around here do need jobs," said Frances Santerre, an unemployed store cashier from Groton, Conn., who was looking for a job.
Outside the warehouse where interviews were taking place, construction on the resort continued.
The resort plans to employ 4,500 permanently. The Mohegan casino will be 150,000 square feet, with 3,000 slot machines and 180 gaming tables.
Less than 15 minutes away is the highly successful Foxwoods Resort Casino operated by the Mashantucket Pequots.
The Saturday job fair was one of several aimed at recruiting people.

HEADLINE: For Some, Steady Job Isn't the End Of the Road

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 19

 BODY:
As a Web-page developer, Jayson Elliot could have his pick of permanent jobs in the San Francisco Bay area. But that's the last thing on his mind.
"I don't want a job," Mr. Elliot said. "I would never take one." 
 Instead he works as a temp, with no job security, no benefits and little chance for corporate advancement. Instead he has the flexibility to pursue his own interests, which include the underground music scene, and most important to him, a freedom from long-term commitment.
"I don't want to get tied down to anybody's plan," said Mr. Elliot, who is 25.
These days, Mr. Elliot can be found in front of a Macintosh computer at the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the giant utility company in San Francisco. Since November, he has helped manage the company's public Web site, building Web pages and posting documents.
His previous assignment was at Peachpit Press, a technical publishing company in Berkeley, Calif., where he worked for nearly a year, far longer than the temporary employment agency, or the publishing company, had planned. Mr. Elliot filled in as technical production manager, a position the company eventually offered him permanently. Mr. Elliot, of course, turned it down and moved on.
The agency he relies on is Mactemps Inc., a national company. When the Pacific Gas and Electric job ends, he has no idea where he will be sent next.
Mr. Elliot's approach is not a life strategy for the faint of heart, but at roughly $20 a hour, the equivalent of more than $40,000 a year if he were to work every day, Mr. Elliot can save money to get him through any slow times. And so far, since beginning his temp career when he arrived in San Francisco from Chicago a few years ago, there have not been many. Mr. Elliot said he could not remember all the places he has worked for Mactemps.
Mr. Elliot grew up using computers, and as a student at the University of Iowa in the late 1980's he became proficient with a wide variety of software. He has been a frequent contributor to the Internet's discussion forums for nearly 10 years, and watched the development of the Internet into a commercial medium. His breadth of knowledge wins him a variety of assignments, but he sees the Internet as the ticket to the more interesting ones.
"I've always been a tech freak," Mr. Elliot said. "It just so happened that when I came out here they could put me to work."
Like most people working on the Internet, Mr. Elliot taught himself most everything he knows about the Web, staying up late at night to build Web pages, try out the latest Web software and generally poke around.
During the assignment at the technical publishing company, he helped co-workers build and start the company's Web site, in the meantime picking up what experience he could.
Picking up skills in one job that can be applied to the next is how many temps raise their salaries. In Mr. Elliot's case, he wants all the Web publishing experience he can get so that he can someday own his own Internet services business. But he is also a jack-of-all-trades computer operator within the Macintosh world, with a wide range of expertise. At Peachpit, he set up the company's data base and helped manage book production.
He turned to Mactemps, he said, because he thought that would land him better assignments than he could find as an independent. And the managers at Mactemps, which has offices in San Francisco and Santa Clara, Calif., in Silicon Valley, say his background is perfect for today's high-tech market. The Internet has led to a surge in demand for anybody with Web development experience.
"The reason an agency is good is it gives you access to places you wouldn't otherwise have access to, like P.G. & E.," Mr. Elliot said. "It used to be companies like P.G. & E. would hire direct, but now they go through agencies."
Like a lot of "permanent" temps, Mr. Elliot is choosing this way to earn money so he has time and energy for what he considers his true career these days: he publishes a culture magazine about the underground music scene, a project he began three years ago while working in Chicago as sales clerk in an apparel shop. Today, he devotes his evenings to the magazine, working out of his apartment after a day at one office or another.

HEADLINE: A Temporary Force To Be Reckoned With;
Wanted: High-Tech 'Hired Guns' And Agencies to Provide Them

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, May 19

 BODY:
The hiring hall of the Information Age is a fourth-floor office encased in glass and granite, just a few blocks from a waterfront that once buzzed with temporary workers of an entirely different sort.
It is not really a hall, of course, nor does it hire out in the traditional sense. It is more like an air traffic control center: a Web-page maker is being sent north to a small start-up company; a "content specialist" is hurried across Lake Washington to the Microsoft campus in Redmond, Wash.; a technical recruiter is dispatched south of Seattle. 
 "The appetite for technical skill in this city has become insatiable," said Sheri Lee, manager of Resource Management Services in Seattle. The company finds temporary workers for high-technology and professional businesses. Six years ago the company did not exist; now it can barely keep pace with demand.
It is at the confluence of two business trends: the unquenchable need for high-technology specialists in all areas and the rise of temporary- placement firms. The resulting demand is not just for technically proficient temporary workers but for controllers to sort them out and direct them where they are needed.
Resource Management is one of at least 229 companies nationwide that specialize in professional temporary placement, high-tech or otherwise. In 1990, there were only 44 such companies, said Jim Kennedy, who publishes an annual directory of temporary- placement companies.
Mr. Kennedy foresees a day in the near future when many corporations will have a core group of permanent employees and then "flex" the rest of the staff -- the "contract" or "just-in-time" employees, as he calls them.
The Labor Department reports a similar wind blowing through the American workplace. In 1983, there were 619,000 temporary jobs in the country. By 1994, that number had grown to 2.25 million, and the Government projects a 60 percent increase by the year 2005. Still, the total number of temporary workers is less than 2 percent of all jobs.
The fastest-growing segment of temporary jobs is in technical and professional fields, which make up 15 percent of the temporary force, Labor Department officials say.
While the image of temps has long been that of downsized, down-on-their-luck people in between real jobs, Ms. Lee laughs at the very idea: the people who come through her office are paid $15 to $50 an hour, for contracts that last three to six months on average.
As competition has heated up among temporary-placement companies, some benefits are now being offered. Resource Management just started a 401(k) program for the temporary workers it places.
"A lot of people consider this a preferred form of employment," Ms. Lee said. "These folks control their own destiny. They are shopping around, in some cases. Or they just don't want to be at one place for a long time."
Critics may see the rise of the technology temporary service as another nail in the coffin of American job security. These jobs, typically, offer no benefits, no chance for lasting bonds with employees. They are held by people who act as digital smoke jumpers.
"The fact is that in today's interconnected global economy, you have to watch out for yourself," said Bruce Steinberg, a spokesman for the National Association of Temporary and Staffing Services, a trade group based in Alexandria, Va. "People are starting to recognize that job security is no longer with the corporation, it is with the individual."
In the argot of this evolving trade, temps are called "a resource" or "talent" or "a hired gun." They are all ages, from all backgrounds. But no matter what they are called, the demand is huge.
Because far more jobs are available than people to fill them, the qualified technical temps tend to have the upper hand right now, Mr. Kennedy said.
Indeed, they are courted and stroked, Ms. Lee said. "In the end, there are jobs we just cannot fill," she said. "People always thought this sort of thing was employer driven. But it's just the opposite."
Employers say the rise of technical temps allows them to be more flexible. At Silicon Graphics Inc., as many as 500 of the workers in technical fields are on short-term assignment at the company's headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., and elsewhere around the country. The company employs 11,000 people.
"I feel what we're seeing is a real reconfiguration of the workplace," said Eric Lane, the director of worldwide staffing for Silicon Graphics, whose powerful computers are widely used for engineering, architecture, special effects for films and other work where three-dimensional design is important. Temps are brought in -- at up to $60 an hour for some specialized people -- to start a new project or complete an old one.
Managing temps is different from managing permanent employees, Mr. Lane said, because "you have to think about how they can be used right away."
A small company, Photodisc Inc., in Seattle, which sells stock photography images from CD-ROM's and a World Wide Web site, has used about 10 people from Resource Management. "It's win-win for everybody," said Ann Fosburgh, a human resources specialist at Photodisc. "You can come in and see if you like us or like doing a certain kind of work, and if it works out there may be a full-time job, and if it doesn't work out, you go home at the end of it."
Ms. Lee said she thought of her job as a cross between a talent scout and broker. Some of her best finds have been people who are looking for less work, people who want more time to ski or spend with their families.
"Downsizing is not a factor," Ms. Lee said. "More often, we're dealing with somebody who wants to get off the fast track."
Meegan Glouner, who is 30, wanted a job at a good-paying high-technology company but did not want to spend months going through endless rounds of interviewing and job searching. Resource Management found her a marketing position at Microsoft.
Though Ms. Glouner works 40 hours a week at Microsoft now, her employer is Resource Management. It collects from Microsoft, and in turn, pays her.
It took only a week from the time Ms. Glouner was first interviewed at Resource Management until she started work at Microsoft.
"The job market changes so fast that if you want to keep going on your career path you have to be flexible," Ms. Glouner said. "This way, you can stay employed without missing a beat on what's going on."
No figures are available yet on what percentage of the work force at high-technology companies is temporary, but Microsoft officials say they expect the trend to grow, reflecting the sprint pace of for-the-moment job demand.
Resource Management relies on word-of-mouth referrals to find recruits, people who usually have advanced degrees. The temps pay nothing to the service, which makes its money from companies looking for workers.
It is Ms. Lee's job to match workers with a company and to negotiate salary and terms of employment. Sometimes, it takes barely a day for a person to go from a fresh prospect to a job. Or it can take weeks. From a pool of about 6,000 prospects, 2,600 people found work from Resource Management last year.
Ms. Lee was a temporary worker herself when she came to Resource Management. She had been in sales and marketing with NCR, the computer company that at the time was owned by AT&T, and was thinking of going to school when she took a temporary job at the temp agency. She started as a recruiter.
"We don't use the term permanent employment anymore because we know that doesn't really exist," said Cynthia Cross, the president of Resource Management. She founded the company five years ago, joining forces with Elizabeth Parker, who was starting an executive temporary service.
At the time, the Seattle area was in a mild recession, primarily from jobs cuts at the Boeing Company, its largest employer. Many of those former Boeing workers had technical skill specific to making airplanes. All they needed, in general, was some tailoring to fit high-tech companies.
The company specializes in jobs that fall along the periphery of most high-tech jobs, positions that carry arcane names, popping up in seasonal fashion. "We call it tech light," Ms. Cross said.
There may be an enormous demand for such jobs one month, only to have them disappear entirely a few months later.
In the traditional hiring hall, a welder or longshoreman would go into a union center and be dispatched to a given job, confident that his skills could carry through any project. In the technical world, it is sometimes hard even to find a company and temporary worker who speak the same language.
"You live for that person who can go in and be an immediate producer, somebody who can accomplish something right away," Ms. Cross said.
Resource Management does not train people, but it recently added a computer room where prospective temps can brush up on the latest programs. On a recent day, the computer room was full, while in the soft-carpeted offices of Resource Management, a slow stream of people came to be sized up for jobs.
What high-technology temps need most is an understanding of basic computer language, which means learning something new almost every few months. But increasingly, Ms. Lee is looking for people who excel in an old-fashioned language.
"English majors," Ms. Lee said. "That's what we really need. Send me an English major."

The second, on Feb. 12, covered the work of artists and programmer's designing sites on the Internet's World Wide Web. The third, which ran on March 11, looked at the industry's supersalesmen, who have made product demonstrations into something between circus shows and performance art.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
A Transformation for Kennedy
After 20 years with almost no improvement, Kennedy International Airport is undergoing a profound transformation. In the next five years, $3 billion is to be spent to replace two aging terminals, rebuild airport roads and parking lots and build a rail line that will ease travel between Kennedy's terminals as well as connect the airport to Manhattan. In part, the plan is notable simply for its scale: $3 billion is triple what it cost to build the World Trade Center. But also remarkable is that the four projects are moving forward after years, or decades, of inaction. Why now? The money is available and the political will is there. [Page A1.]
 
Dispute Widens Over Renewal
City and state officials stepped up their acrimonious public war of words over a stalemate that threatens to destroy an ambitious urban renewal plan for Harlem and the South Bronx. And as the dispute escalated -- with officials from both sides questioning whether the other has the money to contribute and with officials publicly calling each other dishonest -- many in Harlem and the South Bronx who have been waiting for the funds for more than two years said they are prepared to go to court to force the city and state to end the squabble. [B1.]
 
Pataki's Move to the Middle
For much of last year, his first as Governor, George E. Pataki played the part one might expect from a candidate born of the New York Republican Party's resurgent conservative wing and the first Governor elected on the state Conservative Party line. How things can change in a year. For much of this spring, Mr. Pataki has been steering his administration on a moderate tack, doing and saying things that have confounded and angered his conservative allies even as they have surprised and delighted the consumer advocates, women's groups and environmentalists. Political memo. [B1.]
 
5 Injured in S.I. Melee
What started as a routine response by the police to a report of a stabbing quickly escalated to a disturbance that left eight people arrested, five people injured -- including four police officers -- and as many as 100 people marching on the 120th precinct on Staten Island. [B3.]
 
Rangel Stokes a Tempest
Amid citywide rallies to protest the planned layoffs of hundreds of workers at New York City public hospitals, another tempest surged to the fore: Representative Charles B. Rangel's steadfast use of the phrase "gang-raped" to describe what he believes the Giuliani administration and Republicans in general are doing to labor unions. [B3.]
 
14-Year-Old Is Fatally Shot
A 14-year-old boy was fatally shot outside an apartment building in the South Bronx, the police said. The youth was standing in a crowd of teen-agers when a fight erupted, the police said. Mr. Taylor was struck by gunshots, and the police said they did not believe the gunfire had come from within the crowd. [B3.]
 
Reveling in the Heat
In a few weeks, they will be grousing about days like this. But the oven blast of sizzling heat, the first real preview of summer for the New York region, was just fresh and exotic enough to have many New Yorkers rhapsodizing. "By the end of summer, I'll hate it," Nadeem Kayani, 19, acknowledged. But Mr. Kayani said that his memories of the unusually frosty and tenacious winter are still sharp, so he took the muggy clutch of weather as a welcome, if stultifying, sign of deliverance. "At this moment," he said, "it's pleasant." [B3.]
 
$60 Million in Art Donated
Thirteen works of 20th century art by masters like Picasso, Modigliani, Braque and Leger -- a collection experts believe to be worth $60 million to $80 million -- have been given to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Klaus G. and Amelia Perls. The works are from the couple's private collection. The two have been Manhattan art dealers for more than 60 years. The Arts. [C11.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
School Scandal Brings Disbelief
Since school officials in Fairfield, Conn., disclosed that achievement tests at a nationally praised elementary school had been tampered with, former F.B.I. agents have been hired to find the culprit, parents have accused the superintendent of changing the answers herself and the school's pupils have been taunted by children from other neighborhoods. In a community that is passionate about its children and its schools, the feelings unleashed by the disclosure have ranged from the ferocious to the heartbreaking. Parents are in disbelief that any adult at their beloved Stratfield School would change answers on test sheets, and they are in anguish over their children innocently taking on the burden of blame for something they do not understand and did not do. [B1.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Fairway Dreams in Newark
The barren neighborhoods of the inner city usually prize the rough competition on basketball courts or baseball diamonds as the best ticket out. But every spring a small band of students in Newark's high schools develop fairway dreams. Most are rank beginners, playing golf with a hodgepodge of clubs and no small amount of confusion about the rules. The Newark high schools play in different suburban leagues. They find the game in turns frustrating and so exhilarating that they swear they don't want to play anything else. [B1.]
 
REGION
 
Commencements Are Held
Commencement exercises were held at a number of universities and colleges in the region, including Adelphi University, the Southampton College of Long Island University, St. John's University, Vassar College and at the State University of New York at Binghamton and at Purchase. [B5.]

HEADLINE: A Day for Many Diplomas, And for One Famous Frog

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19

 BODY:
Adelphi University, which had a tumultuous year because of questions about the spending practices of its president, Peter Diamandopoulos, gave diplomas to 2,443 students yesterday, and the controversy over the president drew hardly a mention.
Dr. Diamandopoulos had planned to deliver an address, but with 80-degree temperatures roasting the audience during the outdoor ceremony, he decided to deliver it instead by mail -- a decision greeted with applause by students. 
 The university's trustees are facing an inquiry by the State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, who says they may have violated several state laws by financing "extraordinary personal spending."
Dr. Diamandopoulos, despite the university's growing financial problems, received $523,636 in salary and deferred bonuses and benefits in 1994, making him the second-highest paid university president in the United States.
The only speaker at the ceremony to refer to the controversy was Ernesta G. Procope, chairwoman of the board of trustees, who said, "On a personal note, I am especially proud of Adelphi's many accomplishments under the leadership of President Diamandopoulos, and with the support of an outstanding board."
Her comments produced a ripple of jeers from the otherwise festive crowd of graduates, families and friends who gathered here under a sunny and cloudless sky in a grassy field at the center of the campus.
In the text of his speech, Dr. Diamandopoulos avoided commenting directly on the controversy that has split the campus, describing Adelphi as "a strong, resilient university poised to move to its second century with a sharper philosophy."
Among those to receive honorary degrees were John Kapioltas, chairman of the board of the ITT Sheraton Corporation, and Conor Cruise O'Brien, the Irish author, who was the commencement speaker.

Southampton College
The world's most famous amphibian -- Kermit the Frog -- swam away from commencement exercises at the Southampton College of Long Island University yesterday with the first ever doctorate of amphibious letters, an honorary degree bestowed upon him for his contribution to raising environmental awareness, which is a major part of the college's curriculum.
Donning a custom-tailored cap and gown, the diminutive frog delivered the main address to the 245 undergraduate and graduate students -- most of whom supported his appearance by decorating their gowns with green stickers that read "Kermit '96" and adorning their caps with stuffed animals and Pez dispensers in Kermit's likeness.
The decision to confer the honorary doctorate, which attracted unprecedented media attention for such a small private college, was made by Robert F.X. Sillerman, the Chancellor of Southampton College, which is nationally recognized for its programs in marine and environmental sciences. "This school is known for its world-class programs in marine and environmental sciences," he said, "and when you think of the 'green print,' you think of Kermit the Frog."
While most of the students supported the choice, some were angry at having a puppet as their commencement speaker.
"I am officially unhappy," said Samantha Chie, a marine biology major. "I've been here laboring for five years and now we have a sock talking at our commencement. It's kind of upsetting."

St. John's University
He began his education at St. John's University in 1931, when Herbert Hoover was President. Yesterday, Salvatore DeGaetano finally received his Bachelor of Arts degree, some 65 years and 11 presidents later.
Mr. DeGaetano was among 600 students gathered at Alumni Hall at the university's campus in Jamaica, Queens, for the school's 121st commencement, an afternoon ceremony which stressed a return to idealism and pursuit of public service.
The audience at the indoor arena graduation was boisterous, showing an enthusiasm for the class of '96 usually reserved for the school's Red Storm basketball team.
Mary Ryan, a class of 1963 alumnus and assistant secretary for Consular Affairs at the Department of State, delivered the commencement address, contrasting the idealism of the early 60's with a cynicism toward government of the 1990's.
"I ask you what J.F.K. asked the youth of my day to do, to return something to the community which has protected and educated you," Ms. Ryan said.
She urged students to "reject the murderous din of materialism," adding, "There is more to life than the amount of money on your W-2 at the end of the year."
School officials pointed to the 14 graduating members of the President's Society as the students who best exemplified that spirit of public service. Donna Jo Koubek, a criminal justice major who will attend law school in the fall, described the society as the "highest honor" a St. John's student could achieve.
As for the 83-year-old Mr. DeGaetano, he plans to return to St. John's this fall to begin pursuing a master's in history.

Vassar College
Vassar College began its 132d commencement yesterday with a procession of 563 graduates accompanied by other students, who carried two 75-foot-long chains of daisies and laurel.
By tradition, Vassar does not award honorary degrees to distinguished elders. Instead, the three-hour ceremony, which was held on the college's Poughkeepsie, N.Y., campus, focused on the young and those who work with them.
The main speaker of the day was a 68-year-old. But he was Maurice Sendak, an illustrator and author who is well known for his children's books including "Where the Wild Things Are" and "In the Night Kitchen." Mr. Sendak, who said that he had never graduated from college or high school, used a metaphor borrowed from Herman Melville and urged the class of 1996 to be a "generation of deep-sea divers," who accomplish things and tell the truth.
After the opening procession, in which members of the class of 1998 carried the flower chains, Claire V. Johnston, a graduating senior from Berkeley, Calif., presented Vassar with a $4,618.06 gift from the class of 1996. It is to be used for the restoration of a campus fountain and for scholarships, career development and athletics.
In addition to Mr. Sendak, the other speakers included Vassar's president, Frances Daly Fergusson, and Michael D. Keenan, the senior class president.
Mr. Keenan remembered the first moment he saw Vassar. "It's so beautiful here," he said, "that I thought I hope I don't break anything. You have to understand, I come from Queens."

State University at Binghamton
The State University of New York at Binghamton, a campus navigating its way through new financial cuts at a time when the entire southern tier is already economically depressed, put its hopes for prosperity yesterday in 3,153 graduates, including a half-dozen women who put letters on their caps to spell "Will Work for Food."
The university president, Lois B. De Fleur, opened the commencement ceremony by acknowledging alumni from the school's first year, 1946. "We had 600 students who attended classes in unheated Quonset huts and carried their chairs from class to class," she said. "While our budget hasn't gotten that bad," she said, "we have faith it won't."
The keynote speaker, Clifton Wharton Jr., the Chancellor of the State University of New York from 1978 to 1987, told students he abandoned his "The Future is Yours" speech for one that criticized the belief that corporate-downsizing and cost-cutting techniques can be applied to public education.
"How about achieving the maximum efficiency for faculty by putting all students in a football field and having one faculty member talk through a loudspeaker at the 50-yard line?" he said.
Despite the serious messages, students remained playful. As Paula Kramer, president of the alumni association, lectured on the transition that graduates were about to make into the real world, the students tossed three beach balls around.

State University at Purchase
The State University of New York at Purchase has a tradition of inviting well-known people from the arts to speak at graduation: William Styron, the novelist, and Cynthia Gregory, the ballet dancer, are among those who have given addresses in the past. But this year's commencement featured someone who is an investment manager by profession: Richard Maass, whose speech received hearty applause.
Mr. Maass, 77, an art and rare manuscript collector, human-rights activist, college benefactor and president of the Purchase College Council, was applauded even before he began to speak, when the school's president, Bill Lacy, told the crowd that the original manuscript of a speech written by Abraham Lincoln that recently sold at Christie's for $497,500 had been donated to the school by Mr. Maass. The college, which sent it to the auction house, will receive the money.
The roars of approval escalated as Mr. Maass spoke. He said that the word patriotism had been "demeaned" by Presidents Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan and by "disaffected bullies, skinheads, Klansmen, Nazis and trigger-happy men and women who act in loose coalitions known as militias." He further said that the religious right has "perverted honestly held religious beliefs into the coin of hucksterism."
Jonathan Bernstein, who received a bachelor of arts degree in history, agreed. "People don't usually pay attention to these things but, Wow, everyone listened to this speech," he said.
Mr. Bernstein added an original touch to his cap and gown: a model airplane, circa World War II, perched on his mortarboard. . "I hope to go into aviation museum studies and aircraft restoration, not politics per se, but I'll always remember this man's words," he said.

HEADLINE: Worst Drought Since 30's Grips Plains

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HARDESTY, Okla., May 16

 BODY:
Since last October, an average of 2.32 inches of rain has fallen on the wheat fields and cattle ranches that dominate the landscape here in the Oklahoma Panhandle -- the second driest such period since the Oklahoma Climatological Survey started keeping records 101 years ago.
For 71-year-old Lewis Mayer, that means that his winter wheat crop, which normally would be waist-high and turning from green to gold with the approach of next month's harvest, is about to be plowed under and declared a total loss. 
 "There's just no rain at all, it's hotter than blazes, all the grass has thinned out," said Mr. Mayer, crumbling some soil into dust and pointing to wheat stalks that looked like ankle-high weeds at best. "I was a 10-year-old boy in 1935, and as near as I can remember it just looks similar. Very similar."
From Kansas south to Texas, one of the worst droughts on record has pushed thousands of farmers on the Great Plains to the edge of financial ruin and spurred panic selling of cattle in some areas.
Coming after two years of low rainfall and a number of other weather problems, the ferocity of this year's drought has slowly begun to evoke memories for some here of the Depression-era Dust Bowl.
The Oklahoma Agriculture Commissioner, Dennis Howard, predicted last week that 5,000 to 10,000 of the state's 70,000 farming families would go bankrupt this year because of the drought and record low cattle prices brought on by mass liquidation of some ranchers' herds. Mr. Howard said half the farm families in the state were in "critical financial shape," meaning they were in danger of failing to make mortgage or lease payments due this summer.
In Texas, where the $6 billion cattle industry is the largest of any state, 130 counties have applied for emergency Federal subsidies for ranchers to buy feed, after certifying that at least 40 percent of all pasture land is too arid for grazing. That is the highest number of applications ever in the state, according to the Federal Department of Agriculture.
The starkest image of the Dust Bowl -- huge clouds of fine soil blowing across the land, turning day into dusk and rendering crops suddenly worthless -- is unlikely to come to pass. That is because of government-mandated conservation measures that started at the end of the New Deal, including year-round, drought-resistant grasses that hold at least some soil in place, and tree barriers that reduce the force of the wind.
But in other ways the drought conditions are at least as bad. There is simply no rain to speak of, and the heat is withering. In parts of the Texas and Oklahoma panhandles, temperatures reached 105 degrees this week, the earliest that such temperatures have ever been recorded.
Many families, deep in debt for everything from farm equipment to the large tracts of land necessary for modern farming, are clearly struggling.
"There's no such thing as getting by on the milk check and what the hens can lay you," said 81-year-old Denzil Wilmoth of Beaver, Okla., who managed to make it through earlier droughts in much that way. "That's ancient history."
In Hardesty, where a granite highway marker at the edge of town proclaims the small community as the onetime "mecca of early cowboys in no man's land," Jerod Richards, 19, described conditions for his three-generation farm family this way: "It just seems like Mother Nature's against you."
Mr. Richards, his parents and his grandparents spent much of the last two weeks plowing under all 1,100 acres of wheat they had planted last fall, making the crop a total loss. If there is any prospect of rain coming, he said, the family may try to plant milo, a quick-growing crop primarily used as feed.
Some farmers have given up altogether. "It was a losing deal; I just sold off everything," said Tim Schroeder, 37, who recently let all of his dairy cows go for auction and says he does not know how he will make upcoming payments on his house and property.
"The prices on everything went up -- I couldn't afford to keep the cows fed," said Mr. Schroeder over pancakes and coffee at the Outpost Cafe here. He had just got off the midnight shift at his new job, working in a huge hog-processing plant in nearby Guymon.
A casual visitor to Hardesty might think the town was enjoying a spectacularly beautiful spring -- the other day the sky here was a sparkling blue, and the dry heat gave an almost Mediterranean cast to the air. While most of the farm land relies on rain, and thus is a parched brown, there are pockets of green where families can afford irrigation.
But nobody who lives around here finds much splendor in this particular spring.
"It's not beautiful when there's no wheat growing," said Wanda Flaherty, a waitress at the Outpost.
For the consumer, the drought has spurred a short-term boon, as a wave of selling has led to very low beef prices at the supermarket.
In some parts of Oklahoma and Texas the auctions have reached panic level: in Hallettsville, Tex., last month, ranchers inundated the weekly auction with cattle and the sale lasted from 10:30 one morning to 4:30 the next, with bidding per head typically lasting just 12 seconds or so.
But in the long run, the sell-off promises price increases for beef. Eighty percent of the cows being slaughtered in South Texas now are pregnant, according to the Coastal Plains Production Credit Association, meaning that next year's herd will be dramatically thinned.
The economics are as simple as they are devastating: the cost of feeding, watering, tagging and caring for a cow or a steer is more than what the animal can bring at market.
"There isn't a cow in South Texas that will bring enough money to buy a ton of feed," said Johnny Williams, the owner of Alice Feed Supply in Alice, Tex.
The widespread plowing under of wheat in Oklahoma and several neighboring states, even if offset somewhat by normal wheat production in other parts of the country, will probably spur small but noticeable increases in the price of bread, pasta and other products by this fall.
In parts of Oklahoma, the heart of wheat country, many farms that normally yield 55 bushels an acre are instead yielding 1 or 2, which does not make it economical to harvest.
Factoring in irrigated fields and other parts of the state that have had some rainfall, the Oklahoma Wheat Commission's most optimistic prediction is a total yield of 70 million to 80 million bushels, less than half the state's normal total.
The drought has, of course, had a much wider effect than its impact on farmers and ranchers. Cities across Texas have reported sharply lower rainfall -- San Antonio had 3.7 inches of rain from October through April, compared to a normal rate of 15.8 inches. The drought has forced several communities served by the Edwards Aquifer, the natural underground reservoir that provides water for 1.5 million people in central Texas, to impose watering restrictions of varying severity.
In the West Texas communities of San Angelo and Childress, mayors have signed official proclamations asking residents to pray for rain.
In Stratford, Tex., a highway sign proclaiming the city to be "Home of God, Grass and Grit" seems like a cruel joke in part: many of the lawns and farms there are scorched and brown.
And the drought has contributed to the recent wildfires in Arizona, New Mexico and Colorado.
One or two heavy rainfalls will not help much -- even if they do occur, which is not expected anytime soon. And while the drought so far has struck most heavily at wheat and cattle, it will affect other crops, including cotton and corn, if it continues.
"Clearly, what's happened is the establishment of a ridge, a pattern over much of the south-central United States," said Jay Grymes, operations manager of the Southern Regional Climate Center, a federally financed research service in Baton Rouge, La. "It is significantly inhibiting rainfall activity, even in conditions where we have all the ingredients for rain events. It is just not creating the kinds of rains that many of these places are needing."
For people here in the Oklahoma Panhandle, the weather has led to a certain kind of gallows humor. Two farmers passing each other in their pickup trucks on a dusty road in Guymon the other day stopped to exchange pleasantries. "Sure is a wet one today," one said. All around them, as far as the eye could see, it was as dry as a bone.
And Wesley James, a farmer and rancher in Hardesty, said: "If the weather doesn't change any time soon, we could be up the creek without a paddle. Of course, there'd be no water, either."
But no matter what happens, many farmers here say they do not plan to join any kind of "Grapes of Wrath" exodus.
"Oh, I'm here to stay," said Mr. Mayer, whose family has been in the area since 1883. "I'll be here when this one's over. I may be broke, but I'll still be here."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International A3-9
 
INDIA'S HINDU NATIONALISTS
The formation of India's first Hindu nationalist government has raised the profile of a right-wing group that has long existed in the shadows of politics and been derided by critics left and center. A1
