HEADLINE: Fight Widens On Aid Zone For New York

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
A top Federal housing official called on New York State yesterday to back down in an increasingly bitter feud with New York City officials that he said could kill a $300 million plan to revitalize Harlem and parts of the South Bronx.
The official, Andrew M. Cuomo, an assistant secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said that state officials were making an "unreasonable request" in asking the city to agree to rules that would essentially give the state the final word in disputes over how the money -- $100 million each from the Federal, state and city governments -- would be spent. 
 "After all we've been through," Mr. Cuomo said, "the state should know that the city is not willing to cede control in this way," And he added, speaking of state officials, "One must question if they are genuine in their desire to consummate the transactions."
But state officials countered that the agreement cementing the deals of the plan -- which Mr. Cuomo and state and city officials signed -- requires the state to retain ultimate control. They accused the Federal Government of trying needlessly to stall the plan: a so-called Empowerment Zone that would spur development in the economically depressed neighborhoods.
"I can't believe Andrew Cuomo didn't read the document that he signed with great fanfare back in January," said Caroline Quartararo of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's development agency. "But it is typical of Cuomo and the Clinton Administration to promise, promise, promise, and then find excuses not to deliver jobs and opportunity to those who need it most."
The admonition from Mr. Cuomo, who has threatened to take away the Federal Government's $100 million contribution unless the officials settle the dispute, came on a day when the two sides seemed to move even further apart, with city and state officials aggressively arguing their cases and accusing each other of acting in bad faith.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his top financial adviser accused state officials of using the dispute, which centers on a seemingly minor set of rules used to govern the program's board of directors, to hold up the money. They suggested that this was because state officials had little real intention of ever contributing their one-third share.
While state officials have used words like "willing, maybe, promise, set aside," Mr. Giuliani said, he questioned their actual commitment to providing money for the poor neighborhoods. "So far, I should tell you, New York City is the only government group to put any money into the Empowerment Zone," he said. "The state promised, took it away, promised again, took it away and has promised it again. It hasn't come up with any money yet."
For their part, state officials, including the official in charge of state economic development, Charles A. Gargano, said that the city's adamant insistence on the rule changes and their questions about the state's motives were a smokescreen. The real reason for the delay, they charged, is that the city wants to push the program's starting date past the current fiscal year so that it will not have to carry its contribution on this year's already tight municipal budget.
As the dispute escalated, many residents of Harlem and the South Bronx, who have been waiting for the funds for more than two years, said they were prepared to go to court to force the city and state to end the squabble.
The Empowerment Zone is one of six around the country in which the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development agreed to provide $100 million to impoverished urban neighborhoods for grants and loans to businesses, to create job training programs and to lure companies into those neighborhoods.
But while the city and the state agreed to match the Federal contribution equally and signed the agreement in January on the broad outlines of how the money would be used, long-simmering tensions between Mr. Gargano and the city's top financial adviser, Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, surfaced just as the program was to begin.
Ms. Reiter -- who will be the first chairwoman of the board that runs the program under a system in which state and city chairmanship will alternate -- said the bylaws would make it easy for state officials to oust Mr. Giuliani's appointees if there were a dispute between the two sides over which projects should get money. Until Mr. Gargano agrees to change those rules, she said, she will not call a meeting of the board, a requirement before the first dollar can be spent.
"He wants to intimidate the city into moving this thing forward, and we will not be intimidated," Ms. Reiter said.
State officials said yesterday that they had conceded on several other issues in which the city sought more control, but were refusing to give in on changing the rules because the state is required by law to have ultimate control of city-and-state partnerships like this one, which is a legal subsidiary of a state agency.
"They are asking for something that is impossible to give them," said Randy Daniels, a senior vice president of the Empire State Development Corporation, which promotes the state's economic development plans. "To give the city this power to control a state subsidiary is subject to legal challenge."
But Ms. Reiter said yesterday that to go ahead with the program in its present form would be to sign over $100 million of the city's money to the state with no way to control it, an action unacceptable to the Giuliani administration at a time of sharp disagreements between the city and state over budget issues.
"They want to control every project in the zone, and they'll hold everybody hostage to the projects they want to do," Ms. Reiter said. "The city cannot agree to let that happen."
She said she was prepared to hold up the program indefinitely unless the state found a way to grant the city an equal measure of control.
The details of the battle center on rules spelling out how directors of the zone's board can be removed for cause. Under the state's plan, a director could be ousted by a simple majority vote. Because the state is the majority shareholder in the program, however, the votes of Governor George E. Pataki's appointees would have more weight. The city wants a requirement of a two-thirds majority vote to dismiss a board member, which would mean that an ouster could be accomplished only with the agreement of the city and the state's representatives.
Mr. Gargano argued yesterday that all of the state's economic development subsidiaries were set up so that the state had the final word.
Mr. Daniels, who helped negotiate the agreement on the project between the city and the state, claims that the dispute is just one of a number of instances recently in which the city has tried to sway the balance of power to its side in financial partnerships between the city and state, a charge the city denies.
Mr. Cuomo said yesterday that he would call for a meeting this week between city and state officials, and he held out hope that Mr. Gargano could be persuaded to change his mind.
"I don't believe that the State of New York will renege on its commitment to the Federal Government," he said. "There are ways to get around all of this if they really want to get around it."
City officials said yesterday that the current dispute had its roots in the state's refusal to move forward on the Hudson River Park Conservancy, the agency seeking to create a park system along 4.5 miles of Manhattan's Hudson River shoreline. The plan was conceived during Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's administration and since the Pataki administration took over, it has been stalled because of disputes between Mr. Gargano and Ms. Reiter over its makeup.
"We can't get a board appointed," Ms. Reiter said. "We can't even call a meeting there because they have control."
She added that like the conservancy, the empowerment zone was negotiated under the Cuomo administration and that at that time, state and city officials agreed that they would share power equally in dispensing money.
But after the Giuliani administration and state officials signed a memorandum of understanding cementing the details of the deal -- an agreement reached only after more than a year of tense negotiation -- the state presented the city with bylaws that greatly strengthened the state's position on the board.
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, the pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, which is planning a job training and counseling center that would be part of the empowerment zone, joined Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Democrat of Harlem, yesterday in saying that they were both willing to take the city and the state to court to try to force them to end the standoff and produce the much-needed money.
"While they argue over petty issues, people who need better education, better housing and better employment opportunities are left out in the cold," Mr. Butts said.

HEADLINE: Taiwan President Says He Would Go to Beijing for Talks

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, May 20

 BODY:
To the cheers of some 50,000 flag-waving guests, Taiwan's first democratically elected President, Lee Teng-hui, declared in his inaugural address today that he was willing to travel to Beijing to talk with China's leaders.
"In the future, at the call of my country and with the support of my people, I would like to embark upon a journey of peace to mainland China, taking with me the consensus and will of 21.3 million people," said Mr. Lee, an American-educated agricultural economist. 
 "I am also ready to meet with the top leadership of the Chinese Communists for a direct exchange of views in order to open up a new era of communication and cooperation," he promised. But, he warned, "we will never negotiate under threat of attack."
Regarded as a rebel province by Beijing, Taiwan has moved dramatically away from dictatorship and political repression toward the first fully democratic Chinese-speaking nation in five millenniums of Chinese history.
Taiwan has blossomed into one of Asia's economic dynamos and one of the world's dominant trading nations. It is a country with one of the largest foreign cash reserves, a leader in investment throughout Asia and one of the world's most technologically advanced societies.
For several years, Mr. Lee has traveled abroad, mainly throughout Asia, pushing Taiwan's case for international recognition to regional leaders. Those travels have irritated Beijing considerably, and his visit to the United States last June enraged China. It denounced Mr. Lee, saying he was trying to assert Taiwan's independence, something Mr. Lee has repeatedly denied.
In March, against a barrage of threats from Beijing and a round of intimidating war games and missile tests, Taiwan's voters in a landslide chose the 73-year-old Mr. Lee as their first directly elected President.
With that vote, Taiwan shed the last vestiges of the authoritarianism that traced its roots to the government that Chiang Kai-shek established here after fleeing Mao Zedong's victorious Communist armies in 1949. Previously, presidents were chosen by the Legislature.
As jets trailing streams of smoke pirouetted in the sun-splashed sky and the national symphony orchestra played, Mr. Lee and his Vice President, Lien Chan, arrived in the huge Taoyuan stadium. Earlier this morning, Mr. Lee and Mr. Lien, standing before a portrait of Sun Yat-sen, the first President of the Republic of China, took the oath of office in a short ceremony in the presidential palace.
In his inaugural address, Mr. Lee etched in unmistakable terms the chasm that exists between Taiwan and China, a chasm that has widened even further with Taiwan's embrace of democracy and one that owes as much to Western ideas and values as it does to different notions of a Chinese ethos.
And in a challenge to Beijing's claim to speak for all that is Chinese, Mr. Lee declared that Taiwan, and not China, would chart the course for Chinese-speaking people in Asia.
"Taiwan has been able in recent decades to preserve traditional culture on the one hand and to come into wide contact with Western democracy and science and modern business culture on the other," he said. "Equipped with a much higher level of education and development than in other parts of China, Taiwan is set gradually to exercise its leadership role in cultural development and take upon itself the responsibility for nurturing a new Chinese culture."
And although both Hong Kong, in 1997, and the Portuguese colony of Macao, in 1999, will revert to Chinese sovereignty, Mr. Lee's speech insisted that Taiwan retained a legitimate interest in the fate of the two territories. Despite Beijing's adamant stance that it alone is the rightful ruler of those territories, Mr. Lee said, in terms that are certain to provoke Beijing's wrath, that "the welfare of the Chinese in Hong Kong and Macao has always been of great concern to us."
"We are ready to lend them a helping hand to maintain democracy, freedom and prosperity in this area," he said.
As momentous as Mr. Lee's ascent to the presidency via the ballot box is regarded here, his inauguration took place largely in an international vacuum. Only a scattering of small, developing countries, mainly from Africa and Latin America, formally recognize the Taiwan Government. No Western or Eastern democracy sent official representatives here.
Still, Taiwan was determined that its legitimacy, and that of its democracy, should be on parade. The Government-controlled television showed videotape of American senators and representatives congratulating Mr. Lee. They were led by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, who said he expected to welcome Mr. Lee to Washington during his presidency. No letter from President Clinton was mentioned in Taiwanese news reports.
A television camera lingered over letters to Mr. Lee from members of Congress, and long shots of the unofficial American delegation, led by Vernon Jordan, were broadcast on the evening news. Throughout the day Sunday, heads of state from several small countries were received by Mr. Lee, who fastidiously reviewed honor guards with each.
In recent weeks, China has been relatively subdued in its statements about Taiwan, evidently waiting to see what Mr. Lee would say in his inaugural address. Again and again, Beijing has said it would use military force to prevent any moves by Taiwan toward independence. And while Mr. Lee uttered the token concession that he would not push for independence, he did so in words that were uncompromising about Taiwan's separate identity.
"The Republic of China has always been a sovereign state," he said. "Disputes across the Straits center around system and life style; they have nothing to do with ethnic or cultural identity.
"The Chinese who were regarded as dictatorial, feudalistic, penurious and backward by Western countries one century ago have by now created in the Taiwan area a new land of democracy, wealth and progress. We believe that whatever is achieved by the Chinese in Taiwan can also be achieved by the Chinese in mainland China."
Despite his assertions about Taiwan's Chineseness, in the last decade there has been a resurgence of ethnic pride among the island's native Taiwanese. Mainland-born Chinese now make up only about 10 percent of the island's population, and the gap with the mainland -- politically, economically and culturally -- has steadily widened.
Indeed, Mr. Lee's political success is in no small measure due to his own Taiwanese ethnicity. Appointed to the Cabinet in 1972 by Chiang Kai-shek's son, Chiang Ching-kuo, because of his heritage, Mr. Lee climbed steadily through the political maze of the governing Kuomintang Party, forming alliances and spreading his influence. He became President when Chiang Ching-kuo died in 1988. His election to the post by the party-dominated Legislature in 1990, when Mr. Chiang's term expired, marked the transition to local rule from the leadership of the Chinese who fled to Taiwan in 1949.
Today, in his address, Mr. Lee uttered formulaic blandishments toward Beijing, but his determination to preserve Taiwan's way of life echoed clearly. "We now stand on the apex of democratic reform," he said, "and will remain there resolutely. We have proved eloquently that the Chinese are capable of practicing democracy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lee Teng-hui, Taiwan's first elected President, called for "a new era of communication and cooperation" with the Chinese Communists. He took the oath of office today in the presidential palace. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: For Journalism Graduates, Opportunities in New Media

BYLINE: By GIANNA JACOBSON 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, Mo.

 BODY:
When Addie Butt enrolled in the journalism school at the University of Missouri here two years ago, her goal was to become a newspaper sportswriter. But one of the school's newest courses -- new media, an intensive study of on-line publications -- changed her plans.
Within days of graduation, Ms. Butt will report for a $500-a-week job at Fastball, an on-line publication about major league baseball owned by Cox Communications in Atlanta, a unit of Cox Enterprises. 
 "I developed an interest in on-line journalism and went with it," said Ms. Butt, a 20-year-old from Pasadena, Calif. "That's where the majority of jobs are."
And that is where many of this year's journalism graduates are heading. Electronic reporting, especially on the Internet, is creating a boom in the job market for journalism graduates around the country.
"On-line publications are generating more jobs at higher salaries than we have seen in a long time," said Michael Hoeferlin, placement director at Missouri's journalism school.
For print and broadcast reporters, the job market around the country also seems strong this year, journalism faculty members and career advisers say, especially for students with computer skills. Newspapers in the Midwest are hiring copy editors and designers, while demand for reporters is greatest in the South and Southeast, the advisers say.
At Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, "things are pretty healthy in the entry-level job market for journalism, thanks to on-line publications and the network news magazines," said Melanie Hough, the placement director. "Graduates who want to stay in big cities are finding jobs on line and in broadcast. Those who want traditional reporting jobs have to be more open to the whole country, but the jobs are there."
More than 36,000 students will receive bachelor's and master's degrees in journalism from 430 colleges and universities this month, according to Lee Becker, an Ohio State University professor. Professor Becker surveys journalism graduates annually for the Dow Jones Newspaper Fund, a foundation that supports programs to train student journalists. Three-quarters of the graduates will seek jobs in print, radio, television and Internet journalism, he said, while the rest will look for work in advertising, public relations or other fields, or continue their schooling.
In 1994, the last year for which information from the Newspaper Fund survey is available, the median salary for journalism graduates was $20,000. Those working at daily newspapers and in public relations fared best, with salaries averaging around $21,000. Journalism school graduates working at weekly newspapers or in broadcasting earned about $15,000, those in advertising an average of $20,000.
At on-line publications, entry-level salaries approach $30,000 a year.
"It used to be that recruiters asked students for their clips, but now they ask to see Web pages," said Ann Brill, a teacher of the new-media course at Missouri. "There is a window of opportunity for new people coming into the news business to get hired in on-line ventures. The people already in the news organizations don't have the skills or inclination for these jobs."
At the University of Southern California, in Los Angeles, students can get course credit for working on Times Link, an electronic version of The Los Angeles Times. "The on-line experience seems to be crucial in getting jobs," said Ester Ramirez, director of career advisement at the journalism school there. "It is not the traditional job market. The on-line opportunities have created a new area."
In the Midwest, Mr. Hoeferlin at Missouri and John Kupetz, placement director at the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., report a surge in jobs for copy editors and page designers at medium-sized newspapers.
Last year, 5 percent of Northwestern's journalism graduates took jobs with on-line publications or services, and Mr. Kupetz said he expected that number to be "somewhat higher" this year.
While Ms. Butt sought a job with an on-line publication, other Missouri graduates said that their paths to the Internet were less focused.
"Everyone starts out wanting a reporting job in the major leagues, but you end up having to redefine what is a journalism career," said Beth Hardison, a 21-year-old senior from Bloomington, Minn. Ms. Hardison will spend her summer at a postgraduate internship at Advanstar Communications, a trade-publication company in Cleveland, before starting a full-time job at Arizona Outdoorsman, a new on-line publication in Phoenix. The job will pay $20,000 a year.
"It's a job that meets all the requirements of what I wanted," Ms. Hardison said. "Whatever it is, I can build from there."
If the on-line "zines" and broadcasters are keeping journalism graduates in the cities, small- and medium-size newspapers are luring graduates to reporting jobs in the South and Southeast.
In January, as Judd Slivka began his final semester at Missouri, he sent out 50 letters and resumes before he landed a $400-a-week reporting job at The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, in Little Rock.
"I had the job I wanted by the end of February, and that was a very good feeling," said Mr. Slivka, 21, of Livingston, N.J.
Jessica Thompson never wanted a newspaper job when she enrolled at Missouri. Her internship at Advanstar helped draw a $22,500-a-year job writing newsletters and brochures for the American Association of Orthodontists in St. Louis.
"I put my job search on the back burner for a while, then I just got lucky," said Ms. Thompson, who is from Milton, Wis. "I can do computer-assisted reporting and desktop publishing, and the fact that I knew my way around a computer was definitely part of getting hired."
Matt Hebberd is one graduate who has not yet found a spot, after passing up an internship to attend summer school each year so he could earn two degrees, in journalism and European history, in four years.
One newspaper editor in the South has told Mr. Hebberd that he may be hired when a job opens up. Until then, Mr. Hebberd plans to return to his hometown of Guilford, Conn., where he will work as a public relations intern.
"I'm trying to sell myself on good reporting and writing skills," he said. "If that makes me less likable, it's probably not the right job."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 10, 1996, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on May 20 about the job prospects of recent college graduates with journalism degrees misattributed an estimate of where the graduates are seeking work. The statement that three-quarters of journalism graduates will seek jobs in print, radio, television and Internet journalism was based on interviews with educators, placement directors and professionals around the country. It was not a finding of a survey of graduates by Professor Lee Becker of Ohio State University.

"You end up having to redefine what is a journalism career," she said. (Photos by Robert Hood for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Last Laugh

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
It is Election Day. Millions of Americans who would not have voted for Robert Dole are so moved by his decision to quit the Senate that they decide he is their man after all -- enough to make him the President of the United States.
The list of insults to the American voter's intelligence is so large that it is hard for us to notice each new one. But the idea shouted around Washington by so many Republican writers, politicians and analysts that Mr. Dole's decision was so stirring that by itself it can have a critical impact on the election leaps over mere insult to assumption of idiocy. 
 The decision was not the Dole crossroads that can influence Americans through Election Day. It was a common-sensical move, in acceptable self-interest. It gave Mr. Dole more time to campaign. Time for campaigning, and for change, if he chooses to use it. It distanced him from the various gridlocks and dead ends created for the G.O.P. majorities by a shrewd President Clinton and their own ideological blinders.
The true crossroads lies ahead. Will Mr. Dole decide to continue to sweat -- and lose votes -- in the political straitjacket of the Republican ideologues? Or will he take the advice of Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York to break free and present himself as decidedly conservative but decidedly wise enough to see that the American people are not given to electing ideologues?
Maybe he needs encouragement from fancier-type Republicans than Mr. D'Amato. If Republicans like Bill Weld of Massachusetts, say, the kind so admired by liberal G.O.P. money-raisers, gave Mr. Dole the same advice, they would be loaded down with receptions. But, as a particularly wise commentator wrote recently, Senator D'Amato could pull some people out of burning buildings and they would still sneer at him.
After their victory in 1994, Republicans made the classic mistake of believing that it meant what they wanted it to mean -- a wide social and economic revolution. All of a sudden, the first American Revolution wasn't good enough for them. The problem that Mr. Dole inherited was they shot off their revolutionary mouths after the election without finding out whether the American people wanted any such thing.
Republican rhetoric was a lot less threatening to many people before the election than after. Now, conservative revolutionaries facing another election say they did not really mean to give the impression they were threatening old people, poor people, minority people, school-lunching people, people who wanted a cleaner environment, those kinds of people.
"People wanted change," said Mr. D'Amato to a Republican meeting. "But they did not want a so-called counterrevolution that threatened our very foundations. That threatened seniors, that would appear to say we're in favor of dirty water. Are we in favor of dirty water here?"
The soldiers of the revolution say that their Republican critics, and Democrats, are not being honorable Boy Scouts to say such things.
Maybe; to our eyes spring tears, at the unfairness. But the "revolutionaries" made plain that they thought the real enemy was government, somehow missing the point that Americans are against government only when it annoys them and absolutely adore government when it profits them, which is most of the time.
Like Mr. D'Amato I think Mr. Dole is sophisticated enough to grasp the point and hope he will acknowledge it in his rhetoric and proposals. If he does, G.O.P. ideologues will regard that as treason to Mother Revolution.
Mr. Dole will have to pay one price for leaving the Senate. From now on the country will be entitled to consider all his decisions as his alone -- no laying off any on Congressional collegiality. That goes particularly for what he does about denouncing Patrick Buchanan, for "bashing women and belittling them and African-Americans and Jews and gays," as Mr. D'Amato puts it in his frightfully indelicate manner.
So the real crossroads approaches. If Mr. Dole goes down the ideological road, down is where he will go on Election Day. But if he breaks out and becomes entirely his own Republican, next January he might be singing that song played with such joyous triumph at Bill Clinton's inaugural dinners: "Who's Got the Last Laugh Now?"

HEADLINE: Japan's U.S. Trade Surplus Plunged 56% Last Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 20

 BODY:
Japan's merchandise trade surplus with the United States recorded its steepest drop in 17 years in April, mainly because of rising technology imports from Intel, I.B.M. and other producers.
The politically volatile surplus also shrank because American- bound exports from Japan slowed sharply, as companies like Toyota and Sony continued to shift production abroad, including to plants in the United States. 
 The trade surplus decreased 56 percent from that in April 1995, to 172.09 billion yen, or about $1.6 billion, the 14th straight decline, the Japanese Finance Ministry said today. Japan's global surplus contracted at an even faster pace, by 65.5 percent, to about $3 billion.
"It's very surprising, given the strong growth in the U.S. and Asia," said Ronald Bevacqua, an economist at Merrill Lynch here. "It suggests that there has been a structural shift to production bases offshore."
Thus, while Japanese brand-name products are still reaching foreign markets, they are increasingly being made in Malaysia, China or the United States.
For many of Japan's exporters, whose overseas earnings have been adversely affected by a strong yen, producing at home is not profitable.
Toshiba, for instance, no longer exports any television sets, video decks or personal computers from Japan. All models sold overseas are made overseas. Sony, which already makes 47 percent of its products overseas, plans to increase that to 50 percent over the next three years.
The rapid decline in the Japanese trade surplus with the United States is expected to bring it well below last year's level. For the first four months of 1996, it is down 37 percent from the comparable period in 1995.
Trade experts say that most of the reason the surplus has been reduced lies in the strength of the yen. Recent leveling against the dollar notwithstanding, the Japanese currency has appreciated about 60 percent against the dollar since 1985. One result of that appreciation is that Japan's overseas production probably rose to 10 percent last year, up from 8.6 percent in 1994, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said.
The trade report also showed significant declines in Japan's surpluses with Asia and Europe. The surplus with European Union nations contracted 52 percent, while the surplus with Asia fell 33 percent.
American manufacturers have cashed in. Technology companies, led by Apple Computer and IBM Japan, sold 22 percent more personal computers last year than in 1994, according to IDC Japan, a market research firm.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Drop in Japan's Trade Surplus Helps Dollar Against the Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar firmed against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by news of a surprisingly large decline in Japan's trade surplus in April.
The politically sensitive trade surplus with the United States plunged by more than half to $1.60 billion in April from $3.62 billion a year earlier. It was the largest percentage drop since 1979. The surplus narrowed as the volume of imports to Japan surged 30.9 percent while exports grew 5.1 percent. 
 "Japan has had a big surplus for a long time and the fact that it's getting smaller is good for the dollar relative to the yen," said Robert McGee, chief economist at Tokai Bank Ltd. in New York.
During the session, the dollar climbed as high as 107.40 yen, but a bout of profit taking pushed it down from its peak.
It settled in New York late yesterday at 107.08 yen, up from 106.77 yen on Friday. The dollar traded at 1.5343 marks, up from 1.5333. The British pound slipped to $1.5135 from $1.5150.
Gains were also limited by a reluctance to push up the dollar in advance of a meeting today of the Federal Reserve's rate-setting committee.
Foreign-exchange traders are also waiting to see a report showing how much Germany's money supply increased in April. The report, which could be released as early as today, is closely watched because it can influence the direction of German key interest rates.
"People are really apt to sit on their hands today until they see" the German money-supply data and the results of the Federal Reserve meeting, said Charles Fago, a trader at Gulf International Bank BSC.
With the dollar trading in a fairly narrow range against the mark and the yen yesterday, dealers switched their focus to currencies including the Australian, Canadian and New Zealand dollars as prices fell for other commodities closely associated with these countries. For example, some copper prices plunged to the lowest point since April 1994.
Some investors sold these commodity-based currencies fearing that the currencies could be hurt because their countries' exports would be worth less, said Brian Garvey, a currency strategist at IDEA Inc.
The Canadian dollar fell to 72.88 United States cents yesterday from 73.05 cents, and the Australian dollar fell to 79.71 United States cents from 80.60 cents.

HEADLINE: G.M. Wants China's Trade To Be Favored Permanently

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 20

 BODY:
The chairman of the General Motors Corporation declared today that the best growth opportunities for the American automobile industry lay in Asia, and he called for the United States to extend full trading privileges to China permanently.
The strongly worded remarks by John F. Smith Jr., who is also G.M.'s chief executive and president, were a sign of how strongly many American business executives feel about the need for access to the Chinese market. Executives in manufacturing industries, in particular, have led the lobbying for China's most-favored-nation trading status with the United States. 
 While Mr. Smith welcomed President Clinton's one-year renewal today of that preferred trade status, he contended that the long-term stability of American investments in China depended on ending the annual debate over trade relations and making China's current status permanent.
"Most-favored-nation status is the basis for a stable, credible economic policy toward China," said Mr. Smith, who as G.M.'s top executive heads the United States' largest company.
But the odds of his getting his wish appear slim. Human rights advocates and hard-liners worried about Chinese weapons exports have insisted that the annual reviews are necessary to put pressure on China to change its ways. Clinton Administration officials refuse even to publicly discuss the possibility of a permanent renewal.
Mr. Smith contended that American companies would have more influence to improve conditions in China if they had stable business relationships there.
"It is no secret that the days of substantial growth in the U.S. automotive market are over -- this is a mature market, so the growth must come from outside North America," notably in Asia, Mr. Smith said.
He acknowledged that American car producers had failed to recognize the growth potential of Southeast Asia in the 1980's, and he argued that China's auto industry was still so much in its infancy that American auto makers could catch up there.
"China, however, is the great equalizer of missed opportunities," he said. "China is the ideal cornerstone for growth in Asia."
Mr. Smith had little to say about the Clinton Administration's threatened sanctions to force China to begin respecting American copyrights and patents. The two nations need to sit down and resolve their differences, he said.
G.M. has started two joint ventures with China's biggest auto makers, although neither project has yet begun producing vehicles. A planned factory in Shanghai will produce midsize Buicks, probably similar to the Buick Century, while another factory in Shenyang, in northeastern China, is to turn out light trucks.
The Chrysler Corporation is building Jeeps in Beijing, while the Ford Motor Company plans to make small commercial-delivery vehicles in China. G.M. and Ford are in talks to sell each other many auto parts in Asia so as to reduce the expense of setting up separate parts-production operations, the trade publication Automotive News reported today and both companies confirmed.
Mr. Smith, who is 58, also dismissed talk today that he might take early retirement at 62. "I have no plans to retire," he said as he left the Cobo Center here after a speech to the Economics Club of Detroit. "It's a phenomenal job."
But Mr. Smith never ruled out the possibility of early retirement. The growing visibility of Harry Pearce, the 53-year-old vice chairman and heir-apparent to Mr. Smith, has spurred rumors that Mr. Smith might step down several years from now.
Mr. Pearce played the leading role when a 17-day strike by the United Automobile Workers union at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, virtually shut down G.M.'s North American operations. Mr. Pearce also made the announcement last Thursday that G.M. would buy a Detroit landmark, the Renaissance Center, and move its headquarters there.
Mr. Smith said that a previously scheduled business meeting prevented him from attending the announcement on Thursday.
He also said that G.M. would like to be the the United Automobile Workers' primary target during negotiations late this summer to renew the Big Three auto makers' three-year labor contract. While the primary-target company bears the greatest risk of a strike, the first management to negotiate can also work out a contract that negatively affects its rivals.
And he announced that G.M. was in the final stages of deciding whether to locate a new assembly plant in Thailand or the Philippines. Thailand, where the auto market has doubled since 1991, has been the favorite, but the Philippines has tried in recent months to woo G.M. with various incentives.

HEADLINE: Move to the Web Is in the Works For Compuserve

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Deciding to flow with the relentless tide of the Internet rather than fight it, Compuserve Inc. is expected to announce today that it is rebuilding its entire on-line service on the standards of the World Wide Web, people briefed by the company said yesterday.
Compuserve's decision to embrace the open standards of the Web follows similar moves by the Prodigy Services Company, the Microsoft Network and AT&T's Interchange Online Network, all of which started as closed, proprietary services. But Compuserve, the world's second-largest consumer on-line service, with more than four million subscribers worldwide, is by far the largest network to acknowledge that it cannot compete against the rapidly growing Web. 
 "This leaves America Online as the last bastion of the proprietary world," said Gregory Wester, research director for the Yankee Group of Boston. "But even A.O.L. will back away from its proprietary software at some point. It's just a matter of time."
American Online Inc., the No. 1 service, in the past expressed confidence that its proprietary model would continue to be attractive. At the same time, the company has become one of the largest Internet service providers, offering its six million customers access to the World Wide Web.
"Over time, all on-line services will become Internet services," said Mary Modahl, a senior analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "We expect A.O.L. to be last because they have the strongest position in the flood, and they'll hold out longer."
Compuserve, a unit of H & R Block, was the first on-line service to use the proprietary software model, which requires subscribers to use special software and network access points provided by the service. It also requires that information providers use custom software tools to prepare information to be displayed on the network.
According to people briefed by Compuserve in advance of today's announcement, Compuserve has begun rewriting its existing services in the hypertext markup language, H.T.M.L., the industry standard of the World Wide Web.
Allen Weiner, an analyst with Dataquest in San Jose, Calif., said the H.T.M.L. model was attractive to information publishers because it allowed them potentially to reach millions of customers without having to write a different version of the same material for each on-line service.
"In the past, content developers were forced to decide whether to develop for the Compuserve standard, for example, or for the World Wide Web standard, and now there's just one," Mr. Weiner said.
The Web is also appealing to subscribers because it offers more advanced features than any proprietary on-line service can provide. Hundreds of companies worldwide are developing such Web-based features as audio, video, interactive chat sessions, multiplayer games and secure electronic commerce.
Compuserve will continue to support existing versions of the DOS, Windows and Macintosh software used to gain access to the Compuserve Information Service and Wow on-line businesses, the people briefed by the company said. But beginning this summer, the company will distribute new software that more fully integrates access to the World Wide Web.
Compuserve declined to comment on its plans.

HEADLINE: Major Indicators at Highs as Stocks Surge

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average surged yesterday, closing at more than 5,700 points for the first time, and the Nasdaq composite index set another record as Wall Street bet the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates steady at a policy-setting meeting today.
The Dow index ended up 61.32 points at a record 5,748.82, eclipsing the old closing high of 5,689.74 set on April 3 and adding to last week's gain of 169 points -- its biggest weekly point gain so far this year. 
 The Nasdaq index closed up 6.23 points at a new high of 1,248.11 to set its 27th high close of this year. Broader market indexes including the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set records.
The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee is to meet today to consider monetary policy against the background of moderate economic growth and subdued inflation.
"The conclusion is the Fed will not do anything with rates and that allows the market to breathe a huge sigh of relief," said Philip Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management.
Since lowering interest rates in January for the third time in seven months, the Fed has kept rates steady.
The strength of the 30-stock Dow index was aided by gains in oil companies stocks following news that after months of negotiations, Iraq had agreed to a United Nations deal that would allow Iraq to make limited oil sales. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, June crude oil ended up $1.84 at $22.48 a barrel, after initially falling to a two-month low at $19.85 on the United Nations-Iraq agreement.
"The oil market was so short prior to this announcement, however, it became a sell-the-rumor, buy-the-fact event," said Rita Beale, an analyst at Fimat.
Oil-company components of the Dow industrials helped move the index higher. Chevron shares rose 2 1/2, to 62; those of Texaco were up 3 1/8, to 86 7/8, and those of Exxon added 2 1/2, to 87 1/4.
Meanwhile, the shares of base metals producers slumped as rising supplies drove copper futures prices to their lowest level since April 1994. On New York's Commodity Exchange, July copper closed 4.40 cents down at 111.20 cents a pound. Alcoa shares fell 1 7/8, to 63 1/4; Reynolds Metals was off 1 1/2 a share, to 53 7/8; Alumax was off 1 3/8, to 33, and Phelps Dodge lost 1 3/8, to 70 1/2.
American depository receipts for shares in Nokia, the Finnish telecommunications company, surged 3, to 39 3/8, and shares of Motorola added 1 1/4, to 65 3/4, after CS First Boston named Nokia its featured stock of the week and Smith Barney raised its ratings for both companies.
General Electric shares rose 3 1/8, to 84 3/8, on news that GE Capital Services, the company's financial unit, had agreed to acquire Ameridata Technologies for $16 a share, or $490 million. Ameridata shares rose 3/8, to 15 3/4.
Shares of Cycare Systems, a health care information processor, rose 3 1/8, to 50 3/8, and those of HBO & Company jumped 5 1/4, to 128 3/4, after HBO agreed to acquire Cycare in a stock deal.
Valujet shed 1 7/8 a share, to 11 1/4, after the airline said late Friday that it had decided to ground half its flights to inspect its entire fleet following the May 11 crash in Florida.
Iomega jumped 13 3/8 a share, to 82 5/8, ahead of its 2-for-1 stock split.
Shares of Republic Industries, which is run and controlled by H. Wayne Huizenga, the Florida billionaire, rose 3 1/4, to 43 7/8, after saying it planned to acquire Continental Waste Industries, up 2 7/8, to 16 1/4, in a deal worth about $240 million.
The S.& P. index of 500 stocks rose 4.24 points, to 673.15, a new closing high. The American Stock Exchange index rose 4.15 points, to 609.36, also a record.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index of all listed common stocks rose 2.31 points, to a record 361.09. On the Big Board, advancing issues led declines, 1,318 to 1,034.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of New York, American and Nasdaq issues -- was at a record high of 6,719.131, up 37.876 points, or 0.57 percent.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Downsizing That Offers An Upside

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Milwaukee has the unwelcome distinction of being PBS's favorite case history of economic dysfunction. A few months ago "Frontline" brought home the travails of two of the thousands of workers laid off by Briggs & Stratton, once the city's biggest employer. And tonight it is back with another woman set adrift by Briggs & Stratton and a man who was among the 5,000 workers let go by Chrysler when it "downsized" its Kenosha plant, south of Milwaukee. Both programs grow out of a study begun by the producers Tom Casciato and Kathleen Hughes in 1991.
Although tonight's report does not gloss over the pain of unemployment -- which, it is noted, is feeding the resentment at corporate callousness that has become a potent political campaign theme -- "Does America Still Work?" offers a somewhat brighter picture than its predecessor did. By the end of the hour, Bill Donnell, who spent months taking retraining courses only to find himself with plenty of certificates of completion but no job prospects, and Sheila Caldwell, an unmarried mother who lost the health benefits that were paying for her daughter's cancer treatments, are back at work. 
 But the temptation for companies to lower labor costs, often by departing for nonunion climes, remains strong. Secretary of Labor Robert Reich tells the evening's reporter, Jeff Madrick, that "re-engineering or restructuring or downsizing or rightsizing or whatever you want to call it -- it's basically firing -- has gone way too far." How a few Milwaukee manufacturers are resisting the pressure to move south lest their profits go south is the upbeat part of the program.
Mr. Madrick talks to the heads of Harley-Davidson, Master Lock and Chrysler, which has rejuvenated its Kenosha plant and hired back some of the workers, like Mr. Donnell, who were laid off during the company's tough times. All agree that corporate responsibilities go beyond profits, with the caveat that the top priority is still a profitable bottom line.
Richard Teerlink, who runs Harley-Davidson, speaks of his obligations to employees, customers, suppliers and society as well as to investors. Master Lock is helping to rehabilitate homes for employees in its neighborhood. And Chrysler is using state aid to retrain workers to handle its new technology and bring them into management decisions.
Having delivered its happy endings and examples of companies doing well by doing good, the program reminds us that people who lost jobs in the 1990's tend to be out of work longer than those who lost them in the 1980's and that new jobs typically pay less than the old ones. The persistence of Mr. Casciato and Ms. Hughes is paying off with close-ups of what downsizing means to people whose lives have been upended and by focusing attention on what corporations and government can and ought to do about it.
 
 'Nova'
 'Alive on Everest'
 PBS, tonight at 8
 (Channel 13 in New York)
This vivid account of Rick Wilcox's 1991 attempt to reach the summit of Mount Everest is preceded by a report from one of the expeditions in which eight lives were lost last week. "Nova," which had been charting a team's progress over the Internet all month, carries an interview with the climber David Breashears at the base camp about what it must have been like for the exhausted climbers as they struggled toward the summit in a blizzard. To the accompaniment of pictures of a forbidding rock and weather, he says: "Suddenly you're alone in a howling wind, and you don't know up from down, left from right. So you lay down on the ice to stay warm, maybe you're too tired . . . and you lay down to die because there's nothing else left to do."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Mixed On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities turned mixed yesterday, as investors displayed caution ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee.
Although few market participants expect any change in interest rates at the meeting, investors were not inclined to get ahead of themselves. 
 Much of the day's momentum was a carry-over from last Friday's strong rally, but the market failed to build on last week's gains, which were inspired by data that suggested that the pace of economic growth was slow enough to keep inflation from accelerating.
The 30-year bond declined 1/32 , to a price of 8914/32 to yield 6.83 percent, unchanged from Friday.
Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management, a Washington-based firm with $5 billion in bonds under management, said the market continued to exhibit the positive mood that took hold two weeks ago.
That was inspired, he said, by the small movement in the producer price Index. Excluding food and energy, it was up one-tenth of 1 percent, with the year-over-year gain just 1.8 percent. The low-inflation outlook was confirmed the following week by the Fed's beige book report and again last week by the Consumer Price Index.
Other factors are now coming into play, Mr. Carpenter said, notably the recent fall in crude oil prices.
"Additionally, the change in bond market psychology has been aided by the very soft retail sales reported last week," Mr. Carpenter said.
Also working to swing the mood are political and budget issues that relate to the budget deficit, the forecast of a large Treasury surplus for the month of April, from what may amount to a 20 percent to 25 percent increase in tax payments compared with last year, and contemplation of welfare reform to save tax dollars. "Given the big drop in inflation expectations and the substantially lower core numbers at wholesale and retail, and the big recent drop in energy prices," Mr. Carpenter said, "the Fed is not likely to raise interest rates at the F.O.M.C. on one hand nor lower rates given the healthy 2.8 percent growth rate recorded in the first quarter and the great likelihood that second-quarter growth will be in the neighborhood of 3.5 percent."
The earliest the Fed would move to change policy, he said, will be late third quarter or early fourth quarter. It appears that the Fed has more or less correctly set the Federal funds rate within 25 basis points of a level consistent with producing moderate growth of around 2 percent and inflation at around 2.5 percent. In yesterday's Treasury bill auction, the three-month maturity averaged 5.03 percent and the six-month issue 5.11 percent.

HEADLINE: Partners Vote For Changes At Goldman

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs & Company took action yesterday to strengthen its capital base and to limit the liability of the firm's partners.
Goldman said it would retain for a longer period the capital of partners who leave the firm. The firm also said it would become a limited liability partnership on Nov. 30, the end of its financial year. 
 Goldman's partners approved the measures yesterday at a meeting at the firm's Broad Street headquarters in Manhattan. The partners voted at their annual meeting in January to remain a private partnership while also seeking to create some advantages enjoyed by public companies, such as limited liability.
Goldman, which is the last big private partnership on Wall Street, reported profit before taxes of $1.37 billion for the year ended Nov. 30, 1995. Partners said the firm, which has been doing well in the current buoyant financial climate, had more than $5 billion in capital.
The moves approved yesterday are part of a gradual realignment that Jon S. Corzine, Goldman's chairman and senior partner; Henry M. Paulson Jr., the vice chairman and chief operating officer, and the new management committees they installed last November are carrying out as they try to increase Goldman's stability and profitability.
Mr. Corzine and Mr. Paulson described the measures in a letter to Goldman staff that was dated today. "The partners yesterday adopted certain arrangements to strengthen and enhance the stability of the firm's capital base, reduce partners' personal risk in the event of a catastrophic loss, and, by these and related measures, encourage partners to lengthen their active careers at the firm," the letter said.
Goldman declined to disclose exactly how partners' capital would be affected by the changes. "A piece of their capital will have a longer tenure," said a partner who attended yesterday's meeting, explaining that the capital of a partner leaving the firm would probably remain with Goldman for an average of about six years, compared with the current three and a half to four years. The extension of this tenure makes it less likely that Goldman would experience unexpected strain on its capital.
In addition, under the new arrangement, partners with long service would have some greater flexibility in gaining access to their capital once they cease to be active working partners, and instead become limited partners.
In 1994, when interest rates rose rapidly, Goldman, like other big Wall Street firms, suffered losses and some drain of capital as it marked down the value of its huge bond portfolios. Yesterday's moves are an attempt to insure that the firm is well able to deal with similar problems in the future.
Goldman partners played down the new moves, emphasizing that they effectively codify much of the firm's existing practices.
Goldman has 173 working partners and 110 limited partners, a spokesman for the firm said yesterday. The working partners, along with two powerful outside investors, Sumitomo Bank of Japan and the Kamehameha Schools/Bernice Pauahi Bishop Estate, an educational trust in Hawaii, own about three-quarters of the firm's capital, with the limited partners holding the rest.

HEADLINE: Effort to Weaken Bosnian Serb Leader Seems to Have Failed

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: PALE, Bosnia and Herzegovina, May 20

 BODY:
The international campaign to weaken Radovan Karadzic's grip on power, and perhaps even drive the Bosnian Serb leader from office, appears to have ended for now in failure.
Dr. Karadzic, who has been indicted as a war criminal and is not recognized by the rest of the world as the legitimate leader of Serbian-held Bosnia, has succeeded in ousting Prime Minister Rajko Kasagic, and has appointed new hard-liners to fill key government posts. 
 Mr. Kasagic, who worked with other countries to implement the Dayton peace accord, has dropped out of sight. And despite pressure by Western countries to oust Dr. Karadzic, Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian President, has refused to do anything more than issue statements condemning the latest consolidation of Dr. Karadzic's power.
The moves by Dr. Karadzic are ominous. They push back the international efforts to prepare for Bosnian elections, which are due to take place Sept. 14. If Dr. Karadzic is still in power in July, when campaigning is to begin, many Western diplomats say that it will be impossible to hold meaningful elections. And, for the first time since the Dayton agreement, there appears to be an urgency among Western diplomats to get rid of Dr. Karadzic, perhaps, in the end, by military force.
"If Karadzic is in a position to actively take part in the election campaign," said Michael Steiner, the senior deputy to Carl Bildt, "then any election campaign makes no sense."
Mr. Bildt, who is in charge of the civilian aspects of the peace accords, has been trying to bolster moderate Bosnian Serb leaders, including the ousted Prime Minister.
Mr. Bildt has often been criticized for weak leadership, and Western diplomats today welcomed his emergence, for the first time, as a forceful advocate for a change in the Bosnian Serb leadership. They conceded, however, that he has few tools to threaten or cajole the Bosnian Serbs at his disposal, other than the carrot of international aid.
Together with the United States, Mr. Bildt is now rallying international support, much of it aimed at pressuring Mr. Milosevic to force Dr. Karadzic to relinquish power. Mr. Milosevic needs to open trade with Europe and desperately desires loans to jump-start his economy.
But Western diplomats also said that if the elections were canceled it would signal a collapse of the peace process and could lead to a renewal of the conflict. They conceded that they might be forced to go ahead, even with Dr. Karadzic in power.
"We run the serious risk of the collapse of the peace process, in all its splendor, the military dimension and the civilian side," said Robert H. Frowick, the head of mission that will oversee the elections. Mr. Frowick, representing the Organization for Security and Co-Operation in Europe, said, "There is enormous pressure to find a way to meet reasonable desiderata to proceed."
The current clash, although it ended in Dr. Karadzic's favor, is the beginning of a drive by Mr. Bildt to push Dr. Karadzic out of office, according to Mr. Steiner. The focus has now shifted from Pale, the Bosnian Serb stronghold, to Belgrade. And Mr. Bildt's office hopes that European and American envoys will deliver harsher messages to Mr. Milosevic to use whatever forces are at his disposal to get rid of Dr. Karadzic. Western diplomats, in recent days, have told Mr. Milosevic that he will not receive economic support until Dr. Karadzic is replaced.
Those diplomats said, however, that Mr. Milosevic shows little interest in taking forceful action to remove Dr. Karadzic. They said it appears that Mr. Milosevic hopes that the elections, which Dr. Karadzic is not allowed to enter, will remove the Bosnian Serb leader from any major role in Bosnian politics.
"Milosevic has moved and has produced something," Mr. Steiner said, "but it is important that he understands that this is not what we wanted. While he may think he has done enough, we don't think he has done enough."
Dr. Karadzic has announced that he would turn over international negotiations to a hard-line supporter, Biljana Plavsic. Mr. Bildt's office initially greeted this as a sign of weakness. But it was clear today, from statements made in Pale, that it instead meant a stiffening of the refusal by Pale to implement the civilian aspects of the Dayton accord, including permission for displaced people and refugees to return home and the efforts to create a unified Bosnia.
"After three wars in this century, we can't live together," the new Prime Minister, Gojko Klickovic, said tonight, rejecting the call by the peace accords for a united Bosnia.
And Mrs. Plavsic, selected by Dr. Karadzic as a Vice President, said the only reason she had been given authority was because "the international community does not want to talk to President Karadzic."

HEADLINE: GE Capital to Acquire Ameridata Technologies for $490 Million

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The General Electric Company's Capital Services unit agreed yesterday to buy Ameridata Technologies Inc. for $490 million to expand its computer equipment leasing and consulting business.
The purchase will double to $3 billion the annual revenue of G.E.'s Technology Management Services, which specializes in buying, setting up and managing corporate computers. 
 It also gives GE Capital, one of the world's biggest computer equipment lessors, more power to compete with rivals like I.B.M., Electronic Data Systems and Andersen Consulting for top technicians.
"The overall pie in servicing desktop machines is expanding very rapidly, but the cost of hiring talent is increasing," said Waverly Deutsch, an analyst at Forrester Research. The acquisition will give GE Capital a quick infusion of 3,600 workers worldwide, she said.
GE Capital will pay $16 a share for Ameridata; that company's shares rose 37.5 cents to $15.75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday -- a 52-week high. The stock has jumped 26 percent the last two weeks. General Electric's shares rose $3.125, to $84.375.
Ameridata specializes in supplying computers wholesale to its customers. In recent quarters, the company switched its focus to maintaining PC's and networks, an industry that is expected to grow 14 percent a year, according to Dataquest Inc.
The acquisition would give G.E.'s Technology Management Services, based in Norcross, Ga., a bigger share of the $28 billion-a-year industry of managing corporate computer networks, analysts said.
Earlier this year, the unit bought the Ferntree Computer Corporation of Australia to expand its reach abroad.
GE Capital will start a cash tender offer for Ameridata shares in five days, General Electric said. Ameridata's management, which owns 6 percent of the shares outstanding, has agreed to tender its shares. Ameridata, based in Stamford, Conn., also said it adjourned its annual meeting, which had been scheduled for today.
"It's a reasonable purchase price for G.E., because it's a growing business," said Russell Leavitt, an analyst at Salomon Brothers in New York.
GE Capital, which leases equipment as diverse as trucks, airplanes and computers, had an operating profit of $3.52 billion in 1995, on revenue of $26.49 billion.
Since 1992, Ameridata has bought at least 25 companies to bolster its computer systems and services group. Last year, Ameridata bought five international units of Control Data Systems Inc., expanding its reach into Austria, Canada, Mexico, Norway and Britain.
In 1995, the company's net income rose 24 percent to $17.3 million, or 79 cents a share, while revenue rose 49 percent to $1.52 billion. Had Ameridata remained an independent company, per-share earnings were forecast to rise 29 percent, to $1.02 a share in 1996, in a recent survey of three analysts by IBES International Inc.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Game's Big Problem: Futile Tigers

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
On a daily basis, people say Major League Baseball should do something about Marge Schott, should do something about Albert Belle. What baseball should do something about, though, is the Detroit Tigers.
In the best interests of baseball, the acting commissioner, the executive council, the American League president and anyone else who has compassion for people and passion for the game that used to be should do something about the Tigers. What they should do is declare the Tigers' remaining games exhibitions, not to be counted in the standings, and declare their games already played to be exhibitions and remove them from the standing. 
 Projections are meaningless, but to put the Tigers' performance in perspective, if they were to continue playing at the pace they have established in the first seven weeks, they would win 43 games and lose 119, record numbers for a 14-team league. Putting it in further perspective, that record would come humiliatingly close to the 40-120 record the Mets staggered to in 1962, the first season of their existence.
At the same pace (7.7 runs a game), the Tigers' opponents would score 1,253 runs, a total that would shatter records for all league sizes and shapes. As an example of just how bad the Tigers' pitchers are, that total would exceed by nearly 300 the record for most runs allowed in a 162-game season.
High-scoring games are one thing. If baseball officials believe runs and home runs will attract more fans, let the scoring continue. But the Tigers' games go well beyond the call of business. In the Tigers' weekend series with Chicago, the White Sox, no scoring machine themselves, scored 11, 16 and 14 runs, punctuating the final game with a pair of grand slams. Opponents have scored in double figures in 8 of the Tigers' last 16 games and 14 times over all this season.
In short, it has become far too easy for teams to score against Detroit pitchers. They don't even have a challenge anymore. Play the games, but use them for what they are -- batting practice.
It has become far too easy, too, for journalists, both print and electronic, to elicit the most inane and offensive comments from Marge Schott. Like shooting fish in a barrel, reporters who ask the Cincinnati Reds' managing partner a question they know will get some dumb comment that will gain attention.
Therefore, it is time to make Schott off limits. No more cheap and easy stories. If we don't ask, she can't tell.
Furthermore, baseball officials should take no action against Schott. Anything they try to do will lead them to court, and baseball needs a nasty legal fight over the Reds' franchise less than it needs to get rid of Schott. At the rate she is going, she is headed for the economic equivalent of a 43-119 record.
Reds fans will let Schott know that it is time for her to bow out and either sell her share or step aside and let someone else operate the club. She is a hard-nosed, bottom-line businesswoman, and a growing number of empty seats, left unfilled by fans tired not necessarily of her comments but of her decimation of the team, will prompt her to get out.
For precedent, see the Mets of the late 70's, who under the misguided stewardship of the de Roulet family and its Rasputin, M. Donald Grant, drew a decreasing number of fans until a record low of 788,905 showed up in 1979. The de Roulets sold the Mets before the next season.
Baseball officials have tried to do something about Albert Belle, but no amount of counseling is going to change him. At least the Indians hope it won't. The Indians like the Albert Belle who leads the league in home runs, is tied for the lead in runs batted in and is fourth in hitting. And who can blame them?
The Indians know that Belle hits best when angry. The last thing they want to do is defuse his anger. The trick for Dr. Charles Maher, the Rutgers professor who serves as the Indians' sports psychologist, will be to find a way to persuade Belle to stop menacing members of the news media without diluting the intensity and anger that stoke his fire.
It might be in the best interests of baseball to have Belle tone down his off-field behavior, but it is in the best interests of the Indians to keep him hitting. The way the Indians hope it works is that baseball officials can lead Belle to a shrink, but they cannot make him think.
Officials will monitor Belle's counseling visits but not their content. Neither Belle nor Maher will be conducting any interviews on the subjects discussed in their sessions. If Belle's power and production start slipping, though, know that the counselor went too far.
Has Darryl Strawberry gone so far with his off-field problems that he has ended his major league career? Shunned by every major league organization, Strawberry began his comeback last night when the St. Paul Saints of the independent Northern League started their exhibition schedule looking ahead to their May 31 season opener.
"I talked to our manager last night," Marvin Goldklang, the Saints' owner, said yesterday, referring to Marty Scott. "Based on what he's seen, he thinks Strawberry ought to be in the big leagues."
Asked why he thought major league teams have ignored Strawberry, Goldklang said: "I think the concern is more one of media reaction than a lack of ability or unwillingness to take on a player with his background. Maybe some teams are concerned over what their local columnists might write if they signed him. I think it's ill founded."
If the major leagues are big enough to hold Marge Schott and Albert Belle, they should have room for Darryl Strawberry.

HEADLINE: Moratorium on Protecting Species Is Ended

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Ending a 13-month moratorium imposed by Congress, the Federal Government complied with a court order today and granted protection under the Endangered Species Act to a California frog.
But Federal officials said the endangered species program was severely short of money and overwhelmed by a backlog of hundreds of imperiled species -- and by almost as many lawsuits demanding action to save them. 
 Having persuaded Congress to drop the moratorium as part of the recent agreement on Federal spending for the current fiscal year, the Clinton Administration is now struggling under intense legal and political pressures to decide which species to protect first.
Its plan is to act first to help species facing an immediate danger of extinction, followed by those species that biologists determine would be most likely to recover if fully protected under the law, according to a notice published on Thursday. Only later would the Government turn to less pressing questions, including studies of additional species and decisions about lifting protections on species that are now out of danger. Federal protection prohibits the destruction of habitat.
At issue are the needs of species as familiar as the peninsular bighorn sheep and coho salmon of the West Coast, or as obscure as Appalachian mussels, Hawaiian plants and the cactus ferruginous pygmy owl of the Southwest.
The California red-legged frog, the species thought to have inspired Mark Twain's yarn about a "celebrated jumping frog," appeared today to have, well, leap-frogged over the 242 other species whose proposed protection was held up by the moratorium.
In a suit brought during the moratorium by the Environmental Defense Center, a Federal District Court in California had ordered the Fish and Wildlife Service last year to protect the frog. But until now, the Administration could not obey the order because Congress had refused to provide money for the agency to take any such actions.
The California red-legged frog was classified as threatened, a status that under the law means a species is headed toward being legally endangered throughout its range but is not yet in danger of extinction.
Long since eliminated from most of the streams it once occupied, the frog still survives in about 240 streams or wetlands, but there are thought to be only three areas sheltering more than 350 frogs.
Smaller populations than that are considered less likely to survive the stresses of pollution, habitat destruction, and competition from non-native species like bullfrogs, which were introduced after the red-legged frog was largely extirpated many decades ago by hunters who sold its legs as a gourmet delicacy.
Now, as the endangered species program rises unsteadily back to its feet, Administration officials said the Government faced a huge backlog of cases involving species that might merit protection under the law, but that there was far too little money to protect them all right away.
Administration officials said they believed that the California red-legged frog could be protected without undue economic disruption, although grazing, logging, mining, flood control, and other activities would have to be carried out with the needs of the species in mind.
Mollie Beattie, the director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, said the frog's needs were already being addressed in projects at Fort Ord, in the San Francisco transit system, and around the Los Vaqueros Reservoir in the Contra Costa Water District, as well as in several habitat conservation plans.
There seems to be no way for the Government to act quickly on the full range of decisions involving endangered species.
The Fish and Wildlife Service has less than $4 million to spend between now and October on its endangered species program. It faces a backlog of 242 species, not counting the frog, for which protection has already been proposed but not made final. Some 182 species more are viewed as likely candidates but need further research before being proposed for listing.
Almost as worrisome to officials who manage the program, there are about 60 lawsuits pending involving disputes over which species should be listed, and 300 more cases where plaintiffs have notified the Government that they may file suit under the law.
"Biological needs, not the preferences of litigants, should drive the listing process," said the Fish and Wildlife Service last week in an explanation of how it would set its priorities. "In some cases courts have ordered the service to complete activities that are simply not, in the service's expert judgment, among the highest biological priorities."
For example, the Fund for Animals won a lawsuit against the Bush Administration that requires the agency to decide whether to protect 443 species by Sept. 30, 1996, a deadline that the agency had expected to meet but that now appears impossible.
Officials said that if the agency was bound by that decision it would spend its entire budget meeting the deadline and would be unable to address higher priorities.
"The question is, do we want to do this in a biologically sensible way or not, given the situation we are in?" said George Frampton, the Assistant Secretary of Interior for fish and wildlife.
Mr. Frampton said it was not clear which species would be given priority. The agency's biologists had been transferred to other jobs for the past year, and it will take time for them to finish other tasks and then to review the status of endangered species.
As the listing of new species accelerates in the months ahead, it is also unclear how the continuing Congressional debate over revising the law will be affected.
Congressional Republicans at one time believed that the moratorium on protecting new species would pressure the Administration to sign a bill radically overhauling the law. A proposal drafted in the House would have removed restrictions on private landowners and compensated them for regulations that decreased the value of their property.
But Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, has signaled he will not bring that proposal to the floor, and now the resumption of new listings may increase the pressure on Congress to consider a more moderate approach.
