HEADLINE: For First Time, Justices Reject Punitive Award

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Overturning a $2 million punitive-damage award to an Alabama man who bought a new BMW with a touched-up paint job, the Supreme Court set new standards today for determining when an award of punitive damages is so "grossly excessive" as to violate the constitutional requirement of due process of law.
The 5-to-4 decision marked the first time in more than a decade of wrestling with the punitive-damages issue that the Court had actually overturned an award as excessive. The decision, with a majority opinion by Justice John Paul Stevens and over the dissents of four Justices who said the Court should not intrude in an area traditionally reserved for state law, came in a high-profile case that had become something of a poster child of the debate -- now going on in Congress and the Presidential campaign as much as in the courts -- over revising the tort system. 
 The majority opinion was joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy, David H. Souter, and Stephen G. Breyer. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote a dissenting opinion that was joined by Justice Clarence Thomas. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg also wrote a dissenting opinion, which Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist also signed.
In his decision, Justice Stevens said the award went far beyond what BMW might have reasonably expected to suffer for its conduct and said courts should consider factors like "degree of reprehensibility" and the mathematical ratio between punitive and actual damages in deciding whether to uphold awards.
But the decision, BMW v. Gore, No. 94-896, left a number of important questions unanswered, offering what it called "guideposts" rather than specific formulas for assessing the fairness of punitive-damage awards. The case now returns to the Alabama Supreme Court. The Court is also likely to vacate decisions in more than a dozen other punitive-damage cases on its docket and send those back to the state courts as well. A clear view of the boundaries of the Court's analysis today is likely to emerge only gradually, as state courts adjust their practices.
"Elementary notions of fairness enshrined in our constitutional jurisprudence dictate that a person receive fair notice not only of the conduct that will subject him to punishment but also of the severity of the penalty that a state may impose," Justice Stevens said.
In his dissenting opinion, Justice Scalia derided what Justice Stevens called "guideposts" as "criss-crossing platitudes" that he said marked "a road to nowhere."
But while the ruling will clearly not end the debate, "it really gives lawyers and courts something to work with in terms of structuring the inquiry," Andrew L. Frey, the lawyer who won the case for BMW, said in an interview today.
An Alabama jury had originally awarded $4 million, calculating the damages based on the manufacturer's behavior not only in Alabama -- where 14 customers, including the plaintiff, Dr. Ira Gore, Jr., had bought new cars that had been repainted to correct minor paint damage -- but throughout the country.
Nearly 1,000 repainted BMW's had been sold as new in the 10 years before the 1992 trial, most in states where, like Alabama, there was no law on the books that made the specific practice illegal. Viewing the practice as consumer fraud, the Alabama jury reached its $4-million verdict by multiplying 1,000 by the $4,000 it calculated as the loss of value to Dr. Gore's $40,000 car from the paint repair, which itself cost $601.37.
The Alabama Supreme Court, in a 1993 ruling, cut the award in half on the ground that an Alabama jury could not rely on "acts that occurred in other jurisdictions." The majority today strongly agreed with that analysis, while finding the smaller award still too high.
"While each state has ample power to protect its own consumers, none may use the punitive-damages deterrent as a means of imposing its regulatory policies on the entire Nation," Justice Stevens said. Using legal jargon for "wrongdoer," Justice Stevens said that "a state may not impose economic sanctions on violators of its laws with the intent of changing the tortfeasors' lawful conduct in other States."
While an important part of the ruling, this analysis was also a source of ambiguity, because Justice Stevens said that "we need not consider" whether one state's courts could take into account conduct that was illegal in other states. Product liability cases that involve dangerous or negligently made products are likely to raise this question.
Earlier this month, President Clinton vetoed a bill that would have set limits on punitive damages, in both state and Federal courts, in cases involving faulty products. During the Presidential primaries, Republicans ran advertisements attacking the liability system and calling for drastic reform. But the failure of a two-year-long Congressional effort was likely to shift attention to the courts as the forum where the next act in the punitive-damages drama would play out.
In his opinion, Justice Stevens said the $2 million award against BMW failed three tests that courts should use to make sure that a defendant had adequate notice of exposure to heavy punitive damages.
The first was the "degree of reprehensibility of the defendant's conduct": whether the behavior had put people's health or safety at risk, for example, or whether there was evidence of bad faith. In this case, Justice Stevens said, there was only minor economic injury and "no deliberate false statements, acts of affirmative misconduct, or concealment of evidence of improper motive." He said BMW had no reason to think its practice violated Alabama law.
The second of the "guideposts" was the ratio between the punitive and the actual damages, in this instance 500:1. Justice Stevens said the Court would continue to reject "the notion that the constitutional line is marked by a simple mathematical formula," but added that "when the ratio is a breathtaking 500 to 1, however, the award must surely raise a suspicious judicial eyebrow."
The third test was to compare the punitive-damage awards and any civil fines or criminal punishment available in the state for similar conduct. In Alabama, the fine for violating the state's Deceptive Trade Practices Act is $2,000. Justice Stevens noted that in New York, the penalty for a first-time violation of the equivalent consumer-protection law is $50. He said that while the Alabama courts were free to impose a punitive-damage award beyond the statutory fine, "we cannot, however, accept the conclusion of the Alabama Supreme Court that BMW's conduct was sufficiently egregious to justify a punitive sanction that is tantamount to a severe criminal penalty."
Justice Ginsburg's dissenting opinion included a four-page appendix of recent actions or bills currently under consideration in the states to curb punitive damages.
She said: "The Court, I am convinced, unnecessarily and unwisely ventures into territory traditionally within the states' domain, and does so in the fact of reform measures recently adopted or currently under consideration in legislative arenas."
Justice Scalia said the majority had accomplished "nothing at all except confer an artificial air of doctrinal analysis upon its essentially ad hoc determination that this particular award of punitive damages was not 'fair.' "
He said: "I do not regard the 14th amendment's due-process clause as a secret repository of substantive guarantees against 'unfairness.' "

HEADLINE: Pataki and Giuliani End Squabble Over an Economic Renewal Zone

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Breaking an impasse that had held up $100 million in Federal aid for two of New York City's poorest neighborhoods, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that they had overcome their differences over how to share control of the board that will dole out the money.
The dispute over the so-called Empowerment Zone program, in which parts of Harlem and the South Bronx are to receive $300 million in city, state and Federal money for economic development incentives, came down in the end to haggling over legal technicalities. 
 But with the subsidies already more than a year overdue, the squabbling had prompted charges that petty political rivalries were standing in the way of the interests of poor people. And the resolution announced yesterday appeared to be the most expedient way for the Mayor and the Governor to put behind them an episode with potentially unpleasant political repercussions.
"We have been and are prepared to meet our commitment," said Mr. Pataki, who announced the agreement at a joint news conference with Mr. Giuliani in Albany. Federal officials had suggested that the Republican administrations in Albany and City Hall had been dragging their feet because they were reluctant to pay for an expensive program that was championed largely by their Democratic predecessors.
Discussing the dispute over control of the board that will run the program, Mr. Giuliani said yesterday, "The issue very simply is that both the city and the state want to feel that they can be accountable."
Under the terms announced yesterday, the state agreed to a revision in the bylaws of the board that will govern the empowerment zone, giving state officials less power to remove board members they oppose. The city had complained that under the previous rules, the state could have ousted the city's appointees on the board if city and state officials disagreed over which projects should get money.
For its part, the city agreed to indemnify the state against liability lawsuits against the board of empowerment zone, which has members from the city, state and Federal governments but will technically be a subsidiary of the Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency.
With those legal sticking points resolved, officials said the only question remaining before the zone is formed, and the spigot of government subsidies turned on, is when the city will call the first meeting of the zone's board. Since the bylaws of the zone designate the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Fran Reiter, as the board's chairwoman during its first year, it is up to her to call the meeting.
"Our lawyers are meeting with their lawyers, and assuming everyone is on the same page, there is no reason whey there shouldn't be a meeting of the board by the end of next week," Ms. Reiter said in an interview late yesterday.
Unless lawyers for the city or the state come up with other problems, the deal announced yesterday appeared likely to placate a chorus of critics led by Andrew M. Cuomo, an assistant secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, whose district includes Harlem and the South Bronx.
It followed a week of bitter exchanges between city and state economic development officials, reflecting an unusually tense rivalry that had been apparent in recent months in disputes over such projects as development of the site of the New York Coliseum and of a park along the Hudson River in Manhattan.
The dispute was brought to a head by Mr. Rangel, who had been one of the chief advocates of an empowerment zone when Harlem and the South Bronx were selected for the designation in December 1994 after a national competition among cities.
He complained bitterly last week that five other cities that were selected for empowerment zone benefits at the same time quickly established their zones last year, and said the long delay in New York City meant that it might sacrifice the Federal Government's commitment to the program.
That fear was reinforced by Mr. Cuomo, who is charge of administering Federal funds under the empowerment zone program. He said on Friday that New York City was "very close" to losing Federal funds for the zone because of the delay.
Under a agreement reached in January, the city, state and Federal governments, which are to contribute equal amounts of money to the zone -- to a maximum of $100 million each -- agreed to pitch in $6 million each during the first year.
But because of the legal snags that have delayed formation of the zone since then, it was unclear yesterday how much money would be immediately available to the zone once a meeting of its board is called. That is because its first year of operations was to have corresponded with New York City's fiscal year, which ends on June 30, giving the board little time to select projects and dispense money.
Among the Harlem civic leaders who had criticized the delays in the program was the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, who has been planning a job counseling program that would be paid for by empowerment zone subsidies.
"I am very pleased that things seem to have been resolved," he said yesterday. "But I remain deeply concerned that this community was held hostage over details."
The government aid will be used for job training programs, low interest business loans and projects intended to attract small companies to the neighborhood, like a building planned on 125th Street in Harlem to house small startup companies.

HEADLINE: Despite Tensions, Clinton Urges Renewal of China's Trade Status

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Despite a conflict with China over pirated American computer software, movies and music, President Clinton called today for unconditional renewal of preferential trade status for China, saying the step would be "a vote for America's interests" and "not a referendum on all China's policies."
Mr. Clinton's speech began a full-scale Administration lobbying effort to win Congressional approval for the extension of most-favored-nation trade status for China, even though tensions linger over major issues like nuclear proliferation and human rights abuses as well as trade. 
 The President's address to the Pacific Basin Economic Council also came close to being a point-by-point response to a withering election-year attack by Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, on Mr. Clinton earlier this month for "weakness, indecision, double talk and incoherence" in foreign policy, especially toward the Pacific Basin.
Reviewing his Asia policy, Mr. Clinton emphasized the "firmness and steadiness" with which his Administration secured the shutdown of reactors producing weapons-grade plutonium in North Korea. He said the United States must also be "steady and firm" in pushing for a stable, open and prosperous China.
And while Mr. Dole had cited a merchandise trade deficit with Japan last year of $60 billion, higher than when Mr. Clinton took office, the President today countered with his own trade statistics. He said that the trade deficit with Japan was down 25 percent from last year.
Four years ago as a candidate, Mr. Clinton denounced President George Bush for his position that engaging China rather than threatening it with trade sanctions was the best way to promote human rights and protect America's interest in Asia. But once in office, Mr. Clinton came around to a similar policy of engagement.
Last week, after months of warnings regarding the violations of an agreement protecting intellectual property rights -- which include pirating of software, videotapes and music -- the Administration published a list of $3 billion of goods exported from China to the United States annually that could be subject to the largest trade sanctions ever imposed by Washington.
But Mr. Clinton has long made clear his intentions to push to continue the trade benefits, and his action today was expected. His speech displayed the kinds of arguments he will be making during the next few months as Congress weighs whether to vote to revoke China's trade benefits and force Mr. Clinton to exercise a veto. Although the President almost certainly would defeat an override attempt, the battle would make him look weaker on the world stage.
[On Tuesday, a Vice Premier of China, Li Lanqing, welcomed Mr. Clinton's effort to renew the trade status but warned Washington not to impose sanctions over trade disputes, Reuters reported.
["This, of course, is good news," Mr. Li told a seminar in Beijing. "I feel that it is harmful to long-term Chinese-U.S. economic and trade cooperation for China and the United States to argue about this problem each year. It will create psychological instability on both sides and will have no good results."
[Referring to looming tit-for-tat sanctions announced by Beijing and Washington in the dispute over copyright piracy, Mr. Li said: "I don't know who will be imposing sanctions on whom or who will be containing whom. I feel that this is inappropriate. We are not willing to see a trade war."]
Mr. Clinton noted today that China is Asia's only "declared nuclear weapons state" and has the world's largest standing army. In less than two decades, he said, it could be the world's largest economy.
Faced with such an economic and military behemoth, he argued, it would not be in America's interest to drive China toward isolation by denying the "most favored" trade status that is given routinely to most trading partners in the world and allows China to export its products to the United States at the lowest possible tariffs. The sanctions for violating the piracy agreement amount to only a small fraction of China's total imports to the United States.
Revoking the status, Mr. Clinton said, "would drive us back into a period of mutual isolation and recrimination that would harm America's interests, not advance them."
"Rather than strengthening China's respect for human rights," Mr. Clinton said, "it would lessen our contact with the Chinese people. Rather than limiting the spread of weapons of mass destruction, it would limit the prospect for future cooperation in this area. Rather than bringing stability to the region, it would increase instability as the leaders of Hong Kong, Taiwan and all of the nations of the region have stated repeatedly."
Mr. Dole earlier this month spurned the conservative wing of his own party and said he too backed the current status for China, though he sharply criticized Mr. Clinton's overall policy toward Asia.
"President Clinton's long silence and his history of zigzags on China has put extension of M.F.N. in serious doubt this year," Mr. Dole said today in a statement. "The President still needs to articulate a coherent policy toward China and how M.F.N. extension fits into that policy."
Patrick J. Buchanan, Mr. Dole's erstwhile competitor for the Republican nomination, called Mr. Clinton's move to renew China's trading privileges "an act of economic, moral and military appeasement."
He added: "For the Republican Party this will be a defining moment: Do we stand with Bill Clinton or do we stand by the values that made us a Congressional majority. Do we love trade more than we loathe tyranny?"
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton would formally notify Congress of his decision to extend the trade preferences on June 3, starting the time-clock for action. Beginning a month later, on July 3, the House and Senate have 60 days in which they could vote to revoke China's benefits.
Republicans say that there has been rising frustration on Capitol Hill with what is seen as Administration leniency toward China as well as with Beijing's conduct on several issues ranging across the areas of trade, human rights, diplomacy and arms control. The White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, today also acknowledged a tough fight ahead and said that is why Mr. Clinton announced his decision early.
"We are worried enough that we are not taking anything for granted," Mr. McCurry said. A variety of Administration officials were to be deployed to begin making the Administration's case, with Defense Secretary William J. Perry, for example, scheduled to make an address concerning China on Wednesday.
Officials predict that the House will vote against trade preferences or make the benefits conditional because of liberal and conservative concerns alike about China's human rights record and failure to live up to international accords.
Mr. Clinton has stronger support in the more moderate Senate. But even there, Republicans say, the balance could tilt depending on whether the size of the House vote puts pressure on Democrats to split with the President and stand up for human rights or if the United States and China are in the midst of a trade war over intellectual property.

HEADLINE: A New Star In Constellation Of Art's Giants;
Queens Landmark Wins A Coveted Cultural Title

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
The Museum of Modern Art is not part of this club. Neither is the Guggenheim or the Whitney. Not even the Metropolitan Opera or the New York Philharmonic.
Just who is in the "in" crowd? Such giants as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the American Museum of Natural History, Carnegie Hall, the Bronx Zoo and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, to name a few. Their perks are the official city title of "Cultural Institution," a dollop of cachet and, more to the point, a steady stream of city money. 
 "It's a very privileged group," said Randall Bourscheidt, president of the Alliance for the Arts and chairman of the city's advisory commission for cultural affairs. "You can imagine it seems like El Dorado to a lot of people."
Now, after 14 years, (well, nine years if you count the entree of Lincoln Center's parking garage and fountain), the newest cultural institution has just been crowned. It is . . . Flushing Town Hall.
How did Flushing Town Hall manage to net such a plum? Especially in a year when merciless city budget cuts are proposed for culture and the arts?
"I badgered the hell out of the city," said Claire Shulman, Borough President of Queens, who has made the renaissance of Flushing Town Hall something of a personal crusade. "I just didn't let go. I don't really know who the competition was, but I hear that other organizations were looking for institution status. We just kept pushing it and pushing it and pushing it."
The Town Hall, an 1862 Romanesque Revival building that is a national landmark, was once a 19th-century meeting hall, courthouse, police station and village library. It is undergoing a top-to-bottom renovation, and the first floor is being used for art exhibits, jazz and classical concerts and community programs.
The choice has been greeted with a mix of shrugs, applause and grimaces in the city's culture klatches. No one turned green on the record. Off the record, there were some sighs of disappointment.
"How do they justify doing the Flushing Town Hall?" said the head of one organization, who did not wish to be named possibly because the institution is hoping to join the inner sanctum someday.
At stake is a berth in the constellation of museums, zoos, botanical gardens and performance halls that are on real estate owned by the city and get the majority -- 85 percent -- of the money given out by the city's Department of Cultural Affairs.
"Favoring city-owned institutions has been a policy of all mayors," said Mr. Bourscheidt, a former deputy commissioner for cultural affairs. "It's why New York is the cultural capital of the damn world. It's why the Met can be compared to the Louvre."
Cultural institution money goes for some of the least glamorous parts of a museum or concert hall -- but that's exactly why it is so prized. It is operating money, guaranteed each year to pay for utility bills, security guards, maintenance and other day-to-day costs. Being a cultural institution means access to city capital money for construction and renovation. It also means the city covers the costs of pay raises for employees and acts as labor negotiator between a museum's management and staff.
"No private donor wants to contribute money for bricks and mortar," said Judith E. Daykin, the president and executive director of City Center and the chairwoman of the Cultural Institutions Group, an informal organization of city-owned cultural organizations. "They want their money to go to paintings or a sculpture exhibit."
There are other attractions.
In the bone-whittled budget drawn up by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the designated cultural institutions take a much smaller hit than the 400 other organizations that divvy up the remaining 15 percent of the Cultural Affairs Department money for programs, exhibits and performances. Flushing Town Hall had been the biggest recipient of that money for the last few years, getting half a million dollars. That is roughly the same amount of money its director expects to get as a cultural institution. But while the city wants to slash program funds by 59 percent, it is protecting cultural institutions, proposing to cut their money by only 9 percent.
Less tangibly, being one of the 31 cultural institutions (32 if you count Lincoln Center's "public spaces" -- the fountain, plaza, park and the parking garage -- which are on the list, but not its Chagalls, which are not), confers a certain security and stature, something that encourages other donors.
"One of the things I think will come from C.I.G. status is more prestige with foundations," said Jo-Ann Jones, the executive director of the Flushing Council on Culture and the Arts, which runs Flushing Town Hall.
City officials say they are besieged by museums and other organizations that want to float the idea of becoming a cultural institution.
"We certainly have inquiries all the time, numbers of requests from institutions big and small," said Patricia T. Smalley, the Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Cultural Affairs, who said Flushing Town Hall had an edge because it was already city-owned. She would not reveal the names of the hopefuls, but other sources in the arts said some of those actively interested include the New York Historical Society.
Of course, the Cultural Institutions Group, pick-of-the-litter polish notwithstanding, would not really be a great deal for every museum or concert hall. The prerequisites for getting all the city's goodies can seem pretty steep.
The Guggenheim or Museum of Modern Art, for example, would have to relinquish private ownership of their buildings, not a necessarily desirable option even if the city could afford to compensate them. They would have to give up city program funds if they receive them. Then, they would have to adhere to a panoply of codes and guidelines.
Still, even a place with the stature of the Museum of Modern Art does not dismiss the idea out of hand.
"Obviously it would be very desirable, but it's just not feasible with the city's budget problems," said Elizabeth Addison, a spokeswoman for the museum, adding that there have been no serious discussions about the prospect.
Since 1877, when the American Museum of Natural History became the first cultural institution, the city has, little by little, accepted others into the fold, including the Joseph Papp Public Theater, the New York City Ballet, the Museum of the City of New York and the Studio Museum in Harlem. There has also been an effort to knight noted institutions outside Manhattan: the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the New York Hall of Science and the American Museum of the Moving Image in Queens, the Snug Harbor Cultural Center in Staten Island, the Bronx Museum of the Arts and other smaller historical societies and art centers.
All of them have banded themselves loosely into the Cultural Institutions Group, complete with a paid lobbyist.
Like a dogged stage mother, Mrs. Shulman has been trying for years to land this role for Flushing Town Hall. She brought it up at meetings, submitted proposals, worked the phones. She even agreed to use Queens borough money to make up the difference for the first year between what Flushing Town Hall used to get in program money and what it would get as a cultural institution.
"Some people say Claire Shulman is the Golda Meir of Queens," said John S. Dyson, the outgoing Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and Finance, responsible for cultural financing. "I say Golda Meir was the Claire Shulman of Israel."
She began soon after the stately building on Northern Boulevard was turned over to the Flushing Council on Culture and the Arts in 1991, with a mission to turn it into a cultural community center. The hall had fallen into despicable disrepair during the 1980's while it was subleased by an insurance executive.
Mrs. Shulman has pumped more than $7 million of Queens borough money into the renovation of the hall. The first floor, which is complete, is now showing memorabilia from the 1964 World's Fair, including Barbie dolls, neon signs and model space rockets.
Not quite the Picasso exhibit, perhaps, but that isn't the point.
"They have really put their time in," Mr. Bourscheidt said.
Ms. Daykin, the chairwoman of the Cultural Institutions Group said: "If the city in its infinite wisdom has analyzed the programming content and deemed it worthy, then it's not for me to say. It's important for the borough of Queens to be identified as having major institutions or what can be considered major institutions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Flushing Town Hall, which has been given the title "Cultural Institution" by the city, is currently showing an exhibit of memorabilia from the 1964 World's Fair. An elementary-school class toured the exhibit yesterday. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Living Desk 

LENGTH: 1606 words

HEADLINE: AT LUNCH WITH: Julie Salamon;
Growing Up in Ohio In the Shadow Of the Holocaust

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
FOR a moment, Julie Salamon seemed to be speaking in contradictions.
Her mother and father were survivors of the Auschwitz-Birkenau and Dachau death camps, and naturally, when she was growing up in southern Ohio, the Holocaust hovered in the background, a silent specter. Then again, the horrors of the Nazi era commanded little attention at home. 
 As she filled in details about her family over lunch at a SoHo bistro, it became clear there was nothing contradictory here at all, only a reminder that life's important tales are rarely neat.
"The Holocaust was very present in our household, but never in a personal way, never 'this happened to me,' " said Ms. Salamon, who has described what she calls her "family's search for a rightful place" in a new book called "The Net of Dreams." "I couldn't begin to tell you the moment I first knew about it. All I know is that I never didn't know about it. Nobody talked about it. That's the great mystery. I know I never had a discussion with my father about concentration camps -- ever, ever. There was only one moment with my father that I can even identify with the Holocaust, and that was when I was about 15 or 16."
That was when her father, Dr. Alexander Salamon, was asked to take part in a Holocaust memorial ceremony in Cincinnati, 60 miles west of Seaman, the tiny farm town where the family settled in 1953, the year Ms. Salamon was born.
"He had to go up and light a candle," she said. "My father was this tall, handsome, cool guy. And when he went up to light the candle, his hand was shaking so hard that I thought he was going to blow the candle out. I remember sitting there, watching him so completely overcome by grief.
"I just thought: 'I can't believe it. There is something going on in this man that I don't know about, and it's so sad and so horrible.' We never had discussed it."
By contrast, her mother was a talker. But insights did not flow freely from Lilly Salamon. "She would start telling a story," her daughter said, "and might say, 'Oh, when we were in the camp . . . ' She would talk about it almost like Girl Scout camp. But she would never finish the story. She would always be getting up to go do something."
It was left to an intensely curious girl to find out for herself what this ever-present but little-discussed cataclysm was about.
"Since I was very, very young, I was obsessed with reading about the Holocaust," she said. "It was way beyond my comprehension, but I was obsessed."
"The Net of Dreams," whose title is borrowed from a line in William Styron's "Lie Down in Darkness," traces the odyssey of Alexander and Lilly -- Americanized from the original Sanyi and Szimi -- from their hometown in what is now Ukraine to the camps and then on to the postwar United States.
After a false start as a general practitioner in New York, Dr. Salamon found his rightful place in Seaman (population, 714), where Jews were as scarce as skyscrapers. But something about the rolling farmland evoked the Carpathian foothills of his boyhood. There he found peace.
It is hard to imagine a topic further removed from the one Ms. Salamon has since taken on in a novella she is writing, "a fairy tale," as she describes it, about the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center. She wasn't eager, though, to talk much about the new work.
The focus instead was on her family and, not surprisingly, on growing up in the shadow of the Holocaust, a subject familiar to her lunch companion, who grew up in New York among many survivors from Europe and their American-born children.
Ms. Salamon, who was a movie reviewer for The Wall Street Journal for 11 years, until 1994, sets the stage for her story with a visit to Auschwitz, which she and her mother made three years ago.
On the way, they called on Steven Spielberg, who was then shooting "Schindler's List."
Uh-oh, you think, here comes another Holocaust book, with glitzy Hollywood frosting to boot. But that isn't it. It is mostly a story about family and searching for roots. Sanyi and Szimi are not held forth as Victims, as though that was what defined them.
"What's interesting is that they went through the Holocaust and then had a full life afterward," Ms. Salamon said. "My father was a beloved doctor in a poor community, who never talked about his experience and never asked for a thing. My parents never took reparations from the Germans because my father didn't want any pity."
Doc, as he was known in Seaman, died in 1971. A more dominant presence in the book is Lilly, a strong-willed woman with her own built-in contradictions. Julie, the younger of her two children, both daughters, calls her an "undominating Jewish mother," in no way overprotective and convinced that things will turn out for the best.
Yet, her mother also carries around half-eaten sandwiches in her purse, just in case. You never know.
"There was a book party for 'Net of Dreams,' and the hostess had these incredible cookies made," Ms. Salamon said, ignoring her cheese-and-peppers omelet to concentrate on the story.
"The waiters were carrying them around, and I was talking and talking and didn't have a chance to get one. So I asked one of the waiters if he had any more cookies, and he said, 'Well, there's this lady over there who took a whole big pile of them and put them in her purse.' I started laughing and said, 'Oh, I bet that's my mother.' "
It was.
"I think there is something about her that always wants to make sure we're all provided for," she said.
Ms. Salamon picked this restaurant, Frontiere, on Prince Street, because she likes it and because it is a short walk from Sullivan Street, where she has lived since 1976, a year after her arrival in New York. It is also not far from Public School 3 on Hudson Street. She knew she would be cutting it close to pick up her daughter, Roxie, 6, in first grade. A son, Eli, was born in 1994 while she was working on the book.
SoHo seems a far cry from Seaman. But Ms. Salamon finds something small-town about her block, where "there's still a very homey atmosphere."
"I'm going to be one of those old ladies hanging out the window," she said, with one of the many smiles that crossed her oval face, crowned by a helmet of dark hair.
For a critic, usually no stranger to lacerating prose, she showed no trace of sarcasm. Stories poured forth in an almost girlish voice, sentences often curling up at the end as though they were questions.
Until persuaded by an editor to focus on her parents' journeys, she said, she was going to write about life in Seaman. It is a pretty town, she said, but also a place that time and the interstate have passed by. Like so many other dots on the American map, it struggles with recessions and shuttered stores and bored teen-agers, who go to Cincinnati to hang out at a mall.
By now, Ms. Salamon is used to wise-guy New Yorkers, like the fellow who took her to lunch, who find implausible the idea of Jews in Smalltown, U.S.A.
"Jews from the Midwest are different from New York Jews," she allowed.
"You're probably nicer," her companion said.
"We are nicer," she agreed. "Because we can't help it. We're probably more boring, but we are nicer. We've got those Midwest manners."
"Being Jewish in Seaman was strange," she continued. Not that there was hostility, she said. Far from it. "But it was a very Protestant environment, to put it mildly," she added. "I went to Presbyterian Sunday school when I was a little kid. They did the Old Testament up until first grade. Then when they moved into the New Testament, my parents yanked us out before we came home singing, 'Jesus loves me.' "
For college, Ms. Salamon went to Tufts University, where she met her future husband, Bill Abrams, an executive at ABC-TV. She graduated from New York University Law School in 1978. But well before getting her degree, she realized the law was not for her. Journalism beckoned, and she signed on at The Wall Street Journal, starting out on the commodities beat.
At first, she knew so little that she mixed up commodities and condiments. She still recalls it as her stint as "the ketchup reporter."
But the ketchup started to run thin. In 1983, looking for something new, Ms. Salamon became intrigued by The Journal's plans for a new arts page. A film reviewer was needed. "Literally a day before they started the page, they hired me," she said. "I think they were trying to decide whether to hire a name person or a cheap person.
"I was the cheap person."
It sounds like a great job for a self-described cinema buff -- going to movies all the time. Don't kid yourself, Ms. Salamon cautioned as tea arrived. "When you see seven movies a week, you can be guaranteed that at least six of them are going to be horrid or just not interesting. I found that it wasn't new anymore."
Staying fresh is important to her.
She branched out in 1988 by writing "White Lies," an autobiographical novel. Three years later, she produced "The Devil's Candy," a book about the making of the movie flop based on "The Bonfire of the Vanities." Now, there's the novella about the Rockefeller Center tree.
That's some leap, from Dachau to Christmas.
"Once you know the lay of the land, you want to move someplace else," Ms. Salamon said.
Her parents moved many times before coming to this country, under extraordinary duress. Their daughter the writer has led quite a different life. "I've lived in the same place for 20 years now, and I lived in Ohio for 18 years," she said. "So in my personal life, I don't keep picking the wagon up and moving."
"But in my work life," she added, "that is what I do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Focus on family and roots: Julie Salamon at a Barnes & Noble book signing. (Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Calm in Palestine

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Traveling through the West Bank two weeks ago, I drove from Hebron to Bethlehem, through Ramallah and up to Nablus. What you see is a region racked by soaring unemployment among Palestinian youths and an economy sapped by the security measures imposed by Israel and Yasir Arafat. What you see are growing Israeli settlements around Jerusalem and new Israeli roads dissecting the West Bank more than ever. What you see is a grim picture -- and I couldn't be more optimistic.
That's right. Because if you look at the surface conditions in the West Bank today you could only conclude that all the ingredients are there for an explosion. But it's not exploding. In fact, in an odd way it's sort of quiet. There's a story in that quiet. 
 One explanation is that while the West Bank is still a complicated, sometimes messy weave of Israeli and Palestinian police, roads and areas of control, the fact that Palestinian institutions are now increasingly running Palestinian lives is a real calming factor. I was driving out of Bethlehem the other day with a Palestinian journalist, Khaled Abu Aker, and we went the wrong way down a one-way street. A uniformed Palestinian policeman stopped us. Khaled jumped out of his car and started shouting back at the policeman, saying that he was in a hurry and needed to go the wrong way. That was not a discussion he would have ever had with Israeli soldiers. In the end, the Palestinian policeman calmly prevailed and we turned around. But Khaled almost seemed to enjoy the encounter. Palestinians have never really had the luxury of shouting at their own policemen.
Another explanation for the relative calm is that the peace process has worked. It has forged a Palestinian silent majority that believes the peace negotiations, with all their shortcomings, are generally moving in the right direction and deserve a little patience. Save for the extremist fringe, Palestinians in the West Bank are deliberately being quiet now to help Shimon Peres get re-elected -- cooperation that would have been unthinkable five years ago.
Said Kanan, director of the Center For Palestine Research, says the change in Palestinian attitudes is easily tracked in his group's polls. In November 1994, 57 percent of Palestinians said they supported armed attacks against Israeli civilians, while 34 percent were opposed. By March 1996, 21 percent of Palestinians supported such armed attacks (still too high), but 70 percent were opposed. In January 1994, 51 percent of Palestinians supported negotiations with Israel, while 40 percent were opposed. By March 1996, 78 percent supported negotiations and only 16 percent were opposed.
Aaron Miller, one of the State Department's top Middle East experts, argues that these numbers attest to two fundamental changes that have occurred in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. The first, he contends, is that "the conflict is no longer between the Palestinian mainstream and the Israeli mainstream, but between the Palestinian extreme and the Israeli extreme." The second, he says, is that the historic shift of Palestinian political life and leadership from outside the West Bank and Gaza -- places like Beirut and Tunis -- to inside the territories, where people have to deal with the real problems on the ground, "has produced a much greater pragmatism in Palestinian politics."
But the silence of the Palestinian silent majority is not only a reflection of assent, insists Khalil Shikaki, a leading political scientist at the Center For Palestine Research. "Repression by Arafat's security services also has been used to silence the opposition," he said. "Arafat's security services are creating a culture of doubt about what you can and cannot say. I am afraid we will duplicate the Arab regimes around us."
But this relative quiet, whether voluntary or forced, is based on the assumption that Mr. Peres will be re-elected and talks culminate in a Palestinian state of some kind. That is the light at the end of the tunnel that Palestinians are groping toward. If they discover that that light is instead a train coming at them -- in the form of a Likud government and more Jewish settlements -- then look out. If we have learned anything since 1967 it is that nothing in the West Bank is irreversible -- not Jordanian influence, not Israeli control, not Palestinian rejectionism and certainly, certainly, not quiet.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Atlanta 1996: Olympic Profile;
For Czech Athlete, Payoff Is on Field

BYLINE: By SAMANTHA STEVENSON 

DATELINE: DEL MAR, Calif., May 21

 BODY:
They told the building manager they wanted the apartment for only six months, but Robert Zmelik and his fiancee were fighting a losing battle. They were from the former Czechoslovakia, the manager said, without employment. They could be drug dealers. Their application was turned down.
Then Zmelik pulled a shiny Olympic gold medal from his pocket. They got the apartment. 
 Olympic triumph has its benefits, and for Zmelik, the 1992 decathlon champion, the apartment north of downtown San Diego was one. But few other payoffs have come.Zmelik wasn't counting on the economic problems that struck when the Czechs and the Slovaks divided his homeland, and the money-making opportunities he envisioned in America never came for him.
Now, as he battles back from injuries and prepares to defend his title at the Summer Games in Atlanta, the man who once said, "First comes the gold medal, then comes the money," is driven by more than the pursuit of riches and fame.
"Czech is like this, and America is like this," Zmelik, 27, said in his halting English. "Maybe in dreams I make a million. Some guys have won the Olympics and finished with sports, and made millions and millions. Me, I won and I still compete."
"Robert still has the innocence in sports," said Durdam Rocherolle, a friend and aspiring decathlete Zmelik trains with. "Instead of saying, 'How can I make money everyday?' he says, 'How can I improve?' His sport is spiritual. He knows that things aren't always easy, and he only focuses on the positive."
It doesn't seem long ago that Zmelik won the 1992 Olympic decathlon in Barcelona, Spain. He finished with 8,611 points, comfortably ahead of Antonio Penalver of Spain, who had 8,412, and the United States' favorite, Dave Johnson, with 8,309.
But since then, multiple injuries have beset Zmelik, and last July he finished 13th at the world championships. In September, he fell on a tennis court, diving for a ball like his hero, Boris Becker, and tore two ligaments in his shoulder, nearly costing himself his career.
"I know he's been dealing with injuries," Dave Johnson said from his home outside of Los Angeles. "A couple of Americans called me after his meet last weekend in Italy. He posted 82 in the rain, which is an 85 in good weather. He's back, if he can stay healthy."
Johnson was referring to Zmelik's performance in his first pre-Olympic competition, a Multi-Star track evening in Desenzano, Italy. With a healed shoulder Zmelik amassed 8,232 points, which more than meets the Olympic requirement for points needed to compete in the decathlon and sets him in good position to be among the top three decathletes representing the Czechs in Atlanta. Zmelik trains on a track overlooking the Pacific Ocean, at the Shiley Sports and Health Center of Scripps Clinic, north of downtown San Diego. His schedule is monitored by Dean Brittenham, the Shiley director. Each day, Zmelik arrives at 9 A.M. to begin eight hours of training with his fiancee, Andrea Sollarova, a retired 3,000-meter runner from Slovakia, and Rocherolle.
"Robert is the favorite," said Brittenham, who works on speed and quickness with other Olympic athletes in track and field and volleyball. "I think he's the most powerful athlete I've ever worked with."
Brittenham and Rocherolle have tried to help Zmelik pay for his training. Rocherolle's parents have lent financial support, and Brittenham has received help from various companies. Zmelik has a contract with Reebok for shoes and clothing, but no agent, only well-meaning friends. He trains apart from the Czech federation. "Every athlete prepares alone," Zmelik said. "They help me with the shot-put and discus, how I look. The federation only cares how I compete."
Zmelik and Sollarova have kept their apartment in Prague, where they will return to be married after the Olympics.
Zmelik was born in the village of Ivan, in Moravia, a town of 1,000 people, that he describes as "like Idaho." His family members were good athletes, and his older brother, Vilem, inspired the 7-year-old Zmelik to compete in track and field. It was Bruce Jenner's success in the 1976 Montreal Olympics that set his mind on the decathalon.
As a teen-ager, Zmelik was sent to a sports boarding school, where he would become a part of the Czech federation men's team at age 17. "It was a very hard life," Zmelik said. "But after a few years, it was healthy for my life."
Zmelik believes he is still that small boy who got angry if he came in second. But, he refuses to talk about the marks he needs to win in Atlanta. "If I talk about what I want, I lose power," Zmelik said. "I know I will be better. We will see."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Zmelik took the gold in the decathlon in the 1992 Olympics. (Alan Decker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: France's Army Keeps Grip in African Ex-Colonies

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: LIBREVILLE, Gabon

 BODY:
Week in and week out for years, French sentries have manned the lookout towers at a military base here, and French soldiers have drilled behind high concrete walls topped with barbed wire.
Despite such vigilance, France's military outpost here, 3,300 miles from Paris, is not guarding some hostile border or protecting against a foreign threat. 
 Instead, to judge from the base's setting, hard against one of Africa's most extravagant presidential mansions, among Paris's top priorities here is protecting Gabon's autocratic leader, Omar Bongo, who was installed with French help in 1968.
With the end of the cold war, France has begun the difficult process of wrestling with the future size and shape of its large standing army. Earlier this year President Jacques Chirac announced sweeping reforms that would alter longstanding French deployments in Europe and gradually introduce an all-volunteer force.
Left unchanged, at least for now, however, are African commitments like these that date to independence 36 years ago. Besides Gabon, French troops are based in the Ivory Coast, Cameroon, Senegal, Central African Republic, Chad, Djibouti and the Indian Ocean islands of Reunion and Mayotte.
In addition to the countries where it has troops, France has military cooperation agreements with Mauritania, Mali, Burkina Faso, Benin, Togo, Equatorial Guinea, Congo, Zaire, Rwanda and Burundi.
Since its 1964 intervention in Gabon, France has intervened militarily on the continent every other year on average. Paris has repeatedly sent troops into action in Chad, flown in paratroopers to rescue French and Belgian nationals in Zaire and help put down an insurrection there, and used its forces to replace political leaders in the Central African Republic.
[France said May 21 that it was trying to arrange a settlement to an army uprising in the Central African Republic, Reuters reported. French troops had been patrolling the capital, Bangui, at the Government's request, but most of the troops retreated to their bases, witnesses said, as fighting and looting continued.
[A French military plane flew out with 138 French nationals, and an American military plane was used to evacuate 13 Americans as American marines arrived to help. French troops were flown from Gabon and Chad to reinforce those already in the Central African Republic.]
In response to worried appeals by clients across the continent over rumors of an impending cutback of French troops, Mr. Chirac's Government pledged that Paris's military presence in Africa, totaling some 8,700 soldiers, would not be reduced.
If the announcement soothed Paris's main political allies , however, it has also stirred a public debate in Africa's increasingly free press and among opposition parties about France's mission on the continent.
Late last year, France's Minister for Foreign Assistance, Jacques Godfrain, explained the sense of his country's continuing military presence in Africa in terms of stabilizing democracies. Paris "will intervene each time an elected democratic power is overthrown by a coup d'etat if a military cooperation agreement exists," he said.
Given that France had never done such a thing and that most of its African-based troops are billeted in countries of dubious democratic credentials, Mr. Godfrain's remarks unleashed a storm of skeptical commentary throughout West and Central Africa.
The skepticism turned to derision when Niger's first democratically elected Government fell to a military coup in February. At the time, France, which has a defense treaty with Niger, said it regretted the development but would not intervene.
"What justifies this kind of presence?" asked an editorialist in the Ivory Coast daily Le Jour. "An external threat? Nothing could be less certain." For the Ivorian newspaper, and for commentators throughout this region, France's presence here has more to do with perpetuating Paris's predominance in an area that it has long considered its "natural" zone of influence.
"Only the African continent gives France the illusion of being a great power," another Ivorian editorialist wrote, under the headline "France Comes to the Rescue of Dictators," in response to Mr. Godfrain's remarks.
Some countries where French troops are stationed, like the Ivory Coast and Gabon, represent rich markets for France or, like Niger and Chad, are current or potentially important sources of strategic resources such as uranium and oil.
For many experts on African affairs, the history of France's military role in post-colonial Africa can be neatly condensed in the experience of Gabon, where Paris launched the first of many full-fledged interventions in 1964.
When Gabon's first President, Leon M'ba, was overthrown in a broadly popular military coup in 1964, French paratroopers were flown in to reinstate Mr. M'ba, whose devotion to France was legendary.
Mr. M'ba was soon weakened by illness, and by France's promotion of a young aide, Omar Bongo, to near figurehead status. Jacques Foccart, the chief adviser on Africa to the French President at the time, Charles de Gaulle, wrote in his memoirs that Paris literally auditioned Mr. Bongo for the role of head of state, which he assumed in 1968 upon Mr. M'ba's death.
Shortly after taking office, Mr. Bongo banned opposition parties in Gabon, and ruled unchallenged until a democratic reform movement began sweeping much of Africa in 1990. With his huge mansions throughout Gabon and around the world, diplomats say Mr. Bongo has used the country's large oil revenues to become one of the continent's wealthiest leaders.
Diplomats say corporations and businessmen from France, which retains an unusually high degree of influence here, even by the standards of its former colonies, have also done well by Gabon's oil-based economy.
To protect that investment, from their bases in Gabon, the 600 or so French troops here have intervened twice, in 1990 and 1994, to help put down civil disturbances directed against Mr. Bongo's rule.
A second wave of riots occurred after Mr. Bongo declared himself the winner of an election that international observers called "a very flawed exercise," with 51 percent of the vote.
These days, Mr. Bongo, who is also protected by Moroccan security units and privately hired former French military officers, never goes anywhere without first closing off nearby streets to traffic.
"There is no threat to Gabon other than the disaffection of the population towards its leader," said one Gabonese businessman who is sympathetic to the opposition. "When someone needs this kind of protection, that should tell you immediately that something is badly wrong."
For diplomats of other Western nations, France's high-profile security role in countries like Gabon has more to do with preserving Paris's privileged access to business opportunities than it does with questions of democracy.
"You could talk about the French presence for hours and hours, but it comes down to two things: prestige and business," said a Western diplomat here. "And they are absolutely determined not to let go of either."
Though more and more Africans have begun to openly criticize France leveraging its military presence and tight network of political ties in Africa to maintain a commercial grip on its foreign colonies, French officials have been frankly unapologetic.
"When we aid a country, we must have a minimum in return," said Bernard Debre, a former minister of foreign assistance, in an interview with the Paris-based magazine Jeune Afrique. "For France, Africa is also a market. Not a captive market, certainly, but not a sieve either."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Three decades after most of its former colonies in Africa became independent, France maintains a significant presence there. French troops paraded with local veterans in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, on Bastille Day last year. (Robert Grossman for the New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENT;
New School Confers Tips And Degrees

 BODY:
A second day of record-breaking heat in New York could not dampen the spirits of the 904 graduates at the New School for Social Research's 60th commencement yesterday morning. Their spirits were helped in part by the setting, the cool sanctuary of Riverside Church.
The traditional solemnity of the opening ceremony and speeches was eventually eclipsed by cheers, photo flashes and screams that erupted from the church's balconies as the commencement progressed. 
 One student wore a miniature dressmaker's mannequin on her mortarboard. One doctoral student collected his diploma with a pipe in his mouth, and Florence Nkosinkulu from South Africa accepted her master's in human resources accompanied by her 3-week-old daughter.
The president of the New School, Jonathan F. Fanton, giving his 14th commencement speech, offered the graduates six "practical tips," beginning with "Do what you want to do; be what you want to be."
Among those receiving honorary degrees were United States Senator Claiborne Pell; Kitty Carlisle Hart, emeritus chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts; Ornette Coleman, the musician and composer, and Robert A. Dahl, emeritus professor of political science at Yale University. President Fanton said Ms. Hart and Mr. Coleman symbolized "the artistic standards" the graduates should aspire to.
Professor John Eatwell, chairman of the New School's economics department, referred to the ceremony as the "end of the beginning," as he encouraged students to be true to their intellectual inheritance, and reminded them that their education had equipped them with the capacity to change the poverty and unemployment that surrounded them.

HEADLINE: A Defensive McCaughey Ross On Offensive Against Accuser

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
First came reports of Gov. George E. Pataki's displeasure with her. Then came more open slights like the removal of her security detail. And now, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross is facing problems much closer to home -- a former housekeeper has accused her of harassment and of neglecting to pay some taxes on her wages.
Yesterday, the Lieutenant Governor called an unusual news conference at City Hall to declare: Enough already. 
 Ms. McCaughey Ross vehemently denied the housekeeper's charges and, in a flamboyant gesture, slammed $1.44 down onto a table, saying that was the total amount she owed in unemployment insurance payments to the State Department of Labor. Waving copies of state documents and canceled checks to prove that she had no past due payments and owed only $1.44, she said: "I'd like to pay that right now. Here it is. That's what I owe."
Ms. McCaughey Ross's problems with a former housekeeper, Erica Krstec, first surfaced on Monday when The New York Post ran a front-page headline proclaiming "Betsy Is a Bully." In The Post's article, Mrs. Krstec contended that Ms. McCaughey Ross had been verbally abusive to her and had left her stranded in Ms. McCaughey Ross's summer home in Southampton, L.I., without food or transportation. Mrs. Krstec also accused the Lieutenant Governor of not paying required taxes for her salary.
The Post also quoted from Labor Department documents that concluded that Ms. McCaughey Ross had not obtained a registration number from the agency, a necessary step before paying taxes for her employees. An obviously shaken Ms. McCaughey Ross said repeatedly yesterday that all those charges were untrue. "I have fully complied with all Federal and state regulations and tax requirements for my employees," she said.
She also released a letter from the State Department of Labor confirming she had registered as an employer of a domestic worker and had filed all required payments and reports. In her news conference, Ms. McCaughey Ross explained that she dismissed Mrs. Krstec after 10 months of employment because Mrs. Krstec had done a very poor job of supervising Ms. McCaughey Ross's children.
Ms. McCaughey Ross said that, on many occasions while Mrs. Krstec worked for her, she would get home late from work only to learn that Mrs. Krstec had no idea where her daughters were. On other occasions, Mrs. Krstec would tell her that she had allowed Ms. McCaughey Ross's daughters, now 12 and 14, to go to places Ms. McCaughey Ross felt were inappropriate.
"Not knowing where my children are late in the evening, an 11-year-old girl, hearing that she's been allowed to go to a pool hall or to areas of Central Park where drug addicts and drug dealers congregate," Ms. McCaughey Ross said. "Those are unsafe conditions for an 11-year-old girl and I think any mother listening or watching would agree with that."
The public battle is just the latest in a series of incidents that have made Ms. McCaughey Ross one of the most visible Lieutenant Governors in the state's history.
Mr. Pataki and Ms. McCaughey Ross have had a tense relationship for much of his administration. But the problems escalated earlier this year after The Post reported that Ms. McCaughey Ross was plotting to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Governor's friend and political mentor, in the 1998 Republican primary. Also this year, the Governor removed her state police security detail amid allegations that she had asked the troopers to run personal errands for her.
Ms. McCaughey Ross would not speculate on why the latest charges had emerged. "It would be unfair to point blame," she said. "I am concerned, though, about these anonymous charges referred to in The New York Post from State Labor Department officials. Once again, anonymous charges from members of state government that are untrue."

HEADLINE: In New Challenge to Peace Plan, Bosnia May Pull Out of Election

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, May 21

 BODY:
In a new challenge to the American-brokered peace in the former Yugoslavia, the Bosnian Government threatened today to withdraw from elections unless voting rules were drastically changed and NATO arrested the most prominent Serbian war criminals.
The elections, scheduled for Sept. 14, are intended to underpin a stable democracy here and allow the withdrawal of 60,000 NATO peacekeeping troops. But in an interview today, Ejup Ganic, the Vice President of the Muslim-led Government, said the elections would not be held unless Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, Bosnian Serb leaders indicted for genocide, were removed from power. He also insisted that voting rules be changed to prevent Serbs from gaining electoral control over Muslim towns and villages they seized in the war. 
 In a separate interview, the chief prosecutor of the international war crimes tribunal broke a long public silence and warned that NATO's refusal to arrest the Bosnian Serb leaders threatened to undermine the precarious peace in the region. [Page A8.]
Vice President Ganic declared: "We will not participate in these elections unless the rules change. The danger of these elections, if they are not done correctly, is that they will verify ethnic cleansing. They will become a blueprint for how to ethnically expel people."
The elections are intended to play a central role in the reintegration of the Croat, Muslim and Serb entities that now make up Bosnia. Senior Bosian officials say that if the elections lock in the virtual ethnic partition of the country left by the war, renewed fighting is almost certain as displaced Muslims battle to regain their homes.
The need to begin preparing for elections has been the principal obsession of all parties in the civil war here, as well as the international officials trying to hammer this splintered country back together.
The Bosnian Serbs hope the elections will ratify their control over nearly half the country. The Muslim-dominated Government wants to use the elections to reassert control over all of Bosnia, and to hold the international overseers here to the stated goal of the Dayton accords, which is to preserve a unified country.
International officials, the United Nations and the United States all say they support the Dayton goal, but have so far been unwilling to risk conflict by removing Dr. Karadzic and Mr. Mladic, both indicted war criminals who under the accord cannot take part in political life.
The Bosnian Government raised its objections today with the Swiss Foreign Minister, Flavio Cotti, the chairman of the Organization of Security and Co-Operation in Europe, the body that must certify whether by July 14 conditions exist for free and fair elections. But the organization's officials said the Government did not hand them an ultimatum.
"The Bosnian Government expressed these issues as concerns," said Franaz Egle, the spokesman for the Swiss Foreign Ministry, "not as conditions which must be met before participating in the elections."
Still, Mr. Cotti and other outside officials have said they agree that fair elections are improbable with Dr. Karadzic still in power.
An American official in Washington acknowledged that the elections were "the most important element of implementing the peace plan." He interpreted Mr. Ganic's remarks as a bargaining tactic, adding, "I don't believe he's seriously contemplating following through with the threat."
Mr. Ganic, however, was emphatic in the interview today, conducted in English in the presidential offices, that his Government would find it impossible to take part in elections unless the changes took place. He said holding elections under the current conditions would be "obscene."
Bosnian Government officials said that free and fair elections would be impossible as long as Dr. Karadzic and Mr. Mladic remained in power, even behind the scenes.
The Government also worries that under somewhat ambiguous election rules, the Serbs might use large concentrations of Serbian refugees to win political control of local governments in traditionally Muslim towns that the Serbs won by force. The rules allow people to register to votein their former homes, or in places in which they now live. Thus Serbs who have moved into Muslims' homes in towns like Srebrenica, where Muslims were driven out and many were massacred, have a right to vote in those areas. In most cases the Serbs now outnumber the Muslims, making a Muslim return to power in such places impossible, even if absentee voters cast their ballots.
"Today Srebrenica is packed with Serbs from the Sarajevo suburbs and the Muslims are gone," said Mr. Ganic. "If the Serbs are allowed to vote in Srebrenica they will elect a Serb Mayor and a Serb city council. This will give the official stamp of approval to ethnic cleansing.
"The Serbs in places like Srebrenica should go and vote in the places they used to live, not in the villages and towns they took from Muslims and now occupy. Let them go back to the Sarajevo suburbs and elect a Serb Mayor."
But while officials of the Organization of Security and Co-Operation in Europe said they recognized the "contradiction" implicit in the voting procedures they also said that the Muslim-led Government had agreed to the rules, and that change at this stage was impossible.
"There was a long struggle over this issue," said Peter Burkhard, a Swiss official involved in the elections. He said the Bosnian Government had argued strongly in favor of requiring people to vote in the places they lived before the war broke out, but that the Serbs had argued for allowing people to choose, instead, to vote in places in which they were newly settled. But both parties agreed in April to the current procedures, he said.
By all accounts, many of the conditions set out by the Dayton agreement for free elections have not been met. They include freedom of movement for all people in Bosnia, free access by the opposition to news organizations, the establishment of independent news media, freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and a return by refugees and the displaced to their prewar homes.
The Dayton agreement, while prohibiting Dr. Karadzic from running for office, does not stop him from being in power while elections take place. Officials of the Organization of Security and Co-Operation in Europe said it was conceivable that they would certify that conditions for elections were acceptable, although Dr. Karadzic remained in power.
The protest by the Bosnian Government comes on the heels of the failure by the international community, led by Carl Bildt, who is overseeing the carrying out of the peace plan, to push Dr. Karadzic out of office. Mr. Bildt and Western officials have asked the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosovic, to exert pressure on Dr. Karadzic to step down. And Western officials have threatened to withhold economic aid if Mr. Milosovic does not push the Bosnian Serb leader from power.
But so far Mr. Milosovic appears to have little interest in directly challenging Dr. Karadzic. Western diplomats said it seems he sees the September elections as the vehicle for sidelining Dr. Karadzic.
Dr. Karadzic, in a consolidation of his hold on power, recently removed more moderate leaders, who had worked with the international community, and replaced them with hard-line followers. He has also proposed holding a referendum, before the elections, to show the rest of the world that most Serbs support him. While such a referendum would not be recognized as valid by the international community, it might give Dr. Karadzic the ammunition he needs to sabotage the elections.

HEADLINE: Only the Amex Manages to Keep On Going

BYLINE: The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated yesterday in a decline led by oil and computer companies.
Trading was restrained before and after a meeting by the Federal Reserve's policy makers, who, as expected, left short-term interest rates unchanged. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.56 points, to 5,736.26, ending a nine-session winning streak that added more than 325 points to the Dow. On Monday, the Dow jumped more than 61, setting its first record high since early April.
The American Stock Exchange rose to its fourth straight high, but most broad indicators finished lower. The Amex composite rose 2.87, to 612.23.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.39 point, to 672.76, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 3.69, to 1,244.42, ending a three-session string of new highs.
Bond prices edged lower after a report by Johnson Redbook on weekly retail sales showed surprising strength. Bond yields move in opposite directions from their prices, and the yield on 30-Year Treasuries -- a sensitive barometer of inflation fears -- rose to 6.85 percent from 6.83 percent on Monday.
The rise in interest rates helped spur some profit taking in stocks, said Steven Goldman, market strategist at Weeden & Company in Greenwich, Conn.
"We're somewhat overbought," he said. "Looking back, we're up sharply in the last two weeks." He noted that the S.& P. 500 rose 5.5 percent in that period.
After leading Monday's rally on a sharp increase in crude oil prices, energy stocks led the market lower as investors took some profits.
The Dow's three oil issues were among the four biggest losers in the blue-chip average. Texaco fell 1 7/8, to 85; Chevron 1 1/2, to 60 1/2, and Exxon 1 1/8, to 86 1/8. They represented a combined loss of more than 14 points on the Dow.
Computer stocks also retreated. Microsoft lost 1 5/8, to 115 1/8; Cisco Systems 1 1/8, to 55 1/8, and Intel 3/4, 70 1/4.
Among individual issues, Wyndham Hotel, rose to 22 5/8 on its first day of trading, up from its initial offering of 16.
Gucci Group climbed 5 1/4, to 70 7/8, after the Italian company reported that sales nearly doubled in the first quarter.
Dayton Hudson surged 4, to 106, on better-than-expected first-quarter profits.
 Compuware jumped 6 5/8, to 37 1/8, after reporting a jump in quarterly earnings.
 Iomega closed at 43 3/8, up 21/16 , a day after the company annouced a 2-for-1 split.
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, added 2 3/8, to 59; Lehman Brothers raised its rating on the company.
Republic Environmental Systems, surged more than 100 percent from 10 1/4, to 20 1/4. The stock jumped for the second straight day after news that Alliance Holding would merge its Century Surety Group with Republic in exchange for a 51 percent stake and options to buy 2.1 million more shares in the waste cleanup company.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Bill Would Extend Pensions in Small Business

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
House Republicans plan to pass legislation on Wednesday that would make it easier for small businesses to offer retirement savings plans for their 36 million workers. And in a break from decades of pension policy, the bill would let owners reap tax benefits for themselves even if their workers do not participate.
The retirement provisions are part of a $7.5 billion bill filled with changes sought by owners of small businesses to simplify tax, pension and other rules that bedevil companies with fewer than 100 workers. 
 For example, over seven years the bill would increase to $25,000 from $17,500 the value of equipment purchases that can be deducted immediately, instead of being depreciated over several years. The bill would also phase out tax breaks for companies that build factories in Puerto Rico and reinvest the profits on the island, using the increased revenues to offset the small business tax breaks.
These provisions will provide political cover for Republicans who oppose another aspect of the bill, increasing the minimum wage by 90 cents an hour over two years, to $5.15. Polls have shown that raising the minimum wage is widely popular despite concerns expressed by small-business owners and many economists that it would cost jobs.
Republicans, citing a rising public concern about retirement income and the safety of nest eggs, sought to focus attention today on changes to pension law.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the proposals would help workers in small business by "making it easier to get a secure pension and by providing increased security for existing retirement accounts." And he said all 120 million working Americans stood to benefit from one or more of the two dozen pension changes in the bill.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich called the bill "a watered down version of what President Clinton has already proposed." And he noted that it did not require accountants or other professionals who find indications that retirement savings are being embezzled to report their suspicions to the Government.
But the centerpiece of the bill is what the Republicans call a Simple pension plan for small businesses, which is short for "savings incentive match plan for employees."
Companies with fewer than 100 workers at any time during a year could create a sort of mini-401(k) plan in which workers could save up to $6,000, compared with $9,500 under existing 401(k) plans.
Existing 401(k)'s require expensive and complex tests comparing the contributions of highly paid and low-wage workers to insure that tax benefits do not flow only to the highly paid. In Simple plans, these tests would not be necessary if the employer either deposited 2 percent of each employee's pay into the employee's account or matched dollar-for-dollar the first 3 percent that employees saved. Employers who choose the matching option could reduce the match in two of every five years if they fell on hard times.
Under the bill, the owner of a small business could save $6,000 on tax-deferred basis and match the savings with another $6,000, even if none of his or her employees participated in the Simple plan.
A critic of existing pension laws, Karen Ferguson, co-author of "The Pension Book," called the bill "a radical departure from decades of pension policy requiring that lower-paid workers get benefits as a condition of owners and managers' getting tax breaks."
"This is shortsighted, crazy and foodhardy," she said.
Republican staff members said they were confident that millions of workers, even those earning modest wages, would leap at the chance to save money on a tax-advantaged basis for retirement, especially when their money would be matched by their employers.
Mr. Reich noted that the President's proposal would require small- business owners to contribute at least 1 percent of their workers' wages to a retirement savings plan before their own contributions could be tax-deferred.
Another provision of the bill would allow the one in six workers who are employed by nonprofit organizations to have 401(k) accounts. Currently, workers at nonprofit organizations are limited to less generous 403(b) plans.
The bill would also protect the assets of state and local government pension plans from creditors, putting them on the same footing as business and nonprofit pension plans. This provision was added in response to the bankruptcy filing by Orange County, Calif., which focused attention on the disparate treatment of government and business plans.
The bill would also protect truck drivers, carpenters and others who participate in pension plans paid for by groups of employers by making retirement benefits mandatory after five years, the same as the law requires of plans provided by a single employer.
