HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Mixed As Fed Keeps Policy Steady

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were mixed in light trading yesterday as Federal Reserve policy makers left interest rates unchanged, as expected.
Bond prices rose in early trading after a weekly report on retail sales showed weakness, but the price gains faded after another retail survey late in the day showed a sharp rise in sales. 
 Such conflicting reports have fostered uncertainty in the market about the direction of the economy and have bolstered expectations that the Fed will continue its present monetary policy until there is compelling evidence that economic growth is overheating.
"I don't think there is an economist on the Street who thought the Fed would move today," said Nancy J. Kimelman, chief economist and director of research at Technical Data in Boston.
"There are crosscurrents in the data and in the economy as a whole and I imagine that was the subject of great deliberation at the meeting," she said, referring to the meeting of the Fed's policy group, the Federal Open Market Committee. "It has been difficult for the Fed to determine the underlying strength of the economy and the real risk of inflation."
The Fed announced around 2:15 P.M. yesterday that there would be no statement regarding the committee's meeting.
The announcement had little effect on the market. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 5/32 , to 8910/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.85 percent, from 6.83 percent on Monday.
A move by bondholders away from the long end of the market to the relatively safe haven of shorter maturities helped lower the rate on the six-month Treasury bill by a basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.10 percent. The rate on the one-year bill also fell by a basis point, to 5.25 percent.
The market received a lift early in the day after the Bank of Tokyo/ Mitsubishi Schroder reported that its index of chain-store sales had dropped 4 percent for the week ended Saturday. But the Johnson Redbook sales index, which was released in the afternoon, rose 6.1 percent from last month. That index had been expected to show a decline, and bonds immediately gave back some of the day's gains.
Some economists say they expect data later this year will show the economy is not as strong as some recent reports have indicated.
Sung Won Sohn, senior vice president and chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said the current quarter would be the strongest of the year, reflecting inventory buildup. By the second half of the year, he said, the data would begin to show that the economy was too soft.
"We've feasted on short stimulus from mortgage refinance, auto rebates and tax refunds, but all this is behind us now," Mr. Sohn said. "The market is just now beginning to realize this as evidenced by its tone."
Mr. Sohn said he expected that the Fed would not change monetary policy until later this year. Indeed, he expects that interest rates will decline. "The only question is will it be in the second half of 1996, or sometime in the first half of 1997," he said. The Fed will probably keep a low profile until after the elections in November, he said.
Ms. Kimelman of Technical Data said she expected the Fed to be reluctant to act on interest rates because of the election and because "the Fed may still have some egg on its face from the quick easing last December and January."
Robin Mesch, fixed-income-market analyst at Thomson Research of Boston, said, "It looks like bonds will remain in consolidation for the rest of the week." In the futures market, she expects the June bond contract will trade lower at 10825/32 to 1091/32 as the market heads toward a long holiday weekend. At the close of trading yesterday, the June bond contract settled at 10919/32 .

HEADLINE: Time Is Changing The Model S.& L.;
Home Savings Pushes Ahead Into Full-Service Banking

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

DATELINE: ARCADIA, Calif.

 BODY:
The bright California sun filters through the stained-glass windows, creating a reverential mood in this cavernous edifice. Decorated with elaborate mosaics, bronze statues and lots of marble, it is a stolid temple of thrift -- one of many erected by Home Savings of America in affluent suburbs like this one, outside Los Angeles, in the years after World War II.
The ornate branches gathered enough of the growing wealth of Southern California to make Home Savings the nation's largest and in many ways most successful savings and loan. But on this spring afternoon, a slender banner dangling over a half-dozen tellers bears a simple announcement: "We now offer home equity, automotive, personal loans and credit lines." 
 This would hardly be worth noting nearly anywhere else. At Home Savings, though, it is no less than heresy.
Home Savings thrived for more than a century by largely sticking to a simple dogma: harbor the savings of people at or near retirement and funnel the money into home loans for young families. While other giant savings and loans were crashing into ruin, Home and its owner, H. F. Ahmanson & Company, returned even more devoutly to this regime five years ago after a modest but painful diversion into real estate development.
But with those losses and those caused by falling home prices largely behind it, Home is abandoning its creed. Charles R. Rinehart, the 49-year-old chairman of Ahmanson, wants to transform it into a full-service bank with loans, business accounts and the like. Indeed, it will finally add the word "bank" to its name -- probably becoming Home Savings Bank of America -- a decade after similar rechristenings at most other savings and loans.
Mr. Rinehart's goal: to refocus Home Savings on a low- to moderate-income clientele, acknowledging the demographic change in his own customers and, more generally, in California, as well as the competition for the affluent from the state's two giant banks -- Bank of America and Wells Fargo.
Home Savings, in short, has finally discovered that the savings and loan business is fundamentally an anachronism. Traditional savings and loan products -- savings accounts and mortgages -- are now offered on such good terms elsewhere that profits are meager at best. What is more, savings and loan clients are literally dying off: 45 percent of Home's deposits are in the hands of people over 65; their children send their savings to mutual funds.
Congress, meanwhile, is considering merging the savings and loan regulatory system with that for banks, although savings institutions can now offer almost all bank products.
Ahmanson, moreover, must adapt to the changing landscape here. No one expects a return of the surging real estate market that made mortgage lending virtually foolproof. And rising Asian and Hispanic immigration is changing many neighborhoods that Home Savings entered decades ago.
As the banner in Arcadia heralds, Home branches have started making personal loans, and Home has opened finance company offices to lend to an even less affluent population. New offices will be tiny storefront models. Sanctified spaces like the Arcadia branch may be divided, with corners rented out to a Kinkos copy center or a McDonald's Express.
Mr. Rinehart's heresies have not been universally appreciated among Ahmanson's directors or at its headquarters in Irwindale, a bleak patch of gravel pits and beer distributors. And that is why the full dimension of his vision is only now emerging, two years after he took over.
"There was a lot of internal debate," Mr. Rinehart acknowledges. "And in one sense the opponents were kind of right. The idea of getting into a business you don't understand is fraught with peril. But ultimately it became clear to everybody that the business we were in was not viable."
Mr. Rinehart's plan remains fraught with peril. Efficiency drives will mean laying off hundreds of longtime employees. Those who stay will have to adjust to a new regime that values profitability and sales targets, a far cry from the tradition of low-key service.
Even the president, Fredric J. Forster, quit in April in a disagreement about the new strategy. He was quickly replaced by Bruce G. Willison, the highly respected vice chairman of the First Interstate Bancorp, which has just been bought by Wells Fargo & Company.
Other savings and loans, including Great Western, California's second largest, have been trying for years to act more like banks, with mixed results. And Ahmanson is so big, and so late, that its transformation can only be more difficult.
In addition, even if Mr. Rinehart can eventually change Home Savings into more of a bank, he will hardly be home free. Most top banking companies also worry that their business is rapidly deteriorating.
"The best thing you can say about his company over the past few years is they stayed in business when two-thirds of their competitors didn't," said Joseph Jolson, a savings and loan analyst with Montgomery Securities. "Rinehart is a great guy -- young, energetic, open-minded. His problem is he inherited a $50 billion company that structurally has little profitability built in."
[For investors, Ahmanson has been a perpetual disappointment. Its stock hit its 10-year high of $28.625 in 1986, , and it closed at $25.75 on Tuesday, down 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.]
Mr. Jolson and some other analysts like the shares now not so much because of the likelihood of a rapid turnaround but because they see the stock as undervalued relative to other savings and loans. They also harbor a somewhat remote hope that it will be bought by a bank seeking to enter California.
The new plan may be a radical change for Ahmanson, but it is far less so for Mr. Rinehart, who before coming to Ahmanson was president of Avco Financial Services, a finance company owned by Textron, which serves lower-income customers.
An actuary by training, Mr. Rinehart has coldly analyzed Ahmanson's books and concluded that its current business will never earn a reasonable 15 percent return on shareholder equity, double its current level.
Nearly all of its $50 billion in assets are in adjustable-rate mortgages, a highly price-competitive market. Of those assets, the $20 billion backed by low-interest checking and savings accounts makes the profit target. But the remaining $30 billion, made with higher-interest certificates of deposits and money raised from institutional investors, earns barely 6 percent.
"We considered whether to stop originating mortgages altogether," Mr. Rinehart explained, allowing the portfolio to shrink slowly to the $20 billion Ahmanson can make money on. "We would have done that if we thought the mortgage business is hopeless. But we don't."
Instead, Ahmanson is spending $75 million to move its mortgage processing from 100 local offices into two central operations. With a sales force and network of appraisers working through laptop computers, it hopes to pare the cost of originating a mortgage from $3,000 to $1,000.
Ahmanson, wary of making mistakes, has slashed its lending volume to $6 billion this year, half its level five years ago. With thousands of jobs disrupted and many eliminated, Ahmanson has lost many seasoned loan officers. Moreover, Mr. Rinehart, building on his finance company background, wants credit officers to look at a borrower's finances, not just the home's value.
"As long as the collateral value was there, we didn't care about the owner," Mr. Rinehart said. "In the 80's, that worked because values were rising, but in a flat or down market, you will get slaughtered." The loans made in 1990 are still causing losses, with homes often selling for less than the mortgage balances.
Ultimately, Mr. Rinehart hopes to lift mortgage volume to as much as $25 billion, at least in good years. He wants to sell off three-quarters of the loans to investors, keeping on the books only those with higher risk, and thus higher interest rates --like those with down payments of only 5 to 10 percent.
Mr. Rinehart also plans to increase profits by making $5 billion in consumer loans by 2000, largely selling home equity, auto and other loans to deposit customers, half of whom borrow from other banks. He got a jump start by buying 61 First Interstate branches, flush with checking accounts and $500 million in business and consumer loans.
And he has started a finance company, similar to Avco and others, known as Home Consumer Finance of America. It will lend to people buying furniture and other goods through small offices in strip malls.
The albatross of Ahmanson's huge balance sheet actually helps the company here. Since it has so many low-risk mortgages on its books, Ahmanson can make high-risk consumer loans without setting aside much more capital as a reserve.
But getting these new businesses going will not be easy for a company whose staff has been accustomed to doing little more than opening savings accounts.
"It does help if the banker puts the name of the customer on the loan application," said William A. Barrett, the head of consumer lending, who said he has had to deal with myriad "horror stories" as loan products were introduced over the last year.
And now, to drive home the point that bank personnel have to sell these new products, a large part of their pay will be in the form of commissions earned only if they meet sales targets.
"We don't want the Bataan death march, where all the employees who don't want to sell are out," said Carl Forsythe, a former Banc One executive brought in last year to run Ahmanson's branches. "But employees will self-select out. They will say, Gee, the rules have changed and I can't keep up."
In Arcadia, the burden of keeping as many of Home Savings' bankers marching along has fallen to Brett Doty, the 26-year-old assistant branch manager, who joined last year.
"They came to me and said, 'You are going to be the change agent,' " said Mr. Doty, wearing a bright red T-shirt that read "Get Fiscally Fit." So he has been taking classes in "coaching" tellers and account officers, many of whom have been working the same way for more than a decade, to help their sales techniques.
"There has been resistance," he acknowledged. "Moving a company this size is like turning a battleship around."

HEADLINE: 2 Big Retailers Exceed Earnings Estimates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Two of the nation's largest retailers, Dayton Hudson and Kmart, reported better-than-expected financial results yesterday for the first fiscal quarter.
Both chains cited lower expenses among the reasons for their surprisingly strong results. But to increase earnings in the future, retail-industry analysts said, both need to focus on improving their operations, not just cost-cutting. 
 "So they have cut costs, but if you don't get sales growth, what do you have?" said Otto Grote of Derby Securities. "They can't regain profitability just cutting costs forever."
At Dayton Hudson, the nation's fourth-largest retailer, earnings more than tripled on a rebound at its struggling Mervyn's chain of moderate-price stores and strong sales at its larger Target discount business.
The surprising turnaround at Mervyn's has more to do with the resurgent West Coast economy, analysts said, than Dayton Hudson's efforts to revamp the chain. California, where almost half of Mervyn's 297 stores are found, is adding jobs twice as fast as the rest of the country.
Kmart, the nation's third-largest retailer, attributed its narrower-than-expected loss to lower expenses. It pared expenses by $105 million in the quarter, largely because of store closings and the sale of its auto-service business.
Dayton Hudson, based in Minneapolis, reported net income of $41 million, or 50 cents a share, well above the 40-cent estimate of analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. A year earlier, it earned $11 million, or 10 cents a share.
Sales for the quarter, which ended on May 4, climbed 13 percent, to $5.38 billion from $4.76 billion, largely on strong results from its Target chain of 688 stores. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 7 percent.
Mervyn's increased operating profit to $39 million from $1 million in 1995 on lower marketing and headquarters costs. Sales rose 6 percent; same-store sales were up 3 percent.
At Target, the third-largest discount chain, operating profit rose 37 percent as it put less merchandise on sale. Revenue gained 18 percent.
At the department-store division, operating profit declined to $28 million from $38 million. Sales at the 64 stores -- which include Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field -- were little changed from last year, and same-store sales dropped 1 percent.
"We should not forget the company is about where it was two years ago," said Saul Yaari of Piper Jaffray. "All they're doing is recapturing the ground they lost last year."
Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., said its loss from continuing operations narrowed to $38 million, or 8 cents a share, from $109 million, or 24 cents, in the first quarter a year earlier.
The discount retailer had been expected to post a loss of 10 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by IBES International.
In the most recent quarter, a charge of $61 million, or 13 cents a share, for the sale of part of its stake in Thrifty Payless Holdings, a big drugstore chain, resulted in a final loss of $99 million, or 21 cents.
A year earlier, a gain of $84 million from freezing its pension plan and a loss from discontinued operations of $3 million led to a final loss of $28 million, or 6 cents a share.
Sales in the quarter ended May 1 increased 1.8 percent, to $7.58 billion from $7.44 billion. Same-store sales rose 4.5 percent.
At the company's annual meeting in Detroit, its chairman, Floyd Hall, said cost savings should show a "pretty significant" improvement in coming quarters.
Kmart's American discount stores posted an operating profit of $58 million, compared with an operating loss a year earlier of $38 million, not including a $124 million gain from freezing pensions.
Kmart said preliminary votes showed that investors supported the company's recommendations on stockholder proposals, including three from the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees.
The unions sought to require the election of all directors every year and to eliminate director retirement plans. The third proposal called on Kmart to study a possible sale or merger of the company.
The unions said their proposal on director elections had received widespread support and appeared to be ahead. Final vote totals will not be known for as long as two weeks.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The Atlanta airport is being all spruced up for this summer's Olympics, and beyond.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
HARTSFIELD INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT in Atlanta and Delta Air Lines, its biggest tenant, are spending millions on improvements before the Summer Olympics -- changes that will also make life easier for travelers long after the Olympics have gone.
Delta, the official carrier of the games, is investing $45 million in new ticket counters and furnishings, more baggage-claim equipment, a separate underground pedestrian mall linking concourses C and B, and moving Atlantic Southeast Airlines, its regional carrier, closer to Delta's domestic concourse. 
 The airport is spending about $250 million to add escalators, new concession areas, security checkpoints and roving translators at its new international concourse. The interterminal rail transit system is getting new cars and passengers on the system will soon hear a human voice instead of the current computer-generated "voice" (named Hal, after the talking computer in the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey)." The new voice -- its human source has not yet been disclosed -- was chosen by two focus groups of travelers who frequently use Hartsfield.
Airport officials say the new voice will be more friendly and its messages less confusing, especially to foreign travelers. For example, many foreigners regard the word "stop" as a synonym for "halt," but not as meaning the next "stop" on the train. They also have trouble with the warning, over the speaker system and on the outside of trains: "Caution. Doors do not rebound or spring back." That warning has also confused multitudes of Americans. The new warning will simply say: "Caution. Doors do not reopen."
 
Luring Georgians Southward
Speaking of Atlanta, some Georgians are miffed that Florida has blanketed the Atlanta area with 60 billboards aimed at drivers frustrated by the traffic jams caused by Olympic-related construction. The billboards urge them to "Return to Your Senses in Florida." The billboards promote Florida's own "Summer Games," which include beach ball and working on a tan. Charles Dusseau, Florida's Commerce Secretary, said, "We just want to remind folks that when the going gets tough, the tough take a trip -- to Florida."
 
Lodging Inflation
No, it is not your imagination, you really are paying more for a hotel room this year -- 5.4 percent more than last year, for a total bill of $71.08 a night on average, according to Coopers & Lybrand. Hotel profits should reach $9.9 billion this year, Coopers & Lybrand said, about $2 billion more than in 1995 and the third consecutive year of record profits.
 
Waldorf Towers Joins a Club
Many road warriors who check into the Waldorf Towers in New York assume that they have checked into an annex of the Waldorf-Astoria: the Towers have sat atop the Waldorf-Astoria since the hotel was built in 1931, occupying floors 28 through 42. The Towers has its own entrance, own registration desk and own express elevator, but it and the Waldorf-Astoria have the same owner-operator -- the Hilton Hotels Corporation.
But unlike the Waldorf-Astoria, the Waldorf Towers recently joined the Leading Hotels of the World, a group of 300 luxury properties worldwide that have joined in reservations and marketing services. "We wanted the Waldorf Towers to be marketed with similar upscale properties on a global basis," Ron Drake, marketing director for the Waldorf Towers, said.
Hilton, based in Los Angeles, is predominantly a domestic hotel company. Most Hilton hotels outside the United States are Hilton International properties, owned since 1987 by the Ladbroke Group in London.
 
How Tips Are Really Figured
A study by researchers at Cornell University and the University of Houston found little relationship between the size of a tip and the quality of service from a waiter or waitress. The tip, they found, is influenced largely by the amount of the bill and the fear of disappointing the server.
The implication, the researchers say, is that there may be little incentive to provide good service. In fact, they concluded, waiters and waitresses might be tempted to rush their tables so that more diners could be served. That could lead to more tips, but could also create a less pleasant dining experience.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Simple Pensions Planned For Small Businesses
Small businesses could more easily offer retirement savings plans for their 36 million workers under a bill that House Republicans plan to approve today.
In a break from decades of pension policy, the bill would allow business owners to take advantage of tax-deferred retirement plans, even if no workers participate. The bill also calls for a 90-cent-an-hour rise in the minimum wage, to $5.15, over two years. [Page D2.]
 
House Votes to Repeal Gas Tax
The House of Representatives, spurred by public clamoring over a steep rise in gasoline prices, voted to repeal the 4.3 cents-a-gallon Federal excise tax on gasoline. The Senate is expected to approve it and President Clinton has said he will sign it. [A15.]
 
Accountants Tilt With Levitt
The accounting profession, through the Financial Accounting Foundation, is tilting with Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the S.E.C., in a battle over who sets accounting standards. Mr. Levitt wants half the foundation's directors to have no stake in its decisions. [D2.]
 
Fed Leaves Rate Policy Unchanged
The Federal Reserve's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee left interest rates unchanged, as expected. Treasury securities prices were mixed in light trading. [D15.]
 
Stock Prices Decline; Oil Shares Off
Pulled down by oil stocks, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.56 to 5,736.26, ending a nine-session winning streak. The Nasdaq composite slipped 3.69 to 1,244.42. [D8.]
 
A Dream for Once-Sleepy Diana?
The stock of Diana Corporation, once a sleepy distributor of meat and seafood, has zoomed from less than $5 a share to a high of $91 since it acquired an 80 percent stake in a technology company called Sattel Communications. But insiders at Sattel have been sellers. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
 
Russian Fund to Settle With S.E.C.
A Moscow-based fund, Russ-Invest, has agreed to settle S.E.C. charges that it offered Americans unregistered securities. [D4.]
 
Nations Air Quits Scheduled Flights
Nations Air, a small airline that served Boston, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, is halting scheduled service and laying off a third of its staff to go into the charter business. The founder, Mark W. McDonald, cited a drop in passengers following Valujet's crash. [A12.]
 
Retail Results Exceed Forecasts
Dayton Hudson and Kmart, reported better-than-expected financial results, citing cost-cutting efforts. Dayton's earnings more than tripled to $41 million, while Kmart had a narrower-than-expected $38 million loss. [D5.]
 
New Jersey Blue Cross in Merger
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey and its Delaware counterpart said they would combine operations by the end of August. [B6.]
 
A New Satellite Navigation Unit
Ashtech Inc., a Silicon Valley company, plans to introduce the first satellite receiver for business use that can read the signals of both the United States and Russia's global-positioning satellite networks. [D5.]
 
To the N.B.A. and Ad Land
Kobe Bryant, a Pennsylvania high-school senior who is almost certain to be a top pick in next month's National Basketball Association draft, is also a prime example of shoe-company marketing. He will help peddle Adidas U.S.A.'s newest line of sneakers for an few hundred thousand dollars the company finds "affordable." [B9.]
 
Viacom to Retain Spelling Stake
Viacom dropped a plan to sell its 75 percent stake in the Spelling Entertainment Group, the television production company. Analysts said Viacom wanted $750 million to $1 billion. [D3.]
 
Broadcast Networks' Tough Sale
The four broadcast TV networks are scrambling to sell commercial time in advance of the coming season. But with competition from cable, matching the $5.6 billion sold before the 1995-96 season will be tough. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D3.]

CORRECTION-DATE: May 23, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An entry in the Business Digest yesterday, referring to a Market Place column about the stock of the Diana Corporation and the company's ownership of an 80 percent stake in the Sattel Communications Company, misstated the details of a stock sale by Sattel Technologies. As the column reported, Sattel Technologies recently reduced its stake in Sattel Communications to 5 percent from 20 percent, selling the 15 percent stake to the management of Sattel Communications; no insiders in either company sold stock in Diana.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
German Banker's Remark Lifts The Dollar to a 16-Month High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar rose to a 16-month high against the mark yesterday after a German central bank official suggested that a weaker mark could help the nation's sagging economy.
A higher dollar "would have benefits," said Olaf Sievert, a member of the Bundesbank's interest rate-setting council. He said he had "no fear" that German inflation would accelerate if the dollar rose "a couple of pfennigs." A pfennig is a hundredth of a mark. 
 Mr. Sievert predicted that the Bundesbank would make further cuts in an important German money market rate, the rate on 14-day securities repurchase agreements. Lower interest rates tend to hurt a currency by making bank deposits and investments denominated in it less attractive.
The German central banker's remarks were made on the same day that the Federal Reserve, as expected, left United States interest rates unchanged.
Peter Wadkins, manager of interbank currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank, observed: "We are looking at comments from the Bundesbank that a stronger dollar helps and that there is potential for lower rates there again. That gave us the impetus for a higher dollar."
The dollar also benefited from remarks by the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, Lawrence H. Summers, that the United States would "prefer a strong dollar" as well as from a call by Finance Minister Jean Arthuis of France for the dollar to rise further against other major currencies.
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose as high as 1.5450 marks, its highest level since January 1995. It settled at 1.5425 marks, up from 1.5343 on Monday. The dollar traded at 107.18 yen, up from 107.08 yen. The British pound declined to $1.5110 from $1.5135.
The dollar also posted strong gains against the Swiss and French francs, rising to 1.2701 Swiss francs, from 1.2615 francs on Monday, and to 5.2220 French francs from 5.1945.
A weaker mark could help bolster Germany's stagnant economy by making its exports cheaper in foreign-currency terms. Conversely, the dollar, since falling to a postwar low of 1.3455 marks in March 1995, has appreciated almost 15 percent against the mark.
"The Bundesbank has to ease the big noose over the German economy: the strong mark," said Michael Perelstein, managing director for international investments at the MacKay Shields Financial Corporation.

HEADLINE: GOVERNORS' PLAN TO REFIT MEDICAID STARTS TO ERODE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The bipartisan consensus among the nation's governors on Medicaid and welfare, announced with much fanfare in February, appears to be crumbling, reducing chances that the programs will actually be overhauled in this election year.
On Wednesday, Republicans in Congress will introduce a bill to carry out recommendations of the National Governors' Association, which were praised 15 weeks ago by President Clinton and many members of Congress as a possible basis for compromise. 
 But in separate interviews over the last week and at a breakfast meeting with journalists today, three Democratic Governors -- Bob Miller of Nevada, Roy Romer of Colorado and Howard Dean of Vermont -- said the Republicans on Capitol Hill had upset the delicate compromise endorsed by all governors in February.
They said the Republicans were using the bipartisan mantle of the National Governors' Association to cloak a partisan initiative, intended to give President Clinton a bill he would veto.
"Congress has taken the 'bi' out of the word bipartisanship," said Mr. Miller, a moderate Democrat who is vice chairman of the National Governors' Association.
Mr. Dean said that "a right-wing majority in Congress" had drafted legislation that would eliminate the individual entitlement to health care under Medicaid and make substantial cuts in cash assistance for poor families. Mr. Dean said the Republicans would push this legislation through Congress "for the purpose of forcing the President to veto it" a few months before Election Day.
Governor Romer said, "It's obvious the Republicans want to give him a bill he can't sign." Mr. Romer described this as "a pure political strategy" to embarrass Mr. Clinton, who has twice vetoed welfare legislation in the last six months.
Republicans in Congress said their bill generally followed the governors' recommendations. They said it gave the governors at least 75 percent of what they wanted on welfare and more than 90 percent of what they sought on Medicaid.
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, a Republican, said the differing reactions of Republican and Democratic governors were "driven by the politics of the moment." In an interview, he predicted: "Republicans will say this looks pretty close to the governors' proposal. Democrats will say, 'That's not what we agreed to.' "
Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who heads the Commerce Committee, said tonight: "Our Medicaid reform plan meets the governors' objectives. It guarantees health care for the most vulnerable Americans, brings Medicaid spending under control, gives the states maximum flexibility and protects state taxpayers from unanticipated costs that might be caused by changing demographics, economic downturns and natural disasters."
Mr. Clinton has criticized the Republican Medicaid proposals more forcefully than the welfare proposals, and Republicans in Congress insist that the two be linked in one bill. Democratic governors said they had never agreed to such linkage.
The Democratic Governors voiced three other objections:
*Republicans in Congress, in keeping with their new budget blueprint, would cut projected welfare spending more than the proposal of the National Governors' Association. Savings would total $53 billion over six years, as against $43 billion.
*The governors' proposal was developed through months of bipartisan negotiations, but Democratic members of Congress and their aides were excluded from the process of writing the legislation. "There has been no Democratic participation or inclusion," Mr. Miller said.
*Congressional Republicans are not using the exact formula recommended by the governors' association for distributing Medicaid money to the states.
Mr. Romer said this change "knocks the whole negotiation in a cocked hat," because "the formula is the key" to the success of any Medicaid proposal. Medicaid accounts for more than 19 percent of all state spending and is the fastest-growing item in many state budgets.
In short, Governor Dean said, "It's very unlikely there will be any consensus in the National Governors' Association" on this legislation. "We'll end up agreeing to disagree on Medicaid and welfare," he said.
In policies adopted on Feb. 6, the governors' association recommended huge changes in Medicaid and welfare that would have shifted large amounts of money and decision-making power to the states. On many points, they split the difference between entitlements and block grants, giving states more flexibility but preserving Federal guarantees for the needy. Mr. Clinton has said he wants to preserve Medicaid as an entitlement, available to all who meet Federal and state eligibility criteria.
Medicaid and welfare serve more than 36 million people, at a combined Federal cost of $114 billion this year. Medicaid is, by far, the larger program.
Republicans in the Senate and the House worked together in drafting the new Medicaid-welfare bill. They tried to address some of the criticism directed at the governors' proposals by child-welfare advocates. For example, Republicans said their bill would eventually allow states, as an option, to obtain Federal money to finance health care for poor children from the age of 13 through 18.
The governors' proposal would have guaranteed Medicaid for poor children through the age of 12. But it would, in effect, have repealed a 1990 law that eventually guarantees coverage for youngsters 13 through 18.
In addition, Republicans said they would go beyond the governors' proposal by allowing states to provide Medicaid coverage for disabled people and elderly people who do not qualify for Supplemental Security Income, but incur large medical expenses. Supplemental Security Income is a cash assistance program for the aged, blind and disabled.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 24, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A headline on Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about the erosion of consensus among the nation's governors on reshaping the Federal-state health program for the poor referred incorrectly to that program. It is Medicaid, not Medicare.

HEADLINE: Wacky World of Russian Politics: It's All in the Altered Genes

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 22

 BODY:
At a news conference billed as the outlining of the Communist Party's definitive economic program, the economist in charge of formulating it instead spoke spookily this week about attempts by the Yeltsin campaign to tamper with the Russian gene pool.
"It's an attempt to modify the genetic code of ethnic Russians who represent the core of the citizens of Russia, rather than what seems to look like persuasion," the economist, Tatyana I. Karyagina, said. She was apparently alluding to the mass media she said were working on behalf of President Boris N. Yeltsin. 
 She went on to discuss the ways in which the subconscious of voters was being "violated" though their genetic codes, potentially leading to "schizophrenia of society."
Mrs. Karyagina did not reveal much about the party's specific proposals to redress the economic crisis in Russia. But her rambling, at times bizarre, news conference on Tuesday spoke volumes about the party's internal confusion over how -- and whether -- to present an economic program before the presidential election next month.
Her presentation was also emblematic of the confusion and disarray that now afflict the Communist campaign.
The Communist team led by Gennadi A. Zyuganov, which a few weeks ago was fiercely attacking the policies of President Yeltsin, is now on the defensive. It is fending off questions about its economic program, as well as reports of internal dissension within the Communist Party, and leaks of contentious remarks made privately at a party meeting last weekend that have been reported in many of the country's leading newspapers.
Today Mr. Zyuganov did not deny a report that a party member stood up at the closed meeting and asked him to rid the Russian Government of "non-Russians and non-Christians." He said members are entitled to their own views, and instead complained that the party meeting must have been secretly recorded.
"Is it that bugs are being planted, depriving us of a possibility to calmly carry out our discussions?" he asked.
He likened the situation to Watergate, saying, "When elections were held in the United States and the opponents of the Democratic Party installed bugs in their headquarters, it cost President Nixon his job."
As polls show Mr. Yeltsin gaining against his Communist opponent, the Zyuganov campaign has begun loudly proclaiming that the Yeltsin campaign is planning to rig the election results.
"I think the results of the election will in simple terms be falsified," Viktor Ilyukin, a Communist leader and chairman of the security committee in Parliament, said today. "I think the President will not be elected, he will be named."
Anxiety over its current standing has caused the Zyuganov campaign to rethink its strategy.
Stepping back from earlier promises that the campaign would soon disclose a definitive economic program, Communist Party leaders said today that the campaign was still working out a broad "conceptual" outline, which may be issued in the next few days.
Mr. Zyuganov and his advisers have been hammered in recent weeks in press articles criticizing the Communist economic program on the basis of parliamentary draft laws and press leaks. Party leaders have therefore apparently concluded that any effort to produce a concrete plan for reversing economic reform and restoring state control of the economy would only benefit Mr. Yeltsin.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Surge After a Report Showing Low U.S. Inventories

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a report showed that United States inventories fell to 19-year lows last week, heightening concern that rising demand around the world would continue to keep supplies tight.
On other markets, corn prices fell while copper rose. 
 After the oil market closed on Tueday, the American Petroleum Institute reported that crude oil stockpiles in the United States fell 4.54 million barrels last week, to 295.2 million barrels, the lowest since 1977. Imports fell by 10 percent and consumption held steady, the institute said.
The drop came even as members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries produced 26 million barrels of crude a day, more than their 24.52-million-barrel-a-day output ceiling and the highest rate in 16 years.
"The A.P.I. numbers for crude were pretty darn good," said John Saucer, an analyst with Smith Barney Inc. "The inventory situation is a problem and the high levels of OPEC production have done little to change that."
Crude oil for July delivery soared 77 cents, to $21.40 a barrel.
Traders also said that comments by Gen. J. H. Binford Peay 3d, the head of the United States Central Command, regarding Iran's military buildup helped push prices higher. General Peay was quoted by Jane's Defense Weekly, a London-based magazine, as saying that Iran's weapons programs far exceed its military needs. His comments raised traders' concerns that Iran could disrupt oil production or shipping in the Persian Gulf.
"Any time there is possibility of unrest in the Middle East the market goes up," said Lee Taylor, a broker at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York.
Corn prices fell as more warm, dry weather in Midwestern crop regions dried fields for spring planting and spurred development of this year's crop.
July corn fell 14.75 cents, to $4.865 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, the lowest since May 10.
Copper rose for a second day, rebounding from a five-month low, as falling stockpiles in United States warehouses indicate stronger demand from manufacturers.
Copper for July delivery rose 2 cents, to $1.1355 a pound at the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
German Money Report Leaves Traders Puzzled, Dollar Static

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished little changed against major currencies yesterday after new German economic data failed to give any hints about the direction of interest rates.
The dollar narrowly rose against the mark while slipping against the Japanese yen. 
 Currency traders have looked to German money-supply data and to a business-sentiment survey yesterday for insights into whether German monetary officials would reduce more interest rates.
When the data pointed to mild German inflation, traders squared their positions in advance of the long Memorial Day weekend in the United States.
"We were hoping for some guidance and inspiration, and unfortunately we didn't get it," said Lisa Finstrom, a senior currency analyst at Smith Barney. "The main event of the day was another nonevent."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar edged up to 1.5428 marks from 1.5425 marks on Tuesday. The dollar slipped to 107.03 yen, from 107.18 yen. The British pound traded at $1.5086, down from $1.5110.
The broadest measure of the German money supply was expected to have slowed in April and begin approaching German central bank growth targets of 4 to 7 percent.
Although the market expected double-digit money supply growth, it was disappointed by the increase for April against 1995's fourth quarter -- a reduced rate of 11.2 percent. While this was lower than the growth in March, it was not at all close to Bundesbank targets.
Also released yesterday was a report on business sentiment in Germany from the Ifo Institute for Economic Research. The institute reported that sentiment improved in western Germany -- to a rating of 91.1 in April from 90.4 in March, and in eastern Germany to 103.1 in April from 100.5 in March.
The report seemed to contradict Government data released on Tuesday showing two consecutive quarters of economic contraction, which by some standards constitutes a recession.
But to offset the weak economy, the central bank was expected to lower interest rates to spur lending and growth. "Bundesbank officials have come out and said there will room for an ease, but people are not sure about this," Ms. Finstrom said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Agencies use zippy Dr. Seuss-style rhymes and comics to sell Ford Escorts and Mercury Tracers.

BYLINE: By Robyn Meredith 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THE agencies helping to introduce two redesigned small cars for the Ford Motor Company are borrowing techniques from children's books and comic strips to convince buyers the cars are more than mere "econoboxes."
The cars, the Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer, which officially go on sale today as 1997 models, are intended to compete with the Dodge Neon, Honda Civic and Saturn sedans. The Escort ads, by the J. Walter Thompson Detroit unit of the WPP Group, use Dr. Seuss-style rhymes to play up the features found in the revamped car. 
 Television commercials began running Sunday and will appear frequently for three weeks. They will be followed by print ads that use the rhymes, bright colors and even the actors from the commercials.
The Detroit office of Young & Rubicam Inc. is taking an innovative approach to selling the Tracer. Radio will be the primary ad venue -- making the Tracer, its marketers say, the first car introduced by a Big Three auto maker without TV spots since before the television era. Themes from the radio commercials will be picked up in print ads, which use comic-strip panels and trumpet "As seen on radio."
The Escort and Tracer are nearly identical, but are marketed by different Ford divisions and are trying to reach different audiences. Ford is trying to attract 20-something buyers to the Escort, while Mercury is aiming at couples, perhaps in their early 30's, for the Tracer.
Though the Escort is Ford's second-cheapest model after the bare-bones Ford Aspire, the average age of its buyers is 37, said Randy C. Stewart, Escort's brand manager. In the past, the Escort appealed mostly to the wallets of drivers. "It was positioned as an econobox," Mr. Stewart said.
The redesigned 1997 Escort will still appeal to the thrifty -- the cheapest model, at $11,430, costs $500 less than the 1996 version. But Thompson Detroit used the rhymes to promote the features that were added to appeal to the younger consumers.
"We didn't want to get into a laundry list of the improvements," said Kurt J. Schneider, the partner at Thompson Detroit who managed the Escort account, "so we kind of worked them into the rhyme."
In one spot, a young couple consider the car as an announcer begins an extended ode: "This is Ford Escort. It's new and it's nifty. It's made for the smart, the intelligent thrifty." Images appear of the dual air bags and the rear seat that folds down to expand the trunk area.
At the end, the commercial invites buyers to drive the Escort. It signs off with, "We've given you every rhyme, and rhymed every reason." According to Competitive Media Reporting in New York, which tracks advertising spending, Ford spent $28 million last year on Escort ads. This year, Mr. Stewart said, Ford will spend three or four times more.
Mercury is taking a different approach to selling the Tracer. Donald D. Williams, who oversees Y.& R. Detroit's work for Mercury, explained that in a typical auto campaign advertisers look for "a medium that provides a visual image of a car."
But Y.& R. Detroit chose radio for Tracer because consumers "don't see the exterior of small cars as being highly differentiated," he added. Indeed, the redesigned Tracer and Escort look like other small sedans.
Dale L. Jones, marketing communications manager for Ford's Lincoln-Mercury division, said that the ads for Tracer, which begin today, will run in especially heavy rotation in markets like Baltimore, Los Angeles, New York and Washington.
The zippy ads use fanciful scenarios to describe various Tracer attributes. In one, an announcer says he is strapped to the top of a Tracer atop the Parthenon in Greece, while the driver listens to the car's optional six-disk CD changer play the theme from "Zorba the Greek."
"As we drive down the 537 steps, Tracer's solid body construction and quadra-link suspension helps smooth out the bumps while Zorba barely misses a beat," the announcer says. "Now, if the Mercury Tracer can handle the steps of the Parthenon, imagine it handling something even more timeless, like potholes."
Colorful print ads recreate the radio spots using a comic-strip format. The campaign carries the theme "The small car that thinks big."
Because the Tracer campaign excludes television, it is relatively inexpensive for the introduction of a redesigned car. Mercury spent about $13 million in the last two years promoting the Tracer, according to Competitive Media Reporting; plans call for spending at least that much this year on the radio and print ads.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Jump In Light Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose sharply yesterday, but light trading exaggerated the gains.
With a lack of fresh economic data, the impetus for buying yesterday came from the Treasury's announcement outlining next week's auctions of new two-year and five-year notes. The size of the auctions will be much smaller than what many traders had been expecting, and the announcement helped ease concerns about the market's ability to absorb new supply. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32, to 89 23/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.81 percent, from 6.85 percent on Tuesday.
But trading was light yesterday as the market approached a long holiday weekend. The Public Securities Association, a trade group that represents securities firms, has recommended that the Treasury market close early tomorrow, at 2 P.M. The market will be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day.
Many major institutional investors, like hedge funds and portfolio managers, remained on the sidelines yesterday, leaving trading to the dealers and day participants, who turned largely to price and chart analysis as a guide to their positioning in the market.
Market participants had been anticipating that the Treasury would announce plans to sell some $19.2 billion of two-year notes and some $13 billion in five-year notes. They were pleasantly surprised when the Treasury said it would sell $18.75 billion of two-year notes on Wednesday and $12.5 billion of five-year notes on Thursday. Fewer notes available typically bolster prices.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 6.02 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.39 percent.
Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd., said the Treasury's announcement gave the market an excuse to remove excess short positions before the long weekend.
Mr. Bleier said the recent positive tone to the market had been dictated by moderate growth, low inflation and faith in the Federal Reserve's monetary policy.
But market concern that strong producer prices will filter down to the consumer level has caused yields to take the path of least resistance. "So far we've had a number of scares, "with strong gains in grains, commodities and oil prices which are producer-oriented staples," he said. "But the most recent consumer report shows those increases have not filtered through in any major way. So, the whole thought of price stability at the consumer level remains intact."
Mr. Bleier said the yield on the long bond was on the way down to test the 6.50 percent to 6.625 percent level. "Next week, coming economic data will give us a gauge to the course of interest rates the next three months," he said.
In the futures market, which can affect the Treasury cash market, the June bond contract is approaching a pivotal level, said Robin Mesch, fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research in Boston. "Long term, if bonds can sustain a rally above a 110 16/32 to 110 17/32, then a move toward 112 should get under way," she said. The June bond contract settled at 110 5/32, up 19/32.

HEADLINE: Donations to Charities Rose 11% Last Year, Report Says

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Buoyed by a stronger economy, charitable donations jumped nearly 11 percent last year to $143.9 billion, the biggest increase since 1986, according to a report released yesterday. After inflation, the real increase was 7.8 percent, also the largest gain in a decade.
"People had the wherewithal to give," said Nancy Raybin, chairwoman of the AAFRC Trust for Philanthropy, an arm of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. The figures were included in the trust's annual report, Giving USA. 
 Not all charities gained equally, however. Donations to human service groups fell slightly to $11.7 billion, for a decline of 3 percent after inflation. The category includes disaster relief agencies like the Red Cross, as well as human services like youth and family programs and housing and employment agencies.
Total donations to this category often surge in years when there are bad earthquakes, floods or other disasters, and fall in less eventful years. These groups also had a sizable decline in donations in 1994, when they received the lowest dollar amount in inflation-adjusted terms since 1982.
Arts, culture and humanities groups, already faced with cuts in government support, also fared relatively poorly in charitable giving last year. Private giving to these groups rose less than 3 percent, to $10 billion, and was virtually flat after inflation.
"People have had to respond to what the perceived as the most urgent needs," said Stanley Katz, president of the American Council of Learned Societies. "It's a terrible problem, particularly in my neck of the woods."
The group showing the biggest gains was public and society benefit philanthropies, a category that includes research and public policy organizations, community development and advocacy organizations, and charities that collect goods for other charities. Giving to this group rose by 17 percent overall, to $7 billion, for a gain of 14 percent after inflation.
Environmental and wildlife groups also showed strong gains for the second year in a row, with donations growing by 13 percent to $4 billion, for an increase of 10 percent after inflation.
Other types of groups that had smaller real gains included religion (2.5 percent), education (5 percent) and health (6.2 percent). International affairs groups had an overall decline of 9 percent after inflation.
Living individuals provided most of the charitable giving last year -- $116 billion, or 81 percent. About $10 billion, or 7 percent, came as bequests. Foundations gave $10 billion and corporations gave $7 billion last year. Corporate and foundation giving grew 8 percent last year, somewhat lower than the 11 percent growth in individual giving.
Despite continued worries about corporate downsizing and job losses, Americans generally felt comfortable enough to make charitable donations. Ms. Raybin noted that personal income grew 6 percent last year, the fastest rate since the 1990-91 recession.
Congressional discussions about changes in the tax law that would have made charitable giving less useful for cutting personal taxes probably also prompted people to speed up donations they otherwise would have made later, said Ms. Raybin, who is president of Raybin Associates, a fund-raising and management consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn.
She and others at the fund-raising association also say fund raisers worked harder last year to raise money in the face of threatened government budget cuts.
Concerns that the trial of United Way of America's former chief executive and the fraud by the New Era for Philanthropy might curtail giving seem not to have been realized, although organizations like United Way might have been affected.
One reason, Ms. Raybin said, is that nonprofit groups "made a major effort to communicate with their donors, and tried to distinguish themselves from other nonprofit organizations to protect their own images."

HEADLINE: Designing Boutiques Like Palaces

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MASON 

 BODY:
LAST Wednesday, amid feverish preparations for the imminent opening of the luxurious Chanel boutique on East 57th Street, an improbable ballet occurred: workmen in construction gear and French-speaking women in turquoise Chanel suits rushed across a lush, sand-colored carpet in protective blue booties.
An hour later, firefighters -- crowbars in hand, oxygen masks assembled and axes at the ready -- stood poised to break down the bright blue construction facade of the Moschino fashion boutique on Madison Avenue, near 68th Street. 
 "Sorry folks," a weary-looking fireman said, sensing the keen disappointment of the crowd. "It's a 10-92, a false alarm. Problem is, with all these fancy new boutiques going up around here, people keep seeing construction smoke, and we get called out for no reason."
The alarms may be false, but something is definitely burning: ambition. A designer-boutique stampede is taking place from East 51th Street to East 70th Street that is putting the braggadocio of the 1980's to shame. Some 20 international fashion designers at retail's high end are building their own dream houses -- mansions is more like it -- using innovative store design as the bait.
Within a year, Madison Avenue will float a parade of palatial mega-stores, with Prada (21,000 square feet); Valentino (9,000); Moschino (20,000); a new Italian presence, Etro (10,000), and two Armani stores (28,000 square feet, combined). Flagship boutiques coming to anchor on Fifth Avenue include Versace (25,000 square feet) and Ferragamo (6,500), with Piaget (3,750) and Revillon (3,800) branching out on their own.
Chanel, which opens on May 30, will be giving the neighboring Niketown (65,000 square feet) and Warner Brothers (a k a Bugstown, expanding to 75,000 square feet) a run for their money. The 16-story Chanel building -- some are already calling it "Cocotown" -- will include even a five-story Frederic Fekkai beauty salon.
Spokesmen for Donna Karan, Jil Sander, Tommy Hilfiger, Dolce & Gabbana and Genny confirmed this week that they, too, are urgently seeking space in the neighborhood.
"There's a feeding frenzy," said Alex Kabbaz, the president of the Madison Avenue Business Improvement District. "It's amazing when you consider there were 75 empty stores on Madison Avenue between 53d and 96th Street as recently as 1992."
This flourish of new stores seems unlikely to warm the hearts of neighboring department stores that carry the same merchandise (but less of it). Dawn Mello, the president of Bergdorf's, says that almost every leading important name in her store is opening on Madison Avenue. But "we seem to flourish anyway," she said, adding, "There are clients who just like the way a Bergdorf buyer edits a collection."
Why this remarkable boom? Alan Millstein, a retail analyst at Fashion Network, said: "Every leading fashion designer now wants a flagship boutique in New York that serves as a showcase for their entire product -- something a department store can't guarantee them. It's a European concept that was taken up by Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein, and now everyone wants one."
Faith Hope Consolo, a real estate and retail specialist at Garrick-Aug Associates, pointed out that on Madison Avenue, between 57th and 72d Streets, rents that were $200 a square foot in 1991 are now $350.
"And I predict they'll go even higher," she said.
Ms. Consolo added that rates are around $500 a square foot on Fifth Avenue (compared with $400 in 1993), and $425 on 57th Street (compared with $350 in 1993). Michelle Stein, director of marketing for Moschino, said that opening a flagship store in New York is now considered "an investment in your future worldwide, because New York is the window on the world." She continued, "Everyone is literally banking on the renaissance of Madison Avenue."
Mr. Millstein added that projections for luxury goods are buoyed by a climbing stock market and a profusion of South American, Asian and European tourists lured by the cheap dollar.
What might amaze shoppers -- but not the fashion industry, where it is conventional wisdom -- is the notion that these bold new stores are not expected to recoup the millions of dollars lavished on their creation. "Quite a number of them defy retail logic," Mr. Millstein said. "Some are here as corporate flagships that aren't necessarily for profit. They're being used as international advertising tools."
The designer stores and their pop-culture neighbors share more than geography. They will be tourist destinations, complete with souvenirs. At the Warner Brothers Studio Store, $1.50 will buy a keepsake (a Looney Tunes Pez dispenser); the Chanel impulse-buy equivalent is a splash or two of Chanel No. 5 Eau de Toilette at $47.50. For such purchases shoppers at both stores can walk proudly onto the street clutching a logo-emblazoned shopping bag.
Interior designers are providing the spectacle. Peter Marino seems to be making out best. He is designing Vuitton's new store on 57th Street and also those of the rivals Valentino and Armani, which will face each other, "High Noon" style at opposing corners of Madison Avenue and 65th Street.
Mr. Marino's design for Valentino will include a courtyard garden: "lighter" and "brighter" are his new watchwords. "Access to outdoor light has become very important," Mr. Marino said, adding, "the old idea of keeping stores closed and dark so customers would focus on the merchandise is over -- it's literally out the window."
THE prize for lavishness goes to the Chanel building, designed by Platt Byard Dovell. The store's interior, designed by Christian Gallien, has evoked Coco Chanel's legendary salon on the Rue Cambon in Paris. Built from scratch where the jeweler James Robinson used to be, the store has glossy black display cases and a profusion of mirrors and the Coromandel lacquer screens favored by Mlle. Chanel.
At the entrance, the eye will be drawn to a sweeping French-limestone double staircase modeled on one at Versailles. (Visitors can draw their own conclusions.)
Chanel is unlikely to redecorate any time soon. When a 12-foot Paris-made sofa was installed last week, the vast third-floor window on 57th Street had to be removed.
Grandest of all is the 3,000-square-foot Chanel Suite and adjacent Salon Prive, which boasts a luxuriously appointed ballroom-size double-height salon for fashion shows, couture fittings and special parties.
"I woke up a few nights in a cold sweat thinking about it," said Arie Kopelman, Chanel's chief executive. "With the cost of real estate in New York, everyone was asking, 'How can you be turning two floors into one luxurious room you're only going to use for occasional events?' "
At Holland & Holland, the new 57th Street outpost of the London hunting and field-sportswear store, the tail of a stuffed pheasant was quivering next to an air-conditioning vent last Friday. Visitors, their Hermes scarves flapping in the breeze, streamed in to examine walnut and mahogany hunting guns, flax and bridle-hide bags, "half Norfolk" shooting jackets and safari wear.
And lest gleaming mahogany counter tops become warm with all the discreet lighting, each is fitted with an inside fan to keep it cool to the touch. In this rarefied atmosphere, the alternative sportswear at Speedo and the looming Niketown down the street seemed a world away.
A palpably nervous delegation from the display team at the flagship Ralph Lauren store on 72nd Street was spotted on the second floor, checking out the rival goods.
Upstairs in the Brevis Room, adjacent to the Gun Room, patrician-looking gents were observed discussing the finer points of engraving for the custom-made guns they were ordering. While they talk about "the glorious 12th" (the start of the British grouse season on Aug. 12), potential customers are offered single-malt whiskies -- not unlike the free cocktails offered in Las Vegas casinos -- possibly to cushion the shock of paying as much as $120,000 for a gun, however delicately engraved.
Even the less rarefied neighbors are managing to keep up with the Cocos. In the reconfigured 9,700-square-foot Sony superstore, customers try out equipment while splayed on Donghia sofas, sample designer waters and cappuccino from a semicircular cracked-glass bar and screen videos in a room designed by Ralph Lauren, based on one he dreamed up for Sharon Stone's home.
Jim Mansour, the store's interior designer (who did creative work at Bendel's, the Limited and the Warner Brothers store), traces the development of the notion of what he calls "entertainment retail" to Mr. Lauren's success. "Ralph Lauren was the progenitor of all this stuff," he said. "When he opened the Rhinelander Mansion on Madison Avenue at 72d Street it turned the head of every retailer in the nation. It was at that point that people started to understand the compelling nature of having a brand image that was articulated by store design."
At Fifth Avenue and 55th Street, on the site of the former restaurant Cote Basque, giant ink-black paint brushes and a curled film strip rendered in bronze herald the new 45,000-square-foot Disney store (even the huge figures of Mickey and Minnie Mouse above the door were putting on the dog, dressed in black formal wear. Designed by Imagineering, a branch of the Disney empire, the new Disney store spotlights plastic crocodiles dancing in place.
On the third floor, overlooking the staircase from the Game Room, visitors will recognize a life-size Cruella DeVille, the villain of "101 Dalmatians." As the ultimate Fifth Avenue shopper, she has a face-lift-tight countenance eerily reminiscent of a number of socialites to be found at places like Mortimer's and Le Cirque, where Chanel suits abound.
Here, where the customers are called "guests" and the staff is called the "cast," a window overlooks the Christian Dior boutique, still clinging to its Old World elegance in striking contrast. Can the chasm between these two retail worlds be bridged?
"I think it's pure nonsense from people who don't know retail" to suggest that they won't, Mr. Kopelman said. "The woman who buys a Chanel suit is just as likely to want to buy running shoes for the country," he continued. "And let's be honest -- the American retail landscape has changed, and that goes for 57th Street, as well. The trend is toward a diversity which works well for everyone because it creates traffic."
Dr. Stephen Gullo, a diet specialist whose office is on East 65th Street, observed: "The Renaissance of Madison Avenue is a great upper. It's a barometer to the life of New York City. You see many more people walking at night, whereas before the streets were empty. The only down side is you know the rents will go up -- and traffic congestion. Great shops are better than Prozac."
How long can the feel-good retail high continue when rents spiral up to $4.3 million yearly, as they did at Disney?
Mr. Millstein says he often ponders that question. "If something should happen to the economy in a couple of years," he said, "it will be interesting to see how these luxury stores suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortunes."

HEADLINE: The $5.15 Question

BYLINE: By Alan S. Blinder; Alan S. Blinder, a professor of economics at Princeton University, was formerly vice chairman of the Federal Reserve and a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
Some self-evident truths are neither self-evident nor true. Elementary economic theory insists that a higher minimum wage must reduce employment. On this basis, many people dismiss recent scholarly evidence suggesting that higher minimum wages may not cost the country jobs. But perhaps the elementary theory is, well, too elementary.
When evidence contradicts a theory previously deemed indisputable, there are two ways to react. An honestly inquisitive mind will question the validity of both the new and old evidence. Which is stronger? He or she will also ask whether another theory could explain the puzzling new evidence. A polemicist who "knows" the answer, however, will dismiss the new evidence and attack the messenger. 
 So it has been with the minimum- wage increase. Two of my Princeton colleagues have been attacked regularly and roundly for their research suggesting that an increase in the minimum wage might not decrease the number of jobs.
But Profs. David Card and Alan Krueger are among the most careful empirical researchers in the economics profession. A few important points need to be made about their research:
First, when their study of fast-food restaurants in New Jersey and Pennsylvania was conducted, Professor Krueger was not employed by Labor Secretary Robert Reich; indeed, at that point, he had never met him! (Only later did Mr. Krueger work briefly as the chief economist of the Labor Department.) To suggest that his research was politically biased is not only mean-spirited but ludicrous.
Second, evidence casting doubt on the theory that the minimum wage reduces employment is not limited to the Card-Krueger study. About 20 different studies by two dozen authors have produced similar results. Are we to believe that all these researchers are political hacks?
Third, the evidence in the Card-Krueger study represents a quantum jump in quality over previous research. Virtually all earlier studies on the minimum wage were based on time-series analysis, which tries to control for other pertinent influences by statistical methods and therefore always does so imperfectly. The Card-Krueger research is based on something akin to a natural experiment and is thus vastly more powerful and reliable.
Fourth, it turns out that most of the older studies supporting the conventional view fall apart when data from the 1980's are added. The studies no longer imply that raising the minimum wage kills jobs.
 The principal study used to discredit the Card-Krueger findings is by David Neumark of Michigan State University and William Wascher of the Federal Reserve staff. No polemicists they. But those interested in this debate should know that:
* The original data used in their study were provided by the Employment Policies Institute, which is financed by manufacturers, restaurants and retailers and whose director has been a lobbyist for several fast-food chains. That may be fine, but . . . .
* The institute never claimed that its sample of 71 restaurants was drawn randomly, and it still refuses to release the data to other researchers.
* When Mr. Neumark and Mr. Wascher drew their own sample of 150 restaurants, they found a loss of jobs small enough to have been a statistical blip. (In technical parlance, the loss was not "statistically significant.") This more reliable sample, therefore, does not refute the Card-Krueger study.
But how could jobs not be lost, when basic economic theory insists on the opposite conclusion? Here are three possibilities:
* The simple theory disregards the costs of training new employees. Paying a higher minimum wage might reduce job turnover enough to pay for itself, leaving companies with no incentive to reduce employment.
* The simple theory also ignores the problem of recruiting new workers. Employers with many minimum-wage workers may be reluctant to fill vacancies by offering higher pay because they will have to increase the wages of their existing workers as well. A higher minimum wage -- which equalizes the pay for all workers -- makes this issue moot.
* Minimum-wage labor may often be a small and relatively fixed proportion of costs, which include more expensive labor and machinery. In that case, the increase in the minimum wage may only slightly affect businesses' total costs.
I do not know if any of these alternative "theories" are true. But the list demonstrates that one can accept the new empirical findings and still be a card-carrying economist.
Where does this dueling evidence and theory leave us? In my view, it justifies agnosticism. Those who want to raise the minimum wage have not taken leave of their senses, have not forsaken basic economic principles and have not cooked the books.
Frankly, I do not know whether a modest minimum-wage increase would decrease employment or not. If it does, the effect will likely be very small.
But that doesn't answer the relevant question. One can accept the new evidence and still oppose the 90-cent-an-hour increase in the $4.25 minimum wage. After all, it does abridge business freedom. It does impose higher costs on some businesses and reduce economic efficiency. And it might reduce employment a bit.
But other considerations push me strongly in its favor. The folks who earn the lowest wages have been suffering for years. They need all the help they can get, and they need it in a hurry. The claim that most minimum-wage workers are teen-agers from prosperous families is untrue.
About 40 percent of all minimum-wage employees are the sole wage earner in their households, and about two-thirds of the teen-agers earning the minimum wage live in households with below-average incomes.
Yes, there are other ways to help the people at the bottom of the economic ladder. But every solution sacrifices some economic efficiency, and Congress is not about to enact any of them. A minimum-wage increase is being debated now. Congress should pass it.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rally; Dow at a High In 41.74 Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The stock market snapped out of a one-day stall to spurt to record highs late yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 41.74 points, to 5,778.00, its 21st record closing this year. 
 "I feel pretty good about the market," said Peter Anderson, chief investment officer at IDS Advisory Group in Minneapolis. "I believe the economy is in really good shape," adding corporate earnings should continue to advance even as interest rates decline.
Broader indexes also rose to new records. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 5.66 points, to 678.42, and the Nasdaq composite index added 2.96 points, to 1,247.38. The American Stock Exchange's market value index gained 2.76, to 614.99, setting its fifth consecutive record high.
The Dow average recovered from a loss of more than 20 points early in the day and was up fewer than 10 points until shortly before 3 P.M., when the bond market rebounded, cutting a path for stocks to move higher.
Bond prices rose in light, technical trading, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for interest rates -- down to 6.81 percent, from 6.85 percent on Tuesday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
"There was no news to drive it, just a little technical rally in bonds," said Bill Meehan, a stock market analyst at Prudential Securities, "but that was all it took to ignite the Standard & Poor's futures markets, which then spread" into the stock market.
Part of the rebound yesterday came from short-sellers -- investors who had speculated the market would weaken. When stocks advanced, these investors scrambled to buy in order to minimize their losses.
"Everybody's instinctively nervous that we've had a big run-up," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "They're worried they'll be left out if we have another big move up."
But, he added, "the market's likely to be trendless until we get another set of economic numbers" that may direct the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates. The next important report on the economy will be the May employment data scheduled for release on June 7.
Oil stocks rose with oil prices. Exxon climbed 1 5/8, to 87 3/4; Chevron gained 1 3/8, to 61 7/8; Mobil added 1 3/8, to 115 3/4, and Royal Dutch Petroleum advanced 2 1/4, to 152 1/8.
A number of computer issues were weaker yesterday. Shares of Intel, fell 3/8, to 69 7/8. The company increased its quarterly dividend to 5 cents a share from 4 cents, The higher dividend will be paid Sept. 1 to shareholders of record on Aug. 1.
Global Village Communication fell 4 7/16 to 10 13/16, after the company said it expected to report a loss for its first quarter because of Apple Computer's recall of the Macintosh Power Book 5300 and 190 models to remedy defects. Global Village, which makes modems and other communications products sold with the Macintosh, said the recall would reduce the number of new computers sold with its Powerport PC card.
Shares of Forte Software tumbled 4 1/2, to 77 1/4, after the company said company insiders could now sell as many as 1.25 million shares. Forte went public in March at $21 a share.
But Iomega jumped 10 5/8, to 54, after Acer Inc., a Taiwan computer maker, said it would include Iomega's storage drive in a new model. Iomega's share value has increased more than sixfold this year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Brooklyn Lawyer Stole Millions Using Property Schemes

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
A lawyer with a reputation for charitable deeds was charged yesterday with swindling victims out of nearly $14 million using bogus real estate schemes, and a Federal court complaint said that he had told another lawyer that his swindles had totaled more than $50 million.
The lawyer who was charged, David Schick, is a member of a prominent Orthodox Jewish family in Brooklyn, and prosecutors said most of his victims were Orthodox Jews. 
 The victim in one scheme charged yesterday was identified as a British organization, Vindola Ltd., that finances charitable activities in Israel. Prosecutors said it was defrauded of $7 million that Mr. Schick misappropriated from an escrow account set up for what he had promised would be a safe investment paying a guaranteed high interest rate.
Mr. Schick, 36, a Brooklyn resident who was said by his lawyer in a recent interview to have been involved in some bogus investments, surrendered to the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday and was arraigned in the Federal District Courts in Manhattan and Brooklyn on fraud charges.
Federal prosecutors in both districts have been investigating what appears to be an extensive web of activities that one official said may have lost investors $100 million.
But the official, insisting on anonymity, said he could not estimate how much of the total loss resulted from criminal fraud. Prosecutors said the charges reflect only the beginning of an investigation expected to lead to counts involving far more than the $14 million cited yesterday.
The authorities said they suspect that much of what was taken from later investors went to pay back earlier investors in a pyramid scheme. But they also said that some funds may have been used to pay back investors in legitimate deals that suffered losses.
Mr. Schick, a bespectacled, heavy-set man, was released at each arraignment on a $1 million bond secured by his home in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, where he lives with his wife and 10 children, and by the Brooklyn home of his father, Arthur Schick, who heads a well-known Brooklyn kosher catering concern.
Mr. Schick was not required to enter a plea at the arraignments, but in the interview earlier this month, his lawyer, Victor J. Rocco, said that Mr. Schick was "prepared to accept responsibility" for the crimes.
"Today, I'm not going to have any comment," Mr. Rocco said as he and his client's father waited yesterday for Mr. Schick to be arraigned in the Brooklyn Federal Court, where the case involving Vindola Ltd. was outlined in prosecution papers.
Papers submitted in Federal Court in Manhattan charge that an unidentified investor was defrauded of nearly $7 million in a similar scheme.
