HEADLINE: Economics Lesson In a Border Town;
Why That Asian TV Has A 'Made in Mexico' Label

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico

 BODY:
The towering blue sign that lights up the night at Samsung Group's sprawling new industrial complex seems out of place in this gray and grubby border town.
But in the months since it was erected, the 70-foot steel structure has become an unofficial landmark, at once a beacon for poor and restless Mexicans looking for work and a symbol of the free-trade forces that are siphoning manufacturing jobs from the United States. 
 When Kwang Ho Kim, the president of the South Korean conglomerate, pushed a button to activate the assembly lines at the $212 million plant on March 29, Tijuana, with a population of about one million, quietly nudged a step closer to matching the entire United States in the number of workers involved in making television sets and parts.
In all, 24,600 people are employed here by Samsung; by Japanese companies like the Sony Corporation, Hitachi Ltd. and the JVC unit of the Matsushita Electric Industial Company, and by other electronics manufacturers. Together, the Mexican Government says, they assemble more than nine million television sets a year. In the United States, where more than 90 companies once built TV sets, television-manufacturing jobs -- mostly production of picture tubes, receivers and cabinets -- have fallen to 30,000 nationwide, according to the Electronics Industry Association.
"Tijuana's got first world equipment with third world labor," said Harley Shaiken, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley who specializes in labor issues and the global economy. "They now have the ability there to handle a surprising level of complexity and some very sophisticated processes."
Mexico has always had cheap labor and thus has been a magnet for American manufacturers of low-technology consumer goods like clothing and hand tools that can be mass-produced here at a fraction of the cost in the United States. But with trade barriers falling, it has become easier for multinational corporations to make high-tech products in border towns like Tijuana and ship them worldwide.
For the old factory towns and aging industrial parks of the United States, however, Samsung's new tower looms more like a warning flare than a beckoning light. "We invented the television in the United States, and they're going to take it completely out of the country," said Nelson Silva, a forklift operator who was shop steward at a JVC assembly plant in Elmwood Park, N.J., before it shut down in March and moved to Tijuana. "I'm bitter that we lost these people, lost these jobs, not just at JVC but all over America," Mr. Silva said in a phone interview.
The big manufacturing companies say the competitive pressures of the global economy leave them no choice but to abandon workers like Mr. Silva and flee to cheap-labor countries. According to them, an Asian company churning out televisions in a Mexican town for export to American consumers is the wave of the future.
It was the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement that sealed Mexico's status as a manufacturing center for the entire continent. In years past, Samsung operated on the principle that the best way to penetrate a market was to make the product in the same country where it was sold, said Young M. Kwon, president of Samsung Electro-Mechanics America Inc. in Tijuana.
Indeed, after being declared dead in the 1970's, the victim of low-cost foreign competition, the television manufacturing business in the United States was revived in the 80's. Foreign -- mostly Asian -- producers, spurred by political pressures and business efficiencies, opened American plants to supply the United States market.
But with the free-trade agreement guaranteeing a vast free-market zone of nearly 400 million people, Mr. Kwon said, the necessity of building TV's in the United States evaporated. "We consider this place, or America, or Canada, or in the future Latin America, one block in the market," he explained. Indeed, almost 90 percent of the 1.5 million color TV sets that Samsung will produce in Tijuana this year will be sold in the United States.
While Samsung moved its manufacturing operations here from Ridgefield Park, N.J., in 1991, it waited until the trade agreement took effect three years later to begin a big expansion. It now plans to spend $581 million over four years to double TV production to three million sets a year, as well as to turn out more picture tubes and produce more complicated items like microwave ovens. The total Samsung work force, now at 2,300, could quadruple to 9,300.
At the company's plant here, the global economy is less an economic concept than a lesson in cultural accommodation. In the entrance lobby, a sign that begins in Spanish and ends in English instructs visitors to remove their shoes and put on slippers before entering the plant.
The popularity of Tijuana among Japanese electronics companies has driven real estate prices so high that newcomers are looking at other border sites, setting off interstate bidding wars within Mexico. In April, the Daewoo Corporation of South Korea announced that it would open a $250 million picture-tube plant in the Baja California city of Mexicali because the state had offered a better deal than had neighboring Sonora.
But as production surges on the Mexican side of the border, it is drying up to the north. Nearly 200 people lost their jobs when JVC closed the plant in Elmwood Park. "Imagine it, nine lost years I spent working there," said Angela Nasareo, a 39-year-old assembly line worker from nearby Paterson who was let go in March. In a phone interview, she said she was offended that the young women in Tijuana who now have the jobs she and her colleagues lost make about $50 a week, compared with the $9 an hour she had earned. "There the company wants more quantity than quality, that's all," she said.
The United States Labor Department says the North American Free Trade Agreement has so far resulted in the destruction of 66,600 American jobs. Nevertheless, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said the trade accord's overall effect on the American labor market had been benign.
"The premise of Nafta is that trade is not a zero-sum game," Mr. Reich said in an interview in Mexico City, where he met with the Mexican and Canadian labor ministers. Since the accord was signed, he said, increased American exports have created hundreds of thousands of American jobs that pay more than the old manufacturing jobs they replace. "There is no evidence that Nafta has been bad for American workers," he said.
It has certainly been good for Mexican workers. The trade accord eliminated tariffs on most of the electronics products entering the United States from Mexico, causing an estimated 50 percent increase in exports in the first two years. The freer access sweetened the deal for Asian companies that had already made Tijuana their first stop in North America because of its proximity to Silicon Valley and the port of Long Beach in California.
In the recent Mexican recession, the border plants known as maquiladoras, which assemble products from imported parts, were a singular bright spot. Employment grew by more than 13 percent to over 151,000 and maquiladora exports rose more than 10 percent.
Now, the television manufacturers are showing that their plants can offer the local economy more than just the low-paying assembly jobs of the maquiladoras. To meet local-content standards imposed by the trade agreement, the Asian companies have invited some of their traditional providers to join them in Tijuana. Already, at least half a dozen South Korean and Japanese concerns have started producing parts in the city.
Samsung and Daewoo are building factories to produce picture tubes, which are considered the most complex part of the television production line and which until recently were made mostly in the United States. Samsung thinks that by 2000, about 90 percent of the parts it needs will be produced locally, providing higher paying jobs and contributing more to the local economy.
Samsung also plans to open a research and development headquarters, but in San Diego instead of Tijuana. Despite their disappointment at that choice, Mexican officials are upbeat about Mexico's increasing standing as a maker of big-ticket durable goods. Increasingly, they point out, the big automobile companies are switching output to Mexico. The city of Matamoros has already become one of the largest producers of automobile parts in North America, for example, turning out wiring assemblies for car factories in the United States and Canada as well as those in Mexico.
As more factories manufacture finished goods from scratch rather than just assembling parts shipped from the United States, they offer workers an opportunity for advancement to more skilled positions with higher pay. For all that, though, Tijuana's greatest advantage remains cheap labor. Seventy percent of Samsung's workers are young women who dropped out of school before completing the sixth grade. The starting salary for a 45-hour week is 345 pesos, or about $50.
Still, for 17-year-old Mariana Delgado Caballero, it is enough. She is working her first job after having migrated with her father from the central state of Guanajuato in 1995. She says they had no intention when they arrived here of sneaking across the border into the United States, as so many millions of Mexicans before them have done, but the shy way she says it suggests that such an escape is very much on her mind.
And while attaching tiny brass pieces to a tuning board for eight hours a day at Samsung is not her idea of a magical route to a better future, she is glad to be making money at all. "I'll do it," Miss Delgado said, "till I have the chance to better myself."

HEADLINE: America Keeps Peace, Clinton Tells Coast Guard

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
President Clinton mounted a broad defense of his foreign policy yesterday, arguing that in military deployments in Haiti and Bosnia and in his fight for free trade, he had chosen the unpopular course and left America better off for it.
In his second foreign policy address of the week, Mr. Clinton told the graduating class of the United States Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., that he had trod a careful course in an era lacking the clear superpower delineation of the cold war. 
 "Imagine the ongoing reign of terror and the flood of refugees to our shore had we not backed diplomacy with force in Haiti," Mr. Clinton told the rows of white-uniformed graduates and their families.
"Imagine the shells and the slaughter we would still be seeing in Bosnia had we not brought our force to bear through NATO," he continued. "Imagine the chaos that might have ensued had we not used our economic power to stabilize Mexico's economy."
Mr. Clinton urged Americans to stay engaged in the world despite the end of the cold war. "We cannot withdraw into a fortressed America," the President said.
Mr. Clinton also used the occasion to denounce a Republican proposal to require deployment of a national missile defense system by 2003 as wasteful, misguided and a breach of arms control agreements with Russia.
He said the possibility of a long-range nuclear missile attack on American soil by a rogue nation was at least a decade away and that he was committed to working toward a missile defense system that could be deployed in seven years if such a threat were to materialize.
But, without specifically mentioning the Republicans, he stepped up the Administration's attack on legislation sponsored by Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, and Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich that would require the United States to have a national missile defense system deployed by 2003.
The proposal, the President said, "would force us to choose now a costly missile defense system that could be obsolete tomorrow."
House Republicans had planned to vote Thursday on their bill, which revives the national debate over the antimissile technology that is popularly known as Star Wars.
But the Republicans abruptly postponed action when confronted by an analysis by the Congressional Budget Office showing the project would cost between $31 billion and $60 billion by 2010.
Mr. Dole has been sharply critical of Mr. Clinton's approach to foreign policy, accusing him in a speech this month of "weak leadership, vacillation and inconsistency."
Republicans have suggested that a second Clinton term could leave Americans vulnerable to attack from missiles fired by countries like North Korea and Libya.
The President, who campaigned and won the 1992 Presidential election largely on domestic issues, has fashioned himself as an international peacemaker in this election year.
As he has repeatedly since January, he cited his Administration's support for Russia's transition to democracy and a free market economy, as well as the American role supporting peace efforts in the Middle East and Ireland. In the past months, however, the peace efforts have looked tenuous, and Russia's presidential election could restore a revived Communist Party to power.
Mr. Clinton specifically singled out Israel for support today, saying: "We must be with you every step of the way until there is a comprehensive, lasting peace in the Middle East. Now is not the time to turn back, and the United States must do its part."
Later yesterday, the President flew by helicopter to the Intrepid, the floating naval and air museum in the Hudson River along Manhattan's West Side, where he emerged onto a windswept flight deck to welcome sailors celebrating Fleet Week in New York City and to receive the Intrepid's freedom award.
Mr. Clinton was greeted by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican Mayor, who, using a favorite line, welcomed the President to the "capital of the world."
Last night Mr. Clinton addressed a dinner in Stamford, Conn., that raised $2.3 million for Democrats before he flew on to Milwaukee. He is scheduled to meet Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany in Wisconsin today, allowing him to showcase foreign policy once again, this time in the American heartland, in a city with a distinct German heritage.
White House officials said the President's day of talks with Mr. Kohl would encompass issues ranging from the Russian elections, the expansion of the NATO alliance to include former Warsaw Pact nations and America's efforts to isolate Iran. The two leaders -- who have bonded in the past over food -- also plan to sample the local bratwurst.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Submits New Bill to Revamp Welfare and Medicaid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Republican leaders of Congress kicked off a new effort to overhaul welfare and Medicaid today by introducing legislation to meet some of President Clinton's objections to their earlier proposals, but members of both parties said the process would probably end in a Presidential veto.
Under the Republican bill, adults would have to go to work within two years of entering the welfare rolls or lose benefits. States would have to put at least half of their adult welfare recipients to work by 2002, and no person could receive cash benefits for more than five years. 
 Mary Jo Bane, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the new proposals still cut too deeply into Federal aid for destitute children.
The savings in the bill, $53 billion over six years, "do not appear consistent with the goal of bipartisan welfare reform that will move people from welfare to work and protect children," Ms. Bane told the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources.
But Republicans said that the Administration was deliberately blocking action on welfare. Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, told Ms. Bane, "You are setting this bill up to be vetoed again."
Republicans said that their welfare and Medicaid proposals followed the recommendations of the National Governors' Association. The governors offered their bipartisan recommendations in February as the basis for a possible compromise between Congress and the White House, and Mr. Clinton praised them at the time.
But today Ms. Bane expressed "serious concern" about the governors' proposals. She said that the Administration opposed many of the specific provisions, including one that might allow states to substitute Federal dollars for state money now being spent on social services.
Haley Barbour, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, said he was extremely frustrated with the President's "repeated oscillations and gyrations" on welfare policy. In the last six months, Mr. Clinton has twice vetoed other bills containing Republican welfare initiatives.
"This is a persistent pattern of purposeful deception," Mr. Barbour said. "When the TV cameras are on, Bill Clinton talks about how he's for welfare reform. But later, when the cameras are off, his aides and appointees do something different. This is classic Clinton, page 1 of the Clinton play book: fake right, then run left."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said the Republicans' new bill "sets up the campaign face-off" between President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, on welfare policy.
In an interview, Mr. Moynihan, who has studied welfare policy for several decades, said he now felt confident that "we will get through this awful year without something potentially calamitous happening" to the nation's welfare programs.
"This is an agreeable impasse," Mr. Moynihan said of the deadlock between Congress and the White House. "I had hoped we would not do anything until the next Congress, so we could let some of these issues be argued out in the election. The current climate is much too politicized to have any good emerge in terms of social policy."
On April 26, the White House sent Congress a detailed legislative proposal to revamp welfare programs, but Ms. Bane said that no member of Congress had introduced the draft legislation as a bill.
The President said his proposal would impose work requirements on welfare recipients and set a five-year limit on cash assistance. Republicans said the proposal contained so many exceptions and exemptions that the work requirements and time limits were not meaningful.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, the work requirements would not apply to a family headed by a single parent who "has a demonstrated inability to obtain needed child care."
Even if a family reached the five-year limit, it could still receive welfare benefits if one member was working 20 hours a week, if the family resided "in an area with an unemployment rate exceeding 8 percent" or if the family was experiencing "other special hardship circumstances."
A state could define hardship in such a way as to nullify the work requirement for 15 percent to 20 percent of the families on welfare.
Moreover, under Mr. Clinton's proposal, if a family was denied cash assistance because of the five-year limit, the state would have to meet the needs of the family's children by providing vouchers for shelter, clothing, diapers and other goods and services.
A family consisting of a mother and two children would receive vouchers equal to the cash welfare grant for a two-person family; the Administration proposal would provide no vouchers for the mother.

HEADLINE: Essay;
'Ish' vs. Issues

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
What if Bill Clinton's blatant intervention in the Israeli election on the side of the left wing's Shimon Peres backfires? What if the right wing's Bibi Netanyahu -- to the consternation of the media and most leaders of the Jewish community in America -- brings off an upset?
A keening geshrei would go up from doves around the world: Peace process doomed! Disaster looms! Yasir Arafat would go through the roof, gloom would pervade the halls of the U.N. and Syria's Hafez al-Assad would summon Warren Christopher to Damascus for the 21st time, demanding an explanation.
But after the shock wore off, the U.S. President would extend an invitation to the new leader for a state visit, the world's media would find new seriousness in Mr. Netanyahu, and high-level rejoicing would be heard in the capital of Jordan.
That's because the Israeli election next week is not about whether to pursue a peace. That pursuit is a given; neither war nor the status quo is an option. The question is how to give Israelis a sense of personal and national security while giving Palestinian Arabs a sense of political and economic progress. The ultimate compromise would enable each to govern itself side by side.
Terrorists have twice jerked poll standings around. The assassination of Yitzhak Rabin by a crazy rightist caused a spike in Labor's support, which was later flattened by Hamas's suicide bombings. Extremists, either Jewish or Arab, could still deliver a "revulsion vote" against their own mainstreams.
But polls are deceiving because this is the first Israeli election to be decided by Arabs and Russians. Peres is counting on Israeli Arabs, who support him overwhelmingly, but they might not turn out in the light of his need to punish Lebanon for harboring Hezbollah rocketeers. Netanyahu is counting on Russian immigrants who seem to be splitting, but come from a tradition of misleading pollsters. My hunch is that the current 5 percent Peres lead is really a dead heat.
Reached by cellular phone as he was about to address 100 rabbis, Bibi tells me, "Labor is talking the ish and we're talking the issues." This means that his opposition is running a negative personal campaign against him -- ish means "the man" in Hebrew -- while he is stressing the Golan Heights and Jerusalem.
Hawks like me think Likud is right about wanting to make the strategic Golan a permanent part of Israel. Syria lost that threatening position in a war of aggression; Peres has been pleading with Assad to take it back in return for a promise of peace. That would be foolhardy, and the hoped-for American troop tripwire in that dangerous spot will not be forthcoming. The way to deal with Assad's terrorist regime is to be ready to wait for his successor.
Is Likud right about keeping Jerusalem's unity under Israel's sovereignty? Both parties say that's what they're for, but I think only Likud means it. That's because a Palestinian state, which Labor would instantly permit on almost all the West Bank, would demand East Jerusalem as its capital, and Arabists from Turtle Bay to Foggy Bottom would lean hard on Israel to give way.
But Netanyahu's Likud, without breaking agreements already made, would divvy up the West Bank into large Palestinian enclaves with a more limited sovereignty. With an Israeli government resolute about maintaining control of all Jerusalem, Arabs might thus be inclined to accept Gaza as their capital.
That explains Jordan's cordial relationship with Likud. In a final settlement, a "religious solution" would be possible, with King Hussein the key in determining access to, and providing protection of, Islamic holy places in Jerusalem. He competes with Arafat for that considerable power in the Arab world.
The little King has been, in Netanyahu's word, "impeccable" in his impartiality during Israel's current campaign. However, Al Asswak, a leading Jordanian newspaper that reflects his views, just ran an editorial headlined, "Likud victory can save the peace process."
I think it can, too. Is Netanyahu worried about President Clinton's preference for his opponent? "American-Israeli relations are impervious to changing governments," says Bibi, adding with mischievous confidence, "I'll work with whoever is elected President of the United States."

HEADLINE: Clinton Says He Will Veto Republican Plan in Wage Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
President Clinton accused Republicans today of cluttering up a proposal to increase the minimum wage with a provision he said would promote sweatshops. He called their proposal "a giant fraud on the American people" and said he would veto it if it reached him.
The bill would increase the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour from $4.25. But it contains a provision that would allow small businesses with sales of less than $500,000 a year -- companies that now employ more than 10 million workers -- to hire new workers without paying them any specified minimum wage. It would also free them from paying new workers overtime. The proposal would bar pay cuts for those already employed by these companies, but those workers would not get the raise, either. 
 After several hours of skirmishing, the House quit for the night before voting on either the wage increase or the exemptions. Democrats, backed by television adertisements sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. targeting opponents of an increase, ae been pressing for a vote for two months. Votes on both issues are expected on Thursday.
Today, as the House debated taking up the wage measure and related proposals, including tax breaks for small businesses, many Republicans rose to speak. But none defended the exemption of new workers.
The amendment's sponsor, Representative Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania, did send his colleagues a letter saying the plan was necessary to correct flaws in a small-business exemption first drafted in 1989, the last time the minimum wage was raised.
But Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, said in a letter to Speaker Newt Gingrich, "This proposal invites a return to the sweatshop conditions that Americans abhor."
In an interview, Mr. Reich said the exemption for new workers "would create an incentive to a lot of businesses to subcontract their work to new, tiny subcontractors paying 50 cents to a dollar an hour." That, he said, would provide "another incentive for illegal immigration."
House Democrats were uncertain about whether they could find enough Republican allies to defeat Mr. Goodling's proposal. But they continued to revel in the opportunity to hammer the Republicans for not allowing a simple, unencumbered vote on the minimum wage. So all 196 of them who were present voted against taking up the bill under the procedures set by the Republicans.
Fourteen Republicans, mostly very conservative junior members, joined them, as did the House's one Independent, Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont. But 219 Republicans, including the two dozen or so who have supported a minimum wage increase, voted to take up the bill. By a vote of 219 to 211, the House took up the bill.
Some Republicans argued against raising the minimum wage. Representative Porter J. Goss of Florida said such a step "will force many Americans out of work."
Representative Tim Hutchinson of Arkansas called the proposal "misdirected, election-year politics" and "a job killer." He accused Democrats of telling workers, "You're going to lose your job so we can play politics with the American economy."
But Democrats insisted the proposal, which would raise the Federal minimum wage to $4.75 a hour on July 1, and to $5.15 on July 1, 1997, was long overdue. Representative John Lewis of Georgia asked, "How can these mean-spirited Republicans, too cheap to pay a worker $5.15 an hour, claim to care about the American workers?"
Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts asserted, "It's just like Harry Truman said: 'The Republican Party supports a minimum wage -- the lower the minimum the better.' "
Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the second-ranking House Democrat, turned the attack personally on House leaders. "This is just another attempt by Newt Gingrich and Dick Armey to kill the minimum wage," Mr. Bonior said.
The Goodling proposal "bogs it down, it lards it up and it slips a poison pill," he asserted, adding, "Sweatshops, slave wages and pay cuts may be Newt Gingrich's idea of a revolution, but it is no way to build a better America."
As the House worked into the night it first adopted, by a vote of 414 to 10, a series of tax proposals designed to aid small businesses.
The most important of them would authorize a new "savings incentive match plan for employees," called Simple. It would make it easier for companies with fewer than 100 workers to provide pensions for their 36 million employees.
The Simple pension plan is patterned after the 401(k) plans, but with a significant difference. It allows owners to defer taxes on $6,000, plus an equal matching contribution from the company, even if none of their workers participate. Other federally authorized pension plans, including the 401(k) plan, require that lower-paid workers get benefits as a condition of others getting tax breaks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The White House yesterday threatened to veto minimum wage legislation if it included an exemption for small businesses. Representative Jack Quinn of New York briefed fellow Republicans on the negotiations on the bill. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Top Professionals In Layoffs Steered To Temporary Jobs

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
America's largest job-finding company for laid-off white-collar workers has reached an agreement to channel such workers -- particularly managers, engineers, accountants, lawyers, bankers and the like -- into temporary work when it cannot place them in permanent, well-paying jobs.
The unusual agreement, made public yesterday, is between Drake Beam Morin Inc., the job-finding, or outplacement, company, and Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary-help company. It reflects the explosive worldwide growth in temporary employment and also the growing reluctance of corporate America to pay the cost of keeping former top-level employees in outplacement firms long enough to land good jobs. 
 "The traditional support for individuals who had been earning above $50,000 was unlimited five years ago," said Charles Albrecht, president of Drake Beam, who said nearly all upper-level people once received over a year of severance pay from their old companies as well as a year or more of support at an outplacement firm. "Now nearly half are here for only three months and their severance has shrunk. So there are individuals who need help while they are with us job hunting, and temporary work feeds that need."
For Manpower, the arrangement with Drake Beam, provides -- almost overnight -- a huge new supply of highly skilled workers to feed a growing demand for such people to take temporary jobs, not only in the United States but increasingly abroad. For Drake Beam, the agreement would satisfy corporate clients who want to see their laid-off workers re-employed as quickly as possible.
Both organizations operate in more than two dozen countries. And Manpower in particular is facing stiff competition from European temporary-help companies that are expanding rapidly, responding to a growing demand for "flexible workers," which means day work or short-term contracts.
Such work, once concentrated among blue-collar and clerical people, has spread up the income ladder so that it is not unusual today for a company to hire an engineer to carry out a six-month project, or accountants during the income tax season, or even temporary executives.
The agreement between Drake Beam and Manpower, a first for either industry, seems likely to focus attention on one aspect of the election-year debate over the downsizing phenomenon: are white-collar workers laid off from well-paying jobs having trouble finding comparable work that pays as well. .
Many economists, and members of the Clinton Administration, have argued that the economy is creating many well-paying permanent jobs. But Drake Beam and Manpower, in working together, suggest that laid-off workers are becoming more willing to take temporary work, either because they cannot find satisfactory new jobs fast enough or becausetheir severance pay runs out.
But while Mr. Albrecht of Drake Beam, which is based in New York, insists that temporary work is becoming a necessary compromise for laid-off workers, its chief rival, Right Management Consultants, a Philadelphia-based company, criticized the concept of outplacement firms and temporary-help agencies working together.
"The whole idea of outplacement is to help people realize that they can find similar or better positions in a reasonable amount of time, within a year, and they don't have to fall back on an inferior assignment," said Nancy Geffner, a Right Management executive. "If you interrupt this process by taking a temporary job, you lose the momentum of seeking a new career. This agreement is going to set people up for failure."
Mr. Albrecht and Mitchell Fromstein, chairman of Manpower, said the agreement would become effective once final details were worked out. Their arrangement involves no exchange of money, the goal of both organizations being to step up job placement.
The outplacement industry, almost nonexistent 20 years ago, is crowded with companies today, growing with particular speed in the 1990's as downsizing spread from blue-collar and clerical ranks into white-collar jobs well up the income scale. The corporations engaged in this downsizing turned increasingly to outplacement companies to get their former workers placed in new jobs as quickly as possible. One stated goal was to avoid lawsuits; another, to keep up the spirits of surviving employees who might someday need similar outplacement help.
The outplacement companies, in turn, for fees that can range to $10,000 a person and beyond, give their charges a desk and phone, emotional support and an upbeat approach to job-hunting. If the laid off learn how to sell themselves properly, acquiring these skills at the outplacement firms, then the vast majority will land good jobs soon, the firms contend. Above all, the outplacement firms try to teach their clients to suppress any anger at having been laid off. An angry job applicant, the argument goes, will not be hired.
Mr. Albrecht and Mr. Fromstein insist that their agreement supplements this approach without changing it. "It is going to give Drake Beam a channel to put people into work situations more quickly," Mr. Fromstein said. "And many of these jobs will lead to permanent employment. Our clients aren't advertising for an accountant or an engineer. What they want instead is to try people out."
For Mr. Albrecht, the logic is more compelling, and he predicts that outplacement companies, for all their reluctance, will increasingly branch into channeling people into temporary jobs. "Some of these people have children in college," he said, "they have mortgage payments, they have limited dollars in the bank and they need a revenue stream when their severance runs out."
"The question," he added, "is would you go to work on a contract basis for six months, knowing that 40 percent of those who do it end up with full employment. The answer is yes; that is why we are aligning with Manpower."
Mr. Albrecht and Mr. Fromstein said their companies would work together wherever the two have operations, here and abroad. A major competitor of Manpower, Adia International S.A., suggested yesterday that it would soon mount a similar operation. Adia, a Swiss company, announced a merger last week with Ecco S.A., in France. The merged temporary-help companies will be second in size to Manpower, whose sales reached nearly $7 billion last year.
Adia, which has a major operation in the United States, owns an outplacement company, Lee Hecht Harrison, based in New York. One of Lee Hecht's clients is the Bell Atlantic Corporation, and for three years Lee Hecht has been placing some laid-off Bell Atlantic workers in temporary jobs through Adia, often so they can hone new skills, said Steven Harrison, president of Lee Hecht.
Within 30 days, Mr. Harrison said, Adia will expand this practice for clients beyond Bell Atlantic. "We have decided to create a new division of our firm," he said, "to help companies in more than traditional outplacement ways."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Placement Firm Will Steer Clients to Temporary Jobs
The nation's largest job-placement company reached an agreement to channel laid-off white-collar workers -- like upper-level managers, engineers, accountants and lawyers -- into temporary work when it cannot place them in permanent, well-paying jobs.
The pact between Drake Beam Morin, the outplacement company, and Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary-help firm, reflects the worldwide growth in temporary employment and also the growing reluctance of corporate America to support ex-employees at outplacement firms long enough for them to land another good job. [Page A1.]

Looking at Fund Managers' Trades
Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged mutual fund executives to reconsider whether fund managers should be allowed to make investments for themselves at the same time that they manage the public's money. [D2.]
 
U.S. Healthcare Loses Civil Suit
A Federal jury ordered U.S. Healthcare to pay $1.2 million in damages to a smaller company that contended the health maintenance organization had violated antitrust laws by forcing retail pharmacies to buy employee coverage from it. The jury found U.S. Healthcare and three senior executives liable under antitrust and racketeering laws. [D4.]
 
Saks Opens to Applause on Wall St.
Saks Holdings, the parent of Saks Fifth Avenue, the luxury retailer, offered 16 million shares of its common stock to the public. Priced at $25 a share on Tuesday, the stock jumped to $34.75 by the time it began trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Shares of Saks closed at $34.625, or 38.5 percent more than its initial pricing. [D4.]
 
Stocks Again in Ascension
Stocks snapped out of a one-day stall to spurt to record highs. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 41.74 points, to 5,778.00, setting its 21st closing high this year. Broader indexes also set records. The Standard & Poor's 500 climbed 5.66 points, to 678.42, and the Nasdaq composite added 2.96 points, to 1,247.38. [D12.]
 
Treasury prices rose sharply in light trading, and the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.81 percent, from 6.85 percent. [D19.]
 
A Quiet Software Giant
Computer Associates, which gets the bulk of its revenue from selling software for mainframe computers, posted strong earnings for the three months ending March 31, its 18th consecutive quarter of double-digit sales growth. Revenues for its fiscal year exceeded $3.5 billion, solidifying the company's position as the second largest independent software company behind Microsoft. [D4.]
 
Valujet's Uncertain Prospects
Most airline analysts say Valujet's stock should recover from the May 11 crash near Miami by the end of the year unless the airline is found to be criminally negligent. Valujet is unlikely, though, to regain its reputation anytime soon as a rapidly growing company with unusually high profit margins for the industry. Market Place. [D12.]

More Wrangling on Minimum Wage
As the House debated minimum-wage legislation before delaying a vote, President Clinton accused Republicans of trying to shackle a bill with a provision that would promote sweatshops. The House did adopt some tax proposals intended to aid small businesses, including a program to make it easier for them to provide pensions. [B10.]
 
Relying on Whimsy to Sell Cars
The ad agencies helping Ford Motor to introduce the redesigned Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer are borrowing techniques from children's books to convince buyers that the cars are not "econoboxes." Advertising. [D8.]
 
Prague's Formula for Growth
Unemployment in the Czech Republic is running at just 3 percent, and its largely privatized economy is expected to post a second consecutive year of 5 percent growth in 1996. How have the Czechs managed it? Luck figures, but so does political pragmatism, fiscal rectitude and ideological determination. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Shifting Campaign Strategy to Tax Cutting, Dole Meets With Forbes

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Bob Dole met today with Steve Forbes, his former primary opponent, as part of Mr. Dole's effort to move closer to the tax-cutting economics that he has spurned most of his political career but now may need to revive his Presidential candidacy.
"What I intend to propose is a sound, pro-growth tax policy, coupled with economic changes," Mr. Dole said as he and Mr. Forbes, the champion of the so-called flat tax, emerged from Mr. Dole's Capitol office after a half-hour discussion. 
 Mr. Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, declined to discuss the specifics of the economic plan that he and his advisers are developing as a centerpiece of his campaign. But he said it could include a single-rate income tax, much as Mr. Forbes championed, and a national sales tax. A 15 percent across-the-board cut in income taxes was also listed as an option.
Mr. Dole has been consistently identified over the years with balancing the budget as opposed to cutting taxes. In his bitter primary struggle earlier this year with Mr. Forbes, he called the magazine publisher's economic proposals "snake oil," and his television commercials said Mr. Forbes's flat tax of 17 percent would add $200 billion to the deficit.
Still, Mr. Forbes's message of "hope, growth and opportunity" appears to have outlived his candidacy, leading the Dole campaign to consider adopting some of his proposals with the hope that they generate a similar enthusiasm for Mr. Dole.
"Steve Forbes caught the nation's attention with a tax-reform message and with a cutting-taxes message," said a Dole campaign official, explaining today's meeting. "There was a moment when he had a Wendell Willkie-like momentum and captured the imagination of the Republican base and independents, and it's important for people to understand that he is a player in the Republican Party and he is someone who will be helpful in advising the campaign."
For his part, Mr. Forbes said today that he had urged Mr. Dole to consider "radical tax simplification." Mr. Dole said that Mr. Forbes's flat-tax proposal was "a message that resonated."
Unlike Mr. Forbes, Mr. Dole would retain deductions for mortgage interest and charitable contributions. Still, he has given no indication how he would pay for any tax cut.
Other ideas under consideration since Mr. Dole met with a half-dozen economists earlier this month are making payroll taxes, like Social Security, deductible, and a national sales tax.
For some, the Dole-Forbes meeting was full of symbolism. Marshall Wittman, an analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group, said it could be as significant as the meetings in the late 1970's between Jack F. Kemp, the former Congressman, Jude Wanniski, the economist who most prominently promoted the "supply side" theory of promoting economic growth by lowering taxes, and Ronald Reagan, as they developed Mr. Reagan's economic platform.
Mr. Wittman said Mr. Forbes's association with Mr. Dole could help Mr. Dole make his political transition from budget balancer to tax cutter more easily, which he said began last year when Mr. Dole embraced the tax cuts in the Contract With America, the Congressional Republicans' manifesto.
"This is the next significant step, meeting with Forbes," he said. "Tax cuts cannot only unite the factions of the party that would otherwise be divided on social issues, but it gives him an optimistic message about the future and addresses the underlying anxiety."
One flaw with the Reagan analogy is that Mr. Dole, the former head of the Senate Finance Committee, has more experience in the realm of national economic policy than Mr. Reagan had. He has a long record of supporting tax increases, and his steadfast devotion to a balanced budget, born of his Dust Bowl youth on the Kansas plains, creates a major problem for him: He has staked so much of his political credibility on deficit reduction that he would have to be extremely artful in advocating deep tax cuts, or the move could be seen simply as a political ploy. This could mean showing how he would pay for them.
"The problem is that Dole is not a very good spokesperson for this message," said Stephen Moore, an analyst at the Cato Institute, a conservative research group. But he did not rule out a conversion by Mr. Dole. "Dole almost has to do a Nixon-goes-to-China kind of thing."
On the campaign trail, Mr. Dole has consistently talked about "fairer, simpler, flatter" taxes. In March, after it was clear he would win his party's nomination and Mr. Forbes had withdrawn, Mr. Dole called Mr. Forbes's flat tax "a good idea," but he has so far resisted endorsing a specific single-rate income tax, although at one point he raised the possibility of two rates.
One of his closest advisers, particularly on economic matters, remains Senator Pete Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Senate Budget Committee and is a fierce deficit hawk.
"Dole has more of a definition as a budget balancer than as a supply sider," acknowledged one Dole official, "so we have to make certain we are consistent. But nothing says that Dole can't both be a pro-growth tax reformer in the tradition of the modern Republican Party as well as someone who is more trustworthy on balancing the budget" than is President Clinton.
Voters say their top priorities are cutting Government spending and balancing the budget, according to Republican polling. Cutting taxes follows. But tax cuts have traditionally proved a strong and winning issue for Republicans, and many conservatives now are eager to get back to that happier Reagan-like message of prosperity than the budget-balancing message of austerity that dominated the last year.
At the same time, some of Mr. Dole's close campaign officials and advisers are former acolytes of Mr. Kemp. Mr. Kemp is one of the original supply siders, but he is also in the dog house with Mr. Dole since he endorsed Mr. Forbes after Mr. Dole had all but won the nomination. Some of these people are advocating particularly deep tax cuts, both for economic and political reasons.
"The danger for Dole is that if he doesn't come up with a tax plan that is sufficiently bold, Clinton will come out with his own plan," said Bruce Bartlett, a former Reagan and Bush Administration official, who helped formulate the 15 percent tax cut that Mr. Dole is weighing. "Since there seems to be no limit to what Clinton will do to steal Republican ideas, it puts pressure on Senator Dole to move quickly before Clinton pre-empts him -- and to be bolder than his instincts might let him."
Mr. Wanniski, an adviser to the Forbes campaign and not part of the Dole circle, said, "Both Haley Barbour and Newt Gingrich have told Dole that a dinky little tax-cutting idea is not going to cut it," referring to the Republican Party chairman and the House Speaker. "He's going to have to go for something big and bold, a la the kind of tax-cutting ideas Steve Forbes has," said Mr. Winniski, who now runs an economic consulting concern in New Jersey.

The session was part of an effort by Mr. Dole to move closer to tax-cutting positions that he has rejected in the past but that his strategists believe are needed to revive his campaign. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Summer Travel Boom Expected, Despite Hitches

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Against a backdrop of high gasoline prices, a spring that seemed more like autumn and unanswered questions about the crash of a Valujet airplane earlier this month, the summer travel season kicks off this weekend, almost a month before the official start of summer.
Yet despite the handicaps, travel experts predict that summer travel will set a record for the third consecutive year, with 30.4 million Americans taking to the roads and skies by Labor Day. And if the weather cooperates, many traditional tourist destinations expect to post gains well above the projected average increase of 1 percent from 1995. 
 Meanwhile, this Memorial Day weekend will be marked by fun, food and festivals: music festivals in in Philadelphia, Decatur, Ill., Nashville and Charleston, W.Va.; by a folk life festival in Seattle, by a sport kite competition on the beach at Wildwood, N.J.; by the opening of the 17-day Spoleto arts festival in Charleston, S.C., and with a strawberry festival in Garden Grove, Calif., featuring the world's largest strawberry shortcake.
Indianapolis will be its usual madhouse at race time, with several hundred thousand spectators expected for the Indianapolis 500 parade on Saturday and race on Sunday.
In Niagara Falls, N.Y., which is expecting a sellout this weekend, the Maid of the Mist sightseeing boats will launch their 150th consecutive season on Saturday. Among the passengers are expected to be Vicki Conner and Joseph Ulibarri from Phoenix, one of 11 couples scheduled to tie the knot over the weekend at the Niagara Wedding Chapel.
"We thought it would be a romantic place to start the first day of our life together," Ms. Conner said.
Ships of a different kind, cruise ships, will benefit from the long weekend, to which many travelers are tacking on extra days, partly because of fears that the recent run-up in gasoline prices would lead to long lines or even shortages.
Norwegian Cruise Line's 2,000-passenger Norway is sold out for its weeklong Miami-Western Caribbean cruise departing on Saturday, while three Royal Caribbean ships in the Caribbean are also fully booked.
The American Automobile Association and the nonprofit Travel Industry Association of America said at a joint news conference in New York last week that an auto trip from Los Angeles to Washington would cost an average $12 more for gasoline this year over last, Seattle to Yellowstone Park in Wyoming $3.41 more and Philadelphia to New York, 45 cents.
Tourism officials in Newport, R.I., are expecting a big Memorial Day weekend and an even bigger summer, despite high gasoline prices. "Besides, the weather in the Northeast was so awful this winter that people will be itching to get away," said Evan Smith of the Newport County Convention and Visitors Bureau. Similarly, in Myrtle Beach, S.C., about 90 percent of whose 11.3 million annual visitors drive there, pent-up demand is expected to overcome any reservations about paying more for a tankful or two of gasoline.
That biggest concern in Myrtle Beach, the Jersey shore and many other summer resorts is not gasoline prices but weather, especially more cold or rain. That worry is shared by Virginia City, Nev., the frontier town that was the site of the Comstock Lode, the richest known silver deposit in the United States and where Mark Twain worked as a reporter on The Territorial Enterprise.
"Memorial Day kicks off our busiest tourist season," said Julie Lee of the Virginia City visitors bureau, "and this Memorial Day we're expecting about 15,000 visitors -- unless we get snow."
Snow at the end of May? "Why sure," she said. "Last July 12 we got three inches."
The A.A.A. and the Travel Industry Association of America predicted that summer vacationers would take a record 232 million person-trips (i.e., one person traveling 100 miles or more) this summer, 80 percent by auto, truck or recreational vehicle, and that they would spend 8.5 nights on their vacations, compared with 7.9 nights last summer. But because vacationers plan to spend the same as last year, $1,076 for a family of four, the implication is that with a longer vacation period and higher gasoline prices, they plan to spend less on food, lodging or entertainment.
Air travel is projected to account for 17 percent of the trips, five percentage points higher than last year. And while the Valujet crash in Florida earlier this month did nothing to calm fears about flying, travel agents and individual carriers said there had been no significant cancellations.
Unless the economy goes into a downturn or the 10 percent excise tax on airline tickets is reimposed, said David Swierenga, the chief economist of the Air Transport Association, "I would expect to see both domestic and international traffic to continue growing right through the summer." Year-to-date airline traffic is 5.9 percent above the same period last year.
New York City appears headed for what Jennifer McGuire of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau terms "our strongest summer this decade." Hotel reservations already presage the highest occupancies of the decade in each of the summer months, June, July and August, during which the average overall rate of 82.2 percent is likely to mean many hotels will post "no vacancy" signs virtually every night.
Although increasingly overshadowed by merriment, many communities still hold memorial services for those who died in the nation's wars, the purpose for which the holiday is intended.
On Monday, Mystic Seaport in Connecticut will recreate Decoration Day (as the holiday was originally called), as it was observed throughout the state in the 19th century, as a memorial to the casualties of the Civil War.
The ceremony will include a reading of the Gettysburg Address, after which townspeople dressed as Civil War veterans will place a floral wreath on a waterfront cannon to honor Army veterans. A second wreath honoring the Navy dead will be transported by rowboat and left floating in the Mystic River.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Drop by 7,000 in Week

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits dropped by 7,000 last week.
New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 344,000, down from 351,000 a week earlier, the Labor Department said today. It was the lowest since 340,000 claims were filed in the week that ended on May 4. 
 Many analysts had expected about 350,000 new claims. They contend a range in that neighborhood suggests a moderately improving labor market.
The four-week moving average of new claims also fell by 7,000, to 345,750 from 352,750 the previous week. The drop was the seventh straight and pushed the number to the lowest level since the average stood at 345,250 during the period that ended on Aug. 26, 1995.
Many analysts consider the less-volatile four-week average to be a more accurate gauge of labor conditions because it smooths out the spikes in the weekly reports.

HEADLINE: FINANCE BRIEFS

 BODY:

Debt
 
* BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, is selling $300 million of senior notes due in 2001 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are priced at 99.726 to yield 6.69 percent. The issue is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps.

HEADLINE: J.F.K. Trove Available For Love, Not Money

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: CATONSVILLE, Md., May 21

 BODY:
Robert White just hates it when someone picks up one of the treasures of his collection and asks, "So, what's this worth?"
He never started collecting John F. Kennedy memorabilia to get rich. Nor did he change his mind after 1,300 items owned by Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis fetched a staggering $34.4 million at a Sotheby's auction last month in New York. 
 "I'm not into selling," Mr. White said today in the cramped basement of his mother's home, where he keeps much of his collection. "This all belongs in a museum, and that's where I want it."
Mr. White, a 47-year-old industrial cleaning supplies salesman, has been collecting for more than 30 years. By now, he estimates he owns more than 100,000 Kennedy items, including the black alligator-skin Hermes briefcase the President used throughout his political career, a padded rocking chair from the White House that bears an indentation from his back brace, and the wallet and St. Christopher money clip he was carrying when he was shot in Dallas.
The prized items include thousands of handwritten pages of notes, memorandums and doodles; Kennedy's first Washington address book, which lists telephone numbers for family members as well as the Jackson Fish Market; an engraved wristwatch he wore to his 1961 inauguration, and a cigar humidor Kennedy kept on his Oval Office desk. It still contains a dozen cigars.
A humidor offered by Sotheby's -- without cigars -- brought $574,500.
The White collection pales in comparison with that of the John F. Kennedy Library and Museum in Boston, a branch of the National Archives, which has 32 million documents, 300,000 photographs and 17,000 artifacts, Frank Rigg, the curator, said.
But Mr. White says his is "the finest Kennedy collection privately owned in the world," as his business card reads. He even has documentation for his items, like the bill of sale for two "#1000 Jumbo Rockers" that Kennedy bought in 1954 for $12.50 each from the P&P Chair Company of Asheboro, N.C. On a typewritten note from an aide asking the President-elect if he intended to take one of the rockers to the White House, Kennedy answered in pen, "Whither I goest, it goes."
Sotheby's sold a similar Kennedy rocking chair for $442,500.
An aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the President's brother, said Mr. Kennedy was unaware of Mr. White's collection. John Kennedy Jr. did not respond to a request to be interviewed. Mr. Rigg said he could not comment on the White collection unless he saw it.
Mr. White said he had received the majority of his Kennedy items, including the most personal ones, from one source. He would not identify the source but said it was "a White House insider" from the Kennedy Administration. He declined to say more because of his plan to create a museum and dedicate it to his source, who died last year.
He befriended the source soon after the President was assassinated in 1963, he said, and over the years received items that the source had been given by Mrs. Kennedy or items that Kennedy family members did not want or claim after the President's death. He said his source left him even more things in a will.
The collection has grown so vast that Mr. White decided the time had come to share it with the outside world, something that until now had been almost impossible because of the limited space in his mother's house and in his own, just blocks away, in this middle-class suburb southwest of Baltimore.
He has begun discussions with city officials in Annapolis, the Maryland capital, about lending the city his collection if the city can find a site and help finance a museum project. Mr. White said he only wanted to be curator and tour guide of the museum and to collect a small salary.
So far, signs are positive. Carl O. Snowden, chairman of the Annapolis Economic Matters Committee, said he expects the City Council to approve up to $10,000 next month for a feasibility study.
"It's a golden opportunity for the city," Mr. Snowden said. "I'm very excited about the possibility of this coming to Annapolis. Tourism is very, very important to the bloodlines of the city."
Mr. White has shown the collection only to friends, friends of friends, memorabilia dealers and strangers who somehow find him through the grapevine of collectors. He happily ushers them all through his mother's foyer, down a hallway and into the dimly lit basement, which now looks more like a storehouse.
"She's been great about it," Mr. White said of his 82-year-old mother, who carries no insurance for her son's collection. "But now it's time to do something with it."
With many of the items crowded into old display cases or open shelves and evidence of Mr. White's other interests filling up sections of the basement, it is apparent the Kennedy collection needs a home of its own.
In addition to separate displays of material from the assassination, including the uniform worn by Nick McDonald, the police officer who arrested Lee Harvey Oswald, Mr. White has amassed celebrity autographs, old hotel registers and mummified heads. He also has the mummy of a gangster killed in a shootout almost 100 years ago.
The Kennedy material is the crown of his collection. It includes a golden baby ring, the passports of the Kennedys when he was a senator, telephone credit cards, a driver's license, a checkbook from the National City Bank of New York with one signed check remaining, a threatening telegram from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in the Cuban missile crisis and a page of doodled notes that read, "Blockade Cuba," with the name of President Fidel Castro of Cuba squared off in a box.
Other material associated with the assassination include the Ray-Ban prescription sunglasses Kennedy had with him in Dallas. In a wooden display box, Mr. White has two swatches of blood-stained upholstery from the limousine that carried the Kennedys. Hanging in a wall display are the United States and Presidential flags that Mr. White says were flying from the limousine. Mr. White also has what he claims is the shell casing from the bullet fired by Jack Ruby to kill Oswald.
Mr. White said that neither the material related to the assassination nor any evidence that he has of Kennedy's marital indiscretions would be focal points of the museum.
"I don't want any kiss and tell or derogatory things involved with this," he said. "And I don't want to emphasize the assassination. I want to walk people through Kennedy's life, showing the good, substantiated and credible things he did."

HEADLINE: Free (Not) to Farm

BYLINE: By James Bovard; James Bovard is the author of "Lost Rights: The Destruction of American Liberty."

DATELINE: ROCKVILLE, Md.

 BODY:
Drought in the Plains states, along with spiraling grain prices and the specter of inflation in food costs, is drawing needed attention to farm policy.
The so-called Freedom to Farm Act, signed by President Clinton last month, reduces some Federal controls over agriculture while keeping subsidies flowing. Unfortunately, Uncle Sam is still paying lavishly to let tens of millions of acres of farmland lie fallow. And the effects of the drought have been severely worsened by these policies, which continues to limit grain production. 
 The most harmful tourniquet on farm output is the Conservation Reserve Program, supported by both Democratic and Republican politicians. This year the program is paying farmers to leave 36 million acres idle. The acreage, mostly corn and wheat fields, composes about 10 percent of American cropland. While many people believe that the policy of paying farmers not to plant ended with the new farm law, it continues.
The program was begun in 1985, purportedly to protect environmentally sensitive land -- fields vulnerable to erosion, for example. But it is largely a means of increasing Federal handouts. Most land enrolled in the program could easily be farmed with no major environmental harm. Farmers who enroll sign a contract to leave certain lands idle for 10 years in return for annual payments. Routinely, the payments are the equivalent of double or triple the local rental rate for the land. This is like offering people $40 an hour to go on welfare so long as they promise not to look for a job for 10 years.
A result of the Conservation Reserve Program is that much of the best farmland is left unplowed, even as world markets loudly demand more grain. The forgone harvests cut American exports by billions of dollars at a time when politicians claim to be worried about the trade deficit.
President Clinton and Congress had a chance with the new farm bill to end this system. But with its strong appeal for farmers and environmentalists alike, it was renewed. The Administration also had the option of making it easy for farmers to withdraw early from the program if crop prices are high enough to encourage planting, as they are now. Instead, it issued regulations so tangled that most farmers chose to stick with the current commitment.
The Administration has pursued other policies intended to create a domestic grain shortage. Last year, it continued to spend lavishly on export subsidies, using tax dollars to underwrite foreign buyers who wound up getting American wheat at fire-sale prices.
Also, despite signs of a potential shortfall in corn reserves, last year the Administration required corn growers participating in support programs to leave five million acres idle. Since then, corn prices have more than doubled. The mandate symbolized the Administration's determination to minimize harvests in order to maximize prices -- and farmers' votes. (Consumers, who face higher food prices as a result,are also voters, but they usually don't think about farm policy in the voting booth.)
One positive aspect of the new farm bill is that this sort of set-aside is prohibited. But the President is talking about trying to amend the law, and it is difficult to know which foolish policies will be revived.
Food is too important to become simply another political pawn. The Government must stop idling farmlands and end its mindless policy of artificial scarcity.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips a Bit Against Mark In Pre-Weekend Profit Taking

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly lower against most leading currencies yesterday on profit taking ahead of a long holiday weekend in the United States.
The dollar surged against the German mark early in the day on reports that Anatoly Stepanov, a Russian deputy justice minister, had been murdered in Moscow. The news aroused fears of growing instability in Russia leading up to the June presidential elections. The mark is vulnerable to instability in Russia because of the large amount of investment German companies have in the country. 
 But the dollar retreated on profit taking in early New York trading. In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5425 marks, down from 1.5428 marks on Wednesday. The dollar was trading at 106.93 Japanese yen, down from 107.18 yen Wednesday. The British pound rose to $1.5120 from $1.5086.
Trading is expected to be thin today; financial markets in the United States and many in Europe will be closed on Monday.
The mark was bolstered yesterday after Ernst Welteke, president of the regional central bank in Hesse and a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, told a conference in Germany that an April slowdown in the country's money-supply growth did not necessarily imply that interest rates would fall anytime soon.
The broadest measure of Germany's money supply slowed to an 11.2 percent annual rate last month compared with a 12.3 percent rate in March. German monetary officials are sensitive to money supply growth because it can contribute to inflation and diminish the prospects for lower interest rates.
But currency traders have been betting that Germany's sagging economy will prompt the Bundesbank to further reduce interest rates to stimulate growth.
"Welteke's remarks were interpreted as meaning it's too early to say whether there will be a rate cut," said Win Thin, an economist at HSBC Midland in New York.
The dollar declined modestly on that news. Still, buyers emerged when the dollar fell below the 1.5400 level, suggesting that the longer-term trend for the dollar remains stronger against the mark.
"People are still in the mode that the dollar is grinding its way higher," said Steve Jonathan, a director of foreign exchange sales at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "It's going to be a slow grind, but an upward grind nonetheless."

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Deal Shows Banks Ease Loan Rule For Co-ops

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
The East New York Savings Bank closed a $10.7 million mortgage loan to a cooperative apartment building in Queens last week even though only 14 percent of the apartments were owner-occupied. The percentage was well below the 50 percent generally considered the norm for writing mortgages, either for co-op corporations or for individual co-op or condominium buyers.
It is still rare to see mortgages written with such an extremely small percentage of apartments owned by the people who live in them -- not owned by the building's sponsor or by investors who buy apartments from the sponsor. But several major mortgage brokers said the writing of such loans was on the increase. 
 "There were always a few lenders who would do these loans," said Jerry Swartz, partner in Pergolis Swartz, a large mortgage broker whose firm handles the underlying mortgages for buildings. "What's new is that today there are more of them."
"Funds are more available now; the market is much more competitive to loan money," Mr. Swartz added. "There's banks that weren't competing in the market before."
Mortgage brokers and loan officers interviewed stressed that to lend money to the co-op corporation, for the underlying mortgage, or to individuals purchasing co-ops or condominiums when owner-occupancy is below 50 or 60 percent, certain conditions must be met. They explained that without these conditions, the risk of an investor who owns a lot of apartments going bankrupt -- and leaving the co-op in the lurch -- was just too high.
"No. 1, the building must be in a desirable area, where the subleasing of apartments will bring in more money than must be paid for maintenance of the apartments," said Sam Giarrusso, who heads real estate loans at East New York Savings.
To assess whether a building is a good risk, the loan applicant must be able to generate a positive cash flow on the bulk of his apartments. In other words, if the absentee shareholder can sublease an apartment for $900, and pays only $500 for maintenance, the bank may look favorably at the investment.
The bank will next look toward the personal assets and liabilities of absentee shareholders to see if they have sufficient income or liquid assets to make necessary repairs.
"We look at their integrity, their track record," Mr. Giarrusso said.
With individual mortgages for apartment buyers, the bank also looks hard at the percentage of owner-occupied apartments buildingwide, mortgage brokers said.
If the percentage is the same -- less than 50 or 60 percent, depending on the bank -- it is traditionally difficult to obtain a mortgage.
But Ellen Bitton, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, said that more banks than ever would consider such a loan. She said she knew about eight banks of the 24 she dealt with that would do so. "It's very different from two years ago," she said.
But she cautioned that the banks lending to individuals use the same criteria they do when lending to buildings: The desirability of the building and the creditworthiness of the person or persons seeking the loan is taken into account.
The guidelines apply not only to co-ops, although condominiums as a whole are not allowed to have underlying mortgages. Ms. Bitton told of a woman who wanted to buy a condominium apartment in a five-year-old building on Park Avenue. When she applied for the loan the building had almost no apartments sold.
The building had been built as a condominium, but ended up being completed at the nadir of the real estate recession, so its developers decided to rent out the units until the market improved. Although the woman had excellent credit, it took a year to close on a loan. By the closing, nine of 21 apartments had been sold, still a low percentage but nowhere near as bad as zero.
People seeking mortgages on buildings and apartments in which the building has a low ratio of owner-occupants may still have a tough time. But banks are apparently eager to give loans in buildings with more than 60 percent owner-occupancy.
"We just can't compete with what the banks give people with buildings with 65 or 70 percent," Mr. Giarrusso of East New York Savings said. "There's a lot of players in that marketplace." As an incentive, Mr. Giarrusso said, some of the larger banks will offer lines of credit for capital improvements, and some will offer no-point loans, where the buyer does not have to pay an extra percentage of the loan at the time of closing.
While some of the smaller banks may consider giving mortgages to buildings with fewer owner-occupants, they charge more for the loan, Mr. Giarrusso said.

HEADLINE: Senators Offer Bipartisan Plan To Cut Taxes in the District

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
In an effort to reverse years of population and economic decline in the District of Columbia, two Senators said today that they would introduce a bill on Friday that would substantially cut the Federal taxes paid by District residents.
The measure, co-sponsored by Connie Mack, a Florida Republican, and Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, is almost identical to a House bill introduced last month by the District's representative, Eleanor Holmes Norton, a Democrat, which she said was the only viable way of saving the city from ruin. 
 The House and Senate bills would both create a flat Federal income tax rate for District residents of 15 percent, down from as high as 39.6 percent. Standard deductions would rise to $15,000 for single filers, $25,000 for head of household filers and $30,000 for married couples. Those figures were $3,900, $5,750 and $6,550, respectively, last year.
The Senate bill would eliminate capital gains taxes for any business investment in the city, while the House bill would do so only for investments by District residents. The Senate bill would also provide a $5,000 tax credit for first-time home buyers in the District. Ms. Norton's bill has no such incentive.
Describing the tax cuts as "the best way to help" the nation's capital, Mr. Mack said today that he expected both bills to pass this year. And if that happened, Mr. Lieberman said, "I bet you a lot of money President Clinton signs it."
"High taxes are driving people out of the District of Columbia," Mr. Mack said at a news conference, where the Senators were joined by Ms. Norton and Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Bush Administration. Mr. Kemp has been a strong supporter of using tax breaks to attract residents and businesses to cities.
The lawmakers and Mr. Kemp said that if the cuts helped Washington's economy, Federal and state tax breaks could be used to resuscitate other urban areas losing population for the same reasons -- crime, poor schools and inefficient city services.
It is not clear, however, whether the Clinton Administration supports the idea of Federal tax cuts for District residents or of having the cuts be a model for use across the country. In an interview after Ms. Norton proposed her bill, Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, said the measure was "more a dramatization of the problem than a real solution."
Also, at a time when Congress and the White House are straining to balance the budget in seven years, the lawmakers said that neither the House nor Senate had analyzed how much the tax cuts would cost the Federal Government.
Mr. Kemp estimated the cuts would cost $700 million to $800 million a year for up to six years.
The proposed tax cuts have become the latest in a series of efforts to restore the District's economy. Congress last year created a financial control board to help the city curb spending. The White House has appointed a task force to work with city agencies to solve problems. And Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has begun work on a four-year plan to reduce the size of city government by 25 percent.
But the tax cuts would appear to be the most dramatic of the initiatives.
Stressing the bipartisan nature of their efforts, Mr. Kemp nodded toward Ms. Norton and said: "We've joined together in a bleeding heart issue to save the nation's capital. This is an urgent plea to the White House and leaders of the House and Senate. Do it now. People in this city desperately need urgent action."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators Joseph I. Lieberman, left, and Connie Mack yesterday described a bill they will introduce to cut Washington residents' taxes. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
