HEADLINE: North Korean Fighter Pilot Defects to South With Jet

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 23

 BODY:
A North Korean Air Force captain defected to South Korea today in his MIG-19 fighter plane, setting off air raid sirens before arriving on a South Korean air base with his aircraft and a mountain of intelligence about the North Korean military.
The incident lasted only about 13 minutes as the defector, Capt. Lee Chul So, raced to the Yellow Sea from North Korea and then inland toward South Korea. South Korean forces, fearing an attack, set off air raid alarms in the western suburbs of Seoul, the capital, and scrambled six fighters to intercept the Northern plane. 
 Captain Lee dipped his wings, to signal that he was not hostile, and the South Korean planes escorted him carefully to an air base where he landed and was immediately placed under tight security.
"I couldn't live under the North's system any longer," Captain Lee told a handful of South Korean reporters who were allowed to talk to him soon after he landed.
The defection, if genuine, was the first in 13 years of a pilot with a plane. The MIG-19 is an old model and is not expected to yield major new information to South Korean intelligence specialists, but Captain Lee is a rare source of direct information on the abilities and preparedness of the North Korean Air Force.
"It's not just a plane and a man, but information about the state of troops in North Korea," said a senior Government official in South Korea.
The defection comes at a very delicate moment in inter-Korean relations. North Korea, the last Stalinist state in the world, is suffering from economic disintegration and widespread hunger, and some American officials warn that the North could strike out against South Korea out of desperation, believing that the alternative is internal collapse.
The border between the Koreas remains the site of the greatest massing of enemy troops in the world, and the United States keeps 37,000 American troops in South Korea to deter a North Korean attack. To reduce the risk of another Korean war, President Clinton and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea met in the South last month and together offered a new peace proposal to the North.
The proposal, which North Korea has said it is still considering, calls for four-party peace talks involving the two Koreas, the United States and China. Some experts warned today that the defection would infuriate North Korean leaders and might leave them less inclined to accept the peace proposal.
"It will probably make North Korean policy makers more nervous about contacts with South Korea, and they may draw back for a little while," said Kim Kyung Won, a former envoy to the United Nations and the United States.
North Korea had no comment today on the defection.
Defections from North Korea are growing increasingly common, though usually they are civilians who come through third countries. A growing number have been drawn from the North Korean elite, in what may be a sign of growing discontent even in the most pampered stratum of North Korean's society.
"This is another in the current series of defections by members of North Korea's establishment," another senior South Korean Government official said. "This is someone the North Korean leadership trusts."
To reduce the risk of defections, North Korea carefully picks pilots who are thought to be especially reliable politically and who have family members they must leave behind. In addition, the cockpit radios of military aircraft are rigged so that they cannot receive South Korean transmissions, making it impossible for a defecting pilot to explain his purpose to South Korean pilots or South Korean ground control.
Captain Lee leaves his father, his wife and two children behind in North Korea. There have been reports that members of defectors' families are sometimes imprisoned or executed, although on other occasions family members have avoided severe punishment.
South Korea offers rewards for defectors, although it has drastically trimmed them recently, and a South Korean television station said Captain Lee might be able to collect $320,000 for landing the MIG-19 in South Korea.
At the time of the last defection, in 1983, South Korean radar was late in detecting the intrusion. But the radar systems have been upgraded, and today Government officials said with some relief that Captain Lee's plane had immediately prompted an alert.
"The South Korean intercept mission worked perfectly," said Jim Coles, an American spokesman for the United Nations forces in South Korea.
In another unusual incident today, North Korea reportedly sent five naval vessels into South Korean-controlled waters this morning. While such intrusions happen from time to time, military specialists said this involved more boats than any previous such incident.
The episode began, according to an account by the South Korean Defense Ministry, when about 10 North Korean naval craft approached the maritime dividing line. Five of the boats crossed over and remained about 20 minutes before being chased back by South Korean gunboats sent to the area. No shots were fired.
North Korea offered a different version of events, asserting that the South Koreans had illegally infiltrated warships deep inside North Korean territorial waters.
"The infiltration of the warships is a deliberate and premeditated provocation aimed at intentionally aggravating inter-Korean confrontation and tension," the North Korean statement declared.

HEADLINE: Anger at French Troops Grows in Central Africa

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: NDJAMENA, Chad, May 23

 BODY:
A mutiny by unpaid soldiers in the Central African Republic showed signs today of turning into a popular uprising against French intervention in the country, after French soldiers came to the aid of the Government.
With Paris sending mixed signals about its intentions in the Central African Republic, a former colony still under strong French influence, diplomats said what started as a minor army insurrection now threatens to become a serious embarrassment for France. 
 The spreading of the crisis began late Wednesday, when a French helicopter gunship fired on a van carrying several mutineers as they headed into an assault on the national radio station in the capital, Bangui. Nine of the rebellious soldiers were reportedly killed in the attack.
Early today, as news of the French action spread through the city, several thousand angry demonstrators shouting anti-French slogans marched in central Bangui to protest foreign intervention. Emboldened mutineers, many of them shedding their uniforms, secured positions in the heavily looted downtown area, occasionally firing on French troops, at least two of whom have been wounded.
According to radio reports from the city, French troops, together with Central African soldiers who remained loyal to the President Ange-Felix Patasse, fired warning shots to prevent the marchers from reaching the French Embassy nearby. But before the crowd could be dispersed, the demonstrators set a lavishly built French cultural center ablaze, destroying the new structure.
Taking no chances with a further loss of control, Paris announced that all of its citizens in the country, along with departing Americans and other foreigners, were being evacuated immediately.
With airplanes operating around the clock, French officials said they expected the bulk of the evacuation would be completed by early Friday.
"The people were shouting anti-French slogans and we felt quite threatened," said one evacuee who was interviewed on French radio. "They were altogether out of control. Uncontrollable."
Along with Chad, the Central African Republic represents the heart of France's military presence in Africa. Its forces in the region are intended to protect French interests and help project the country's power from the shores of the Indian Ocean to the Atlantic.
An opposition leader, Abel Goumba, told the BBC that he blamed the French intervention for the sharp deterioration of a situation that even on Wednesday seemed well on its way to being resolved by negotiation.
Mr. Goumba accused the French of waging a "veritable war." The French Government sent increasingly confusing signals about the purpose of its intervention.
When the Central African Republic's second army mutiny in two months began on Saturday, the French Minister of Foreign Assistance, Jacques Godfrain, who routinely manages France's relations with its former colonies, said on French radio that France would not intervene in its former African colonies except in cases of "external aggression."
"We are not the gendarmes of Africa," Mr. Godfrain said.
On Wednesday, however, as Paris began to receive panicked calls for intervention from its African clients, including many unpopular governments of questionable democratic credentials, the French Government seemed to change its tune.
"The mission is to maintain the democratic state; that means freedom of movement and freedom of expression," Mr. Godfrain said.
Today, as the situation deteriorated further, Paris retreated from this position, with Mr. Godfrain saying that the French military had been dispatched primarily to assure the safety of some 2,500 French citizens who live in the Central African Republic, along with that of other foreigners.
Late today, French and other radio reports from the country said that negotiations had resumed between a leader of the rebels, Sgt. Cyriac Souki, and a French general, Bernard Thorette, who was flown to the country from Paris, along with his staff, 100 special forces commandos and 24 armored personnel carriers early Thursday.
Prior to the stepped-up French intervention on Thursday, the mutineers were demanding the resignation of key defense aides to Mr. Patasse, in addition to an ultimatum made in an uprising last month that their back salaries be paid.
When Mr. Patasse balked at replacing his military confidants, the rebellious troops in the capital, emboldened by the spread of the mutiny to the countryside, raised the stakes, saying for the first time that Mr. Patasse himself must step down.
France's relations with Mr. Patasse are complicated by his long history of opposition to the presence of French bases in his country, which Paris has frequently used to intervene in the country's politics or mount missions in neighboring countries.
Mr. Patasse was elected in 1993 as a wave of democratic reforms that swept much of this region early in the decade ended a long string of dictatorships here. Diplomats say he has proven to be an ineffectual leader, however, and as the country's economic difficulties have multiplied, he has shown increasingly autocratic tendencies.
Serious political turbulence began in April when troops, whose monthly salaries rarely top $100, rebelled, demanding back pay and better working conditions.

HEADLINE: A Fund to Bail Out Countries in Crisis Is Doubled, to $50 Billion

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The big industrial nations agreed today with a group of smaller countries to double the money available for dealing with a severe international financial crisis, to $50 billion.
The agreement comes a year and a half after the global economic system was shaken by the near-collapse of the Mexican peso, and is intended to provide more firepower in keeping acute, destabilizing financial problems in one country from spreading to others. 
 The money would be lent to the International Monetary Fund rather than directly to a country in crisis, and would be disbursed only to countries agreeing to strict economic programs, officials said.
The doubling has been a key objective of the big industrial democracies since the Mexico crisis. American officials said this agreement, along with an I.M.F. plan adopted last month to require all nations to disclose more economic and financial data, strengthened the ability to prevent and deal with financial catastrophes.
The expanded war chest is being financed by bringing about 15 new countries into the crisis fund and by extracting higher pledges from current participants.
The agreement spreads the burden of dealing with a large-scale crisis from 11 of the biggest economies -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain, Canada, Belgium, Switzerland, Sweden and the Netherlands -- to smaller European nations like Austria and to fast-growing Southeast Asian countries like Singapore and Malaysia.
The American commitment would increase by 50 percent, from $6.16 billion at current exchange rates to $9.25 billion. Although the increase requires Congressional authorization, officials say it would not require any actual budget outlay or add to the Federal deficit because any money lent to the I.M.F. under the program would be secured by the monetary fund's own financial reserves, including billions of dollars' worth of gold. Treasury officials said they did not expect any problem getting the authorization.
"This is a sound and prudent agreement," said Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. He said the fund would be called upon "only in exceptional circumstances" and only when the borrowing nations "are willing to take strong corrective policy actions."
The new arrangement would require the approval of participants representing 80 percent of the money pledged to the fund. The weighted American share, according to figures provided by Treasury officials, would be slightly over 20 percent, giving the United States a veto.
Indeed, the emergency fund was set up to protect against a crisis in one of the big industrial economies.
The last time money from the fund was borrowed was in 1978 when the United States called on the fund to help build up its currency reserves. Since then the fund has become a last line of protection against a potentially destablizing crisis.
The agreement was reached in Paris at a meeting of the 11 industrialized countries. Mario Draghi, the Treasury Secretary of Italy, who presided at the meeting, said in a statement that agreement "has been reached both on the broad principles and on the key substantive points for new arrangements to increase the resources available to the I.M.F. to deal with international financial emergencies."
Officials said the agreement was likely to win final approval in the coming months. They said they expected it to be adopted by the I.M.F., whose managing director, Michael Camdessus, was appointed on Wednesday to a third five-year term.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Excerpts From Dole Speech: 'Referendum on the Basic Values of the Country'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a prepared text of Senator Bob Dole's speech yesterday at the Catholic Press Association's annual convention in Philadelphia:
 Most of us grew up in a time when it wasn't politically incorrect for our parents, our schools and our churches to instill some values in us. Values like civility. Decency. Charity. Personal responsibility. Individual initiative. 
 I said last week when I announced my decision to leave the Senate that my campaign for the Presidency is not merely about attaining office. It is about fundamental things, consequential things, things that are real.
The values I just mentioned are fundamental. They are consequential. They are real. And restoring them to their rightful place in our society is what my campaign for President is all about. . . .
Every Presidential election is, to some degree, a referendum on the basic values of the country. This election, I believe, will turn even more than most on those bigger questions -- on the direction our country is headed now, and where it should be headed.
It is no secret that the majority of Americans believe our nation is on the wrong track. Today's newspapers are filled with stories about job layoffs and corporate downsizing. Two incomes are now an economic necessity for too many families, not a choice. Our economy is not growing as fast as it should.
But while these feelings of economic anxiety are certainly widespread, I believe our problems go much deeper than that. There is a sense of moral drift in America -- and it has us worried.
Look around. Americans are all too often faced with schools that don't teach, courts that don't punish, welfare policies that impoverish, a popular culture that undermines our most cherished values and a whole range of other social problems that politicians promised would be solved long ago. . . .
Once, our schools were places of learning and order. In public schools from Philadelphia to Chicago to Russell, Kan., generations of Americans -- kids of all classes, races and creeds -- were brought together. They instilled ambition, hope, discipline, decency and love of country. That was the purpose they were meant to serve and can serve again.
But where is that spirit today? Many parents today view our public schools as hostile to their own deepest values. Instead of instilling hope and discipline, too often our schools breed resentment, despair and mediocrity. Our schools are teaching recycling and AIDS prevention, but our kids can't add and too often aren't allowed to pray.
That is why I favor the most sweeping reforms of our public schools -- beginning with the principle of school choice. I support our nation's public schools, for how could I not? I am a product of one. Nonetheless, I believe every parent in America should have the right to choose the school that is best for their children -- public, private or parochial.
Our welfare system discourages work, undermines families and perpetuates poverty. If some enemy of our country wanted to undermine the fabric of American society, it could not inflict anything upon us worse than the welfare system we have inflicted upon ourselves. . . .
On Tuesday, I outlined a series of welfare reforms which would address the national epidemic of illegitimate births, discourage drug use among welfare recipients and encourage people on welfare to work. That will go a long way towards fulfilling a well-known promise to "end welfare as we know it."
But I am determined to go further. We all know that too often a baby born on welfare belongs to a baby who was born on welfare. We are just beginning to recognize that perhaps half of the fathers of those babies are grown men, 20 years or older. In other words, a central feature of the plague of illegitimacy is older men preying on young girls.
Solving the welfare problem must include ending the epidemic of these male sexual predators. That is why I issued a call to our nation's governors: Enforce the statutory-rape laws you already have on your books. Make them stronger where need be. But enforce them to the fullest.
There are things government can do to help those in need. Social Security -- which I helped to save in 1983 -- has lifted generations of elderly out of poverty. Food stamps and the WIC program -- which I helped to create -- have provided nourishment to the most vulnerable among us. The Americans With Disabilities Act -- which I sponsored -- opened for millions a door that had been shut for too long. And Medicare -- which I am fighting to preserve -- has helped protect millions of elderly and disabled Americans.
These are our responsibilities as a government, but they do not exhaust our responsibilities as a people. Our faith in the Great Society has ended, but our moral duties to the poor have not.
I do not believe in the hard philosophy of sink or swim -- the survival of the fittest. Because that is not the way my community treated me. Because my life is a tribute to the people who thought life was bigger and nobler than that. I learned the hard way that while self-reliance is an essential part of the American character, so is that generous spirit that reaches out to those wounded in body and soul.
The alternative to cold bureaucracy is not indifference. It is the warmth of families and neighborhoods, charities, churches, synagogues and communities. These value-shaping institutions have the tools to reclaim lives -- individual responsibility, tough love and spiritual renewal. They do more than care for the body, they restore the spirit. . . .
America does not lack community organizations or parishes or synagogues willing to help restore goodness to our country. The problem is, these organizations lack the resources they need to do so.
To this end, I will propose a charity tax credit, which over time would allow taxpayers to earmark a portion of their annual taxes to private and religious charities -- faith-based or not -- that spend over 75 percent of their money on poverty relief. This credit will be up to $500 for individuals and up to $1,000 for couples.
The goal is to get funding and authority into the hands of institutions that reclaim lives. It would present Americans with a stark choice: Give your money to the Department of Housing and Urban Development, or give it to Habitat for Humanity; give it to the Department of Health and Human Services, or to Mother Teresa and the Sisters of Charity; to Big Government, or to Big Brothers and Big Sisters.
Americans, I believe, have lost patience with the Great Society. But they have not lost their compassion for the poor and their commitment to the common good. This direction is a way to both part with our political illusions and maintain our human decency. . . .
Indeed, many of the cultural problems America faces cannot be solved by reforming failed government programs. This places public officials at every level in a new role -- a role that may not be comfortable, but which has become essential. We must speak not just for innovative policies but for enduring values like family, work, responsibility and tolerance.
I decided that I must use the bully pulpit to discuss these issues if I am to lead. Our times demand more of us than policies and programs -- they require a vision of the kind of people we aim to be.
Early in this campaign, I raised some questions about popular culture and the industry that shapes it. While I spoke out against the Hollywood movies and music which celebrate casual sex and mindless violence, it touched a chord with people everywhere. Parents know the pull of the popular culture. They know that televisions and movie screens, boom boxes and headsets, are windows to the world for our children -- an advance report on the adult world our kids are so eager to experience.
Leaders in our entertainment industry enjoy all the freedoms and privileges America can offer. What do they offer in return? All too often, they give us films, music and television which debases our culture, scorns virtue and celebrates shamelessness. I do not question anyone's right of artistic expression. But I would again remind that industry that art and virtue are not opposites. Art should lift us up -- it does not have to drag us down. You don't have to be an art critic to see the difference between freedom and license -- between Michelangelo and Mapplethorpe. . . .
Finally, Americans look to the White House for moral leadership. Yet, in some way, we have an Administration that reflects the most troubling features of our culture. An Administration that seems to believe in everything and nothing. An Administration which talks about the "politics of meaning," and with such talk reinforces, for far too many, the meaninglessness of politics. An Administration guided by nothing more profound or permanent than the latest polling data. An Administration constantly exhorting itself and lecturing the public but itself fundamentally adrift, without direction or moral vision.
The saddest evidence of this came last month when President Clinton vetoed a bill to prevent partial-birth abortions.
Let me speak to this issue as simply and directly as I can. I am pro-life. I am opposed to abortion on demand. But I understand that reasonable and decent people can disagree on certain points. Here, though, was an easy call. Here was an issue where all Americans can come together.
With his veto, President Clinton pushed the limits of decency too far.
When the vote to override that veto is cast, I may no longer be a Senator. But if I am, I will stand proudly with all the Democrats who voted against the President on partial-birth abortions. I would vote with Senator Moynihan, a man of conscience who calls the practice "too close to infanticide." Though not a Catholic, I would listen to Pope John Paul II, who calls the practice a "brutal" act of inhumanity.
And if I am President, I can tell you exactly what I would do. I will ask Congress to pass a bill banning the practice, and I will sign it into law.
I know that on this particular issue there are those who seek to focus on what divides us. I prefer to focus on what unites us -- the values that hold us together as a people. It is in these values that I have found my strength and our nation has found its strength.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mayor's Stalled Plans Leave Public Hospitals in Trauma

SERIES: PROGNOSIS: POOR -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Ever since he was elected, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has derided New York's public hospitals and vowed to turn some of them over to private hospitals, which he says will provide the poor with better care and save the city money. Three hospitals are on the auction block and the administration predicts a deal this summer.
But as the Mayor and his advisers try to spin off large chunks of the system to the private sector, so far unsuccessfully, critics say they have so neglected the hospitals that patient services and building conditions are worse than at any time in recent years. 
 In two years, the Mayor has trimmed more than three-fourths of the city's annual direct subsidy to the public hospitals, and he plans to give only $37 million in the next fiscal year. His advisers have presided over rapid-fire downsizing campaigns designed to eliminate inefficiency, which last week culminated in the system's governing body, the Health and Hospitals Corporation, announcing it would lay off 2,800 of the system's 38,000 hospital employees by July 1.
At the same time, the planned hospital sales and other efforts to move public hospitals out of the system are stalled primarily by a shortage of potential buyers, who are worried that Medicaid cuts will make it less profitable to care for the poor. So the infusions of private cash and know-how that were to help rescue the hospitals and replace public funds have not materialized.
Administrators, doctors and nurses at the public hospitals describe a flagging system in which bed sheets go unchanged, patients wait months to see specialists, repairs on X-ray machines are delayed or forgone and storerooms run out of essential supplies, like suture material for emergency rooms.
What's more, hospital directors say that budget demands have prevented them from buying equipment -- such as computer systems -- that they desperately need to survive in a competitive market dominated by managed care.
"The corporation finds itself under siege and the city has done a very poor job of trying to explain how they believe it will survive," said Martin Arrick, managing director of Standard and Poor's Corporation, the bond-rating agency that lowered the corporation's rating in November. "It is fine to say we want to off-load hospitals, but that's not a policy or a plan."
Maria K. Mitchell, whom the Mayor chose as his special adviser on health policy and installed last year as chairwoman of the hospital agency, insisted that the city's tougher fiscal policy would "strengthen these hospitals." But instead of propping up a failing system, the city was insisting for the first time that each hospital achieve financial independence and learn to compete in the private market, she said. "They now have that mindset, so they are stronger and that makes them a bigger player," she said.
Revamping the hospitals corporation by bringing in private investment was one of two planks in the Mayor's election platform on health care; the other was to enroll Medicaid patients in managed care plans. The latter is also stalled.
While health experts credit City Hall with injecting accountability into a system long known for loose spending and mediocre medicine, many say that if the Mayor knowingly throws these struggling hospitals into the turbulent seas of New York's managed care market without more support, some will sink, and fast.
Already, the combined effect of dwindling financing and new market forces have caused the public hospitals' patient census to drop 21 percent in the last 18 months. Prized employees and insured patients are fleeing to the private sector, leaving decaying buildings and the sickest or uninsured patients behind.
"The Mayor's action -- or in some cases his lack of action -- is driving the public hospitals on a downward spiral," said Emilio Morante, who resigned two years ago as director of H.H.C.'s North Central Bronx Hospital. "At some point, care will become so atrocious that he will be able to say these really are terrible places. And no one will care if they disappear."
 
Unfolding Strategies
Hospitals Search For Private Support
City Hall's strategy for taking care of the poor relies heavily on the notion that private hospitals or other independent agencies would acquire public hospitals and -- importantly -- pay to improve them. A mayoral advisory panel recommended last year that the entire public hospital system be dismantled, although the Mayor distanced himself somewhat from that suggestion.
Mr. Giuliani has offered Coney Island Hospital, Elmhurst Medical Center, and Queens Hospital Center for lease. And the city is quietly but aggressively trying to move several other hospitals out of the corporation by more circuitous routes.
Dr. Luis Marcos, the corporation's president, said he would like to see Kings County Hospital Center merged with an adjacent state hospital, University Hospital of Brooklyn. The Mayor's health advisers hope that Montefiore Medical Center, a large private hospital in the Bronx, will take over North Central Bronx Hospital and, perhaps, Jacobi Medical Center, according to a corporation official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
With managed care companies demanding streamlined medical care rolling into New York in the past few years, it has become clear that the oversized Health and Hospitals Corporation needs restructuring. The corporation has eliminated 2,000 of its 8,000 beds in the past two years and reduced its work force by more than 20 percent, to 38,000, mostly through severance and early retirement offers.
But reworking the agency, with its $3 billion annual budget, is a political minefield, since its 11 hospitals and dozens of clinics are as much community symbols and employers as they are sites for medical care.
Ms. Mitchell acknowledged that the Giuliani administration was now courting partnerships between public hospitals and others, and defended that approach as the most effective way to bring innovation, and investments, into the lumbering hospitals corporation. She said that Harlem Hospital Center is developing a Medicaid health maintenance organization in conjunction with two private hospitals, North General Hospital and Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center -- and said she expected other similar arrangements to follow. Private hospitals, which have themselves lost business to managed care, have become increasingly interested in treating poor people with government insurance, she said.
But with Medicaid rates now plummeting and the ranks of the uninsured rising, health experts say that private medical centers once intrigued by the prospect of owning a public hospital now have second thoughts.
Although a mayoral advisory panel recently disclosed its plan to cover the uninsured through a tax on hospitals and insurers, the Mayor has not endorsed the strategy and health economists question its financing. The New York State statute that compensates hospitals for charity care expires July 1.
Hospital executives say that sales prospects wane as the city watches patients leave and buildings decay. "These hospitals are slipping, their patients are leaving," said an executive at a private hospital that has been mentioned as a buyer. "Soon, there may not be anything left to sell or even give away."
 
Deteriorating Conditions
Patient Care Slips With Slimmer Budgets
As the public hospitals wait for their unnamed saviors, they are falling apart.
"There are prolonged waiting times for charts, there are no elevator operators around, elevators and X-rays don't work and aren't fixed," a physician, who spoke on condition of anonymity and has worked at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx for decades, said. "As the Mayor cuts back, he will make it extraordinarily difficult to take care of patients here."
The Mayor has said that services at H.H.C have not been affected by the streamlining campaign. But doctors, nurses and administrators who spoke on condition of anonymity told of a dirtier system falling into deeper disrepair. They mentioned these conditions:
*The Emergency Department at Kings County Hospital last month ran out of suture material to close wounds, forcing doctors to use a more expensive, delicate thread normally reserved for plastic surgery. At the same hospital, a referral to an eye doctor is taking more than four months, and to a neurologist, more than three months.
*At some hospitals, like Bellevue and Harlem, psychiatric patients brought to the emergency room who do not require admission must wait three to five weeks for a follow-up visit -- although many are actively schizophrenic and delusional.
*Queens Hospital is so short of nursing staff members that patients are not always washed daily nor are their sheets always changed.
*Patients at Bellevue now wait more than a month for a new gynecology appointment, although the corporation standard stipulates a wait of no more than 10 days.
*Staffing shortages have forced the closing of the outpatient X-ray department at Jacobi for three of five days in each of the last two weeks.
*At North Central Bronx, doctors taking care of AIDS patients now see 15 a day, up from 8 this time last year.
Numerous projects planned within the past two years -- including customer service training and cultivating a health maintenance organization based at the public hospitals -- have been held up in large measure because executives have little time or money for forward-looking pursuits.
"The idea that you can strip the budget and get rid of staff and the quality will stay the same is ludicrous," said Howard Berliner, professor of health policy at the New School for Social Research. "If H.H.C. does not hurry up and get itself into the managed care game in a major way, it is out of business."
 
A Murky Vision
Critics Question Giuliani's Motives
In interviews, current and former public hospital executives said that the attitude displayed by the Giuliani administration and Ms. Mitchell toward the corporation ranges from overt hostility to benign neglect.
"The administration constantly undermines these hospitals because of an ideological bias against the institution," said David Jones, a corporation board member who has clashed frequently with the Mayor. Mr. Jones said that the Mayor's advisers shot down an advertising campaign proposed by the board after the corporation's 11 acute care hospitals finally received full national accreditation last year. Likewise, a state official said that when the public hospitals received surprisingly high marks in a state survey of maternity care, the Mayor's office effectively canceled a press conference that had been scheduled by officials of the corporation to promote the results.
"There is no guiding vision here except that any way you can dismantle the system or show that privatization is working is good," said one H.H.C. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "As long as H.H.C is inefficient and delivering poor care, it's a great argument for privatizing H.H.C."
 
Shrinking Resources
Projects Stall As Priorities Shift
Ms. Mitchell, the Mayor's special adviser on health care, disputed reports of troubled services at the public hospitals, noting that "access to care had improved dramatically at H.H.C."
Ms. Mitchell also said she was not overly concerned about the exodus of patients to private hospitals. "It's not a bad thing that patients have choices and can choose a place they perceive as being better," she said. "It is our goal to give them choices and to upgrade facilities that are not up to par."
Dr. Marcos, appointed as president by the Mayor within the last year, acknowledged the hard times caused by downsizing. But he said that the root problem was, simply, a lack of money. The corporation almost did not make its payroll payments in late March -- an H.H.C. aide had to fly to Albany to pick up a state Medicaid reimbursement check and deposit it at Chemical Bank, said one corporation official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
"We simply don't have the money to support this huge organization," Dr. Marcos said. "The big issue for me is that these hospitals are struggling for survival and how are they going to make it." The corporation faces a $550 million deficit for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
Dr. Marcos said that he would be hiring fewer consultants and streamlining outpatient clinics -- which, he noted, lost $250 million last year. He pointed out that the public hospitals have far more employees than private hospitals their size, and will need to further trim the workforce -- particularly given patient defections.
In these lean times, Dr. Marcos said, there was not even money set aside for hospital projects that had been previously approved, such as the rebuilding of Queens and Kings County hospitals. Both hospitals still house patients in large open wards.
The administration hopes that a private purchaser will rebuild Queens, whose renovation was last estimated at $550 million. And the Mayor's advisers are counting on the Federal Government or New York State to help foot the bill for the Kings County project -- although state officials say they will not bankroll it.
 
An Unsettling Limbo
Private Hands Wary Of Unstable Hospitals
Thus far, H.H.C.'s efforts to wrangle deals with the private sector have yielded mixed results and left the fate of many hospitals hanging.
More than a year ago, corporation executives announced that they would pay less and demand more from the private hospitals and medical groups which provide doctors on contract for the public hospitals. But so far only the Woodhull Medical Group -- a physician company that staffs Woodhull Hospital -- has agreed to the new terms. Albert Einstein College of Medicine and New York Medical College each decided not to renew contracts. In such cases, Dr. Marcos said, the corporation would find new partners.
The city's plans to sell hospitals have met unexpected obstacles.
Mount Sinai Medical Center, long considered the obvious purchaser of the Queens hospitals because its doctors already work there, abruptly withdrew from the bidding last month, citing unacceptable terms set by the city. Its original proposal required that Elmhurst and Queens be bought together, that any buyer rebuild Queens and provide guarantees to continue charity care. High-level officials at Mount Sinai last week confirmed that they were once again negotiating with the city, but refused to discuss the new ground rules. Dr. Marcos said that if no buyer agrees to rebuild Queens, the hospital would probably be converted to an outpatient clinic. Some health planners have questioned the need for a hospital at that site.
Politicians and patient advocates worry that the Mayor, facing reluctant buyers, will not be able to protect the health of the poor.
Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough president and a political rival of the Mayor, said that he had "reluctantly" decided to pull $1 million from his office's discretionary fund out of the public hospitals this year, for fear that private owners might soon be in place who would not serve the community.
"Selling these hospitals is more important to the Mayor than getting a good deal," said Rory Lancman, a member of the Queens Hospital Center Community Advisory Board, which has filed a lawsuit to stop the sale. "He'll give away the farm -- forget caring for the uninsured, or forget rebuilding Queens -- in order to get a sale."

HEADLINE: Republican Senate Passes Budget Blueprint

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Senate Republicans passed their six-year road map for a balanced Federal budget on a party-line vote late today, as everyone expected. What no one expected was an uncommon spate of bipartisan good feeling that very nearly swept a different blueprint to passage in its stead.
A middle-of-the-road spending plan offered by John Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, nearly passed before a flurry of nays sealed its defeat, 46 to 53. 
 The Republican budget passed hours later, 53 to 46, but not a single Democrat supported it, in sharp contrast to the Chafee-Breaux plan.
The budget blueprint, which will be melded with a similar plan the House passed two weeks ago, is not a law and thus does not require the President's assent. Instead, it sets the boundaries for the House and Senate committees that will begin writing a detailed fiscal 1997 budget in June.
But as a practical matter, this year's resolution is more a state of Republican fiscal principles than a working document. President Clinton has already warned that he will veto many of the spending measures it contemplates, and Republicans do not have to votes to override him.
Mr. Chafee and Mr. Breaux had argued that theirs was the only plan that could actually become law in the partisan climate of a Presidential election year, and that argument apparently proved powerful.
Before today's vote, only the 10 Democrats and 10 Republicans who helped Mr. Chafee and Mr. Breaux compile the plan this spring had formally endorsed it. In interviews today, both men said they had expected to win no more than 38 votes.
Like the Republican budget blueprint approved today, and a White House alternative defeated earlier, the Chafee-Breaux plan would erase the Federal deficit -- but in seven years instead of six.
Their plan split the difference between budget proposals put forward by the White House and Republican leaders in Congress, in part by reining in entitlement programs like Medicare and Medicaid. Both men said later that their strong showing suggested that a political consensus was forming to restrain spending on the entitlement programs before their costs consumed the entire Federal treasury. In theory, that would occur early in the next century if current spending rates continue.
"People are beginning to realize something's got to be done about these entitlement programs, or they won't be there," Mr. Chafee said. "And this solution we proposed was a realistic one."
Mr. Breaux said the plan was a safe alternative to the two parties' own budgets, whose own proposals to curb entitlement spending have become prime targets in this year's election campaigns.
"The good thing about what happened today was that it was bipartisan," he said. "That kind of cover is the only way this thing is going to get done."
With $105 billion in tax cuts through 2003, the Chafee-Breaux plan held savings and tax cuts midway between those of Mr. Clinton and the Republican leadership. But the plan would pare domestic spending on Federal agencies and programs like road building and the environment significantly less than would the other two.
It would also reap $126 billion of its savings on entitlement spending by a means neither side would embrace: a half-a-percentage-point cut in the inflation index used to set cost-of-living increases in many benefits and all Government pensions.
Many economists contend that the current index overstates inflation by at least that much. But the Labor Department, which compiles the gauge, is loath to make such a major change without intense study. And neither party has been willing to support a move that could be read, fairly or not, as a cut in Social Security and other Federal benefits.
The Democratic leader in the debate, Senator Jim Exon of Nebraska, urged his party to oppose the Chafee-Breaux plan because of the cut in the inflation index. Mr. Clinton has raised the same objection.
The Republican chairman of the Budget Committee, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, said in a speech that the proposal might be the basis for compromise later, when control of Congress and the White House are not so clearly at stake. But to support it now, Mr. Domenici warned, would be political folly.
No Republican should support the plan "unless those members who vote for it want to take on the President of the United States five months before a Presidential election," he said.
Twenty-two of the 53 Republicans voted for it anyway, as did 24 of the 47 Democrats. Senator Bob Dole was in the Capitol but did not vote. Among the ayes were both of New York's Senators and two Democrats from surrounding states, Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.
Mr. Bradley has announced his retirement at the end of this year. Indeed, 12 of the 14 Senators who have said they are leaving office voted for the Chafee-Breaux plan.
Mr. Domenici, the budget expert among Senate Republicans and something of a fiscal moderate himself, said he had voted no because he pledged last year not to draft a budget that touched Social Security benefits. But he did not seem especially disappointed that the budget he did draft was almost eclipsed.
"Dynamite vote!" he said, adding that the plan's supporters had cast "a courageous vote."
Hours later, the Senate did approve Mr. Domenici's budget blueprint, which closely follows a six-year budget outline that the House approved this month.
The Republican plan would cut taxes by $122 billion through 2002, largely in the form of a $500-a-child tax credit to most taxpaying families. It also would pare deficit spending by more than $700 billion on the way to fiscal balance, mostly by slowing the growth of benefit programs, cutting domestic spending and selling some Government assets like the broadcast spectrum.
The Senate passed the last two weeks mulling over more than 40 amendments to the bill and batting down most of them. None of the few that were adopted made major changes to spending plans.

HEADLINE: Manager of Biggest Mutual Fund Quits After Recent Subpar Gains

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Jeffrey N. Vinik, the embattled portfolio manager of Fidelity Magellan, the country's largest mutual fund, resigned yesterday, stepping out of the spotlight as Wall Street's most closely watched investment manager.
Mr. Vinik said he was leaving to start his own money management company, but the sudden departure came after five months of subpar performance. The announcement was enough to help send bond and stock prices lower, as investors and traders worried about the possibility of a shift in strategy at the fund, which has 4.3 million shareholders and $56 billion invested. 
 Mr. Vinik's resignation also sent some tremors through the mutual fund industry, which has become the vehicle through which nearly 40 million Americans are investing hundreds of billions of dollars a year to pay for their retirement and their children's college educations.
Mr. Vinik, whose resignation set off a shift of six other portfolio managers at Fidelity Investments, will be replaced by Robert E. Stansky, a company employee for 13 years. Mr. Stansky is known as a methodical, consistent "growth" investor, who invests in the stocks of companies that are selling increasing amounts of their products or services. [Page D1.]
This was the second major shake-up in three months at Fidelity, of Boston, the country's largest fund company, with 238 mutual funds. And Mr. Vinik is the third high-profile portfolio manager -- each of whom has had a reputation for making aggressive market bets -- to leave Fidelity this year.
Analysts said yesterday that the change in leadership at Magellan could lead to a change in the fund's investments and performance. But since 1990, there have been three different portfolio managers at Magellan, each of whom has put together a better-than-average long-term record. In Mr. Vinik's case, it was only this year, after he bet that the stock market would start 1996 poorly, that Magellan's performance flagged. In addition, more than 75 percent of the fund's money is invested through retirement plans, and analysts said that money was unlikely to be taken out quickly.
In the nearly four years that Mr. Vinik ran the Magellan fund, its value jumped almost 84 percent and it outperformed a majority of its competitors.
In part, that growth came from Mr. Vinik's astute investment decisions, like a huge bet on technology stocks last year. But Mr. Vinik has also been the subject of withering criticism this year as he has put much of the Magellan fund's money into long-term Treasury bonds and cut the proportion of the fund's investment in stocks.
As interest rates have risen this year, that decision has caused the fund's performance to lag behind, growing less than 5 percent while the Dow Jones industrial average has climbed more than 12 percent. And the flow of new money into the fund has slowed significantly. In addition, several analysts of Fidelity have predicted that Mr. Vinik would soon leave or be forced out.
In an interview, Mr. Vinik said he was "absolutely not" dismissed or asked to leave Fidelity, a unit of the FMR Corporation of Boston.
"This was strictly an idea I had on my own," he said, adding that in the last week he received a vote of confidence about how he had been running the fund during the last six months from Fidelity's chairman, Edward C. Johnson 3d. His resignation is effective on June 3.
Taken together, the recent changes have led some analysts who specialize in watching Fidelity to speculate that the company has been tightening control over fund managers in response to pressure from large institutions that offer Fidelity funds in employee retirement plans. The managers have traditionally been given wide latitude by Fidelity to invest as they see fit.
Fidelity, which manages about 13.5 percent of the $3 trillion in mutual funds, has tightened its control in other ways as well. Last year, the company forbade fund managers to talk to the press about specific stocks. The ban came after several lawsuits charged that Mr. Vinik had tried to manipulate the price of Micron Technology stock by making positive public comments about the semiconductor maker at about the same time that he was selling shares of the company from the Magellan portfolio. The firm also tightened regulations under which employees could trade stocks and bonds in their own accounts, forbidding them to own brokerage-firm accounts outside of Fidelity.
Mr. Vinik's is the third resignation of a high-profile Fidelity manager this year. In January, David J. Breazzano, manager of the Capital and Income fund, and Dan Harmetz, who managed three private partnerships, left the company when Fidelity abruptly said it was discontinuing its aggressive style of investing in the securities of weak and insolvent companies.
Mr. Vinik, however, said none of those developments had led to his decision to leave Fidelity. "I had three goals when I took over the Magellan fund," he said. "To beat the market, to spend more time with my family and to last a significant amount of time in the position. I achieved all of those."
Mr. Vinik also played down the rash of criticism he has faced in the last two years. He first drew questions last year as he moved 45 percent of the Magellan fund's assets into technology stocks. Outsiders feared that a fund as large as Magellan could not help but roil the financial markets when it started to sell such a huge position.
In November, Mr. Vinik, who had worked on Wall Street as a trader specializing in the buying and selling of huge blocks of stock, cut the fund's technology position nearly in half, selling $10 billion in technology stocks in a month's time without causing an upheaval in the sector or the market as a whole.
Mr. Vinik's next move drew a greater amount of criticism. Instead of quickly redeploying the cash into other stocks, during the next few months he built up cash reserves to more than 15 percent, put another 20 percent in bonds and cut the fund's stock holdings to 65 percent of assets.
In the Magellan fund's annual report, issued last week, Mr. Vinik wrote that "euphoria surrounding the stock market in general and certain sectors in particular" led him to believe that long-term bonds were the most attractive assets for the next 12 to 24 months.
That may still turn out to be the case, but since Mr. Vinik started moving Magellan's assets into bonds late last year, the fund's performance has suffered. Through yesterday, the Magellan fund was up 4.16 percent since the beginning of the year, compared with a gain of about 10 percent for both the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks and the average growth mutual fund.
Last year, the Magellan fund recorded a gain of 36.8 percent, slightly behind the 37.6 percent gain of the S.& P. 500 but better than 80 percent of the funds in the growth-stock category, according to Lipper Analytical Services, a mutual fund research company. And since Mr. Vinik took over the Magellan fund in July 1992, the fund outperformed 68 percent of its peers.
In compiling that record, Mr. Vinik has managed the fund quite differently from his two predecessors, Morris Smith, who ran Magellan for two years beginning in June 1990, and Peter Lynch, the legendary manager who ran the fund for 13 years.
Mr. Smith and Mr. Lynch were known for working incessantly, but Mr. Vinik vowed he would run the Magellan fund in the same manner as he ran other, smaller funds. And his life style has changed little: Mr. Vinik works at Fidelity's downtown Boston office from 7 A.M. to 5 P.M., then goes home for dinner with his wife and three children. After putting the children to bed -- all three are under age 6 -- Mr. Vinik spends two to three hours making out a list of stocks to buy and sell the next day.
People who know Mr. Vinik say that he has become increasingly uncomfortable with the level of criticism aimed at him. Mr. Vinik, however, said that was not part of his decision.
"I don't worry about the criticism," he said. "One thing you learn in this industry is you're never as smart as the press says you are when things are good, and you never are as dumb as they say you are when things are bad."
Eric M. Kobren, executive editor of Fidelity Insight, a newsletter that follows Fidelity funds, said it was not surprising that Mr. Vinik had decided to quit. "Why does he need to withstand this level of criticism?" he asked. "He has a great opportunity. He loves to play the market. And I think he can raise the money" to start his own money management firm.
Mr. Vinik said his plans for the structure and strategy of his new firm, to be called Vinik Asset Management, have not been completed. While he said he had no current plans to run a mutual fund, he added that he "always wanted to run money for my friends and my family."
At the new firm, Mr. Vinik will be joined by two other Fidelity employees whose resignations were announced yesterday: Michael S. Gordon, who was appointed manager of the Fidelity Retirement Growth fund last March, after three years running the Blue Chip Growth fund, and William Copeland, a senior technical analyst.
In addition, Mark Hostetter, currently general counsel for equity markets at Merrill Lynch, will join Vinik Asset Management as chief operating officer, Mr. Vinik said.

HEADLINE: A Newly Clean Hudson Awaits Swimmers

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
In a sign that the Hudson is again a bountiful, swimmable river and no longer an open sewer and convenient dump site, Westchester County officials have announced that the county's only public beach on the river, at Croton Point Park, will open for swimming for the first time since 1987, starting on the Fourth of July.
For decades, the beach had been shunned and then closed because the water was tainted with sewage and the graceful half-mile arc of white sand was only 100 yards from the county's smelly, seeping landfill. 
 Elsewhere along the river, some stalwart swimmers have always braved the water, adjusting their strokes and bathing times to avoid contact with sewage or industrial waste. But the pronouncement Tuesday by county officials -- after repeated tests for bacteria and other health threats turned up no dangers -- gives the lower Hudson its first official clean bill of health in nearly a decade. With the landfill sealed and water clean, swimmers have been clamoring to return to the river.
Susan Gonda, a boater who has already swum at the Croton Point beach several times this year and who took an unofficial dip yesterday, said her only complaint now was that thousands of people would soon crowd the waters that until recently had been the domain of braver folk.
And in an indication that further improvements in the river may be in store, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he wants to spend $43 million over three years on new state programs to resolve environmental, economic and recreational problems along the Hudson.
No new staff or funds will be added this year, and the commitment of money is small, but in endorsing the first comprehensive state plan for restoring the Hudson, Mr. Pataki said he was hoping to make the cleaner river the basis for the economic recovery of the Hudson Valley. The plan was to be released today.
Mr. Pataki said he was confident that the Legislature would provide the money for the proposed programs. "Without this, we'll run the risk of backsliding with one of the most important areas in the state of New York," he said.
"As a kid growing up, the Hudson River was the back door," said Mr. Pataki, who grew up in Peekskill. "That's where the garbage went, where the pollutants went. Now the river is becoming the focus of communities again."
Along with proposing money for everything from land purchases and underwater surveys to eight new boat launching ramps, the plan would strengthen regulations on wetlands and streams along the river and lay out how its banks -- for 150 years filled and reshaped to suit human needs -- might be re-tailored here and there to restore natural vegetation and fisheries.
In many areas, the plan would restore funds for research projects that had been sharply cut or eliminated over the last decade, said Frances F. Dunwell, a special assistant to the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation who has been the plan's chief architect since the Legislature created the effort in 1987.
For example, financing for research on two of the river's most important fish -- shad and sturgeon -- had shrunk 50 percent in a decade, she said. With up to $726,000 in state and Federal funding, the programs would be revived. With populations of shad and the 9-foot-long Atlantic sturgeon, the Hudson's greatest denizen, in sharp decline, the revival is welcome, she said.
Ms. Dunwell, who was dismissed last fall by the Pataki administration as a holdover from the Cuomo administration only to be rehired a week later after a bipartisan outcry, said Mr. Pataki has sent strong signals that he intends to fight for the plan. "He gets misty-eyed when you talk about the river," she said.
Mr. Pataki's political opponents said they were encouraged by the Governor's endorsement of the plan, but skeptical.
"He puts out plans all the time and refuses to put up the money for them," said Richard L. Brodsky, the chairman of the Assembly's Environmental Conservation Committee and a Westchester Democrat. It was likely that the plan would receive the support of the Legislature, he said, adding, "We will look at this in a most cooperative way."
Focusing on the 150-mile stretch of the river south of Troy, the plan provides a detailed menu of research projects aimed at filling in large gaps in scientific understanding of the river and its inhabitants. One of the biggest gaps, Ms. Dunwell said, is that there has never been a thorough survey of the river bed. "We know virtually nothing about the habitat types on the river bottom," she said.
Ms. Dunwell said the plan would help unify the policies of half a dozen state agencies with land holdings or responsibilities along the river. "It's all been scattershot before," she said. One project would spur the transfer of unused tracts of state land to agencies, like the Parks Department, that can open the land to public uses.
Environmental groups were particularly pleased to see that the plan calls for strengthening regulation of wetlands along the river's margins. Under state laws passed in the 1970's, any swatch of marsh north of the Tappan Zee Bridge had to be 12.4 acres or larger to qualify for strong state protection. Now all wetlands south of Troy will be regulated, no matter how small.
"These wetlands are very critical habitat," said Andre Mele, environmental director of Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, a 10,000-member group based in Poughkeepsie.
He said the plan had several weaknesses, including a lack of any attention to the problem of pollution from dispersed sources like agricultural runoff and faulty septic systems. But over all, he said, "We're cheering up here."

HEADLINE: Financier Pleads Guilty in Banking Fraud

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, May 24

 BODY:
Michael Carlow, the financier who once owned the companies that make the Clark candy bar and Iron City beer, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to a $31 million fraud against the PNC Bank of Pittsburgh.
The United States Attorney, Frederick Thieman, said more people would probably be indicted in the check-kiting scheme. 
 Mr. Carlow, 45, who is to be sentenced on Aug. 16, faces at least six years in prison and could serve as much as eight years and one month. He pleaded guilty to one count each of bank fraud and conspiracy and four counts of falsifying income tax returns. He also pleaded guilty to wire fraud and embezzlement charges in Connecticut, where he swindled $13,000 from the employee benefits plan at the Helikon Furniture Company.
Mr. Carlow defrauded PNC by writing false checks to shift money among different accounts. He also defrauded the Government by not paying at least $550,000 in income taxes in 1992 and 1993.
Mr. Carlow, who told the court he was unemployed, once controlled the Pittsburgh Brewing Company and the D. L. Clark Company, both of which were ailing before he restored them in the early 1990's.

HEADLINE: March Fed Meeting Unanimous for Steady Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers voted unanimously at their March 26 meeting to keep the overnight bank lending rate unchanged, according to the minutes of the session, released today.
The 10-to-0 vote by the Federal Open Market Committee's left the target for the Federal funds rate at 5.25 percent. The committee left the rate unchanged again at its latest meeting on Tuesday. 
 "Information on the economy and prices did not seem to indicate developing inflation pressures that needed to be contained" by raising interest rates, according to minutes from the March 26 meeting.
In addition, Fed members noted that recent increases in Treasury bond yields and other market interest rates were likely to slow economic growth.
"Nonetheless, a number of members noted that inflation was not expected to moderate further" in the months ahead, the minutes said. That could require rate increases to stem rising prices, the minutes suggested.
Some analysts are predicting that the committee could raise interest rates as soon as its session on July 2 and 3 as a way of slowing the economy to keep inflation in check.
The low unemployment rate, which was 5.4 percent in April, suggests that labor costs may rise as businesses are forced to pay more to attract and keep workers, analysts said. Labor costs account for about two-thirds of consumer prices.
At their meetings in March and this week, the choices before the Fed policy makers were limited. Richard Yamarone, an economist at the Market Data Corporation in New York, said the committee was operating "with limited and distorted data" at the March meeting following the temporary Government shutdowns and the severe weather of the winter.
And this week, the decision against raising rates suggested that the Fed officials had discounted recent run-ups in energy prices and were looking for more evidence that the economy was gaining momentum before tightening credit.

HEADLINE: Still Life, With Tourists;
Can Visitors Revive the Economy for Philadelphia?

BYLINE: By JANE L. LEVERE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
The promoters of this city's summer blockbuster art exhibit, which opens May 30, aren't missing a trick. Already, tourists can buy neon-hued, vinyl-covered baseballs plastered with Paul Cezanne's signature, or see the sights on a bus decorated with a 40-foot-long copy of a Cezanne still life of fruit. The exhibit is even being touted in a 20-page special-advertising section in Business Week magazine.
While the showing of 170 paintings by the French master is a major cultural event, its real objectives are economic. Philadelphia has lost tens of thousands of jobs in recent years, and now the nation's fifth-largest city has become the latest Eastern dowager to embrace tourism as its economic salvation. 
 Mayor Edward Rendell, re-elected in November to a second four-year term, is spearheading an aggressive $12 million tourism-marketing campaign. Described by both admirers and foes as a tireless cheerleader for his city, he has solicited public and private funds to develop tourist attractions like the $330 million "Avenue of the Arts," a concentration of museums, theaters and concert halls that one local observer called a "strung out Lincoln Center," and a $90 million entertainment, dining and hotel complex on the Delaware River. He has revitalized the historic district and has obtained funds for a new $20 million visitors center at Independence Mall, home of the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall.
In the course of the summer, Philadelphia officials are counting on the Cezanne exhibit alone to draw more than 500,000 visitors to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, pumping at least $40 million into the local economy. Fifteen Philadelphia hotels have banded together to sell Cezanne packages to out-of-town visitors, and major restaurants, including the top-rated Le Bec-Fin, are offering discounts to museum-goers. The Advanta Corporation, a big issuer of credit cards based in suburban Horsham, is hoping to help its business and its image by spending $1 million to underwrite the show and an additional $2 million to publicize it.
Few locals fault Mr. Rendell's approach. With manufacturing shrinking and corporations fleeing, tourism is one of the few things the city has going for it these days. The problem is that it isn't very much.
Specialists in urban affairs say it is a mistake to pin too much hope on tourism. "Tourism is certainly a desirable thing, but I doubt you can revive all of a central city on it," said Edwin Mills, a professor of real estate at the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill. "What really generated jobs in the 1980's were financial services, real estate, health care and high-tech industries. These still have potential in the 1990's, but I'd hate to see a city expect to derive all of its benefits from tourism. That's putting too many eggs in one pot."
In Philadelphia, the 1.3-million-square-foot convention center, hailed as the engine of the city's tourism-driven economic renaissance, has fallen dismally short of its backers' promises. Constructed around the old Reading Terminal train shed and connected to a $212 million, 1,200-room Marriott hotel, it was completed in the summer of 1994, three years behind schedule. By then, its cost had soared to $522 million, double the original estimate by the Philadelphia Industrial Development Corporation, the city's economic-development arm.
Worse, the economic payoff that the group predicted a decade ago -- 10,000 full-time and part-time new jobs and a steady flow of profits that would increase to $23 million by the year 2000 from an initial $4 million in 1991 -- has not materialized. So far, the center-and-hotel complex has created only 1,100 full-time jobs, according to Robert Butera, executive director of the Pennsylvania Convention Center Authority. (In part, this is because the city originally anticipated the development of two -- rather than the current one -- large convention hotels at the center.)
And instead of profits, Mr. Butera foresees only red ink. He said the city would be saddled with an annual debt-service bill of $24 million for the next quarter-century. And while revenues from the center and a 6 percent hotel tax should exceed operating expenses, the net cost to taxpayers will still be huge, he predicts: $20 million this year, then declining somewhat year by year to $15 million by the turn of the century.
What of the early promise of the center's economic contribution? "It sounds like an exaggeration in order to get a deal done," Mr. Butera said.
Critics concede the convention center is an impressive architectural achievement but say it is an extravagance for a city that only recently pulled back from the brink of bankruptcy. The money spent to build it, they maintain, should have gone to repairing Philadelphia's decaying infrastructure.
"The structure is elegant and excellent," said David Cohen, who has served a total of 17 years on the City Council. "I only wish we could afford it. Undoubtedly, certain businesses will be helped, but we're paying an enormous amount of money for it. The city has heavy needs, in schools, recreation, housing, mass transit. Every level of government is in crisis. We face tremendous deficits."
Even nearby merchants, who in theory stand to gain from the influx of visitors, are casting a skeptical eye on the convention center. George Mickel Jr., who owns By George, an Italian-food store in the adjacent Reading Terminal Market, said he lost 15 percent of his customers while the complex was under construction. And while most of them have returned, and convention-goers have increased sales a bit, he estimates that business is still down 20 percent for the fresh-food purveyors that account for one-third of the market's shops. "They're struggling," he said.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Rendell dismisses his detractors' concerns as overblown or plain wrong. In an interview in his office, he said the convention center "probably produces" a net gain of tens of millions of dollars, because convention-goers shop, dine out and pay taxes on liquor. If the taxpayers' subsidy were eliminated, he said, "you'd be eliminating 30, 40, 50, 60, 70 million dollars in tax benefits we get by having conventioners in town." "So," he added, "it's a ridiculous argument."
Mr. Rendell and other city officials say there is ample evidence that the tourism strategy is paying off. The convention center boasts strong advance bookings, they say, and private developers are negotiating with the city for the construction of four new hotels. They add that the hospitality industry is providing job training for hundreds of high-school students and unemployed adults.
Besides, they argue, they have no choice but to seize on tourism as an economic lifeline because there is not much else. Other ailing cities, after all, have followed the same path, with Boston developing its historic Faneuil Hall district and Baltimore sprucing up its scenic inner harbor.
For its part, Philadelphia is one of the sickest cities in the Northeast, desperately trying to halt an economic slide that began more than half a century ago at the close of World War II. According to David Elesh, an associate professor of sociology at Temple University in Philadelphia, the portion of the city's work force employed in manufacturing has shrunk to just 9 percent today from 50 percent in the mid-1950's. Since 1980, he estimates, the number of Philadelphians with jobs has fallen by 16 percent, to 669,000 from 794,000.
The city's population has likewise contracted, to 1.5 million last year from nearly two million in 1970. Ed Schwartz, a former director of Philadelphia's Office of Housing and Community Development and the current president of the Institute for the Study of Civic Values, estimates that one-fifth of the city's residents live below the poverty line. Weed-strewn lots and abandoned buildings dot many neighborhoods.
"There is no way the residents there can do any broad-based renewal, and the city can't do it either," said David Bartelt, a professor of geography and urban studies at Temple.
While the city does have several buoyant sectors -- notably its medical centers, its colleges and universities and a vibrant business-service industry -- analysts say these are not enough to turn the economy around.
That leaves tourists -- and, for the moment, Cezanne. While even Philadelphia's biggest boosters say tourism's long-term impact is limited, hoteliers are optimistic about the potential for immediate gain. The Latham Hotel predicts the show will add at least $250,000 to its revenues during the usually slow summer season; the Four Seasons Hotel foresees a minimum windfall of $500,000.
Advanta, the credit-card company, is also making commercial hay out of the extravaganza, sponsoring a local art contest and underwriting a documentary on Cezanne that will be broadcast nationally on the Public Broadcasting Service. Not least of the beneficiaries will be the Museum of Art itself, which expects $3.5 million in ticket sales and $3 million from the sale of souvenir items.
There is always the chance that tourism really will help turn Philadelphia around, of course. A recent study of the economic impact of the convention center by the Pennsylvania Economy League, a public think tank, predicts that by the end of the fiscal year 2004, Philadelphia should collect $30 million annually in taxes "connected with convention center activity."
But even some backers of the Mayor's tourism gamble -- those who call it a key ingredient in any long-term solution to Philadelphia's economic woes -- say there are severe limits to how far visitor dollars can take a big city.
"Tourism alone won't bail out Philadelphia's structural difficulties," said Graham Finney, a consultant and the former chairman of Philadelphia's planning commission. "Its tax base is pretty well tapped out, and the state is not generous to older cities. Tourism is no silver bullet."

HEADLINE: April Orders For Durables Down 1.9%

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods fell 1.9 percent in April because of slack demand for aircraft, the Government said today, as the sluggish recovery in manufacturing crept forward.
The 1.9 percent decline was larger than analysts had expected and was in contrast to March's increase, which was revised to 2.6 percent from 2.5 percent. Orders for durable goods have declined in three of the year's first four months. 
 Analysts said the drop came mostly in orders for aircraft and other transportation equipment. Excluding that often volatile sector, they noted, orders rose 1.7 percent in April after having fallen 1 percent in March.
Transportation orders fell 12.6 percent in April, the steepest decline since July 1994, Commerce Department officials said. About one-quarter of all durables orders are for transportation items.
"A large decrease in aircraft and parts more than offset an increase in motor vehicles and parts," the department said. The Government does not break out aircraft orders separately.
Orders for new cars rebounded in April from the strike that idled most of the output of General Motors for much of March.
"What was going on in April was that the motor vehicle industry passed its strike-driven low point while the rest of the economy was basically holding its own," said Robert Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
With low inventories of new vehicles, auto makers geared up to restock dealers' lots while some other industries were still working down stocks of unsold goods.
"The motor vehicle industry has basically completed its inventory correction, but other industries still were being affected in April," Mr. Dederick said.
The Federal Reserve said last week that industrial production surged in April after being hurt by the strike at General Motors.
Orders for industrial machinery, including computers, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in April after falling 4.5 percent in March. Military orders fell 35.1 percent after soaring 62.9 percent in March. Electrical goods orders dropped 2.7 percent after a 4.8 percent March increase.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods, taken as an indicator of business investment in new equipment, fell 12.2 percent after a 4.8 percent increase in March. Aircraft are included in this category.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Durable Goods Orders" shows manufacturers' total new orders for durable goods, from November 1994 to April 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)
