HEADLINE: Burmese Crackdown May Be Tactical Victory for Opposition

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 24

 BODY:
With a sweep of more than 200 arrests around the country, the military Government of Myanmar has succeeded in preventing a full-scale meeting this weekend of the democratic opposition party that won a parliamentary election six years ago but was never allowed to take power.
In doing so, it may have handed a tactical victory to the opposition party, the National League for Democracy, and its charismatic leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. They have regained the limelight that was in danger of fading, and their claims of repression have been vividly underscored. 
 The arrests have been condemned by the United States and Japan, two of the most important investor nations in Myanmar, formerly Burma. And they have given a lift to an effort under way in Congress to enact economic sanctions against the Southeast Asian nation.
At her home in Yangon, the Burmese capital once called Rangoon, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi said today that she did not believe that such sanctions would harm ordinary citizens there. "I certainly will not protest against them, not the way this Government is behaving," The Associated Press quoted her as saying.
The White House criticized the clampdown, saying in a statement, "We have strongly protested these arrests to the Burmese authorities and have warned that a continued crackdown would lead to further deterioration in our already strained relationship." And on Thursday the Senate banking committee opened previously scheduled hearings on two bills that would impose far-reaching economic sanctions on Myanmar.
In Tokyo, Foreign Minister Yukihiko Ikeda demanded the release of those arrested and said their continued detention could discourage Japanese investment.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi said the planned three-day meeting at her home would proceed symbolically on Sunday even if only a handful of members could attend. She said the number of arrests since Monday had risen to 217, including 195 of the party's elected delegates and 15 members of a youth wing who were helping organize the conference.
In 1990 her party won 392 of 485 contested seats in Parliament, but the junta refused to honor the results and continued to rule by decree.
In a statement distributed to reporters in Bangkok today, the Government, known formally as the State Law and Order Restoration Council, said the arrests were meant to prevent "disturbances and riots."
"The measures are taken with a view to maintaining stability, as the recent preparation for convening a conference of N.L.D. may endanger the stability and tranquillity strenuously and successfully restored during these years," the statement said.
In a reminder of the powers wielded by the military Government, the statement, quoting the Deputy Minister for Information, U Thein Sein, referred to the events of 1988 in which hundreds of people died in a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations.
Mr. Thein Sein's remarks, which were presented as the text of a news conference in Yangon on Thursday, described the opposition as jealous that the country was developing economically under the military Government and criticized it for hampering that development by supporting economic sanctions.
He added, "Those who were called in for questioning were not arrested but were being accommodated comfortably at guest houses."
The diplomats said it remained unclear whether the authorities would move directly against Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi or the party's 10-member executive committee, which has been gathering at her home. It was also uncertain whether those arrested would be freed once the time of the planned meeting passes.
The diplomats in Yangon and other foreign analysts said it appeared that nearly a year after Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was released from six years of house arrest, Myanmar was entering a new period of increased tension.
In recent years the Government has opened the economy and eagerly sought foreign investment, while keeping a tight rein on political expression. Analysts said that after freeing Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi in July, it had hoped that human rights protests would wane and that her movement would be marginalized.
"The N.L.D. has clearly decided not to lie low and go quietly away," a diplomat said. "I would not be surprised if this meeting is part of an attempt to maintain the profile of the opposition, as well as to keep it active as an organization. Things seem to be moving toward increasing confrontation, but what form it will take remains to be seen."

HEADLINE: The Bronx Is Up, the Battery's Down and the Fleet Is in Town

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
In his crisp dress whites, Lieut. Paul Durso plunged into the sea of pin stripes at the wood-paneled bar.
"Are you sure you want the Penn Club?" the bartender asked in that icy tone that all but screams, "You don't belong here." 
 Lieutenant Durso flashed his Penn Club membership card and ordered a beer for himself and a couple of buddies from the destroyer Arleigh Burke. Penn degree or no Penn degree, he is in the Navy now.
In the last few days, the city has been flooded by sailors who clambered off the ships that paraded up the Hudson River on Wednesday. The first-time visitors have spent their days boarding civilian vessels, like the Statue of Liberty ferry, and checking out civilian territory, like Times Square, Central Park and the Empire State Building. They have been noticed wherever they have gone. Those starched uniforms are hard to miss, different from the workaday crowd: more disciplined, more gung-ho, less stressed out.
But some bunks in the ships docked alongside the Intrepid Museum, at 46th Street and the Hudson River, are occupied by sailors from the New York area. They grew up humming the "On the Town" lyric about the Bronx being up and the Battery down. They know their way around by subway. They never thought of New York as Sodom or Gomorrah. And they have spent Fleet Week showing their shipmates the city New Yorkers know.
"Old haunts" is how Lieutenant Durso, who grew up in the Rockland County community of Pearl River, described the places he headed for. He decided to make his first stop the Penn Club, a watering hole for alumni of the University of Pennsylvania on West 44th Street, near Fifth Avenue.
"They were kind of shocked to see a bunch of sailors," said Lieutenant Durso, who attended Penn on a Reserve Officers Training Corps scholarship. "But it was nice to have a place to take your shipmates. They sure liked it."
Lieutenant Durso, 24, majored in European history and economics at Penn, but on the Arleigh Burke he is an engineer. He has responsibility for the 466-foot-long destroyer's hydraulic steering gear and her water-supply systems, which circulate drinking water for the sailors and coolant for the air-conditioning and refrigeration equipment. "The Navy is great about training you to do anything," he said. "All you need is a positive attitude."
Lieutenant Durso oohed and aahed about the Manhattan skyline from the water. "This was the most special way I've ever arrived in Manhattan," he said. "Poignant."
Petty Officer Joseph Peisher of Clifton Springs, N.Y., near Rochester, spent his first day "on the beach" with Petty Officer Jeremy Thompson from the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy. Mr. Thompson is a Vermonter who had never been to New York before. They headed for Times Square.
"It wasn't the same 42d Street I wasn't allowed to look at when my parents would say, 'Cover your eyes,' " said Mr. Peisher, an electronics technician on the destroyer John Rodgers.
Mr. Peisher noticed another difference: "It's cleaner. We just came back from Edinburgh. I couldn't believe the amount of trash there. I was expecting the same kind of thing, blowing newspapers and stuff, here."
Something Mr. Thompson said made Mr. Peisher aware of another difference. "Just walking down the street, he couldn't believe how many pretty women smoked," Mr. Peisher said. The antismoking laws had taken effect since his last visit, leaving the streets as one of the few public places where smokers can puff freely.
Ens. Jason Stevens, who grew up in Knox, N.Y., near Albany, lived in the Bronx while he attended the New York Maritime College. He headed for Hurley's, a restaurant on the Avenue of the Americas side of Rockefeller Center. Ensign Stevens had baked clams and shrimp "the size of giant whales," and chatted with landlubbers at the bar.
"Their only nautical experience had been racing sailboats," he said, "and they wanted to know what it was like to do it professionally."
He said he gave them the "straight scoop," something about "long hours and how it's kind of tough being away from home, but you definitely get to see some interesting places."
Were the people at the bar Navy material, and did Ensign Stevens succeed as a recruiter?
Negative on both counts. "I think," Ensign Stevens said, "they were past the age limit."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Edge Higher As Holiday Gets Early Start

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks tiptoed higher yesterday, lifting some indexes further into record territory, as trading slowed before the holiday weekend.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose just 0.74 point, to 5,762.86, finishing the week with a gain of 75.36 points. The blue-chip average, which set new highs on Monday and Wednesday, was up nearly 37 points at the start of yesterday's trading before the advance faded. 
 Broad market measures were mostly positive, but the Nasdaq market was weighed down by the technology sector.
Analysts said there was little motivation for buying in a pricey market that has already ridden a wave of encouraging economic reports well into record territory.
"It's a meaningless day in terms of setting any agenda for where we're going," said John Cleland, chief investment strategist at Security Benefit Group in Topeka, Kan. "Everybody's already on vacation and we're taking a break."
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a slim margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 329.2 million shares, down sharply from Thursday's 431.9 million.
Although the market's advance was modest, it was enough to break some records.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 1.31 points, to 363.74, barely topping Wednesday's record finish of 363.69. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.51 points, to 678.51, edging Wednesday's record high of 678.42.
At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.27 points, to 613.95.
The Nasdaq composite index, which on Thursday set a new high, fell 0.85 point, to 1,247.80, as investors sold some high-flying technology issues. Two makers of disk drives, Iomega and Syquest Technologies, plunged after a weeklong rally based more on speculation than news. Iomega lost 6 11/16 , to 44 9/16 , while Syquest slid 7, to 10 7/8.
Investors took some profits on tobacco stocks, which enjoyed a big run-up on Thursday after a Federal appeals court rejected a class-action liability suit filed on behalf of millions of smokers. Philip Morris fell 3/8, to 103 1/2; Brooke Group was off 1/8, to 6 3/4, and Loews was unchanged at 82 1/8. But RJR Nabisco rose again, adding 1/2, to 33 5/8.
Among other issues, A. G. Edwards rose 1, to 24 7/8, after it said it planned to buy back up to 22 million common shares over the next five and a half years.
Systemix soared 7 5/8, to 18 5/8, after it received a proposal from Sandoz to acquire the remaining 27 percent of the company at $17 a share.
LSI Logic fell 2, to 30, after Robertson, Stephens cut its 1996 and 1997 earnings estimates for LSI.
Masland gained 1 1/2, to 25 3/4, after Lear agreed to acquire it in a deal valued at $26 a share. Lear also rose, gaining 2 1/2, to 37 5/8.
In Tokyo, Japanese stocks ended higher yesterday, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues gaining 74.35 points to close at 21,798.43. For the week, the Nikkei ended won 118.17.

HEADLINE: In Post-Cold-War Washington, Development Is a Hot Business

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
While foreign-policy makers have trouble even defining the post-cold-war era, Washington deal makers have already figured out how to make millions in it.
A cottage industry of consultants, business executives and lobbyists are tapping into one of Washington's least-known pools of money: international development banks. Foreign aid budgets are shrinking, but these banks are growing. Each year they generate some $30 billion in contracts. 
 And in the Washington tradition of revolving doors, former officials of these banks are taking advantage of the new business opportunities. The institutions, which are financed in part by American taxpayers, have much less restrictive rules on what former officials can do and how much they must disclose about their activities.
Those deals often benefit from another new trend of the post-cold-war era: the worldwide emphasis on privatization. Big public works projects that were once undertaken by governments -- from airports to water treatment plants -- now are often being done by private entrepreneurs.
"The cold war's demise removes the philosophical underpinnings for the earlier support of government intervention," said Moeen Qureshi, a former top official of the World Bank, who sees development banks acting now as "catalysts" for business executives like himself.
Consider the Inter-American Development Bank, which is owned by 46 nations and helps Latin American countries reduce their chronic poverty. It recently made available some of its billions of dollars in annual loans to private businesses, following the trend at other international lending organizations.
Last fall the bank entered into a first-of-its-kind alliance with a private group of investors whose advisers include several prominent former development officials, from Mr. Qureshi to Lloyd M. Bentsen, who served as Secretary of the Treasury in 1993 and 1994 and was a governor of the inter-American bank.
Now a businessman, Mr. Bentsen is helping organize a billion-dollar investment fund backed by giant corporations and pension funds. They hope to realize profits of as much as 25 percent a year by investing in Latin American power projects, telecommunications systems and toll roads, according to Mr. Bentsen.
In a turnaround, Mr. Bentsen went to Buenos Aires last March to attend the inter-American bank's annual meeting even though he was too busy to attend those sessions when he was Treasury Secretary. This year he went to entertain executives of the bank and potential investors who were attending the bank's annual meeting. However, Mr. Bentsen said, he has not been involved in actual negotiations with the bank.
When raising money for its fund, Mr. Bentsen's group makes note of its unique agreement with the Inter-American Development Bank, which offers information sharing and possible co-financing, and the previous ties of the group's mangers to various development banks, according to Mr. Bentsen and other fund officials.
"If the bank can provide comfort to investors in the project -- fantastic," said Enrique V. Iglesias, the inter-American bank's president. He hopes the agreement with Mr. Bentsen's fund will be the first of many such alliances.
But some bank officials and outside experts question whether a public bank set up to finance projects in developing countries that the private sector considers too risky should be helping wealthy private investors.
"The I.D.B. shouldn't be in the business of making life easier for the capital markets," said Jerome Booth, a former official of the Inter-American bank who is now head of emerging markets research for the Australian New Zealand Bank, a private bank. "It's in the business of helping development of countries, typically things like water, sanitation, health and education, not toll roads, telecommunications or power stations."
Moreover, the world of development banks is one of Washington's least regulated. Most lobbyists before Congress or the executive branch of Government must register and disclose their clients. In addition, Federal law limits or prohibits former officials from having substantive dealings with the Government agency that had employed them. None of these rules apply to the development banks. And though the banks are financed by governments, their loans face far less scrutiny from the public.
"These institutions are pretty opaque, pretty much beyond scrutiny," said Doug Bandow, a senior fellow at the Cato Institute.
The principal international financial organizations in Washington are the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and its affiliate, the International Finance Corporation and the Inter-American Development Bank.
Mr. Iglesias said in the interview that the inter-American bank would prod Mr. Bentsen's fund to follow its lead and invest in the region's neediest countries. But he acknowledged that he fears "money will only flow to the best projects" since Mr. Bentsen's fund's stated intention is to make 80 percent of its investments in the region's six richest countries.
Mr. Qureshi has told investors the fund hopes to generate returns of 20 to 25 percent.
"That's a genuinely high rate of return," said Louis T. Wells, the Herbert F. Johnson Professor of International Management at Harvard Business School. While the high rate may reflect the risky history of private projects in Latin America, it may, ironically, create even further risk, Mr. Wells contends.
"Its going to be questioned in the host country where somebody is going to say we could have raised this money a lot cheaper, " he said, adding, "It's an unfortunate dilemma."
While the inter-American bank's principal activity is to make development loans to member countries, it has become infected with private-sector fever, enthusiastically supported by the United States.
And in Latin America, where some $60 billion is needed each year for infrastructure, private capital is becoming the primary source of financing.
Last year, the Inter-American Development Bank lent $7 billion while the World Bank lent $12.7 billion. The inter-American bank also began making riskier loans to private capital projects last year as part of a program to lend up to 5 percent of its capital without any official guarantee.
This came on the heels of the bank's creation in 1994 of a new private sector department. And in 1989, 30 years after its inception, the bank set up a separate investment corporation, the Inter-American Investment Corporation, to lend to and invest in Latin American businesses.
The result of these changes has been an expanding new market, where contracts resulting from those loans are in the billions, whether they are made directly to private companies or governments.
"The multilateral development banks do $30 billion a year in contracts awarded by borrowers, and the banks give out another $4-$5 billion in consulting contracts," said Donald Strombom, a Washington consultant who advises companies on how to win these contracts. "It's a very sizable market. U.S. firms are getting more of the contracts but most U.S. companies don't understand the multilaterals." Mr. Strombom was once head of procurement at the World Bank.
Mr. Qureshi, the former senior vice president of the World Bank and chairman of the Washington-based Emerging Markets Corporation, agrees that now is the time to jump into private business using his old contacts with the banks. Since he left the World Bank, where he spent most of his career, Mr. Qureshi has avoided business dealings with it.
"I decided to work with the I.D.B. so nobody could say I was using my old contacts, although I've known Enrique Iglesias for 20 years, and I still know virtually everybody at the I.D.B. because we've been in the same field," Mr. Qureshi said.
After 23 years with international banks, he moved to the private sector in 1992 because "my feeling was that private sector institutions would be playing an increasingly important role in the flow of capital to the developing world," he said in an interview.
The brains behind Mr. Bentsen's Latin America infrastructure fund, Mr. Qureshi has convinced several of his colleagues to join him, including Donald C. Roth, the former treasurer of the World Bank; Everett J. Santos, who headed Latin American affairs for the World Bank's private sector affiliate, and Arnold H. Weiss, former general counsel to the Inter-American Development Bank.
But Mr. Qureshi also needed some deep pockets. He formed an alliance with Maurice R. Greenberg, the chairman and chief executive of American International Group, the largest international insurance company.
Mr. Qureshi joined the insurer's international advisory board, American International invested in Mr. Qureshi's corporation and the two groups formed an infrastructure investment fund for Asia.
With the Asia fund up and running, Mr. Qureshi and Mr. Greenberg turned their attention to Latin America. They brought in another financial giant as a sponsor: the General Electric Capital Corporation. G.E. and American International have pledged the first $300 million for the fund.
Why was it necessary for the Latin American fund to enter into an alliance with a public development bank like the Inter-American bank? Mr. Qureshi's answer: "They have a triple-A credit rating. We felt there would be a great benefit from having the the close relationship with the I.D.B., particularly in raising money. The I.D.B. itself can be a lender to some of the projects we invest in."
He also explained how the ties to the bank can reduce the risk that a country will renege on its obligations to private creditors.
"The risk is lower with the presence of a multilateral institution," Mr. Qureshi said. "Governments will think twice about reneging on an obligation where a public institution is involved."
The bank's agreement with the fund is mostly symbolic, but in the world of marketing, symbols are important, which is one of the main attractions of hiring former officials for these groups. It was Mr. Greenberg who enlisted Mr. Bentsen to help raise money for the fund: Mr. Bentsen sits on the board of American International, which is based in New York.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lloyd M. Bentsen is helping to organize a huge Latin American capital investment fund. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times) (pg. 6)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Lear to Buy Car-Parts Maker As Industry Consolidates
The Lear Corporation, a large supplier of car seats and other car parts, plans to acquire the Masland Corporation, a maker of car interior carpets, in a $384 million deal that reflects the changes and consolidation in the international auto parts industry. 
 Wall Street liked the acquisition, which valued Masland at $26 a share. Not only did Masland's shares gain $1.50, to $25.75, Lear's stock jumped $2.50, to $37.625. [Page 33.]
 
Mazda Squeaks Out a Profit
Mazda Motor, whose two years of heavy losses led to its effective takeover by Ford, returned to profitability, barely, in the latest fiscal year. But while the results indicate that Mazda is recovering, its health is not as strong as the bottom line would suggest. The gains came from stock and real estate sales, offsetting an operating loss from auto sales. [32.]
 
Orders for Durables Fall
Orders for durable goods fell 1.9 percent in April because of slack demand for aircraft, the Government said, as the sluggish recovery in manufacturing crept forward. The decline was larger than analysts had expected and was in contrast to March's increase of 2.6 percent. Orders for durables have declined in three of the year's first four months. [33.]
 
Stocks Edge Up in Quiet Trading
The stock market ended a record-breaking week with modest gains, as trading slowed to a crawl before the Memorial Day weekend. The Dow Jones industrial average rose just 0.74, to 5,762.86, finishing the week with a gain of 75.36. Some other indicators set records, but the Nasdaq market was weighed down by weakness in technology stocks. [35.]
Bonds got a lift from the drop in durable goods orders. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.83 percent. [34.]
 
Black Raises Southam Stake
Conrad Black is moving to increase his already sizable newspaper holdings in Canada, sharply raising his company's stake in Southam, which publishes The Montreal Gazette and The Vancouver Sun. [32.]
 
U.S. Pullback in Trade Talks
The United States signaled that it was withdrawing from the negotiations to liberalize world trade in maritime services, dealing another blow to the fledgling World Trade Organization. [32.]
 
Merrill's Retreat in Indiana
Merrill Lynch will refrain from selling securities for some Indiana agencies for two years because an official of the firm donated $1,000 to the Lieutenant Governor. [34.]
 
Unanimous Vote on Rates
Federal Reserve policy makers voted unanimously on March 26 to keep the overnight bank lending rate unchanged, minutes of their meeting showed. [44.]
 
Abbott Labs Settles Suits
Abbott Laboratories agreed to settle, for $32.5 million, lawsuits brought by 17 states that contended that the company had fixed the price of baby formula. Abbott said it continued to maintain its innocence but settled to avoid further legal costs. In one case, Minnesota sued after finding that formula prices had increased 130 percent from 1980 to 1993. The settlement represents Abbott's effort to put years of litigation over baby formula behind it. [34.]
 
With Texas Dry, Cotton Prices Rise
Cotton futures prices advanced with the July contract up 0.96 cent, to 82.55 cents a pound, as traders worried about a severe drought in the important West Texas growing areas. [41.]
 
Dollar Gains Against the Yen
The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen in early trading on reports that a Japanese finance official expected strong dollar gains, but the surge slowed later in New York. [41.]

HEADLINE: About New York;
How to say 'Grass Roots' In Russian

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
WHAT is 'chimichanga?' " asked the puzzled Russian visitor, who studied the menu at Los Tres Aztecas Restaurant on Rivington Street as if it were a nuclear test ban treaty.
It's sort of like a spicy blintz, an American said. 
 Too bad there weren't easy analogies for business improvement districts, community housing development companies and tenant patrols. The people who brought the world the dictatorship of the proletariat, communal flats and collective farms need pointers on starting volunteer neighborhood groups. Their interest is part of a newfound move to create the kind of not-for-profit agencies that in this country have provided housing and social services and restored sanity to chaotic communities.
That's why a dozen Russians ventured to centers for the elderly in Flatbush, renovated tenements in the South Bronx and union-sponsored cooperative apartments in Manhattan. They want to learn from this city's grass-roots champions how to become organizers who can rally their Moscow neighborhoods in the fight against privatization and poor government planning.
"Before," said Igor Kokarev, "we lived like an atomized society, organized only at the top of government." Mr. Kokarev, a filmmaker, is president of the Citizens Foundation, a Moscow group that is training organizers. "When we all belonged to government, we had free education, medicine, free funeral. Everything. But we had no right to even move a bench in our courtyard without getting 17 signatures to approve it. Now, government becomes much less powerful and citizens, especially tenants, feel abandoned."
In a country where "not for profit" applied to state-owned businesses, Mr. Kokarev finds that many Russians misunderstand the American do-good motive. These days money talks in Moscow, and people walk away from anything that smacks of the forced voluntarism of Soviet times.
"Sometimes people believe they are not able to change something," said Yelena Kudriavtsev, who runs a children's group in her Moscow neighborhood. "Of course the young people have to look for money. They don't have the opportunity to spend their time without being paid."
T HE Russians huddled under the patchwork shade of the trees lining Sara Delano Roosevelt Park as they learned about the poor planning that created a seven-block strip of green cut through by streets and ringed by sagging sidewalks. Representatives of the Citizens Committee for New York City, a resource agency for advocates, explained how they had helped a neighborhood coalition create a center for the elderly, and gardens, as well as designs for making the park more inviting to its Asian, Hispanic and Jewish residents.
"No one is trying to buy parts of the park to build something?" asked one visitor.
The fear of privatization is understandable, said Dan Karan of the Urban Homesteading Assistance Board, a New York housing group sponsoring the visit. In the Moscow housing market, new millionaires are buying out families from communal flats, creating a bizarre income mix.
"Imagine a welfare mother and Donald Trump living in the same building," Mr. Karan said. "What an organizing challenge that would be."
THERE were no millionaires on their next stop, the grassy hills of Sunset Park, where lower Manhattan's skyline sprawled behind Brooklyn's steeples, row houses and factories. Tony Giordano, executive director of Sunset Park Restoration, explained the intricacies of building coalitions among the area's Irish, Italian, Hispanic and Asian residents.
He ambled down to a busy commercial strip on Fifth Avenue, where a few years back he had persuaded merchants to tax themselves and create a business improvement district to clean the streets, put up lights and improve security.
This, he said, is what an organized community can do with the help of volunteers.
"Any volunteer group that hires a worker for money loses its volunteers," Mr. Giordano said. "The things you do without personal gain give you greater gain."
"He's a socialist!" Mr. Kokarev said.
"I consider it direct democracy," Mr. Giordano replied. "Part of the problem in America is we've given away our authority to people who claim to have greater brains and greater hearts."
Across the street, an abandoned building with decals of plants and shades on its boarded windows stood as a reminder of past policy brainstorms. The Russians weren't falling for the Potemkin tenement. It was time to get real.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Downsized

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
'YOU SHALL MARK many a duteous and knee-crooking knave," says Iago in "Othello," "that . . . wears out his time, much like his master's ass, for nought but provender, and when he's old, cashiered." Such is "the curse of service."
If the Bard were writing today, the conniving Iago would be saying, "and when he's old, downsized." 
 Despite economic growth and low unemployment, the word that strikes fear into middle managers and white-collar worrywarts is downsizing. Though the word's connotation is positive when President Clinton speaks of "downsizing the Government," it has gained a pejorative aura when applied to layoffs of workers.
The word was born in a happy spirit. The United Auto Worker leader Leonard Woodcock was an early user, reported the quarterly American Speech, speaking of "the down-sizing, as G.M. calls it" on "Meet the Press" on Sept. 5, 1976. A month later, an ad for Ford LTD's in Southern Living asked, "Will 'down-sized' cars have 'down-sized' prices?" The raising of oil prices by the Shah of Iran in 1974 sped the need to reduce gas consumption, and Newsweek in 1978 reported "the rush to down-size cars to meet tougher fuel-efficiency standards."
In the 80's, when the verb about making cars smaller extended its sense to making work forces smaller, it was greeted with enthusiasm by stock analysts and met with narrowed eyes by unions and by easily replaced managers. Britain's Longman Register of New Words dates the current sense to 1987, defining downsize as "to reduce (a work force) in size by redundancy." (That can result from outsourcing, based on a similar formulation of direction-and-verb, outsource, meaning "to manufacture elsewhere," and causing workers to be outplaced.)
The obvious reverberant coinage was upsize, which made an appearance in an ad in the March 1983 Car and Driver. Its meanings, however, were "to enlarge, amalgamate, conglomerate, grow," as in the 1996 Variety headline about the ballooning of show biz: "The Upsizing of Hollywood." However, these related meanings are not the opposite of "to fire" in the current, personal sense of downsize. A newly hired person does not say cheerily, "I've been upsized," unless he has been putting on weight as well.
In "The Dilbert Principle," the cartoonist Scott Adams writes of his years of employment at Pacific Bell: "Companies realized they had to make downsizing sound like more of a positive development in order to keep morale high. This was accomplished through a creative process of inventing happier-sounding phrases that all meant essentially the same thing. 'You're fired' (1980); 'You're laid off' (1985); 'You're downsized' (1990); 'You're rightsized' (1995). . . . You'll see the following phrases used during the next five years: 'You're happysized!'; 'You're splendidsized!' "
The lexicon of layoff has a wide range. Cashier, the verb Shakespeare chose in the sense of "discharge," is from the French casser, "to annul," not from cassier, "to put in a money box" (which is why we don't cashier cashiers). The verb cashier is "to dismiss from a position of high rank, usually with dishonor." To dismiss is to let go without taint; to discharge lies between, to dismiss for cause but without tearing off epaulets and putting a reprimand in the 201 file. Sack, bounce, give the heave-ho and can are all informal synonyms for these verbs of peremptory riddance. The government bureaucracy's rif stands for "reduction in force" and imputes obedience to budget cuts rather than firing for cause. Walking papers is passe. Ax is still in use, a favorite of sports headline writers, and suggests that the owner doing the firing of the manager gets a sadistic kick out of the act.
All these are more vivid than downsize, which in turn has more blood in its veins than the recent restructure and re-engineer, leading to the even more vapid noun phrase work-force imbalance correction.
A counter-euphemism is called for to denote an opposite of dismissal. The language is struggling to come up with a verb expressing irate voluntary departure better than the currently muttered I'm outta here. Lexicographers can almost hear it now: "You can't downsize me -- I [future euphemism]!"

Duh

"Duh . . . N.F.L. Players Really Aren't So Dumb," read a recent headline in The Wall Street Journal over an article about the measurement of cognitive ability given to football draft prospects.
Is duh considered paralanguage, like the uncertain uh or the interrogatory hunh? No. Is it what the sociologist Erving Goffman calls "a response cry," like ouch or yecch? Sometimes.
Most often, duh is an interjection, an exclamatory sound ejaculated for a lexical purpose -- that is, to convey a specific message. For that meaning, let us turn to Frank Nuessel, professor of classical and modern languages at the University of Louisville and the leading, and perhaps only, authority on duh.
"The interjection duh appears to have a general meaning of 'Boy, am I stupid!' " notes Professor Nuessel. "It may also appear as a 'tag form' at the end of a sentence, meaning 'Don't you think I'm behaving in a stupid (ignorant) fashion?' This usage implies another person in a conversational dyad." (Duh? Dyad means "pair.")
In one use, duh is a response to which the person does not know the answer. Person 1: "Do you know the square root of 1188?" Person 2: "Duh." (Meaning: "I don't know.") In the tag form, a person would say self-mockingly: "I'm really good at this. Duh!" (Meaning: "I really haven't the foggiest notion how to do this!") Here the interjection equals "Not!"
"The choice of this interjection is a calculated usage," Nuessel points out. "It represents a linguistic convention designed to symbolize ignorance. It differs from the paralinguistic form um because um is an automatic response while the use of duh is deliberate."
To avoid the need to assert ignorance, all I do is hit my Num Lock key and transform a portion of my keyboard into a calculator, thereby getting the square root of 1188. Done. So where's the square root key? Duh!

HEADLINE: How To Get To Mars (And Make Millions!)

BYLINE: By John Tierney; John Tierney is a staff writer for the Magazine.

 BODY:
[The urge to venture afar] arises from the threefold nature of man. One motive is fame, for it is the nature of man to journey where there is great danger, and thus win honor and praise. A second motive is curiosity, for it is also man's nature to see the things he has heard about, and thus learn whether they are as he has been told or not. The third is the desire for gain, for men seek wealth wherever they have heard that gain is to be gotten. -- FROM "THE KING'S MIRROR," A 13TH-CENTURY NORSE TREATISE
 WHEN HUMANS FINALLY ACQUIRED the technology to travel to another planet, it occurred to them that they didn't really want to go. A manned mission to Mars, the fantasy that had paid the mortgage for generations of science-fiction writers, lost its appeal as soon as NASA plotted the itinerary. The $400 billion price tag seemed absurdly high to a nation bored with the sight of astronauts lumbering around craters. We already had enough extraterrestrial rocks, thank you. 
 Recently, though, an intriguing modification to NASA's Mars plan has been suggested: ditch NASA. Let private explorers, modern Vikings inspired by the Norsemen's third desire, seek wealth on Mars. The basics of the expedition have been worked out by Robert M. Zubrin, who has his own research and development company, Pioneer Astronautics, in Denver. Since devising the technology for a simple and cheap mission to Mars, Zubrin has been traveling the globe giving passionate lectures about "our generation's New World." He tells audiences of the prizes offered by 15th-century Portuguese and Spanish rulers to entrepreneurs for venturing down the African coast and across the Atlantic. (Columbus's expedition was financed not only by Queen Isabella but also by private merchants who stood to gain trading concessions.) Zubrin thinks that if the United States Government were to offer a Mars Prize of $20 billion -- four times what he estimates a private mission would cost -- entrepreneurs would take the bait. If they made it to Mars and back, pocketing the prize, they could turn a nice profit; if they failed, taxpayers wouldn't be stuck with the bill.
The Mars Prize would be a bargain for the public, and not merely because it would cost so much less than a NASA mission. It would also have the wonderful consequence of making exploration interesting again. Unlike NASA's conservative officials, entrepreneurs couldn't afford to bore everyone with meticulously plotted test missions executed by bland technicians. They would have to take chances, risking their lives (or at least their employees' lives) with one bold venture, as explorers used to do. And because they would finance their mission by selling media rights and marketing tie-ins, they would have to appeal to the public's imagination. They couldn't go to Mars just to perform arcane scientific experiments and drop off a plaque with politicians' names. They would have to turn Mars, once again, into a dangerous and romantic destination.
The journey would be a multimedia entertainment package put together by someone like Joel Rosenman, one of the promoters of the original Woodstock festival and its recent sequel. Rosenman, whose venture-capital projects have included an expedition to salvage doubloons from a sunken Spanish galleon in the Caribbean, has no trouble imagining the commercial possibilities of a journey to Mars.
"Under NASA, space exploration has been a low-yield cash hog," Rosenman says. "To make a Mars mission profitable, you'd have to create a global consciousness. People have to be eating Mars cereal, listening to Mars music, entering Mars dance contests, watching Mars pay-per-view TV shows, driving cars with technology from the Mars mission. You'd want to put a celebrity in the crew -- Harrison Ford would be perfect -- or at least turn the crew into celebrities. I'd set up a betting parlor on the Internet where people could bet on everything from the temperature of the spaceship to which astronaut will be the first to catch a cold. Sprint would have Candice Bergen offering free phone calls when Mars was in a certain apposition to the Earth."
The Olympic Games, a three-week media event, currently generates close to $2 billion from television and marketing deals; packaged properly, the three-year Mars extravaganza might make considerably more. "A Mars mission could attract the largest global audience ever," says David Hill, the president of Fox Sports. "The Olympics are just the Olympics -- people running, jumping, throwing balls. Mars has figured prominently in man's imagination for thousands of years. It's the Red Planet, the God of War. Now it's the next logical step in human endeavor. The crew would be on live television traveling through space at 200 million miles an hour, and they could die at any moment -- it's the world's greatest soap opera."
A commercial Mars mission may sound impractical and undignified, but that's only because our thinking has been warped by NASA, which is an anomaly in the annals of discovery: the wilderness has not usually been conquered by bureaucrats. The best models for a Mars mission are provided by the kind of explorers who early this century raced to the North and South Poles -- regions that seemed as remote, inhospitable and useless as Mars does today. Forget all those cautious mission planners speaking NASA jargon to emotionally repressed astronauts. We need explorers with flair, adventurers like . . . Amundsen and Shackleton.

The Amundsen Approach
ZUBRIN IS BORROWING HIS MARS strategy from the greatest of the polar explorers, Roald Amundsen, the first man to reach the South Pole and the first to sail the Northwest Passage. Before Amundsen started his trip through the Arctic ice in 1903, dozens of expeditions had unsuccessfully tried to traverse the Northwest Passage from the Atlantic to the Pacific. The British Navy, the NASA of the 19th century, kept sending armored ships with scores of sailors and tons of salted meat, but the massive ships always ran aground or got blocked by ice, and when the food ran out the men would give up.
Norway, Amundsen's homeland, didn't have a grand navy; Amundsen had to pay for his own expedition. He spent his inheritance on a tiny old fishing boat and hired a crew of six. "Amundsen's expedition was by far the smallest one ever to attempt the Northwest Passage," Zubrin says. "He didn't go into the Arctic with 300 tons of salt pork. There wasn't enough room in his boat or his budget. As an expedition done with private money, it had to be, we might say, a pork-free mission." Amundsen was prepared to live off the land. When his ship got frozen in at the same spot where British sailors had perished, he and his men survived by using local Inuit techniques. They built igloos, wore fur underwear and hunted caribou from dog sleds. Eating heartily, the men proceeded all the way through the Bering Strait.
The Amundsen approach, as Zubrin calls his strategy for Mars, is nothing like the $400 billion Battlestar Galactica approach proposed by NASA engineers. NASA's ship, according to the 1989 plan, would have carried enough fuel for the round trip and was so big that it would have had to have been assembled at a space station. Zubrin prefers an expedition that would travel light and live off the land -- or, more precisely, the atmosphere, which would supply the Martian equivalent of Amundsen's caribou: carbon dioxide. The expedition would bring machines for converting Mars's carbon dioxide into liquid oxygen and methane to power the spaceship home. This local fuel would also power the utility vehicles used to drive around the Martian surface. Because the ship wouldn't have to lug so much fuel to Mars, it could be launched from Earth with rockets that have already been built and tested. Instead of NASA's 1,000-ton space liner, Zubrin proposes a pair of 120-ton ships; instead of a 30-year timetable, he thinks he could get there in as few as 6.
NASA was skeptical of the plan when it was drawn up six years ago by Zubrin and David Baker, both of whom were then engineers at Martin Marietta Astronautics. But once it became obvious that NASA's Mars scheme was unaffordable, the agency studied Zubrin's plan and provided $47,000 for him to build a prototype of the machine for converting carbon dioxide into rocket fuel. NASA's engineers, concluding that the Amundsen approach was technically feasible, drafted their own version of Zubrin's plan. NASA estimates that its mission would cost $55 billion -- a big improvement over $400 billion, but Zubrin thinks NASA could trim the budget to $30 billion by making do with less equipment and more spartan accommodations.
Even greater economies, though, would come from bypassing NASA's bureaucracy, which is why Zubrin and others have been urging incentives for space entrepreneurs. (Last weekend, the privately financed X Prize Foundation announced a $10 million prize for the first manned, completely reusable spacecraft that can take off on its own, rocket 62 miles above Earth and safely return to make another flight.) Zubrin figures that private explorers could get to Mars cheaply by cobbling together off-the-shelf equipment (like Russia's low-priced booster rockets), renting a launch pad and subcontracting NASA to perform some tasks, like tracking the spacecraft. He estimates that the whole mission could be done for $5 billion.
That's not much money by NASA standards -- the Apollo program cost 20 times as much -- but it's a daunting figure for private investors. To compete for the Mars Prize, explorers will need creative financing. To pay for the Amundsen approach, they'll need to learn from Ernest Shackleton, a charismatic Anglo-Irishman who became the greatest polar salesman.

The Shackleton Sell
ON JUNE 11, 1909, AS HIS SHIP approached the Italian port of Brindisi, Shackleton was pacing the bridge and talking to himself. He was returning to Europe from a failed and nearly fatal expedition. Poor planning had forced him and his men to stop about 100 miles short of the South Pole. Stumbling into ice crevasses, desperately sick and malnourished, the frostbitten men made it back to their ship by taking hourly doses of cocaine-laden "forced march" tablets.
If Shackleton had worked for NASA, he would have faced the scrutiny of Congressional committees and journalists. NASA's officials would have been advising him to be quiet. But as it was, the self-employed Shackleton was eagerly preparing for the European press corps clustered on the dock, muttering phrases in search of what he called the right "catchword."
"I've got it at last!" he finally cried out. "Death lay ahead and food behind, so I had to return."
A true pioneer: a man in 1909 searching for the right sound bite. Shackleton couldn't afford to be unquotable: he paid for his expeditions by mortgaging profits from media ventures. Before leaving for Antarctica, he auctioned off the news and picture rights to London newspapers; upon returning, he dashed off a book that was immediately translated into nine languages. Shackleton turned his expedition ship into a museum and charged admission. He sold special postage stamps with a cancellation mark from the Antarctic. He went on a 20,000-mile lecture tour, mesmerizing audiences with poetry and harrowing tales. Using the new media of his day, he made a phonograph record and showed the first movie of the Antarctic. Other explorers had similar commercial instincts -- Peary designed a brand of Peary North Pole snowshoes and outerwear -- but no one could match Shackleton's verve.
His hustling taught him a lesson that NASA hasn't yet learned: if you want to explore a place with no intrinsic value, you must create value. You need compelling characters and drama -- the kind of risk that NASA can no longer take. Manned missions have become tedious and prohibitively expensive because the agency's bureaucrats must take every possible precaution: one more accident like the Challenger explosion would doom their careers, perhaps the whole space program. A failed Government mission is always treated as a public scandal. When men died on a United States Army expedition to the Arctic in 1884, The New York Times dubbed it "The Shame of the Nation" and demanded that America stop financing this "folly." The paper's crusade helped force the Government to cease Arctic explorations -- and then, two decades later, The Times itself proudly underwrote Peary's expedition.
Folly somehow becomes acceptable if your own money is at stake. In fact, it can be an excellent career move. Shackleton's audacious misadventures in 1909 made him an international idol. His next expedition, when he was marooned in the Antarctic after ice crushed his ship, turned into an even more glorious failure -- perhaps the most astonishing survival epic ever told (and, of course, sold). The worst trips make the best stories. Apollo 11 was a marvel of technical precision; "Apollo 13" grossed $337 million worldwide.
Certainly no sane explorers would wish for disaster on the way to Mars. But whatever happens, they must have a Shackletonian knack for media exploitation. While Mars may be a more expensive goal than the Antarctic ever was, today's global markets offer much bigger returns to the explorer who can seductively package the trip.

Mars: The Sales Pitch
 THE FIRST VOYAGERS TO MARS WOULD spend six months getting there, two years exploring its surface and six months coming home. In selecting the explorers, the natural temptation is to ask: Who has the best chance of pulling through the three-year ordeal? That's the wrong question. That's how NASA produced all those scintillating astronauts. The first question should be: Who has the best chance of pulling the audience through the three-year ordeal?
Fortunately, the market has already come up with answers, starting with the optimum size of the crew. The most successful television shows about isolated groups -- "Gilligan's Island," "Star Trek" and "Lost in Space" -- all enjoyed long runs with rosters of seven or eight people. Sending a family to another world offers classic sitcom opportunities, as demonstrated each week on the new hit "Third Rock From the Sun," but the crew should also include unattached adults.
The Mars expedition leader must ignore the advice of Michael Collins, a former astronaut and the author of "Mission to Mars," a 1990 book proposing a crew of married couples. "An element of stability, of old-shoe comfort, would be introduced by having one's husband or wife to fall back on," Collins argues. "Certainly a singles-bar atmosphere, a charged mixture of sexually unattached competitors, would be a disaster." A disaster for whom? Take a look at the ratings for "Friends."
Each crew member needs the talents of an explorer -- physical stamina, emotional fortitude, technical resourcefulness -- and the charisma of a performer. Call it the Bright Stuff. To find the right candidates, and to generate publicity, the expedition leader can stage televised competitions around the world, testing candidates' physical, mental and telegenic skills: "American Gladiators" meets "Jeopardy" meets "Star Search." Finalists will spend a winter of competition in the Antarctic, the closest equivalent to the frozen plains and mountains of Mars. There, they'll hone their exploration and media skills while living in a model of the mobile home that will carry them through space and shelter them on Mars.
"The habitation module's design is inspired by the Bumble Bee tuna can," Zubrin says. "It's a can 27 feet in diameter and 16 feet tall, divided into two decks. The upper deck is laid out with rooms for the astronauts, a laboratory, an exercise area, a galley and a food-storage area that would double as a solar-flare storm shelter. The lower deck is more of a cargo hold, workshop area and garage for the rover that would explore Mars."
Whether they're traveling through space or living on Mars, the explorers will always be in front of cameras feeding live images back to Earth, which would reassure the audience of the mission's integrity. Unlike some exploring "heroes" -- Peary and Byrd -- the Mars adventurers won't be able to come home with tales of places they never reached. They'll have to make their money honestly. But at least they'll have lots of opportunities for profit. A few possibilities:
Corporate sponsorship. "Mars is a compelling platform for what we in the business call borrowed imagery," says Jay Coleman, the chief executive of the E.M.C.I. marketing company and an expert in special-event promotions. "If you're AT&T, it's a great way to align your brand with high technology and the future. When you see companies like Coca-Cola spending $40 million just for the right to say it's an Olympic sponsor, and then hundreds of millions more to buy time to advertise that fact, you have to assume that they'd pay a lot to be associated with Mars."
Marketing tie-ins. "I'd have a ball marketing the apparel, creating a whole new Mars look, selling the first sneaker to touch down on Mars," says Brandon Steiner, whose New York company is one of the leading sports marketers. "There'd be a collectibles market -- you could break a Mars rock into tiny pieces and mount each one inside a glass case. I'd love to see the spaceship going up with a Nike logo on it. Of course, a model of the spaceship is going to be a great toy, and Mars would be happening for kids in cartoons. If you do everything right, you could net maybe a billion every year of the mission."
Video games. Besides being lucrative -- their grosses exceed movie box-office sales -- video games create celebrities now that CD-ROM's feature real actors filmed on movie sets. The first Mars game, filmed during the explorers' training period, would come out well before the launch.
"Millions of kids will pay to play the game and start to think of the astronauts as their friends," says Tom Zito, the president of Digital Pictures, which has been filming members of the "Star Trek" and "Baywatch" casts for its popular science-fiction games. "Kids will be eager to follow the real mission when it starts on television -- especially if one of the astronauts looks like Cindy Crawford. Then you use video clips from the mission itself to make more games. The ultimate cool thing would be to put a robot with a camera on Mars, so you could send it commands and go out exploring the planet yourself, searching for treasures hidden by the astronauts. At the end of the game, you'd find a statue of Elvis."
Name that peak. Shackleton sensibly affixed the names of his patrons to the geography of the Antarctic. For about $34,000, William Beardmore got his name on a 100-mile-long glacier. What would Rupert Murdoch pay to put his on Mars's 2,800-mile-long canyon? How much for an 18-mile-high volcano named Mount Gates?
Mars on line. Technophiles pay to watch a Martian sunset, join the explorers in chat rooms or track the data streaming back to Earth, like the readings from the machinery converting carbon dioxide into methane. If the converter is running properly, the explorers should have enough rocket fuel to get home; if not . . . well, let's take a look at the crew members' pulse rates.
Mars TV. "The networks won't want to pay for access to the mission," says Av Westin, the producer who developed "Close-Up" and "20/20" at ABC. "But once cable pays and the public gets interested, they'll find a way. They'll probably save the purity of the news divisions by getting their entertainment divisions to put up the money. You want the astronauts doing a weekly news update show -- you know, 'Live from Mars, it's Saturday Night.' Then you want occasional documentaries. You need to produce a sense of drama, the way Geraldo did when he opened the Capone vault on live television, although you'd like it to turn out better than that. You could do a live show with a payoff at the end. You start out asking: 'Is there water underground on Mars? Are there fossils down there? Tonight we'll drill below the surface strata. . . .' "
The most popular television program, though, might be an extraterrestrial version of "The Real World," MTV's weekly documentary chronicling the personal lives of a bunch of young narcissists sharing a living space. To a casual observer, the footage of roommate squabbles seems dreadfully tedious, but it's one of the highest rated programs on MTV, a testament to the strange allure of real-life soap operas.
"The mission gives you a $5 billion set for a drama," says Rosenman, the venture capitalist. "You might even think about giving the explorers scripts, although with the right crew, the reality might be more compelling. We could become riveted to this thing developing between Florence and Greg when she was supposed to be sweet on Homer -- a timeless story of a love triangle, or of someone whose conscience is being tested for elasticity. Once you have a devoted band of addicts, everyone will start to care if Greg and Florence and Homer make it to Mars and back."
The uncertainty of the mission will complicate financing, of course, since investors will be leery of a project that could end at any moment. But if investors take the truly coldblooded, long-term view, they'll realize that even an utter failure -- the loss of all eight explorers on the way to Mars -- wouldn't necessarily mean financial ruin. Like the failed expeditions to the poles, a Mars disaster would fascinate the public, sell books and movies and inspire sequels. New competitors would be tempted by Mars's deadly glamour. Billionaires bored with mountain-climbing expeditions and America's Cup yachts could race one another to Mars. But to succeed commercially, Rosenman says, a Mars mission must at least seem to be grander than a sporting event.
"You can't trivialize this massive effort to reach another planet," he explains. "The ancillaries fizzle if the audience thinks you're doing it just for the heck of it. You need a larger reason to get there -- a Hollywood twist like the Mars mission as the only way to divert an Earthbound asteroid, or chemicals in the Martian soil believed to cure cancer. As with my salvage operation in the Caribbean, the entrepreneur has to ask: What is the motivation? What is the Martian equivalent of those Spanish doubloons?"
That's a difficult question. Mars, at first glance, seems to have nothing of value. But Zubrin is ready with an answer. His plan comes complete with doubloons.

Our Favorite Martians
 ONE OF THE MOST FAMOUS PASSAGES IN science fiction is the conclusion of Ray Bradbury's "Martian Chronicles," published in 1950. It describes a family that has fled a holocaust on Earth. Their spaceship reaches Mars, uninhabited because its civilization of gentle extraterrestrials was wiped out by previous human invaders. The family lands and emerges from the spaceship next to a canal:
"I've always wanted to see a Martian," said Michael. "Where are they, Dad? You promised."
"There they are," said Dad, and he shifted Michael on his shoulder and pointed straight down.
The Martians were there. Timothy began to shiver.
The Martians were there -- in the canal -- reflected in the water. Timothy and Michael and Robert and Mom and Dad.
The Martians stared back up at them for a long, long silent time from the rippling water.
The dream of colonizing Mars, so popular for so long, today seems as quaintly anachronistic as the canals that previous generations of astronomers thought they saw on its surface. But Zubrin, as usual, has a new plan. He and Chris McKay, a planetary scientist at NASA's Ames Research Center, propose to release chlorofluorocarbons into the Martian atmosphere. They figure that CFC's could jump-start a runaway greenhouse effect, warming the planet, melting its polar caps and thickening the atmosphere with carbon dioxide released from ice and soil. Humans could then walk around the surface without pressurized suits, and as trees and plants produced oxygen the atmosphere would eventually become breathable.
"Relative to the technology we have today, Mars is no more hostile to us than America was to Europeans in the 1600's," Zubrin says. "Granted, the transportation costs are higher -- back then a middle-class person could pay for the passage by liquidating his assets. But the costs will come down quickly once somebody makes the first trip. If a developer could persuade a research station to sign up as an anchor tenant, he could start a small settlement with its own greenhouse and build from there."
To advance his theory, Zubrin likes to quote Frederick Jackson Turner's classic essay on the American frontier. "To the frontier the American intellect owes its striking characteristics," Turner wrote in 1893, arguing that the "stubborn American environment" nurtured creativity because it offered "a gate of escape from the bondage of the past."
Zubrin sees only one new frontier capable of providing that escape again. "Mars is far enough away to free its colonists from intellectual, legal or cultural domination by the old world," he says. "It's rich enough in resources -- water, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, metals -- to give birth to a new world. Having a planet of refuge could be of enormous social use. It would reinvigorate civilization on Earth with its new ideas, just as America reinvigorated Europe. In human history, free dynamic societies have existed only during the four centuries of frontier expansion in the West. Without a new frontier, our civilization is doomed to stagnation."
Mars as the new America, Mars as the only hope of civilization: here are some serious doubloons. Here is sufficient motivation to ennoble any Mars mission. And if the Mars-as-America analogy later turns out to be wrong -- if a Mars colony isn't practical during the next few centuries -- the mission will have served a fine purpose anyway. Posterity will enjoy a new exploration saga, probably more stirring than the Vikings', maybe even as good as Shackleton's.
The Antarctic's recent history, in fact, may be the best guide to Mars's future. Although it failed to become a hot spot of colonization after being charted by the polar explorers, Antarctica has nonetheless been a boon to humanity. Government scientists, taking advantage of the risky trailblazing done by private explorers, have set up research stations that have yielded vital data for today's environmental debates. And another group of people has followed the explorers. Arriving in cruise ships during the Antarctic summer, clad in identical bright red parkas, these visitors clamber on the white cliffs and take pictures of one another posing with penguins. Mainly wealthy and elderly, they fatten up on buffet dinners along the shores explored by Shackleton. In his direst moments, stumbling in the snow and popping cocaine tablets, Shackleton probably never imagined that he was risking his life to make a continent safe for geriatric tourists.
If the destiny of Mars, too, is to be an adventure-travel package, an exotic segment of the entertainment industry, then the first humans to land will experience something quite like the famous moment in "The Martian Chronicles." When the explorers disembark in front of a television camera and address the audience back home, they won't have to imagine what future Martians will be like. They'll see the Martians staring back from the monitor of their own camera: local guides showing foreign customers the sights, standing next to an interplanetary tour bus as they pursue the Vikings' third and most enduring desire.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
On Maui, Free Splendor On the Outskirts of Luxury

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
THE famed 50-mile highway that winds around the northeastern coast of Maui to the town of Hana strikes many who drive it as more an amusement park ride than a road -- one hair-raising lane most of the way, with 600 tight curves and 56 battered bridges spanning fast-flooding streams that course down the rain-forested flanks of the Haleakala volcano. Roadside barricades don't look formidable enough to keep a grocery cart from crashing over the sea cliffs to the breakers below; sweeping vistas of the coast tempt drivers to take their eyes off the road, and frequent rain squalls slick the pavement, leaving behind a litter of bright orange African tulip blossoms.
Few thrill seekers reach Hana Town unsatisfied by the trip (which takes about two and a half hours from Kahului Airport on the north coast of Maui). But because Hana is on the rainy side of the island and there isn't much to the little country town (population 1,895) besides a luxury hotel, most day trippers feel let down when the ride is over. In fact, one morning as I was standing at the bulletin board outside the tiny Hana post office, a man in a rented car pulled alongside me and asked, "Which way to the center of town?" 
 I paused, trying to decide how to break it to him that he was in the center of town. Then I tried to cushion the blow by telling him about the barbecued chicken and ribs served as part of the $8.95, all-you-can-eat lunch buffet at the Hana Ranch Restaurant and by describing a red sand beach nearby where he could swim -- if he didn't mind nudists.
I'm fairly sure that, regardless of anything I said, he was going to do what most day trippers do when they reach Hana -- turn around and drive back to the sunny west side of the island, where there is no shortage of shops, resorts and tourist attractions. But I confess that I threw in the nudists to speed him on his way, because most day trippers look askance on clothing-optional beaches. By that time I had been in Hana, on the isolated east coast of Maui, long enough to know that it is nicest when there aren't too many people around.
I spent six nights there. This is longer than I usually stay in any one place, but it gave me the chance to watch Little League tryouts at the Hana Ball Park (which is naturally greener than Astroturf), to sample shave ices (as they call snow cones) in the full spectrum of tropical flavors from Tutu's snack shop at Hana Bay and discuss bait with fishermen on the pier, to sing old familiar hymns in Hawaiian during Easter Sunday services at Wananulua Church (founded by Congregationalist missionaries from New England in 1838) and finally to understand why people put bumper stickers on their cars that say Thank God for Hana.
Actually, people have been thanking God for Hana for at least a millennium -- beginning with the early Hawaiians who settled in large villages along the coast, growing taro, building paved roads and lava-rock temples called heiaus, spinning legends that persist in place names and waving to Captain Cook when he sailed by in 1778.
A century later, planters from Europe and America found the flowing eastern skirts of Haleakala fertile ground for sugar cane, and imported workers to tend the fields from China, Japan, Portugal, Spain, Puerto Rico and the Philippines. By the 1930's Hana's population had swelled to an all-time high of 3,500; the Hana Highway had been built; the town had two movie theaters, three barber shops, a Buddhist temple, the landmark Hasegawa General Store (which opened in 1910) and a beautiful ethnically mixed face. Indeed, one of the most striking exhibits in the little Hana Cultural Center near the bay (admission free) is a bank of large photographic portraits of town residents with names like Iwalani Librando Castro, Elizabeth Redo Tanaka and Solomon Hoopai Jr.
But like the heiaus, the sugar mills are mostly unmarked tumbledown ruins now, closed in the 1940's. At about that time, 14,000 acres of stubbly fields surrounding Hana were sold to an entrepreneur from San Francisco named Paul I. Fagan, who planted pangola range grass to feed herds of Hereford cattle shipped over from the island of Molokai and branded with the five-pointed Hana Ranch star. The cattle still graze right above the 96-room Hotel Hana-Maui, which was built by Mr. Fagan in 1946 (but has changed hands several times since). Oddly, steaks sold at the Hana Ranch Store are frozen (and along with all other imported comestibles, extremely expensive), leading one to suspect that lowing cattle are largely set dressing.
These days, high-end tourism seems to be what keeps little Hana tenuously afloat. And I mean high end, because standard rooms at the luxury Hana-Maui cost $395 a night; Sea Ranch Cottages at the hotel have private hot tubs and cost $525.
Hana caters to guests who frequent the hotel and pays rather offhand attention to day trippers, known locally as "rent-a-car tourists." Of course, this posed an irresistible challenge to me because I love to find reasonably priced ways of hanging around the edges of expensive resorts. So a month before leaving, I called Waianapanapa State Park, set on 120 acres bordered by sea cliffs and a small black pebble beach about five miles north of Hana; the park's 12 rustic cabins are extremely popular, which is why I was lucky to get one of them for just a night at $45. Then I phoned several vacation rental firms in Hana and found two options I could afford -- the downstairs unit in a house called Hale Kipa for $90 from Blair's Original Hana Plantation Houses (where I stayed for two nights before moving to the state park), and a little studio apartment at the rear of a bayfront home called Hale Waikoloa for $65 from Hana Alii Holidays (which I booked for my last three nights in town).
Hale Kipa turned out to be a nicely kept, modest, brown-shingled duplex out of sight of the bay but within earshot of the surf. The downstairs unit was a bit dark, and like everyplace else I stayed, haunted by mosquitos (I had packed insect repellent). A wide wood lanai surrounded by blooming heliconias and hibiscus gave way to the spacious interior, which had sleeping quarters with a double bed, a television room cooled by a ceiling fan, a bath and well-equipped kitchen. In the driveway there was a barbecue grill, and at the side a fenced-in hot tub.
I tended to start my mornings on the lanai at Hale Kipa with coffee and a papaya purchased for about $1 at one of the little unattended fruit and flower stands dotting the roads around Hana. Then I'd run the 2.5-mile trail that winds through pastures above the Hotel Hana-Maui, explore the precarious, ironwood-shrouded paths around Kauiki Hill, which forms the south arm of Hana Bay, or climb to the cross honoring Paul Fagan atop an old volcanic cinder cone just west of town. It didn't really matter where I roamed, because there was always something to occupy me -- like watching calf-roping practice at a ring below the headquarters of the Hana Ranch, grocery shopping at the jammed Hasegawa General Store and, best of all, swimming at the red sand beach on the south side of Kauiki Hill. Reached by a steep path, this small beach hugs a dramatically eroded cliff and is fronted by a row of jagged black rocks, forming a beautiful protected pool favored by lovestruck couples, scruffy campers and unself-conscious families frolicking in the buff. (The clothed are welcome as well.)
In the afternoon, I'd take a dip in my hot tub, clean up and then wander over to the Hotel Hana-Maui to admire the displays of coral in the airy lobby and have a mai tai for $7.25 in the Paniolo Bar, where I liked to imagine how the people at the tables next to me had made their money. One night I watched the Hawaiian show in the main dining room featuring members of the hotel staff (free, from a couch near the entrance to the restaurant). On another I splurged on dinner there, choosing one of the least expensive entrees -- lovely Thai chicken in almond and red wine sauce, which came with taro rolls ($23.50), accompanied by a glass of white wine ($7.50).
After living like this for two days, I admit it was something of a jolt to check into Waianapanapa State Park cabin No. 10, a plain green, boxy building set among pandanus trees, with a porch where there was a picnic table, garbage can and mop hanging over the balustrade to dry. Inside was one big room with a kitchen, a table and two single beds, another room with two bunk beds and a bathroom with a shower. Freshly laundered sheets were ready to be put on the beds; the linoleum floor was cracked but basically clean, and spigots yielded hot water. So I put a few red ginger blossoms in a juice pitcher and settled in.
By the time I got around to exploring, the day trippers had all gone home, leaving the rough little black stone beach, lava tube caves and the path that winds along the rugged coast to me and just a few other overnighters in the clusters of cabins in the park. That evening the most luminous full moon I've ever seen rose in the sky, and early the next morning while perched on a little ledge in the cliffs and doing nothing in particular, I saw a whale spout and then breach about a hundred yards out to sea.
To me, a whale sighting is hard to top -- though the remnants of a heiau (listed on the Hawaiian Register of Historic Places) in the front garden of Hale Waikoloa almost did. Beyond the breezy brown house lay a stone-lined curve of Hana Bay, and to the side there was a fish pond. My little studio next to the garage was very private -- one small room (with a bath alongside) holding a plump double bed, small table, television and kitchenette, all nicely finished in wood. Outside my door was a hibachi on which I barbecued a steak one night, a table and chair where I ate a plate of pasta primavera on another and a washer and dryer. The guest book revealed that a young man and woman had decided to get married while staying there.
BY the time I moved into the Hale Waikoloa studio, I'd seen most of the sights in Hana, so I ventured about five miles south to Hamoa Beach, a pretty scallop of white sand with gentle surf, frequented by guests from the Hotel Hana-Maui. South of that, the lush, rolling countryside along the Hana Highway opens up, providing exquisite views of coast and mountain all the way to the Kipahulu area of Haleakala National Park, a finger of land that stretches southeast of the volcano's crater to meet the Pacific about 15 miles south of Hana. In the park I hiked two miles on a popular, well-maintained path up along a streambed to Waimoku Falls, passing through magical bamboo groves along the way, and took a swim in the pools at the mouth of Pipiwai Stream. A mile south, I found the simple, bucolic Palapala Hoomau Congregational Church on an isolated spot near the sea cliffs where I paid my respects at the grave of Charles Lindbergh, who spent his last years on the Hana coast. I turned back toward Hana when the paved road devolved into gravel.
Actually, the rough road continues all the way around the southeast coast of Maui. But I didn't think the little Geo Metro I'd rented (from Alamo Rent a Car at Kahului Airport, for $133 a week) was up to the trip. And, frankly, I needed to get back to Hana, because it was time for my afternoon visit to Tutu's, where for $1.75 you can choose two flavors to coat each half of a huge snow cone. Among other combinations, I tried pineapple-lime. But it is my considered opinion that banana-cherry is the best.
 
The bottom line in and around Hana
During my trip, I spent an average of $102 a day, $70 of which went toward accommodations. In Hana there are a number of activities available -- like kayak-and-snorkel tours of Hana Bay lasting two hours for $59, (808) 248-7711; horseback riding around Hana ($29.95 an hour, for reservations stop at the the social desk in the Hotel Hana-Maui); or three-hour horseback trail rides in the Kipahulu section of Haleakala National Park for $95, for information call Oheo Stables, (808) 667-2222. But those prices discouraged me. Most of what I spent apart from accommodations went toward groceries, available at steep prices from both Hasegawa's and the Hana Ranch Store. If you drive to Hana from Kahului Airport, it's wise to purchase somewhat less expensive staples in the town of Paia on the Hana Highway.

 Getting There
To get to Hawaii in late March, I contacted a consolidator called Cheap Tickets, (800) 377-1000, and got a round-trip fare from New York to Honolulu for $584. I flew on T.W.A., with a stop in St. Louis. However, when I checked in April T.W.A.'s lowest round-trip fare from New York to Honolulu cost $515, traveling on Tuesday or Wednesday, with a 14-day advance purchase.
Should you happen to be going to Hawaii from Los Angeles or San Francisco, check the Sun Trips charter company, (800) 786-8747, which has a round-trip Los Angeles-Honolulu fare of $239. For interisland flights, try Mahalo Air, (800) 462-4256. My trips, from the Big Island to Maui, and from Maui to Honolulu, cost $49 each. Mahalo can also book rental cars; in April the airline got me an economy-class Geo Metro from Alamo at Kahului Airport on Maui for $133 a week. Hana has its own tiny airport, served by Island Air, (800) 323-3345; there are two flights daily to and from Honolulu, priced at $81 each way.
Dollar has an office at the Hana Airport, (808) 248-8237, where full-sized cars are $299 a week; smaller cars can be requested, but Dollar cannot promise their availability.

 Information
The Hawaii Visitors Bureau has an office at the Empire State Building, Suite 808, 350 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10118, (212) 947-0717, fax (212) 947-0725. The Maui Visitors Bureau is at 1727 Wili Pa Loop, Wailuku, Maui, Hawaii 96793, (808) 244-3530, fax (808) 244-1337.
For information on the Kipahulu area of Haleakala National Park, write the superintendent at Post Office Box 369, Makawao, Maui, Hawaii 96768, or call the Kipahulu Ranger Station, (808) 248-7375.

 Accommodations
Blair's Original Hana Plantation Houses, can be reached at (800) 228-4262 or (808) 248-7868, fax (808) 922-6068. Rentals range from $70 to $160, double occupancy per night, $10 extra for each additional person.
Hana Alii Holiday, (800) 548-0478, fax (808) 248-8595, has rentals that range from $65 to $300, double occupancy; generally each additional person costs $10.
To reserve one of the 12 cabins at Waianapanapa State Park, contact the Department of Land and Natural Resources, Division of State Parks, 54 South High Street, Room 101, Wailuku, Maui, Hawaii 96793, (808) 984-8109. Cabins sleep six, with linen included, and cost $45 for one to four people, $50 for five, and $55 for six. A 50 percent deposit is required at the time of booking.
