Excursions From New York
 
 Q. I do not drive. Are there any short excursions to Newport, Tanglewood, Provincetown or Saratoga? -- Alice Strouse, New York, N.Y.
 
 A. There is a goodly selection. The bus tours in this sampling take two or three days, and some stop at more than one of the destinations you have in mind. Most leave from Manhattan.
 If you're bound for Saratoga, home of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, you might want to note when there's music and when there's dance. The New York City Ballet performs from July 9 to 27 and the Philadelphia Orchestra from July 31 to Aug. 17. In this alphabetical listing, rates are for double occupancy and include tickets and entry fees. 
 Biss Tours, 62-85 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park, N.Y. 11374, (718) 426-4000, runs excursions that offer one performance each at Saratoga and Tanglewood, the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The trips leave every Saturday from July 13 to Aug. 3 and on Aug. 17. Lodging: Quality Inn, Albany. Rate: $239, which includes two meals.
 You can visit Newport on a three-day tour called Nantucket, Newport and More, which includes Providence. It departs on two Fridays, July 12 and Aug. 16. Lodging: in July, at the Hampton Inn, Fall River; in August, the Biltmore Grand Heritage, Providence. Rate: $257, which includes two meals.
 Or you can opt for the three-day Martha's Vineyard and Newport tour, which includes Mystic Seaport. It departs on July 4, Aug. 2 and 31. Lodging: the Biltmore Grand Heritage, Providence. Rate: $249; one meal at a dinner theater.
 The 92d Street Y Center for Adult Life and Learning, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10128; (212) 415-5628, fax (212) 415-5578. The three-day Berkshires Art and Music tour, leaving on Aug. 23, takes in a play at the Williamstown Festival, the Clark Art Institute, the Williams College Museum of Art, a concert at Tanglewood and a tour of the estates of the writer Edith Wharton and the sculptor Daniel Chester French. Lodging: Williams Inn, Williamstown, Mass. Rate: $399.
 Another three-day excursion, which leaves July 19, covers Newport and Block Island. The itinerary includes the Touro Synagogue, two Newport mansions and a full day on Block Island. Lodging: Hotel Viking, Newport. Rate: $399.
 Parker Tours, 255 Executive Drive, Plainview, N.Y. 11803; (516) 349-0575 or (800) 833-9600, fax (516) 349-0574. Parker offers at least six two- or three-day excursions to the areas that you mentioned. The two-day Tanglewood-Williamstown tour, for example, visits the Mead Art Museum in Amherst and the Clark Institute and includes two performances. Lodging: Brattleboro (Vt.) Inn and Conference Center. Rate: $250; two meals.
The Tanglewood-Jacob's Pillow tour offers both music and dance performances and a visit to Arrowhead, the home of Herman Melville. Lodging: Ramada Inn, West Springfield. Rate: $255; two meals.
 The itinerary for a three-day excursion to Block Island and Newport includes two mansions and a tour of Block Island. Lodging: Days Inn, Providence. Rate: $320; five meals.
 
Swedish Jubilee
 
 Q. I will be in Stockholm for the 150th Swedish Immigration Jubilee. Could you provide directions to the cemetery where Queen Louise is buried? I have ancestors buried nearby and would like to visit. -- Edith O. Allen, Ridge Manor, Fla.
 
 A. To get to the cemetery, take Bus No. 515 from Odenplan, downtown, to Haga Norra, about an eight-minute ride; fare $2.25.
 The grounds of Haga Castle and Haga Park as well as the grave of Queen Louise are on the side of the road where you get off the bus. Across the road is the Northern Cemetery, one of the city's largest.
 While at the park you may wish to stop at the Butterfly House, (46) 8-730 39 81, fax (46) 8-83 48 18. Amid a 21,500-square-foot tropical forest (temperature about 81 degrees), 800 tropical butterflies fly about freely. Starting June 27, a display of the Monarch butterfly goes on view. Admission $8, children $3.20. Closed Monday.
 The jubilee you mention celebrates the twin themes of emigration from Sweden and immigration to Sweden.
 In Stockholm, an exhibition called "New Life, New Country," describes the experiences of emigrants and runs until July 28 at the Nordiska Museet, 6-16 Djurgadsvagen; telephone (46) 8-666 46 00. Admission $8, children $1.60. Closed Monday.
There are also many celebrations planned in the United States, including events in Bishop Hill, in western Illinois, where many early arrivals settled, and in Minnesota, where a very large concentration of emigrants from Sweden lives today.
In New York, at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum, much of the exhibition shown in Stockholm will be on display from Aug. 30 to Jan. 20 under the title "From One Life to Another." King Carl XVI Gustaf and Queen Silvia of Sweden are to visit Ellis Island on Sept. 10 for the exhibition's official opening. Information: (212) 363-8340.
 
To Quebec by Boat

 Q. We are thinking of traveling to Toronto in July. Do any boats travel from Toronto or a city near Quebec? -- Ben Yen, San Francisco
 
 A. While there are no cruises to Quebec starting in Toronto, there is a six-night, seven-day cruise along the St. Lawrence River originating in Kingston, where Lake Ontario flows in the St. Lawrence.
 The trip, aboard the 66-passenger Canadian Empress, is operated by St. Lawrence Cruise Lines, 253 Ontario Street, Kingston, Ontario K7L 2Z4; (800) 267-7868. Service for this season was scheduled to start last week and the last trip of 1996 to Quebec City is to depart Oct. 19.
 En route, the ship stops for visits to the Antique Boat Museum in Clayton, N.Y.; the Frederic Remington Museum in Ogdensburg, N.Y., and Fort Wellington in Prescott, Ontario.
 The fare, based on double occupancy, is $1,223 to $1,620 (in United States currency), with the rate depending on the location of the cabin and the season.
 To get from Toronto to Kingston, you can drive or take Via Rail. Departure times include 10 A.M. except Saturday and 11 A.M. and noon daily. Running time for the 158-mile trip is 2 hours to 2 hours and 20 minutes. Boarding the ship does not start till 5:30 P.M. The train fare is $71 for first class and $40 for economy, plus tax; if you travel any day but Friday and Sunday and book at least five days in advance, the fare is $24.40.
 Passengers interested in shorter trips from Kingston can take the cruise to Ottawa (five nights) or Montreal (four nights). PAUL FREIREICH

SECTION: Section 2; Page 23; Column 5; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 940 words

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Risking All On a Dream Of Renewal

BYLINE: By Bernard Holland 

 BODY:
AMERICAN ORCHESTRAS ARE FEELING justifiable anguish about the future, but some of them are doing intelligent soul-searching. The Pittsburgh Symphony has gone to its constituents, asked them what they need and offered its services. The St. Louis Symphony has answered the call for more arts education by buying its own school. The problems in Detroit are considerably worse, but this city's orchestra is attaching its fortunes to the Detroiter's dream: urban renewal.
Orchestra Hall, renovated and acoustically sound, reopened six years ago, but its lonely presence on the near-wasteland of Woodward Avenue has carried with it as much despair as joy. Hope comes now in the form of real estate; the performing-arts organization turns entrepreneur and developer and sees salvation in its business acumen. 
 The Detroit Symphony has quietly bought up eight acres of adjacent land in recent years and is going into partnership with the city school system and with one of the area's major employers. First, the orchestra will add to its own building. (Backstage facilities for musicians have been a form of camping out.) The public school system will build a performing-arts high school next door. And the Detroit Medical Center, which is affiliated with Wayne State University and operates seven hospitals, a nursing home and various outpatient centers around the city, will move its corporate headquarters into a new 175,000-square-foot office and retail building.
Symbiosis is the watchword for this triumvirate. Rooftop parking for employees will give way after dark to concert parking for patrons. A restaurant seating 250 is being talked about; galleries and music and book stores are part of the plan. The city is enthusiastic. So is the corporate community. The philosophy for Detroit's renewal goes like this: establish strong enclaves at various points downtown, and they will eventually reach out and join one another.
It is not the first time Detroit has tried to rescue itself from decay. The giant retail complex called the Renaissance Center, which was bought last week by General Motors, was to have revitalized the inner city, but it remains a kind of self-contained fortress, not easy to get to, more or less keeping the rougher neighborhoods around it at bay. Mark Volpe, the Detroit Symphony's executive director, says that Orchestra Place (as the new complex will be called) is designed to reach across adjacent streets and draw the city toward it. It's a nice thought and a big job.
The Detroit Symphony has had a rocky recent history: deficits, labor problems and hostility from lawmakers at municipal and state levels. Elected representatives of heavily black areas have asked what the orchestra does for their constituents and questioned the spending of public money for an organization they see as relevant only to a privileged, mostly white minority. Michigan "outstaters,"people living north and west of Detroit, have traditionally resented the large amounts of tax money poured into this troubled city. Governor John Engler, himself from "outstate," cut the orchestra's annual state grant from $5 million to $2 million. The city's contributions have gone from $800,000 a year to zero.
The Detroit Symphony's problems are familiar but unusually severe. The retreat of the middle and upper-middle classes to the suburbs and the reluctance of prosperous patrons to cross imaginary boundaries at the edge of the inner city at night have not reversed themselves. Musically, on the other hand, the orchestra is on sound footing, with a distinguished music director in Neeme Jarvi, attendance now at about 78 percent and activity in the recording studio.
Ford, General Motors and Chrysler -- along with the utility companies, law firms and parts suppliers who share their work -- drive this city. So the fortunes of the Detroit Symphony will forever fluctuate with those of the Big Three. The orchestra raises $8 million in operating expenses a year, $1 million coming directly from the auto manufacturers.
The school, to be built on 2.5 acres donated by the orchestra at a cost of $28 million, comes through a bond issue already approved by the city. The Detroit Symphony's share of the $80-million Orchestra Place project adds up to $52 million, with local banks most likely financing the $30 million office building. Twenty million dollars for the Orchestra Hall extension and $2 million more for added amenities will depend on philanthropy. Quiet commitments have already been made, Mr. Volpe says, but risks exist.
The symphony has been using recent surpluses to pay off an accumulated debt, and like most of its colleagues, it is involved in an endowment campaign. The bill for Orchestra Place will be added on. The endowment, now at $25 million, is aiming, Mr. Volpe says, at "the $40 or $50 million range."
The performing-arts school, four years old and operating in cramped quarters elsewhere, has a current enrollment of 500, which will grow to 800. Symphony musicians will come from next door to help with the teaching; so, too, visiting soloists. Construction on the office building is to start this summer. Hall expansion and the school come a year later, according to present plans.
Current wisdom says that inner-city revivals come less from business and industry than from arts and entertainment. Mr. Volpe points to Cleveland's Playhouse Square and its Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame, and then to Detroit's renovations of the Fox, Gem and State Theaters, the Music Hall and the Detroit Opera House. This is a city whose savage breast has need of soothing, so music, he hopes, will play on.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1475 words

HEADLINE: The First Freedoms

BYLINE: By Richard A. Epstein; Richard A. Epstein is the James Parker Hall Distinguished Service Professor of Law at the University of Chicago and the author, most recently, of "Simple Rules for a Complex World."

 BODY:

Freedom's Law
 The Moral Reading of the American Constitution.
 By Ronald Dworkin.
 404 pp. Cambridge, Mass:
 Harvard University Press. $35.
Ronald Dworkin, one of the most distinguished constitutional thinkers of our time, offers us a collection of his previously published essays that is both eloquently written and forcefully argued. It is, moreover, a set of essays whose substantive threads evoke mixed emotions in readers like me who admire his staunch defense of the traditional freedoms of speech and conscience but who question his endorsement of state regulation, often by default, on matters of property rights, economic and religious liberties. His selective invocation of "Freedom's Law" -- freedom of speech and conscience but not of contract and association -- illustrates one of the great unresolved tensions, and weaknesses, in modern constitutional doctrine. 
 Mr. Dworkin divides his essays into three broad groups. Part 1 addresses "Life, Death and Race" and chiefly defends the soundness of the legalization of abortion in Roe v. Wade. Part 2 is devoted to "Speech, Conscience and Sex" and offers an impassioned defense of broad reading of the First Amendment. Part 3, "Judges," reproduces his sustained if overwrought attacks on the Supreme Court nominations of Robert Bork and Clarence Thomas -- essays that stand in stark contrast to his affectionate closing remembrance of Judge Learned Hand, for whom he clerked just after law school.
Thematically, these essays are linked together by Mr. Dworkin's frontal assault on the "historical" or "originalist" view of interpretation, which purports to limit the scope of the great constitutional clauses to specific vices identified by the framers. For Mr. Dworkin, what the Constitution says, taken at the highest level of philosophical abstraction, must direct our interpretive efforts. The crabbed imaginations and hidden reservations of the draftsmen count for naught. So what if the authors of the equal protection clause debated its merits before segregated galleries: its underlying principle -- equal concern and respect for all citizens -- drives us inexorably toward the Court's 1954 banning of school segregation in Brown v. Board of Education. So what if states routinely enforced anti-sodomy laws in 1868, at the adoption of the 14th Amendment? Only rank prejudice keeps them in place today. No historical practice can block the inherent moral argument.
Mr. Dworkin's approach works best on pornography and academic freedom. He rightly stresses that freedom of speech is a high-risk enterprise. The Constitution offers no guarantees to the speaker whose most cogent argument falls on deaf ears. Nor does it comfort an audience bound to endure speech harshly offensive to its deepest beliefs. Starting from these premises, Mr. Dworkin effectively demolishes Catharine MacKinnon's ill-conceived and overbroad anti-pornography ordinance, and his fine essay, "Why Academic Freedom?" forcefully explains why private universities, even though not bound by the First Amendment, should reject the "hate speech" codes that could readily inhibit the free and open exchange that nourishes independent thought. His defense of a vibrant, open and tolerant society is one of which John Stuart Mill could be proud.
So far, so good. But Mr. Dworkin should have then marched on to explain fully how the First Amendment digs into the next level of knotty disputes: national security, government employees, public records, use of public streets, parks and facilities. His moral dictates rightly exclude certain irrelevant considerations from the constitutional calculus. But they do not tell us how to incorporate other relevant considerations -- public order, public places and public employment -- into the law. If you want guidance on what books a school board can remove from its libraries and why, you'll have to look elsewhere.
Mr. Dworkin is still less successful in using his libertarian theme to justify a woman's constitutional right to an abortion. The obvious objection to this position appeals to the countervailing interest of the fetus. Mr. Dworkin parries by introducing a contrived and counterintuitive distinction between "derivative" and "detached" condemnations of abortion. The derivative view -- which might better be called the "realist" position -- refers to the fetal interest "in staying alive and a right not to be killed." The detached view protects the fetus only "as an objective or intrinsic good, a value in itself, quite apart from its value to the person whose life it is or to anyone else."
Mr. Dworkin claims that abortion implicates only the weaker, detached interest. But why? Conception is at least as relevant a break point in the unfolding of human life as are consciousness and sensation. If people have, as Mr. Dworkin himself does, ethical qualms about abortion, isn't it because they embrace the "derivative" (or "realist") view? Today the law protects the fetus against attacks by third persons on just that view. Mr. Dworkin's constitutional case, therefore, depends on showing how the mother's interests trump those of the fetus -- a balance Mr. Dworkin never troubles to defend. Indeed, his penchant for philosophical generalization only accentuates the tension in allowing abortions in the teeth of a general prohibition against inflicting harm on others. Mr. Dworkin seeks to bolster his position by noting that the legislature cannot make the fetus into a constitutional person by stipulation, any more than it could a tree or a monkey. But monkey or tree does not become human: a fetus has that potential long before viability.
The chinks in Mr. Dworkin's philosophical armor are revealed by his limited topic menu. "Freedom's Law" does not address the palpable tension between the free exercise and the establishment of religion. To give both religion clauses grand readings risks placing them on a collision course. But giving them no reading at all undercuts Mr. Dworkin's claim to constitutional universality while leaving unaddressed the modern controversies over school prayer, religious displays on public property and public aid to education in religious schools. We need to hear more.
More strikingly, Mr. Dworkin dismisses the Constitution's takings and contracts clauses with the terse observation that conservative judges (he does not distinguish between majoritarian and libertarian) "will naturally interpret abstract constitutional principles in a conservative way, as they did in the early years of this century, when they wrongly supposed that certain rights over property and contract are fundamental to freedom." His ex cathedra pronouncement has no empirical backing. And his curt dismissal of property and contract rights blocks any interpretive answer on how he would sustain the now ascendant distinction between the preferred freedoms of speech and (perhaps) religion and the lesser freedoms of association and economic pursuit.
Why this selective acceptance of freedom? Why not seek the most general moral principle behind the Fifth Amendment, "nor shall private property be taken for public use, without just compensation"? Imagine how American law would look if the takings clause reached the common forms of land-use regulation (that is, large lot zoning), or precluded wealth redistribution by taxation. Stunned? But note that some elements of a Lockean defense of property are easily assembled. The framers defended property to reduce the power of the state and, following Madison, to control the dangers of faction. As the guardian of other rights, private property protects both free speech and religious association from government regulation and retaliation and thus advances the liberties that Mr. Dworkin rightly prizes.
Other omitted interpretive issues illustrate the same theme. What is the scope of Federal power under the commerce, bankruptcy or copyright clauses; sovereign immunity or Federal-state relations; Presidential power; or the amendment process? All these issues are getting hotter by the day. And all raise the question of whether and how separation of powers and federalism can help secure essential individual liberties.
Sensing difficulty, Mr. Dworkin tries to meet the charge that his philosophical method assures him of a set of "happy endings" by countering that his constitutional views require him to defend positions that he personally abhors. But to make good on the promise of "Freedom's Law" he would have had to venture forth from his favored bastions to explore the entire Constitution, including those key clauses whose broad sweep goes against his intellectual grain. By sticking so close to his emotional home, Mr. Dworkin illumines one corner of freedom's map, but only at the price of leaving large portions of its terrain unexplored.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 6; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1344 words

HEADLINE: Why Trust Went Out the Window

BYLINE: By Jim Sleeper; Jim Sleeper, the author of "The Closest of Strangers: Liberalism and the Politics of Race in New York," is at work on a new book about race.

 BODY:

IN DEFENSE OF GOVERNMENT
 The Fall and Rise of Public Trust.
 By Jacob Weisberg.
 209 pp. New York:
 Scribner. $22.
A lmost despite itself, Jacob Weisberg's engrossing "In Defense of Government" perpetuates a confusion that has bedeviled other recent attempts to defend the relatively strong public sector that Americans have had since the New Deal. "We need an activist government more than ever to heal the injuries of race and to reverse our growing stratification based on class," writes Mr. Weisberg, a political columnist for New York magazine and a contributing editor of The New Republic. And his preface defends this claim with an account of the Gautreaux program, a court-ordered fair-housing initiative that has successfully placed approximately 7,000 black inner-city Chicago residents in white suburbs. 
 "But if we aspire to use government for such ambitious purposes, we must first repair it," he adds. "The loss of public faith is a complex phenomenon, but it is based on realities. Until we overthrow those realities, we cannot hope to win back the public's trust. . . . Government has a problem of ends as well as means. A fundamental reconsideration is now called for." Liberalism, he writes later, "must recognize that 'social progress,' however noble an idea, is not, and cannot be, the primary function of government."
Well, which is it? Should we "repair" government and reform its means in order to continue its pursuit of "ambitious purposes," as Mr. Weisberg seems at first to suggest? Or should we redefine its very ends in order to "overthrow" the "realities" -- which Mr. Weisberg portrays vividly -- of government's failures to ameliorate racial and class divisions? "It is my contention that while the conservative critique of government is incoherent and at times transparently dishonest, most of the replies liberals have offered are insufficient," Mr. Weisberg writes, promising "to lay out an alternative approach" in the final chapter. While his accounts of conservative hypocrisies and liberal failures are acute, nuanced and sometimes revelatory, his alternative approach comes down to prescriptions for repair and a call to revive "nationalist fellow feeling" through carefully delimited, if energetic, public initiatives.
The early-20th-century Progressive prophet Herbert Croly rides again in this book, as he already has in John B. Judis's "Grand Illusion," Michael Lind's "Next American Nation" and E. J. Dionne Jr.'s "They Only Look Dead." Mr. Weisberg clips Croly's statist, centralist wings more than Mr. Judis and Mr. Lind do: he counsels government to accept rather than try to forestall many of the risks and inequalities that are inevitable in a free society. But like his recent predecessors, Mr. Weisberg means to vindicate an "affirmative government" that does more than provide basic public services and outlaw racial discrimination.
The devil is in the details, however, and Mr. Weisberg's portrait of the Gautreaux litigation against Chicago's shamefully segregated public housing exemplifies his, and our, problem. His father, to whose memory his book is dedicated, was one of the attorneys who prosecuted the suit, he explains, and the author's interviews with its beneficiaries are the book's only direct accounts of ordinary Americans whose faith in government, or lack of it, he wants to address. Mr. Weisberg acknowledges that the Gautreaux program worked only because its champions' ambitious intent to build scatter-site housing projects in white neighborhoods was stymied by massive opposition. That forced the program's implementers to place individual black families quietly in existing housing in white areas, using so few vouchers that only the most disciplined, almost entrepreneurial applicants managed to obtain them. By Mr. Weisberg's own account, these admirable single mothers found decent white landlords and neighbors thanks to a program that had become highly selective, unobtrusive almost unto secrecy and hence impossible to replicate on a large scale.
If there is a lesson here for affirmative government, I'm not sure what it is, and Mr. Weisberg barely returns to Gautreaux in the rest of his book. Americans' loss of faith in court-ordered, bureaucratically driven government is a "complex phenomenon" indeed. Absent fresh public reckonings with race, class and the delicate balance of rights with responsibilities -- reckonings that turn-of-the-century Progressives often fudged and that modern liberals have bungled -- the nation is far from a politically viable alternative to conservatives' outright avoidance of these great challenges.
It is when Mr. Weisberg recounts all this bungling and avoidance that his book is most convincing. His anatomy of the Republicans' and the Democrats' factionalism, their campaign financing and their manipulations of race and class demonstrates that the two-party system doesn't give us the new approaches we need. In one brilliant chapter, Mr. Weisberg foresees a Republican "crack-up" stemming from the irreconcilable if often disguised conflict between the party's libertarian free-marketeers, like the House majority leader, Dick Armey, who seek a minimalist state, and what Mr. Weisberg calls its "authoritarian" conservatives, like William Bennett and Pat Buchanan, who champion government's role as a guarantor of moral and civic order. Meanwhile, Mr. Weisberg ridicules "pseudolibertarians," like Newt Gingrich and Bob Dole, who try to paper over the conflict; he likens such Gingrichian flourishes as the Contract With America to the posturing of a "circus weightlifter hefting a plaster barbell" and the exertions of a "crazed used-car salesman."
Mr. Weisberg is equally scathing about "reactionary liberal" Democrats like Mario Cuomo, "economic populists" like Representative Barney Frank and "economic nationalists" like Ruy Teixeira of the Economic Policy Institute, accusing them of demagoguery and an "obsessive" advocacy of economic redistribution. In his view, "paleoliberals" talk the talk of organizing grass-roots movements but resort to courts and bureaucracies to dodge the hard public choices inherent in reforming welfare programs and racial remedies.
By casting as elitists and racists the responsible critics in the Democratic Leadership Council who seek to balance government entitlements with individual responsibilities, the traditional liberals, in Mr. Weisberg's account, have squandered their chance to win broad support for universal public health care, initiatives in education and effective government action against stark discrimination and exploitation. Mr. Weisberg portrays President Clinton's synthesis of these contradictions in his New Covenant as little more than a campaign strategy as disingenuous as Mr. Gingrich's Contract With America.
Mr. Weisberg would curb the liberals' redistributive, protectionist and racialist initiatives in order to restore credibility to limited public interventions against both chronic unemployment and corporate welfare. Liberals, he writes, should abjure governmentalism by accepting the realities of risk, by "underpromising," by killing discredited programs, by curbing bureaucratic extrapolations of vague Congressional mandates and by putting a ceiling on government's claims on the Gross Domestic Product. The best guide to the recovery of national purpose, Mr. Weisberg says, is Croly, but he is unclear about how we might follow him: "Whether a third party is the appropriate vehicle for New Progressives is a matter beyond this book's scope," as is discussion of some other national movement.
New political leadership that convinces most Americans that government is sometimes needed to liberate individuals from exploitive private interests won't come from Mr. Weisberg's own cohort of New Progressive writers but, if at all, from a Theodore Roosevelt, as it did in Croly's time. Such a leader would have to cut through the unresolved contradictions in Mr. Weisberg's book, but he or she would profit by studying it.

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Connie Hogarth;
22 Years as a Champion of Political Causes

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
VIETNAM, Indian Point, disarmament, South Africa, South America -- the list of causes that Connie Hogarth has fought for and been arrested for seems almost endless.
For 22 years, Ms. Hogarth, a resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, has headed the Westchester People's Action Coalition, known as Wespac, a White Plains-based, grass-roots organization, which she helped to found. She has marched on too many picket lines to count and has been arrested about 20 times, both close to home and in Washington. Now, at the age of 69, she has announced her retirement as Wespac's executive director, effective sometime over the next few weeks. But Ms. Hogarth says her days as a political activist are not over. 
 Wespac will hold its annual Music Festival and Picnic on June 29 at Lamont Home, 116 Hawkes Avenue in Ossining. The number at Wespac to call for more information about the event is 682-0488.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Ms. Hogarth:
Q. Your father was a union activist. Tell me about your earliest memories of that.
A. My father, Stanley Holubar, was a motion picture projectionist, but his real love was music -- he played the organ and the piano in the silent movies. When he became involved with projectionism, there was a very strong union and he was very active in it. There were a lot of strikes in the 1930's, which is why the union was effective. Whenever there was a strike or a picket, I would walk the picket line around the theater with them. We had a lot of conversation at dinner about unions and union officials and strikes and the struggles. It was kind of a constant. And I guess at that early age it gives one a sense of your place in the world that goes beyond the family.
Q. Sometimes the reverse happens: a child who is exposed to liberalism goes on to rebel and become a conservative and vice versa.
A. Yes, that's true, but it was there; it wasn't forced on me. It was just something that was so much a part of the milieu. One other thing is my mother, Rose, who is still alive; she was no wallflower either. She was really an early feminist. Throughout my young school years, she was always involved in things and as a personality made her presence and opinions felt.
Q. Looking back on your years of activism, do you think the world is a better place today? Or have we just found new controversies to substitute for old ones?
A. I think it's one set of controversies that are replaced by another. That's never ending, especially when you are striving toward democratic goals. You know, there is one bumper sticker that I love that is on my car: "If the people will lead, the leaders will follow" -- which is to say that certainly in any democratic tradition you can't take anything for granted. If ever that were true we see it now, with the total abuse and absolutely out-of-control campaign financing and how that has affected who our leaders are. I'm hoping Wespac will get more into that issue than it has been.
Q. Is it harder to get people involved in the way, say, people got involved during the Vietnam War? Some of the issues you're concerned with may not strike people as being close-to-home problems.
A. Again, an old saw: think globally and act locally. That has really been a key part of Wespac's strength, I think. What we've been able to do is to create a link between some of the domestic struggles on social issues and our understanding of corporate power and military power. We did that on Central America, on the Middle East and now on Cuba, and it has developed tremendous new understandings, especially for young people. Of course, in the environmental area there is no such thing as a boundary between nations or states, and the oceans don't make a difference when you have something like Chernobyl happening. We think globally about Chernobyl and act locally about Indian Point.
Q. Looking back, is it one of your biggest disappointments that you have not permanently closed Indian Point?
A. It's really not a disappointment because the struggle there is so ongoing. I know we've made a huge dent. There is now a great awareness about the dangers of Indian Point in the metropolitan area. There is also a resurgence of interest locally in shutting it down. And it's becoming more and more clear that economically it's not beneficial to keep the plant operating. It's too bad that health and safety, which should be primary concerns, sometimes aren't as important as whether it's saving us money.
Q. Do you see this as Wespac's key cause?
A. Definitely not. There is really no key cause. There are a number of concerns that move back and forth on the front burner constantly, which is why the spectrum of work is so incredibly broad. For 8 or 10 years our primary concern was South Africa. If you want to talk about successes, as far as I'm concerned for the world we've seen a miracle -- the miracle of South African freedom. When we first started to get into that struggle, it didn't look very hopeful.
Q. What was Wespac's role?
A. A powerful role. As a grass-roots organization, we played an important role in all the protests, civil disobedience actions, at the Consulate, at Citicorp. And with the help of two County Legislators, Ernie Davis, who is now the Mayor of Mount Vernon, and Herman Keith, after a couple of years of pushing and pushing and educating, I would say that Wespac was responsible for the county voting not to put money in banks that did business with South Africa. That was a very enormous victory.
Q. So you took a case that was at first viewed as radical and stuck with it until it became mainstream?
A. Yes, but there are a lot of other causes like that. The gay and lesbian movement in Westchester was really launched at Wespac, and now it's a big operation. That's also true for the Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion. They had a desk at Wespac until they grew and the movement, again, is today mainstream. Today we have a Haitian-support group using Wespac and growing.
You asked about major thrusts: for a long period of time, it was Central America and the work we were doing on issues of self-determination in Nicaragua and El Salvador -- fighting the funding for the contras. Then there was the Gulf War that became a major issue. I was also very much involved with the Jesse Jackson campaign and was on the national board of the Rainbow Coalition. I have to say that one of my biggest disappointments was not that Indian Point was not closed but that the Rainbow Coalition, in the context of how it was growing, was not maintained. The potential for change was so enormous, and if ever we need it we need it now. That was one of the saddest things in my life. We had it, and we dropped the ball -- partly because of Jesse, I have to admit.
Q. You've been arrested a lot of times. How do you define when civil disobedience should be used?
A. I think civil disobedience can be abused. You just don't go out and lie down on the street at any time. It has to be the activist's role of last resort. It's when all else fails. When you have leafletted your life out, when you've lobbied your life out, when you've protested with marches and rallies and you have not had movement forward. At that point, you make an attempt to have an impact on people who can understand that the commitment is so powerful and the need is so great. As Martin Luther King established very clearly, this can be a very effective tool for social change.
Q. Any particular cause you were arrested for?
A. The first one was during the Vietnam War. We represented 100 Vietnamese a day who were dying, and we lay down in front of the White House. I was with the New York group on that one. Then there was the B-1 bomber and there were only six of us and we blocked the White House driveway and had to be carried off. Then there was Seabrook, the New Hampshire nuclear Power plant. Then it was Shoreham. And that was another big victory. Then, of course, Indian Point. And South Africa and Central America.
Q. Now what will you do with yourself?
A. Clearly one doesn't change one's total direction. I'm not going to not be politically involved. I may be a little more involved in some of the electoral aspects, in alterative politics. I also want to do some writing, perhaps children's books, and my interest in music is very profound. There is a great deal out there I want to do politically and in the arts.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Connie Hogarth, retiring as executive director of Westchester People's Action Coalition. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 2534 words

HEADLINE: Out East, Fierce Rivalry On Radio Dial

BYLINE: By MERYL SPIEGEL 

 BODY:
AS a college student in the late 1950's, Joseph J. Sullivan Jr. spent his summers on eastern Long Island driving a bakery truck and dreaming about starting the first radio station to cover the two forks.
In those days the only stations reaching the East End were in Connecticut, he said. There was WRIV-AM in Riverhead, but its signal was so weak that it did not reach his summer rental house 15 miles away on the North Fork. 
 "My landlady complained that she knew more about the people running for office in Connecticut" than in her area, Mr. Sullivan recalled in an interview.
Almost 40 years later Mr. Sullivan has created the first double station in the area, broadcasting on two frequencies from the same site, WLIE-FM, at 102.5, a country-music station, and WBAZ, 101.7, with a lightcontemporary music format.
WLIE, which went on the air in March, licensed in Bridgehampton, is the ninth FMstation on the East End, according to Mr. Sullivan. The number of stations reflects the tremendous interest in radio for an area of the Island that is still rather meagerly populated, except in the summer.
Broadcasting syndicates and wealthy second-home owners have identified the East End as a place to invest, particularly since Federal laws on radio ownership in one area have progressively become deregulated and the Federal Communications Commission, following a national trend, has released a number of new radio frequencies in the area in recent years.
Most local broadcasters agree that the market is quite lucrative during the summer season, when national advertisers place substantial ads on the air, but many question whether the year-round population can support more than the five stations that have survived up through the 1980's.
Many investors are "dreaming of gold that flows in the Hamptons," said Zoe Kamitses, general manager of WBEA-FM in Amagansett. But, she maintained, they "do not understand the seasonal nature of the business."
Robert Sargent Shriver 3d, a son of Eunice Kennedy Shriver and R. Sargent Shriver, and Derrick Sephas, a lawyer in Manhattan and a former state banking superintendent, started WBEA in 1993.
Business people are creating stations and buying existing operations because "radio is a hot investment," Ms. Kamitses said. "As long as you are breaking even, your equity is increasing."
According to the Long Island Regional Planning Board, the East End's year-round population is growing slowly, mostly on the South Fork. In 1995, there were 108,800 residents -- just 2 percent more than in 1990. During the summer months, however, the number almost triples. And by the year 2000, planners expect the five-year growth rate to increase to 7.3 percent, when there would be 116,800 year-rounders.
Until 1992, one company could not own more than one FM and one AM station in a particular area. But those limits, enforced by the F.C.C., have progressively loosened in the 90's. In February, President Clinton signed the Telecommunications Act of 1996 allowing one broadcaster to own as many as eight stations in a single market.
While industry experts say investors are responding to the loosening of federal regulations on group ownership, local broadcasters are wary of the new stations' longevity.
Paul Fleishman, general manager of four Long Island stations, including WHFM-FM, 95.3, in Southampton, an affiliate of WBAB-FM, 102.3 in Babylon, called the market in the summertime "very lucrative," but felt the area could "probably support only two or three stations very well." Each area has a finite amount of business, he said, and each time a new station goes on the air "the pie is carved up into smaller pieces."
The household density on the East End is far too small to support the number of radio properties there, agreed Tom Reilly, president of Long Island Multimedia, the owner of WLUX-AM at 540, a new "pop standard" station broadcast from Farmingdale.
Investors from other industries have a "romantic connection" with radio and see it as a chance to become associated with the entertainment business, Mr. Reilly added. It gives them a "certain panache" and a new level of credibility that works to their benefit in the Hamptons, he asserted.
"It's a frequency rush like the gold rush in the late 1800s," said Frank Sundram, the new general manager of WPBX 88.3, the public radio station transmitted from Southampton College. Two years ago, the 14-year-old station boosted its power from 1,000 to 25,000 watts.
Even the public radio arena is becoming more competitive. Last summer, WSHU, a classical music station transmitted from Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn., began simulcasting its signal from the WLNG tower in Noyack in addition to locations in Selden and Dix Hills.
As the area grows, investors are hoping they can "hang on till the population catches up," Mr. Sundram added. What costs them $1 million to start a new station now, he explained, would cost $10 million when the market becomes viable.
Many local broadcasters complain that group ownership is homogenizing radio in the area and diminishing original, local programming.
Mr. Sullivan, of Peconic Bay, stressed that although nine stations cover the area, five are truly local, devoted to local news, weather, traffic and public affairs. Those include his two, WBAZ and WLIE, plus WLNG, WEHM and WBEA.
The other four have agreements with larger stations to pipe in programming from outside the area.
Several years ago, Hampton Bays' WWHB began simulcasting WNEW's rock music programming from Manhattan after it was purchased by South Fork Broadcasting, a company headed by Eddie Simon, the brother of Paul Simon.
Last fall, SFX Broadcasting, based in Manhattan, signed a contract to acquire Liberty Broadcasting, owner of 19 radio stations, including the four managed by Mr. Fleishman on Long Island -- WBAB/WHFM, WBLI in Medford, and WGBB in Freeport. Robert F.X. Sillerman is the executive chairman of the broadcasting company and the chancellor of Long Island University's Southampton College. The deal is pending F.C.C. approval and financial closure, Mr. Fleishman said.
As restrictions have eased, the F.C.C. has made available hundreds of new frequencies but it does not understanding the economic consequences, said Barry Umansky, deputy general counsel of the National Association of Broadcasters.
In 1992 the F.C.C. opened four new frequencies for the East End. It was "one of the more egregious examples" of adding stations without considering whether the area could sustain the additional stations, Mr. Umansky added.
Two of the channels have blossomed into stations, including WLIE and WLIR, 98.5, which came on the air in 1993. WLIR is an affiliate of WDRE-FM, 92.7 in Garden City, owned by Jarad Broadcasting of Garden City. It basically broadcasts the same rock format as its parent.
The other two frequencies, in Southampton and Calverton, have not been assigned. Eight companies, including out-of-town syndicates, are competing for those, according to James Crutchfield of the F.C.C.
One group, Women's Broadcaster's Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., is trying to extend a construction permit for another station, which was opened in Montauk before the new frequencies became available.
Local broadcasters say that because the Arbitron Company, which measures audience ratings, monitors a small number of year-round East End listeners, their statistics are not reliable for the area. Arbitron surveys include just 80 to 90 diaries from East Enders, according to Mr. Sullivan.
Shelly Cagner of Arbitron could not estimate how many East End listeners are represented in their quarterly surveys. The service's Suffolk East region is comprised of 160 diaries, she said, but its boundary extends west of Riverhead. East End stations are rated against all other stations on Long Island; the service does not provide separate ratings for the area.
The economic viability of an East End radio station is not a function of ratings, because most of them "don't even show up in Arbitron," explained Mr. Fleishman of WBAB/WHFM. And since there are only four summer months "to make money," he said, "it all depends on how well they can market their product and sell advertising."
Paul Conroy, general manager of WEHM-FM, 96.7, an adult rock station that started with celebrity fanfare in 1993, estimated that the market was valued at $2.5 to $3 million in revenue from local and national advertisers.
He added that WLNG-AM, 1600 kHz, and FM, which have a mix of top 40 hits, oldies and 24-hour live local broadcasts, probably generates the most sales in the region.
The general manager, Paul Sidney, agreed that banks regarded WLNG as the most successful station on the East End. Mr. Sidney, as well as other local broadcasters, would not release sales figures.
Known as a "vanity station," WEHM generated intense attention in 1993 when it began broadcasting from a storefront studio on Montauk Highway in East Hampton, where disk jockeys are visible to motorists who drive by. In the summer of 1993 Billy Joel visited the station to promote his "River of Dreams" album.
When the station was financed by several high profile figures, "people thought the gravy train was going to run through East Hampton with everyone's name on it," Mr. Conroy said.
The owner is the East Hampton Broadcasting Group, whose principals are Michael P. Schulhof, former president of the Sony Corporation of America, and Leonard Ackerman, a real-estate lawyer who represents well-known second-home owners and has owned stations in major markets, according to Mr. Conroy. Other investors include Mr. Joel and Christie Brinkley, he added.
Before going on the air, the owners hired two "high-priced consultants who were well respected from a programming perspective," Mr. Conroy said, but their expectations of the Hamptons marketplace were unrealistic.
"We came on very aggressively," he said. At first the station hired well-known news figures like Liz Smith and Pia Lindstrom. In the first year, the morning program featured Gary Lee Wright, the highest paid on-air personality on the East End, according to Mr. Conroy.
But, after about nine months, when "the dust settled," the management gained a "grasp on reality," and "people got off at stops along the way," he added.
They started to realize that the station broadcasts 12 months a year for the resident population and that for "13 weeks we become the playground for well-to-do homeowners," Mr. Conroy said.
WEHM has since cut back considerably. The station bought out Mr. Wright's contract; reduced the staff,from 32 to 8, and eliminated the news department.
The station initially had live local news 18 times a day. Now one of two disk jockeys writes and reads the local news at the top of the hour from 6 A.M. to 6 P.M.
WEHM has also changed, from "light adult contemporary," to "adult album alternative." After conducting a survey, Mr. Conroy said, "we found out that people didn't want generic radio."
Although the programmers continue to highlight current hits, they often go back to the late 60's, and they never play two current hits in a row.
Last year WEHM turned a profit for the first time, Mr. Conroy said, adding that the station earns 40 percent of its annual revenue from national advertisers who seek the summer crowds.
Although the station contracted, he said, "we've found our niche in the market."
"We've identified our listener and programmed the station to that listener," Mr. Conroy said, adding that the target market was local professionals from 25 to 44, with mortgages and children in local schools.
Down the road in Amagansett, Ms. Kamitses said WBEA went into the black last year, at the end of its third year on the air.
"We didn't start off with a grand scheme," Ms. Kamitses said. "We've been working close to bone from the beginning." She said she built the station on her own without interference from the two absentee owners.
Like WEHM, the station carries its year-round operations with summer sales to national advertisers. About half of its revenue comes from companies that sell products like beverages, movies and cosmetics to beachgoers.
The station has carved out a niche by developing "a marketing concept tailored to the beach," Mr. Kamitses said. And because "more and more of Manhattan is moving out here five days a week," WBEA has created a "Hamptons sound" that integrates local and city tastes of adults aged 25 to 49.
The "hot adult contemporary format" includes hits from the 80's and 90's, as well as "alternative" selections.
WBEA pays close attention to the local mood, she said, adding that it is not a vanity station, and "not a cookie-cutter station from outer space."
The station, Ms. Kamitses said, develops talent from within. "We are the Montessorri School of Broadcasting," she added.
The industry has experienced a complete turnaround, added Ms. Kamitses, a longtime radio professional on the East End. "In the old days," she said, "you wanted to sound like the big guy. Now local is it. You want to make sure you know where you are."
Running a double station is a cost-effective way to create a local radio network. With an investment of $200,000 for equipment that includes a link to two antenna towers, one in Noyack and one in Southampton, Peconic Bay can broadcast two stations from its headquarters, according to the station manager, Lauren Grant. Ms. Grant added that the company was planning to build a studio in Bridgehampton for producing public affairs programs for South Fork residents.
Both stations subscribe to Westwood One, a national programming service based in Los Angeles, and aim for the 25-to-64 group. But their music differs. WBAZ features a "light adult contemporary" format, and WLIE plays strictly country.
Mr. Sullivan said he had considered creating an all-news or oldies station, but chose country because it was the most popular format nationally.
Mr. Sullivan added that most of WBAZ's advertisers had responded well to a new sales effort to buy spots on two stations and double the coverage for less than 50 percent more in charges.
Peconic Bay, Mr. Sullivan's company, and East Hampton Broadcasting are vying for a new frequency in Southampton, 92.9 MHz, along with Connecticut Public Broadcasting, and Sabbath Inc., a religious network from Indianapolis.
If Mr. Sullivan obtains the license, he said, he plans to expand, perhaps with a classical station.
If East Hampton Broadcasting obtains the channel, Mr. Conroy said, it would most likely operate a duopoly similar to Peconic Bay's.
The managements of WEHM and WBEA said WLIE had not affected their listenerships or revenues. Because its programming arrives by satellite and the music has "no local feel," Mr. Conroy said, he is not concerned. In fact, he said, "it will get people talking about radio on the South Fork."
"I'm surprised it went country," Mr. Conroy added. "Just because it is the hottest format nationwide, it doesn't mean it is going to catch on out here, because the East End is unlike any other market in the country."

LENGTH: 561 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Mundy Scheme' In Croton Falls

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: CROTON FALLS

 BODY:
LEE POPE is crazy for Brian Friel. How else to explain the unearthing of "The Mundy Scheme," a trifle by the Irish playwright, which ran on Broadway in 1969 for 13 previews and 4 performances.
As owner-producer-curator of the Schoolhouse, an art gallery and an arts center here, Ms. Pope presented Mr. Friel's "Faith Healer" -- another Broadway failure -- in a production by the company Wordplay II in 1994. As a theatergoer, Ms. Pope is a devotee of Mr. Friel's honored plays: "Philadelphia, Here I Come," "Dancing at Lughnasa" and the recent "Molly Sweeney." 
 And as a tireless searcher for unsung plays in unexpected places, Ms. Pope recently found a used copy of "The Mundy Scheme" in an old book shop on Martha's Vineyard.
Herself a find in theater, Ms. Pope operates on pure instinct with an emphasis on pure and a disregard for practicality. She adores Mr. Friel, she said, because of his singular gift for language. And remember that last year, Ms. Pope presented John Steinbeck's "Burning Bright," which is about as obscure as a play by a great writer gets.
"Mundy Scheme" purports to be a political satire though economic is more apt than political and satire is here reduced to the level of a one-joke sketch.
Mr. Friel was not writing about the war in Ireland. His political aspect concerns the use of politics as pejorative, synonymous with guile, deceit and treachery. And the cast of characters consists of the Prime Minister and his scheming aides as well as his daft mother, whom he constantly berates.
Even though it could mean resuscitating the Irish economy, which has been in the pits for 700 years and is being written off as irreparable, the Prime Minister rejects intervention by the United States Defense Department.
Impoverished neutrality is preferable.
Then comes the Mundy Scheme, thought up by a real estate tycoon. It involves the leasing of remote unused land -- thousands of acres -- to be used as graveyards. Bodies will be flown from overcrowded cities the world over to be buried in Ireland, hence forth to be heralded as "The Eternal Resting Place" -- and a new world power.
So goes the scheme. The merchandising spinoffs -- air excursions to include two planeloads a week guaranteed, crematoria supplies -- are endless. So is the in-fighting among the cabinet members with their self-serving deals and manipulations.
No surprise. Mr. Friel was never at a loss for devilish word play -- the Minister of Finance talks of being "on the threshold of a great new abyss" -- but the pros, the cons and the convolutions of the Mundy Scheme, incessantly reiterated, barely sustain the first of two acts.
In a variable cast of 10, Steve Parris is a convincingly duplicitous Minister for External Affairs, and Dan Fitzgerald is an enjoyable mischievous Minister for Finance.
The lively staging is by Johnny Duncan, and therein hangs another tale. It is about how Ms. Pope transported Mr. Duncan from Vancouver, British Columbia, where she happened upon a theater he manages.
"Mundy Scheme" or no, Ms. Pope should not be deterred from scavenging bookstores and discovering directors wherever she goes.
"The Mundy Scheme" by Brian Friel at the Schoolhouse, 1 Owens Road in Croton Falls. Remaining performances today and next Sunday at 4 P.M. and Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. Box office: 277-8477.

HEADLINE: Belated Remembrance of the Forgotten War in Korea

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

 BODY:
IT has been called the forgotten war. Sandwiched between World War II and the Vietnam War, the conflict in Korea was relatively brief and the fighting fierce. Nearly as many Americans (54,259) died in the three years of fighting in Korea as in nine years of the Vietnam War (58,002), but Korean veterans have remained a comparatively silent and unrecognized group.
"It wasn't even called a war; it was called a police action," said Richard M. Hadad of Somers, who served in the 32d infantry and was stationed on Heartbreak Ridge in North Korea. "In addition to the dead, we had about 8,000 prisoners of war taken and about 3,000 who died in captivity. This was a major conflict. It was an infantry war, and it was fought mostly on the ground. It was a brutal war." 
 Until now, the county, which has monuments to honor veterans from World War I, World War II and the Vietnam War, had no memorial to honor those who fought in the conflict in Korea, which lasted from 1950 through 1953. But next month, ground will be broken in Lasdon Park in Somers -- also the site of the Vietnam memorial -- for a Korean War Memorial, which some veterans say is long overdue.
"The memorial is a commemoration of what we have gone through and done," said Seymour Lehman, president of the Westchester Korean War Veterans Association and a Yonkers resident. "If we don't have a memorial put up, no one will remember us, not only as individuals, but as a group, and what we have done."
The Westchester Korean War Veterans Association was formed only last year, though it is now one of the fastest-growing veteran's associations in the state. At the first meeting, 25 men showed up; there are now 157 members.
The fact that the county monument to Korean War veterans, who fought more than 40 years ago, is being built nearly 10 years after the memorial to the more recently fought Vietnam War is testament to the belated recognition that Korean veterans have received, some say.
The memorials in Westchester followed the pattern of those put up in Washington. The national Vietnam Memorial Wall -- a stark and powerful structure with names etched into black granite -- was dedicated in 1982. The national Korean War Memorial, which sits across the reflecting pool near the Lincoln Memorial, was not dedicated until last summer.
In fact, it was during the process of building the county's Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Somers in 1987 that the question of honoring Westchester's veterans of the Korean conflict arose.
"During the process of assembling the Vietnam memorial, I was often confronted with the question, 'Why Vietnam before Korea?' " said Richard W. Dwyer, chairman of the Westchester Veterans Memorial Committee. "I really didn't have an answer. So even during construction, we knew that the next step would be a Korean memorial." Mr. Dwyer said the Vietnam veterans in the county have been very supportive of the new project. The Lasdon Park site will be shared by both memorials, though the Korean memorial site is on an upward slope and will not be within sight of the Vietnam memorial.
The Korean War Veterans Memorial in Lasdon Park, designed by Mr. Dwyer, includes two bronze statues of soldiers on guard at a sandbag wall. It is meant to replicate a Korean War landing zone. Also included in the sculpture is a Korean war-era helicopter, which will be mounted above the rest of the memorial, as if it were carrying wounded American soldiers. A 48-star American flag will wave over the center of the site, from a pole surrounded at its base by plaques bearing the names of the 105 Westchester residents who lost their lives in the Korean fighting.
The monument is expected to cost about $300,000. Mr. Dwyer said his committee has raised more than $25,000 so far. They have received key donations from the Lasdon Foundation, a private family foundation based in Somers, as well as from the Korean Good Neighbor Society, a group of 25 Korean families from Rockland County who Mr. Dyer said wanted to show their gratitude for America's intervention. The committee plans to hold fund-raising events and solicit individual and corporate donations.
Over the last decade historians have debated the question of how to record the Korean War in American history. Controversy exists over whether to label the conflict a victory or a defeat, a brave stand against Communism or a costly stalemate. The delay in constructing a national Korean monument -- it took nearly 15 years for a design to be approved -- reflected the debate over how to commemorate the war. The original design called for 38 soldiers to march up a hill toward the American flag, with the postures and expressions of the soldiers reflecting the course of the war: early defeats, later victories and the final deadlock.
But veterans balked and called for a more patriotic memorial, honoring duty and service. The final design includes soldiers who are larger than life as well as a wall with engravings, and at the top of the incline, the number of the war's casualties, and the words, "Freedom Is Not Free."
No similar debate went on with respect to the Westchester memorial's design, and veterans expressed no ambivalence about the purpose of their service and the importance of their mission. "We did not win, but we did push the Communists back into the north," Mr. Hadad said. "The Communists had taken over the entire peninsula, and our job was to push them back where they came from. We did that, so essentially the fighting and the war was successful. We maintained the freedom of the South Korean people, and they're a thriving economy today."
Mr. Lehman concurs. "Not only did we stop the enemy, but if they had succeeded they would have taken over Japan, Australia and more. Our way of life today is like it is because we stopped them. We were there, and if we didn't stop them, nobody would have."
Mr. Dwyer said that the purpose of the memorial is not to make a judgment on the war but to honor those who served. "It is the desire of the committee not only to recognize the sacrifices of fallen and surviving comrades but to educate the American public of the terrible cost of warfare," he said. "We are not constructing monuments to warfare but the memory of those who served, and the principles for which they died must always be preserved and honored."
Mr. Hadad said it was grossly unfair to judge soldiers for flawed military plans. He said that Vietnam veterans were treated particularly harshly. His son served in the Navy in Vietnam, and together father and son traveled to Washington to visit both the Korean and Vietnam memorials. Now, he and his son will have a memorial they can visit in their own county.
"After 45 years, we're finally getting a memorial to honor us and to honor the dead," Mr. Hadad said. "Everyone sort of forgot about us, and now we're finally being recognized. I'm 66 years old, and I'm happy to be alive. I'm thankful for this country and for what I have. Sometimes I just feel, Why was I spared when so many others over there with me did not make it? I will never forget them, and that's why I support this memorial."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Proposed Korean War Veterans Memorial in Lasdon Park would consist of two bronze statues of soldiers behind a sandbag wall, an American flag and a helicopter of the period. (Jerry Roach)

HEADLINE: What's Ahead For the Class of '96?

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, when Alison Slavin first passed under the imposing clock tower at New Rochelle High School here, she felt like most of the other freshman entering that fall -- awkward and overwhelmed. Today, the gargoyles on the clock tower are like old friends to the 17-year-old class valedictorian, but the picture gallery of distinguished alumni inside the school building still sends a chill down her spine.
Even for a class with six acceptances to Harvard University -- Alison is among them -- alumni like the following might seem like a hard act to follow: Dr. Henry J. Heimlich, class of '37, who developed the lifesaving Heimlich maneuver; Don Hewitt, class of '40, executive producer of CBS-TV's "60 Minutes"; Louis R. Rukeyser, class of '50, television journalist and economist; H. Jesse Arnelle, class of '51, lawyer and football athlete, and Alan Menken, class of '67, composer and lyricist, to name only some. 
 How will the members of the class of '96 distinguish themselves? It is a subject very much on Alison's mind these days as she prepares the valedictory charge to her fellow students. Most of the 575 graduates will go on to become the college class of '00 at the start of another millennium -- a new beginning that brings with it many responsibilities, she said.
Alison is a tall girl, the captain of the soccer team, with a quiet earnestness about her -- especially when she talks about the social issues that concern her and her friends. Like some of the other students, she presses hard for more AIDS awareness.
"In part, it is because my uncle died of the disease," Alison explained, adding that she is also worried about some of her friends who do not take the threat of AIDS seriously. Like her friends, the valedictorian is proud of the racial diversity of the student body, which is 47 percent white, 32 percent black and 17 percent Hispanic -- what she calls "a real sample of the world out there."
The ceiling of the front entryway to the school is lined with 65 flags representing the national backgrounds of 2,500 students. In brochures, the school calls itself New Rochelle "International" High School, and many students describe it as a mini-United Nations.
Indeed, some of the students' parents work in consulates in Manhattan. But educators at the sprawling school make a point of the fact that many pupils come from low-income housing complexes in the center of this city of 71,000 as well as from the expensive homes along the Long Island Sound shore and in the north end of town. "There is every problem here, every vision, every interest, every desire and conflict that you can imagine in the student body, and the potential for every level of greatness," said Michael A. Tedesco, a guidance counselor.
"Some kids come from healthy, caring homes, and others are carrying a lot of heavy baggage -- death, divorce, parents with AIDS or cancer," he said. "But tip-top kids know no ethnic, racial or religious limits. Good kids can come from any background if given a chance."
Principal Donald Baughman described New Rochelle's class of '96 as driven -- serious, hard-working and worried about finding their place in a rapidly changing world.
Not a playful or partying class, they are "pushing hard to take us into the next millennium," Mr. Baughman said.
"Maybe there is a sense that things need to be better, although I wouldn't call them crusading kids," he continued. "It's just that they seem so determined to make a difference."
Born in the late 1970's, the class of '96 is statistically still a part of what has been called "Generation X" (from the 1991 book by Douglas Coupland, St. Martin's Press) -- a group with no formal name and what many observers say are few distinguishing characteristics, except perhaps that they follow on the heels of a generation of baby boomers.
But these are students who have seen their parents, the baby boomers, lose jobs and who say that as a result they do not expect to work only for one company during their lifetimes. Melissa Langsam is one of those students. She is a petite 17-year-old who, like Alison, is Harvard bound. A serious student who started a nationally based magazine called "Common Sense" to foster debate, Melissa describes herself as one of the few Republicans in her class, explaining that "politically, most of us are in the closet here."
Most of all, Melissa says she worries about her generation's ability to find jobs in an economy that has downsized workers like her father, a banker.
"We have to make life fair, so everyone who wants a job can get a job," she said. "Kids today have to be prepared."
According to the State Department of Labor, Division of Research and Statistics, Melissa and her classmates are part of a generation that will fare best trying to find employment in the health, business, social and professional services industries, which will see the largest growth in the next decade.
It is also a generation more interested in pursuing education careers than law and engineering, according to a study by the University of California at Los Angeles. A 1995 survey of freshmen revealed the highest level of interest in education careers in more than two decades, with 9.7 percent of freshmen planning to become elementary or secondary school teachers, compared with 4.9 percent in 1982.
The university study, which is the country's longest standing and most comprehensive assessment of student attitudes and plans, also said incoming freshmen have become less interested in keeping up with political affairs, promoting racial understanding or participating in community-action programs.
It is what the survey's director, Alexander W. Astin, a professor at the university's Graduate School of Education and Information Studies, called "a growing sense of powerlessness" among students.
But students at New Rochelle High School seem to defy the statistical trends -- especially in terms of their involvement with social, political and racial issues. Savon Jones, 18, for example, who will attend Fordham University in the Bronx in the fall and pursue a pre-law curriculum, describes herself as strongly political -- although she is not necessarily allied with a party. A member of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the president of the Black Culture Club at the high school, she invited the Rev. Al Sharpton to speak at the high school because she said that controversial figures "help people think about the world."
Justin Friedman-Hurvitz has a similar agenda. A dark, curly haired 17-year-old with earrings in both lobes -- who described himself as "the only Jewish kid on the New Rochelle basketball team" -- he plans to attend Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., and study radio, television or film. He said he wants to make art that "breaks down the hypocrisy of bleeding-heart liberals, conservatives and members of the Christian Right."
Which of these students will become part of the school's distinguished alumni photo gallery in years to come?
Perhaps it will be Emeka Nwanze of Nigeria, an 18-year-old pre-med student who is on his way to Harvard and wants to become a cardiologist. Or Eytan Oren, 18, who is going to Columbia next year and wants to write music. Or Caroline Ohmer, an 18-year old with the dark looks of her father, a member of the Osage tribe, and her Colombian mother, who will study at the New York Institute of Technology on Long Island to become a teacher.
But social and political concerns among students notwithstanding, many educators in the county, including those at this school, observed that graduates this year were above all concerned about their ability to succeed economically.
"Most classes have personalities," said Dr. Barbara Gruen, coordinator of guidance services for the White Plains School District. "Some are givers, others are into causes. This class appears to be into working hard. Most of all, they're worried about their ability to get jobs."
Dr. Joseph S. Schwartzberg, director of occupational education for the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services in Valhalla, reported a growing sense of anxiety among students.
"Invariably, what is uppermost in their minds in this rapidly changing world, is, 'Will there be a place for me?' " Dr. Schwartzberg said.

(Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times); Eytan Oren, class of '96, at New Rochelle High School. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
Unlocking New Doors With Bonds

BYLINE: By BARBARA J. MOORE; Barbara J. Moore is a managing director in the New York office of the SEI Corporation, a global asset manager.

 BODY:
THE Treasury's adoption of "real," or inflation-indexed, bonds will provide an attractive alternative to conventional bonds for some investors, offering them precise inflation protection not currently available. The new bonds, the Treasury believes, will broaden the market for Government securities and eliminate the need to compensate investors for inflation risk.
In addition, the bonds now open the door for other governmental issuers. 
 State and local authorities with huge infrastructure needs have been crying out for new sources of capital, principally to pension funds and other institutional investors. Some pension funds have been actively seeking so-called economically targeted investments that will promote social welfare while still delivering an economic return, because the ultimate responsibility of pension funds is to current and future retirees.
Current capital improvement programs are frequently deemed to be "for the public good" and hence the interest payable is tax-exempt. The borrowers are thus able to secure financing with interest rates significantly below taxable interest rates. While this creates cheaper financing for public works, it comes at a significant cost to the taxpayer. These costs are beginning to receive closer scrutiny as a staggering amount of infrastructure waits for repair or replacement.
In addition to being quietly expensive for taxpayers, this form of financing precludes participation by pension funds and other tax-exempt investors, who cannot afford to accept interest rates significantly below those in the taxable markets.
The real bonds provide the opportunity to open new sources of financing for infrastructure while saving money for the taxpayer. Assuming the current Treasury payment structure and the suggested 3 percent real rate, the interest paid on real bonds would be about 50 percent of conventional bond payments at the outset. This debt service would gradually increase with inflation or decrease with deflation. Over its life, this financing would probably not be as cheap as current tax-exempt bonds for eligible issuers, but it could be cheaper than taxable bonds because there would be no premium for inflation risk built into the rate.
For projects whose bonds are repaid from tolls or user fees -- bridges, for example, or even baseball stadiums -- real bonds could be ideal. The initial fees could be set lower because the initial interest charge is less. The fees would then rise or fall as interest costs did, in line with inflation or deflation.
Indexing tolls to inflation would also ease a legislative burden. It is highly unpopular to raise tolls, especially in sporadic, "rounded" amounts -- witness the recent furor in New York City over the increase in subway fares from $1.25 to $1.50, versus a smaller percentage increase in commuter rail fares. New toll-collection technology, including automated vehicle identification and multiple-use fare cards like New York's Metrocard, will make it practical and more socially acceptable to collect tolls that rise with inflation.
This application of real bonds can be found in Canada with the Straits Crossing Finance bonds, issued in 1993. The proceeds are being used to build a bridge from the mainland to Prince Edward Island. Real bonds are also being used in Australia to help finance the Sydney M2 Motorway.
Financing toll roads, bridges and other projects on a real basis will be far more socially equitable than the present practice of burdening current generations with inflated nominal tolls and taxpayers with the cost of tax-exempt debt. With inflation-adjusted tolls, today's users will pay the same tolls in real terms as their children and grandchildren.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
David Strasberg, Lindsey Monzingo

 BODY:
Lindsey Nicole Monzingo, the daughter of Dr. Constance Fish of La Jolla, Calif., and the late Daniel W. Monzingo, was married yesterday to David Lee Strasberg, a son of Anna Strasberg of New York and the late Lee Strasberg, the acting teacher and director. His father was the artistic director and president of the Actor's Studio in New York. He founded the Group Theater, one of the first ensemble companies established in the United States. The bridegroom's mother is the director of the Lee Strasberg Theater Institutes in New York, Hollywood and London.
