HEADLINE: IN THE WILD;
Ecotourism: Mixing Dollars and Environmental Sense

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Two incidents from the frontiers of ecotourism:
Item 1: On Sunday, Gil Mika, a state naturalist, was leading a wildflower hike through Wharton State Forest. Just as he was pointing out a flotilla of yellow cow lilies in the Mullica River, he was cut off by a voice booming around the bend. 
 "Spatterdock," called a man in a canoe, using another name for the cow lily as he delivered a nonstop lecture to the two children his boat. "There's some yellow club, those clusters of flowers on the white spikes. Up here you can see some lance-leafed violets . . . " He paddled out of earshot.
Item 2: This month, state tourism officials took half a dozen travel writers from Canada canoeing on the Batsto River as part of a campaign to persuade Canadians -- Canadians! -- to visit New Jersey for its open spaces and unspoiled scenery.
Superfund jokes notwithstanding, nature in New Jersey is more and more becoming serious business. This year, the Division of Travel and Tourism is spending a big chunk of its $2.6 million promotional budget pushing New Jersey as a place of natural wonder, including another wilderness trip for travel writers in June. A workshop on how to identify, protect and market the natural resources of the Skylands region drew 100 people to Warren County last fall.
State Senator Joseph Kyrillos, Republican of Middletown, organized an all-day Senate hearing on ecotourism in March and plans to introduce a series of bills next week to help develop the state's nature-based economy. Cumberland County adopted an ecotourism plan in February that includes everything from zoning changes to the suggestion that someone invent a greenhead pie (named for the vicious biting fly of the Delaware Bayshore) to compete with the shoo-fly pie of Pennsylvania Dutch fame.
Nor are the developments limited to mere plans. The Delaware Bay Schooner Project, a floating classroom docked on the Maurice River, has given school tours of the local maritime industry and the flora and fauna of the Bayshore every weekday day since it began sailing this spring. At the other end of the state, William Sheehan's pontoon boat has shown hundreds of people the marvels of the Hackensack River meadowlands since last June. The American Littoral Society's brochure of spring events this year includes, along with the guided tours of barrier reefs of Belize and Alaskan bear country, a trip to see the Red Knot migration on Delaware Bay.
"We're finally getting past the talking stage of people saying we need to do this and actually doing things," said Michael Catania, executive director of the New Jersey chapter of the Nature Conservancy, another driving force in the effort to develop the nature business. In the last several years, the conservancy has been erecting observation decks and building trails at the rate that some developers put up condos.
But just how big a part ecotourism -- defined by Ecotraveler magazine as "tourism that helps to create a dollar value on standing trees, live animals, intact cultures and intact rivers" -- can play in local economies remains to be seen. Today it is only a tiny fraction of New Jersey's $23-billion-a-year tourism industry. Its future will depend to large extent on the cooperation of state and local governments, environmentalists and business interests -- not always the most congenial of partners.
One corner of the state already has a fully developed ecotourism economy. In Cape May, bird-watchers spend well over $10 million a year, said Paul Kerlinger, a former director of the New Jersey Audubon Society's Cape May Bird Observatory, who is now an ecotourism consultant based in New York. Birders from all over the world jam the hotels during the spring and fall shore bird and hawk migrations -- what would otherwise be the off-season.
They stock up on ornithological supplies at a shop called For the Birds. They take $165 package tours that include whale- and bird-watching cruises. They go to restaurants recommended in the Cape May Bird Observatory's "Places to Stay, Eat and Shop" list of business that donate to the observatory. They leave Nature Conservancy "business" cards at stores and hotels to let business owners know how important ecotourists are to the local economy.
But what about places not blessed with an existing tourism infrastructure or the cachet of being one of the top 10 birding spots on the continent? The Pine Barrens, for all their million-acre vastness and subtle stands of pitch pine, are not Yellowstone.
Part of the trick, experts agree, is cross-pollination: combining natural and other tourist attractions so visitors stay for days rather than a few hours.
"A lot of people might not want to go out and look at birds all day," Mr. Kerlinger said. "They might want to go antiquing for a while. At the Cape May Bird Observatory, the wife would go out birding and the husband would go out looking at the old buildings in Cape May."
For many would-be entrepreneurs, the government's attempts to striking a balance between protecting the environmental and creating opportunities to capitalize on it still have a long way to go.
But what about the Canadians, who already flock to Wildwood each summer but tend not to stop between the beach and the border? Can they be persuaded to choose the wilds of New Jersey over the great north woods? Susan Melnyk, who runs the New Jersey tourism program in Canada, thinks they may.
"Canadians do tend to do a lot of hiking and biking and birdwatching in Canada," she said. "But sometimes you want to do the same thing, but in a different location."
Felicity Munn, a Montreal-based travel writer who took the state-sponsored tour, said she had found much to recommend: "There were so many spots where you'd want to stay at bed-and-breakfasts and hire a bicycle and ride around, and the canoeing was lovely.
"Before the trip," she said, "I knew nothing about New Jersey except that it was the armpit of America. This really opened my eyes."

HEADLINE: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS;
Once Grand St. George Hotel Eyed as Student Housing Site

BYLINE: By MARK FRANCIS COHEN 

 BODY:
Empty rooms loom throughout the St. George Hotel, once the largest hotel in the city. Now it is largely vacant, home only to $50-a-night rooms, about 40 elderly couples, and a dim reputation.
But the 12-floor hotel, which is part of an eight-building complex at 100 Henry Street, may get an overhaul if negotiations between a not-for-profit housing group and the hotel's owners are settled. The St. George complex went from being a neighborhood nuisance to a real hazard after one of its buildings was destroyed by a fire last August. 
 Educational Housing Services, which provides housing for 4,000 college students from 10 schools, would like to lease 300 of the hotel's 500 rooms. Last week, George Scott, the group's executive director, said that he was hopeful the deal with the owners, Sholom Drizin and Moshe Drizin, would go through, but that they were still wrestling over an "economic issue."
"They'd like to see it rented for a certain amount," Mr. Scott said. "It's an economic issue we're trying to resolve."
The hotel's owners did not return calls for comment.
Educational Housing Services plans to spend the summer refurbishing the rooms and others parts of the building that will be used by the students, including communal kitchens. Mr. Scott said students from nearby colleges, including New York Law School and Pace University, would be charged about $600 a month for the rooms, which are 175 square feet.
The elderly residents would be allowed to stay, he added.
Mr. Scott said the deal must be completed by Saturday if he is to have enough time to make renovations to the building in time for the fall semester. MARK FRANCIS COHEN

LENGTH: 768 words

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
One for All, All for One, on the Beach

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
A SHORE mayor talking about something that sounds even remotely inclusive? Oh my God!"
That, says Ken Pringle, the Mayor of Belmar, is the reaction he has been getting to his recent proposal that Jersey Shore municipalities, many of which do everything they can to keep outsiders from setting foot on their sand, join in a plan to issue reciprocal beach passes, good for any participating town. 
 It's a modest proposal that would apply only to seasonal passes. Still, any talk about increasing public access is heresy in many shore towns, where the exclusivity of beaches is defended with the tenacity of the German garrison at Monte Cassino.
"There's been some support," Mr. Pringle said. "But a lot of what I hear from other mayors is 'Over my dead body.' "
Beyond the chain-link fences, gates and ticket booths that limit access to a good chunk of the 130 miles of New Jersey's coast, though, there is growing statewide opposition toward entrenched local attitudes that the Jersey Shore belongs only to those who own property facing it, and Mr. Pringle says he is aware of the implications.
"There has been a mom-and-pop attitude permeating the Jersey shore for as long as anyone can remember," he said. And he suggested that this summer, as Federal and state tax money pours into the $2 billion Corps of Engineers restoration of New Jersey's eroded beaches, would be an excellent time for shore towns that benefit from "those billions of taxpayer largess" to start paying attention to the world west of the Garden State Parkway.
A 38-year-old lawyer who has lived in Belmar since he was 4, Mr. Pringle wants shore towns to start taking a "macro approach" to common issues -- not just beach management, but also traffic, ocean-front zoning, economic development, growth, marketing and the environment.
A regional beach pass would be a good start, he says, adding, "I really don't think beachgoing patterns would change significantly." The way he sees it, season passes could be issued for a group of adjoining towns, or for all shore towns in a county. They would cost perhaps $10 more than local passes (currently $40 to $55). Participating towns would agree on a formula to share the extra money.
"I don't expect we'll see drunken firemen from Staten Island coming down looking for badges so they can pillage local beaches all summer," Mr. Pringle said. "What this is really about is trying to elevate the level of discussion -- to attempt, at least at some point in the next 100 years or so, to develop a common approach to tourism."
Unlike some of its more exclusionary neighbors, Belmar, a town of 6,500, has always welcomed summer crowds. "In fact, the only thing Belmar was known for in the 70's and 80's was beaches and bars," said Mr. Pringle, who won office in 1990 after campaigning against his predecessor's threat to lease the town beach to commercial operators rather than comply with a court order to lower the beach fees. The order was prompted by a lawsuit by the now-defunct State Public Advocate's office, which had charged Belmar, Avon, Spring Lake, Sea Girt and Bay Head with setting excessive daily fees of as much as $10 a day.
"Frankly, the Public Advocate suit was really a very good thing, in the sense that what it said was, any money you bring in off the beach you have to spend on the beach," Mr. Pringle said. "All of a sudden, politicians lost the incentive to squeeze every dollar out of beach operations to keep property taxes down."
Many shore towns have lowered their daily fees, but continue to discourage day visitors with parking prohibitions and other disincentives. But Belmar began spending all its beach revenue -- it was about $1.7 million last year -- on such amenities as a refurbished boardwalk, new pavilions, restrooms and playgrounds. At the same time, the town cracked down on public rowdiness.
The investments paid off. Today, Belmar is a pleasant, accessible town with a broad, uncluttered beach that attracts families and well-behaved young people. No one misses the bad old days.
Belmar improved its fortunes not by excluding people but by changing its attitudes toward itself, says Mr. Pringle, who thinks the lesson could be applied all along the shore, from the honky-tonk towns to the hamlets hiding behind walls. "Right now, for the first time in generations, the Jersey shore has ocean water quality that rivals anything in the U.S.," he said. "But that's not much good if people walk around with the same attitudes they've always had -- which is that the Jersey Shore is where you go if you can't go anyplace else."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Why Small Stocks Are Leading the Parade

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
MANY aggressive investors had mediocre performance in 1995, largely because the small-capitalization stocks in their portfolios dragged them down. But small stocks have barreled ahead of big stocks this year.
"They're catching up to the rest of the market," said Byron Wien, United States investment strategist for Morgan Stanley in New York. "Last year, people were more cautious because they were worried about the economy. Now they're feeling more adventurous." 
 The shift in market leadership stems from a confluence of events. Last year, larger stocks were helped along by lower interest rates and a weaker dollar. Economic weakness and corporate earnings growth helped fuel a flight to quality, often to blue-chip, stocks.
By early February this year, expectations began to shift. After a series of cuts in short-term interest rates, including one in late January, the Federal Reserve grew quiet. Since then, long-term rates have been rising instead of falling, bucking the conventional wisdom of just a half-year ago. Last week, the Fed again abstained from rate action.
Likewise, prognosticators who spoke several months ago of gloom and doom on the economic front have been proved wrong so far this year. Government reports on employment, retail sales, industrial production and other indicators have shown that the economy is getting more energetic, not less.
A result has been some astonishing returns for mutual funds that invest in smaller stocks. As a group, the small-company funds returned 18.9 percent through May 17, compared with 12.2 percent for growth-stock funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago. Of the 37 fund categories tracked by Morningstar, only the precious-metals group has done better than small-company funds.
Sitting atop the list with a return of nearly 48 percent this year is Oberweis Micro-Cap, a new fund managed by James D. Oberweis, in North Aurora, Ill. The fund, begun on Jan. 1, closed to new investors on Wednesday once it surpassed its goal of $50 million in assets. The average market capitalization of the stocks in its portfolio is $120 million, compared with an average of $500 million for its sister fund, Emerging Growth, begun in 1987.
"This is the kind of market environment where investors have been willing to pay increasingly high prices for successful companies," Mr. Oberweis said in a phone interview last week. "The question I have right now is will earnings grow fast enough to justify current P.E. ratios, which are very high, or will we have a market correction."
Another leader among the small-company funds this year is Van Wagoner Micro-Cap, also a new fund. Its manager, Garrett Van Wagoner, set up shop in San Francisco recently after several sterling years leading Govett Smaller Companies. His astounding record continues, with a gain of more than 42 percent this year.
Micro-cap funds are a growing subset of small-cap stock funds. Three years ago, only 17 funds had portfolios whose stocks had an average market capitalization of less than $250 million; today there are 24, by Morningstar's count.
The growth at that end of the market makes perfect sense to Robert E. Kern, who handles smaller equities for Morgan Grenfell Capital Management in New York and who leads the team that manages Fremont United States Micro-Cap. He says the micro-cap market is in a similar position to that of the small-capitalization stock market 15 years ago. The sector is just becoming recognized, and mutual funds are beginning to stake their claims.
Mr. Kern attributes part of the popularity of micro-cap investing to the growth in entrepreneurial ventures, many of which go public. From the investor's point of view, "micro-cap provides opportunities for stock selection in the least efficient sectors of the small-capitalization market," he said, "because there's less coverage by research analysts and few institutional investors."
Not all the funds that buy small stocks fall into the small-company category. The Dreyfus Premier Strategic Growth fund is placed in the aggressive-growth group by Morningstar's method. But the fund invests in small companies, with a median market capitalization of $500 million.
Michael L. Schonberg, who has managed the fund since July 1994, can boast of a 37 percent return so far this year. He points to the broad-based strength in the domestic economy as the prime driver of small-capitalization stocks. Smaller companies tend to do most of their business in the United States, meaning they are directly affected by swings in the economy. In contrast, large, multinational companies tend to have global businesses whose foreign revenues can help offset any slowdown in domestic sales.
The price-to-earnings multiple of the overall stock market is closely related to interest rates, Mr. Schonberg argues. When short-term rates are stable, the market multiple does not change much, so earnings have a greater impact on stock prices. Companies with strong earnings growth tend to outperform in such environments, and with corporate earnings growth tending to slow down this year, small companies have the edge in his view.
Small stocks and big stocks seesaw as market leaders, but each group tends to take the lead for a few years at a time. How long small-company stocks will outperform depends in large part on interest rates, by Mr. Schonberg's argument. Until the Fed pushes rates higher, small stocks will retain their edge.
 Louis G. Navellier, who runs an aggressive small-cap equity fund bearing his name, said that bigger companies gained in early May because of rising long-term bond yields, but that spurt is likely to be a fluke. Earnings growth for the smaller companies is still much stronger, he explained, and a lot of money is moving into that area.
Growth will not be limited to one part of the small-cap market, like the technology sector, Mr. Navellier said. "This is a stock picker's market," he said. "You have to buy the leaders in each sector."

HEADLINE: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: GARMENT DISTRICT;
Rents Push Morale Down and Koreans Out

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For 15 years, Chalie Chung, a Korean immigrant, ran his hat-and-glove business out of the same store at 29th Street and Broadway. But rent spiraled until he could no longer afford the increase he was presented with last year, to $15,000 a month from $10,000. So last summer, he moved his business, Charm Creation, three crosstown blocks to 28th and Seventh Avenue. His new rent? $5,000 a month.
Still, he feels a loss. "It is like you live in a house for a long time," Mr. Chung, 48, said. "You have your family there. You see your friends there. It is hard to leave." 
 Korean immigrants and Korean-Americans, by far the largest ethnic group in the Herald Square area, are worrying that a one-two punch of higher rents and a sluggish local and international economy will drive the remaining Koreans out of the business district they helped build. For example, as Mr. Chung's rent has risen, he says, his sales have declined: last year, sales totaled $1.5 million, down 20 percent from 1994.
Koreans have been opening stores near Herald Square since the early 70's, and Broadway from 33d Street to 25th became known for the import-export business. Koreans specialized mainly in costume jewelry, wigs, handbags and hats.
"Landlords are digging their own graves," said Illsoo Kim. "If the Korean business district fades away, I think it would hurt New York's economy." Mr. Kim is the author of "New Urban Immigrants: The Korean Community in New York."
The New York Society of Korean Businessmen says there are as many as 500 Korean-owned businesses in the area and that the numbers have fallen by perhaps two-thirds since the mid-80's.
As in Mr. Chung's case, they sometimes move only a few blocks. But in other cases, they move to Queens or Long Island and even out of state.
"I don't blame them for moving," said Henry Justin of Justin Management, one of the largest landlords in the area. "I can't believe how many other landlords make me look good."
Mr. Justin said, however, that the problem was sour business rather than higher rents. Rents have gradually risen to about $18 a square foot per month. Because he has so many Korean-American tenants with sluggish businesses, he said, he has tried to keep rents at about $14 a square foot.
"When money's flowing like water," he said, "nobody complains about the rent. Now that money isn't flowing, people notice the rent. The Korean community took a tremendous hit when the peso went down because Latin Americans are some of their biggest customers."
Won S. Byun, who has been a wholesaler of sequins and other ornaments since 1971, said, "More and more of us old-timers have to decide whether we stay or go. But we are getting more and more worried." ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Fidelity's Managers: Freewheeling No More

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
IT'S one thing to invent the electric light bulb; it's quite another to run Con Ed.
That is the lesson that Fidelity Investments -- and, in fact, the entire mutual fund business -- is learning, as funds replace banks as the repository of Americans' wealth. Although Fidelity grew to be the nation's biggest mutual fund company by emphasizing innovation and an aggressive style, it has now become almost a public utility in the minds of many Americans. So dependability and predictability are becoming more important than creativity -- and Fidelity is struggling to cope with that change. 
 Such shifting public perception ultimately lies behind Jeffrey N. Vinik's announcement last week that he was departing as manager of Fidelity's gigantic Magellan fund.
Whether Mr. Vinik jumped or was pushed, chances are very good that he did not leave Fidelity because his fund had been lagging behind the market for five months. After all, Mr. Vinik had outperformed both the market and most of his peers for several years. And every money manager worth his salt -- including the legendary Peter Lynch -- goes through slumps.
What got Mr. Vinik in trouble was not his underperformance, but how he did it. He made a big bet on bonds -- while running a stock fund. The bet went sour, and there was little chance that the fund's performance could have been salvaged this year.
The bond bet angered investors and investment professionals, who felt that they were paying Mr. Vinik to put their money into stocks. If they wanted to take a flier in the credit markets, they could do that off their own bat.
"People bought Magellan as the premier growth-company fund, and they have not been getting that over the last six months," said Donald R. Dion Jr., publisher of Fidelity Independent Adviser, a newsletter that follows the funds. "There are many bond funds that they can buy."
Twenty years ago, money managers were expected to put their clients' dollars into bonds if that was where they found the best values. Indeed, if really worried, they could put customers' money in the bank.
While fund companies have been busy tightening restrictions on fund managers over the years to get them to stick to their core investments, Fidelity's managers continued to have free rein as long they remained fully invested. What really mattered was total return; nobody really cared how they got it. Fidelity's fund managers were encouraged to take risks and to try new techniques. Among the company's innovative products were funds that specialized in particular industries, funds that invested using a computer's artificial intelligence and a fund that invested to take advantage of big social and economic trends.
Even the managers of more traditional funds were encouraged to seize the "best" investment opportunities, wherever they might be. That is how Fidelity Capital Appreciation ended up with heavy holdings of foreign stocks and how Fidelity Blue Chip Growth ended up with a host of small-cap stocks, and how all sorts of unlikely Fidelity funds ended up with Mexican bonds.
The ground rule under which Mr. Vinik operated was simple: "Be a genius," said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Investor, the Chicago fund tracking firm's publication for individual investors. He describes Mr. Vinik as "old-style Fidelity, idiosyncratic and intuitive."
This system worked as long as Fidelity's customers were concerned only with total return -- and as long as the aggressive and unusual investments paid off. But both things changed.
Despite Fidelity's power and its awesome research, it made some big mistakes. When emerging markets plunged in 1994, Fidelity funds suffered. And the firm clamped down on its fixed-income group, which was told, "No more surprises." After two years of lagging performance, the company abandoned the controversial approach of its Capital and Income Fund, which had been active in managing companies emerging from bankruptcy. And earlier this year it reshuffled the management of 23 of its stock and balanced funds to align the managers' skills with the funds' stated objectives.
THAT last change is significant because it signals that Fidelity is starting to pay attention to how managers achieve their results and is trying to make the funds more predictable -- changes driven in large part by changes in the investing public.
While many investors are still chasing the hottest performance they can find, still more are really saving. They will not tolerate certain surprises. If they buy a domestic stock fund, they want it to hold American stocks, just as if they buy a can of tomatoes, they expect it to be full of round red fruits.
Furthermore, in picking funds, many of these investors rely on advice from newsletters or investment advisers, or choose from a limited menu of funds in 401(k) and other retirement plans.
Either way, the funds have to pass muster with professional evaluators, who prefer that fund managers not wander afield. Investment advisers want to be able to compare funds within a category and to devise diversified fund portfolios.
If a fund manager who usually buys the stocks of small companies starts loading up on blue chips, the advisers object. In fact, they often fire you, said Mario Gabelli, a longtime money manager as well as the head of a mutual fund company. This straying from a fund's category has also drawn the attention of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which wants mutual funds to hew more strictly to the investments suggested by their names.
Such changes in the marketplace have left Fidelity with an identity crisis, said Geoff Bobroff, a consultant to the mutual fund industry in East Greenwich, R.I. He suggested that Fidelity might have to split a fund like Magellan into a gunslinging offering for aggressive investors and a more predictable vehicle for retirement plans.
It may be hard for Fidelity to make such changes, and even harder for its aggressive, freewheeling and very competitive portfolio managers. Some of them have already left. Michael S. Gordon, who epitomized the kind of manager Fidelity had long lionized, is leaving with Mr. Vinik to manage money.
"There's a very big challenge here," said Eric Kobren, executive editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter that analyzes the funds. "How do you create an atmosphere that fosters creativity while still maintaining the controls?"
The answer may be that you don't, and that big mutual fund companies will look more like Chase Manhattan Bank or Procter & Gamble -- or AT&T -- than like the old-fashioned money management shops. Aggressive investors will have to turn to small fund families and boutique firms to meet their needs, but the bulk of the savers will be well served.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Is Tupperware Dated? Not in the Global Market

BYLINE: By JON E. HILSENRATH 

 BODY:
THE Tupperware Corporation has spent the last 10 years hidden in a cupboard of sorts. As a division of Premark International, a slow-growing conglomerate, Tupperware and its famous plastic containers have often been overlooked on Wall Street.
But Premark will spin off Tupperware on Friday and put it on display on the New York Stock Exchange. Premark shareholders will get one share of Tupperware for every share of the conglomerate that they owned at the end of last week. 
Should today's investors take a shine to a newly independent company whose sales parties seem as dated as Ozzie and Harriet? Though the company is confronted with some competition and changing tastes, the answer may be yes.
One reason is foreign markets. In many ways, Tupperware fits the mold of the many American consumer product companies -- Avon, Coca-Cola, Gillette, Procter & Gamble -- that have flourished in recent years by marketing their strong brands abroad. Tupperware -- which was founded in 1946 by Earl Tupper, a chemical engineer -- has pushed overseas aggressively as it has struggled with declining business in the United States.
The result: In 1995, Tupperware threw about 13 million Tupperware parties, not just here, but in more than 100 foreign countries. Tupperware's sales abroad accounted for 85 percent of the $1.36 billion in total revenue last year and for all of the division's growth. And the overseas possibilities are expanding. In the last 12 months, Tupperware has received permission to begin throwing its parties in two emerging giants of the global economy: India and China.
Second, Tupperware stock seems cheap compared with that of other consumer goods companies. In the weeks leading up to the first official trade on the Big Board, Bear Stearns has been making a "when issued" market, in which Tupperware stock can be traded before its debut. In that market, Tupperware closed on Friday at $44.625. That is equivalent to about 16.5 times the company's expected earnings of $2.70 a share this year, according to a survey of Wall Street stock analysts.
This price-to-earnings ratio is lower than that of the companies usually compared to the container maker. Stock in Avon, which analysts consider the most comparable because the two companies use similar door-to-door sales approaches, was trading at 20.2 times its projected earnings at Friday's close. And Rubbermaid, which also sells plastic household containers, has a multiple of 21.
Tupperware looks even cheaper compared with other global consumer product companies. Gillette, for example, is trading at about 27 times projected earnings.
If the when-issued price foreshadows how the stock will fare once official trading begins, Tupperware may well be a bargain, many analysts and investors said. The low price, they say, reflects Wall Street's unfamiliarity with the stock rather than serious company shortcomings.
"You get a discount coming out of the chute because you don't have a history" with Wall Street, said Susan Potto, an analyst with the Mutual Shares Fund, a large holder of Premark shares.
The 10 years that Tupperware spent as part of Premark adds to the unfamiliarity, the analysts said. The conglomerate also makes such well-known products as West Bend appliances and Hobart food equipment. As a separate entity, analysts said, Tupperware will command a greater following among institutional investors and analysts.
How high might Tupperware stock go? Ms. Potto predicted it might trade at $55 before too long, or 20 times her estimate of 1996 earnings, $2.75 a share. Many analysts expect earnings to exceed $3 a share by 1997, implying a stock price of almost $60 if the market began to value Tupperware at about the same price-to-earnings ratio it has bestowed on Avon and Rubbermaid.
Not everyone likes Tupperware, however.
Many investors were spooked by a downturn in sales last quarter in Tupperware's greater European region. Compared with the corresponding period in 1995, sales in the region -- Europe, Africa and the Middle East -- fell by 15.3 percent. These regions account for more than 40 percent of the company's revenue.
Tupperware attributes the drop to sluggish economic growth in its principal market in the region: Germany. But Matthew Roswell, a consumer products stock analyst with Legg Mason, said the decline could be the first hint that Rubbermaid, which has bought plastics companies in Poland and France in the last 15 months, is beginning to eat into Tupperware's market share.
"I don't think it is going to be as good a business as it has been," Mr. Roswell said of Tupperware's foreign activity.
But Rubbermaid, which had foreign sales last year of $337 million, compared with $1.15 billion for Tupperware, does not have the same presence in Europe that Tupperware has. And Rick Goings, Tupperware's president, said that Rubbermaid's less expensive products did not pose a direct threat to the high-end part of the market that his company was seeking.
Moreover, he said, results from the European region will be strong in the second quarter, though Tupperware will have to give up some of those gains in foreign-exchange losses. Mr. Goings, who came to Tupperware from Avon in 1992, said he foresaw a single-digit increase in sales in Europe in the second quarter and for the year, and a double-digit increase for those periods in Latin America. In Asia, he expects single-digit increases.
Compounding the skepticism over Europe, however, is Tupperware's domestic business. Revenues have fallen as more women have entered the work force and have become unable or unwilling to attend sales parties, and as stores like Wal-Mart have offered cheaper alternative products. In 1995, sales in the United States fell 9 percent, to $208.6 million, and profits dropped 36 percent, to $10.3 million. Domestic sales have fallen in six of the last nine years, for a total decline of 37 percent.
But Tupperware is angling to reverse the trend. It hopes to relieve its local agents of the job of storing and delivering the merchandise, for instance, so that they can concentrate on recruiting more representatives and expanding sales. The company has also taken its parties into the workplace and is peddling its containers in catalogues.
These plans are expected to help. But so will simply taking Tupperware out of the shadow of Premark, Mr. Goings believes. "People need to get to know the stock better," he said. "For many, we've been a great secret."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
At Tax Time, Your Land Rover Might Not Be a Guzzler

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
WITH your 1995 tax refund in hand, you are ready to buy a new car for your business needs. And, like millions of other Americans, what you really want is one of those expensive, gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles. But you know such a purchase would be impractical.
Guess again. Because of a little-known tax rule, a sport utility can, in the end, be much less expensive than a car. 
 Under the rule, owners of vehicles that are used for business and that weigh more than 6,000 pounds can depreciate a larger portion of the vehicles' value annually than can owners of other vehicles. As a result, the after-tax cost of these heavy vehicles -- not just sport utilities, but also vans and pickup trucks -- can often be less than the cost of many cars of equal or lower price.
Consider a person who buys a $45,000 Cadillac Seville solely for business use. He can depreciate only $3,060 of the car in its first year and, after five years of taking the maximum annual depreciation, he will have written off only $14,460, less than a third of the price. To fully depreciate the Cadillac would take 23 years.
Now look at the buyer of a sport utility vehicle, a $45,000 Toyota Land Cruiser. The amount that can be depreciated in the first year is $9,000. After five years, the owner will have written off $42,408. By the end of the sixth year, the full $45,000 will have been depreciated.
If the car is also used for personal purposes, depreciation can be taken only for the time it is used for business. But the advantage for the sport utility still applies.
The reason for this different tax treatment is just 2,578 pounds. At 6,470 pounds, the Toyota Land Cruiser is exempt from the depreciation caps that apply to the 3,892-pound Cadillac Seville and to every other passenger car on the American market, none of which exceeds 6,000 pounds.
What makes 6,000 pounds so important? The tax code has long given trucks, which are generally costly to buy and to run, more favorable depreciation treatment than it has to cars. A decade ago, Congress picked 6,000 pounds as a simple way to distinguish between trucks and other vehicles.
But legislators didn't reckon with the evolution of the automotive market. "When the depreciation rules changed in 1986 and the limitations were set, the sport utility vehicle market was not what it is today," said Dick Locastro, a tax manager for Coopers & Lybrand in Washington. "Generally, we didn't have a vehicle over 6,000 pounds that could be treated as a passenger vehicle."
That has changed. Among sport utility vehicles alone, many exceed 6,000 pounds, enabling business owners and self-employed doctors, lawyers, sales representatives, consultants and others to use the speedier depreciation schedule. They include the Chevrolet Suburban and Tahoe, the GMC Yukon, the Toyota Land Cruiser, the Lexus LX 450, all Land Rover models, the AM General Hummer and some versions of the Mitsubishi Montero. The Ford Motor Company plans to introduce larger sport utilities in the next couple of years, beginning this fall with the Expedition, which will probably weigh more than 6,000 pounds.
If their owners meet a variety of other criteria, these big sport utilities offer a second tax advantage. If the owner of the Land Cruiser used in the example met certain requirements for business income, he might be able to deduct part of the vehicle's cost as a business expense. After five years, the owner would be able to write off even more -- $43,416 -- than he would under the accelerated depreciation rules by themselves. Again, the Cadillac and other cars would not qualify for this benefit because they weigh less than 6,000 pounds.
And because vehicles weighing more than 6,000 pounds are considered trucks, they are exempt from the excise tax applied to luxury cars. In 1995, that tax, which is adjusted annually for inflation, equaled 10 percent of a car's cost in excess of $32,000. With the $45,000 price, the owner of the Cadillac Seville would have owed a luxury tax of $1,300 if he had bought the car last year.
The luxury tax, which applies regardless of whether a vehicle is used for business, is more familiar than the 6,000-pound rule. Even accountants are only beginning to discover the latter. "It's not well known," Mr. Locastro said.
Nevertheless, big vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles are the fastest-growing segment of the auto industry. In 1995, some 1.7 million sport utility vehicles were sold, up 12 percent from the previous year, according to J. D. Power & Associates, the automotive market research firm. So far this year, sales of sport utilities are running ahead of last year's blistering pace.
And large sport utility vehicles -- the ones most likely to exceed 6,000 pounds -- are the fastest-growing part of this segment. In 1995, sales of these "full size" machines rose 32 percent, to 287,535, and so far this year they are running about 70 percent ahead of last year's pace, largely because of the introduction of new models.
With sales like these, the tax clause may not stay obscure for long, Mr. Locastro said. "There must be people out there using it," he said, "because you see a lot more Land Rovers and Hummers out there now."

HEADLINE: Report From North Korea;
Flood Waters Come and Go. Misery Endures.

BYLINE: By TREVOR PAGE 

 BODY:
North Korea's perpetual economic crisis may be turning into famine. Earlier this month, two United Nations agencies reported that "without emergency food imports the consequences are likely to be devastating for large segments of the population." This week, Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, is scheduled to travel to North Korea, where few visitors are allowed. Trevor Page last week returned from six months there as country director for the World Food Program, one of the United Nations agencies. This article expresses his personal view of what he saw.
NORTH KOREA is a land of extremes.
Pyongyang, the capital, regarded as a sort of Valhalla, is where two million of the North Koreans most faithful to their political system live in a surrealistic environment, much like a film set, with tall buildings, broad boulevards and landscaped parks. Since there is nowhere to go on to after Valhalla, those privileged to live in the capital are shrouded from the shortages the rest of the country faces. 
 Sangdan Ri is a collective farm, on the northwest frontier with China, which looks today as though it is straight out of Sudan or the Sahel. It lies engulfed in sand deposited from the Amnuk River by last year's floods.
Between these extremes, some 20 million ordinary North Koreans struggle to make ends meet as the country's food and fuel crisis deepens further.
Lee Sok Fae, a 57-year-old farmer in Sangdan Ri, was one of the 500,000 people who were rendered homeless by last summer's floods, the worst in living memory. Flood waters from the Amnuk River, nearly a mile away, submerged the entire collective farm for a week. For two months, Mr. Lee, his wife, his two children and a cousin were billeted in a school building with other flood victims before they were able to go back to rebuild their home. Cement, timber for the rafters and door frames, and tiles for the roof were provided by the state. Mr. Lee rebuilt the house himself with the help of a few hands from the local work brigade, who were pressed into action under the system labeled Juche, or self-help, on which the country has been built.
Lee Sok Fae went back home, but the collective's rice paddies remained buried under more than a foot of sand. There was no rice crop at Sangdan Ri this year, nor on some 100,000 acres of farmland elsewhere. The loss was all the more devastating because 80 percent of North Korea is mountainous and its food has to be produced on the remaining 20 percent.
Work started last November to repair the breached flood dikes and clear the debrisbut more than half of the repairs remained undone. Mr. Lee and his family have got by on occasional handouts from the state, supplemented by sporadic food aid from the international community.
Spring brought Mr. Lee, his family and the other 20 million North Koreans who live outside the capital some relief. Wild edible roots and grasses were gathered to expand the family soup pot. Farmers in Sangdan Ri said that some varieties, such as chok, a long, bitter, fibrous root, hadn't been eaten since the desperate days of 1951, during the Korean war.
For millions of North Koreans, it is going to be a long, hard haul until October, when the next harvest should replenish the granaries. In the meantime, Lee Sok Fae will have to yank in his belt a few more notches and keep up the grim determination that is expected of North Koreans.
Pak Chong Il is in his early 20's and is an architecture student at Kim Il Sung University in Pyongyang. He plucked up the courage to approach a colleague and me as we sat talking one Sunday afternoon in a park. Mr. Pak wanted to practice his English, which he has been studying for seven years. His spoken English was quite good, although we never really got past discussing mundane matters like the weather.
What shook me, however, was that fairly early in our conversation I asked him what work his parents did. He said his father had died eight years ago and that his mother, a doctor, had died last year. When I said how sorry I was to hear that, he looked me straight in the eye and said there was no need to be sorry. He said he was not sorry. "Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il would live forever and would always take care of me." He said he had a lot to be grateful for. (The late Kim Il Sung was North Korea's leader; Kim Jong Il is his son and heir apparent).
Most foreigners living in North Korea are not allowed to travel out of the capital. An exception has been made for the few resident relief workers with the Red Cross, UNICEF and the World Food Program. There is also a fledgling expatriate business that is mainly involved in the manufacturing of garments and cigarettes.
One highlight of the week for expatriates in Pyongyang is the Wednesday "expatriate dinner." In an attempt to break the monotony of working in the world's most tightly closed society, everyone tries not to talk shop. Aside from talking about the weather, which is highly changeable, the conversation tends to focus on who arrived on the weekly flight from Beijing, or who didn't get an entry visa.
There are other distractions like the International Club, where Eastern Europeans drown their sorrows every Saturday night as young Arab men dance with each other. Or there is the Tongi restaurant, a sprawling pagoda-like structure on the banks of the Tedonggang River, where dog is the specialty; it is a favorite haunt of Korean and Chinese businessmen. For the residents of Pyongyang, there are the parks and riverfront walks, which cost nothing.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
What's a Medal Worth Today?

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda understood the value of medals in motivating a sailor. When visiting a ship or Navy base, he liked to arrange an impromptu awards ceremony, the pleasure obvious in his face as he pinned one of those bits of ribbon and brass to a proud sailor's chest.
So when he took his own life this month, apparently over the question of the legitimacy of two Vietnam War combat medals that he had worn for years, veterans may have been dumbfounded, but could understood the mortification that the Navy's highest-ranking officer would have felt. 
 Lieut. Gen. Bernard E. Trainor, a retired Marine Corps general, said that if the Admiral had worn combat medals that he had not earned, "it would have irreparably tarnished him" with sailors, even if it had been an entirely innocent mistake.
The "fruit salad," that accumulation of decorations on a sailor or soldier's chest, serves as a public resume, a biography, a means for one service member to size up another in the blink of an eye. The decorations have an importance all out of proportion -- sometimes, absurdly so -- to the intrinsic value of the nylon and brass they are made of.
During the early history of the United States military, decorations were rare, and handed out only in cases of extraordinary bravery or sacrifice. Many commanders considered them silly affectations, and official portraits of several of the country's most celebrated warriors, including Grant and Sherman, show them without any campaign ribbons or medals at all.
The most famous American military decoration, the Purple Heart, dates to the Revolutionary War, when George Washington presented violet, heart-shaped cloth patches edged with silver braid to men commended for acts of bravery. Only three were ever awarded.
Handing out large numbers of war medals began in earnest only in World War II, when a soldier or sailor could return with a chestful of medals and ribbons, each earned in a different combat zone.
The number of medals exploded in subsequent wars; today's admirals and generals find their uniforms weighed down with decorations, and troops have come to expect an award not just for valor, but simply for having shown up in a war zone.
After the American invasion of Grenada in 1983, the Defense Department handed out 8,600 medals, even though no more than 7,200 troops ever set foot on the tiny Caribbean islands. Many of the decorations went to soldiers who got no closer to Grenada than the corridors of the Pentagon.
Every one of the military's 3.5 million uniformed troops and reservists in 1991 received a medal after the American victory in the Persian Gulf war, and the 540,000 soldiers who were actually dispatched to the Gulf also received campaign medals from Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.
There was outrage among veterans in 1989, when a Purple Heart, which in this century has traditionally been presented only when a soldier has been seriously wounded or killed, was awarded instead to a paratrooper who had suffered heat stroke during the American invasion of Panama. The Navy awarded combat ribbons to the crew of the guided-missile cruiser Vincennes shortly after they mistakenly shot down an Iranian civilian jet in 1988.
Military historians and many veterans say the phenomenon, known as medal inflation, has lessened the value of all decorations. "Frankly, it dismays me," said Capt. Edward L. Beach, retired, a naval historian and author of the novel "Run Silent, Run Deep." "It's demeaning to me to feel that the medals I earned -- that I thought were so great -- are now a dime a dozen."
Rivalry among the armed services has added to the problem. The Air Force has been handing out nearly twice as many decorations per service member as the Navy, which has added to the pressure on the leadership of the Navy to keep up.
A survey by the newspaper Navy Times found that in 1994, the Air Force handed out an average of 287 decorations for every 1,000 service members, compared to 148 for the Navy and 70 for the Marines. Comparable Army statistics were not available.
The newspaper quoted Rear Adm. Joseph S. Mobley, director of the Navy staff overseeing the awards system, as saying, "We're probably not giving out enough awards -- I think it's the most emotional and motivational tool we have."
John Garavelli, a military awards specialist with the American Uniform Association, said he thought that the proliferation of medals was "pretty harmless so long as the decorations that are really meaningful stay that way, and I think they have been careful about that."
Still, Mr. Garavelli remembers being dumbfounded when he learned in the 1980's that the Army was presenting all new soldiers with a decoration called the Army Service Ribbon. "That one really turned my stomach," he said. According to Army regulations, the ribbon goes "to members of the regular U.S. Army, Army National Guard and Army Reserve to indicate the successful completion of initial entry training."
"Boot camp, in other words," Mr. Garavelli said. "Now we're giving awards for boot camp."

HEADLINE: Big Victory for a Small Frog

 BODY:
It was especially fitting that the California red-legged frog should be the first creature granted protection under the Endangered Species Act when a 13-month moratorium imposed by Congress ended last week. Though not nearly as important to the national psyche as the bald eagle, the frog is a minor cultural icon, having reportedly inspired Mark Twain's yarn about a "celebrated jumping frog." The frog's dwindling numbers also signaled a larger problem, the deterioration of the California streams and wetlands that provided its habitat.
The frog is thus an apt symbol of what the Endangered Species Act is supposed to be about -- saving threatened plants and animals whose plights symbolize broader dangers to entire ecosystems. The Federal judge who invoked the act in 1991 to save the spotted owl put the matter nicely when he said the issue was not only the owl but also the survival of the old-growth forests that protected it. 
 There are many in Congress, however, who see the act as an arbitrary Federal weapon used to harass property owners and block economic progress in order to save species of relatively trivial value. This is a cruel caricature, but Congressional Republicans were able to exploit it early last year to shut down the Interior Department's ability to identify threatened species and develop conservation plans for their survival.
The Republicans hoped the moratorium would pressure the Administration to accept a bill radically overhauling the law. As part of this strategy, the House Resources Committee approved a measure last fall that would have gutted the act by making it impossible to protect species on private land and greatly weakening protections on Federal land. The bill has not been brought to a vote, in part because Speaker Newt Gingrich realized his party had already bought itself enough trouble with its year-long assault on the country's other environmental laws.
Congressional moderates are working on a compromise bill that would preserve the act's basic powers but make it less burdensome on landowners. Under the present law, for example, fines and jail sentences can be imposed if landowners do not take steps to preserve the habitat of a listed species. Though such sanctions are rare, many environmentalists believe the law relies too heavily on sticks and not enough on carrots, in the form of financial incentives for sound land management. The act is also badly underfunded, damaging the Interior Department's ability to design recovery programs and, if necessary, to buy private land.
Smart administration of the present law can also minimize what Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt once called the "legal train wrecks" inspired by the act. For years, regulators and environmentalists wrangled with property owners over imperiled habitats, tract by tract and species by species. Invoking a little-used 1982 amendment that encouraged broad conservation plans, Mr. Babbitt promoted negotiations aimed at preserving entire ecosystems.
There have been dramatic successes. Several years ago, the department listed the tiny California gnatcatcher as threatened, which could have put hundreds of thousands of acres of Southern California scrubland off-limits to developers. Rather than face interminable lawsuits, an unorthodox coalition of California officials, conservationists, scientists and landowners spent five years working out plans to set aside as many as 200,000 acres to protect troubled wildlife while freeing developers who build outside the preserve from further liability under the Endangered Species Act.
This agreement may help arrest Southern California's long-term slide toward ecological disaster and make it a far better place to live. If that happens, thank the gnatcatcher -- and the act protecting it.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The New China Consensus

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When people across the political spectrum start giving speeches on the same subject in an election year, it usually means there is sharp disagreement. But in the past few weeks Bill Clinton, Bob Dole, Warren Christopher, Bill Bradley, Sam Nunn, Charles Robb and Newt Gingrich have all made statements on U.S.-China relations, and what's remarkable is how much they agree in their recommendations. What's going on here? What's going on is that seven years after the Tiananmen Square massacre, a new American consensus on how to deal with China is finally taking shape.
The old U.S. policy consensus on China was shattered in the late 1980's. The collapse of the Soviet Union deprived the U.S. and China of their common enemy, which really was the glue holding together their strategic partnership. At the same time, the Tiananmen massacre shifted the focus in Washington from looking for ways to cooperate with China on foreign policy to looking for ways to alter China's domestic policy. And there went the China consensus. While President Bush wanted to find a way to maintain a strategic dialogue with China, Congress and the public were so outraged over Tiananmen all they wanted to do was punish "the butchers of Beijing." 
 But then two things happened. As China became an ever more lucrative market, Democrats started evolving a new strategy -- one designed to let them have their cake and eat it too. They argued that trading with China was both good business and good for promoting human rights, because it opened China to the world and forced it to adopt some rule of law. As this view gained currency in Congress and within the Administration, the left wing of the Democratic Party, which wanted to isolate China to promote human rights, became marginalized.
A parallel shift occurred on the strategic front. Geo-strategists gradually went from arguing that the U.S. and China had to work together to deter a common enemy -- Russia -- to arguing that the U.S. and China needed to work together to deter a common enemy -- China. That is, China became so big and potentially powerful, with an ability to disrupt everything from Asian stability to the global environment, that U.S. strategic interests mandated that Washington engage China -- no matter how odious its regime. As this argument gained currency, the right wing of the Republican Party, which wanted to protect Taiwan and isolate the Chinese Communists, became marginalized.
And thus was born the new U.S. consensus on China, which says: Give China most-favored-nation benefits to promote commerce and rule of law; intensify the dialogue with China's leadership to find areas of common strategic concern; work with China (using sanctions if necessary), so that it becomes a "responsible" member of the international community and embraces global rules on trade, copyrights and weapons proliferation; deal with China's human rights abuses in a low-key manner; protect Taiwan against any forced unification with China.
If the Chinese are smart, they will seize on this new consensus and meet Washington halfway. In doing so they could defuse the immediate tensions in the relationship -- over trade and arms sales -- and delay the fundamental tension, which is that we want China to become a free-market democracy and its leaders do not.
But here's my fear. What if Washington is knocking on Beijing's door and nobody's home? What if China's leaders are either too consumed by infighting to respond to the U.S. overture, or have lost too much control over parts of their country, like Guangdong Province, or parts of their Government, like the military, to live up to global rules on trade, copyright and missile sales? Or what if the Chinese leaders are now feeling so economically powerful that they think they can bend international rules to China's low standards, rather than having China bend to the world's?
The fact that serious people in America are thinking about China in a serious way is both an opportunity for China and a challenge. Beijing can no longer get by with saying, "If only the Americans had a realistic policy to engage us, then we could have a proper relationship." A realistic engagement of China is exactly what Americans are now talking about. It is up to China to prove that we're not just talking to ourselves. Because if that's the case, then another consensus will eventually take shape here, and it won't be for engagement with China. It will be for containment of China.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Focus on Those Displaced by the Fall of the Soviet Union

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 24

 BODY:
With millions of people still displaced or living as refugees almost five years after the collapse of the Soviet Union, three international agencies will hold a conference next week in Geneva to address what relief organizations call a colossal problem largely unnoticed outside the Commonwealth of Independent States.
Since the Soviet Union was formally dissolved in 1991, officials say, nearly nine million people have been uprooted, creating one of the largest and most complex migrations ever faced by international agencies. 
 At least two million people have fled regional conflicts like those in Tajikistan and Georgia. Millions more are trying to undo the forced deportations of the Stalinist era or are seeking to flee ethnic tensions that have erupted since the fall of Communism. The ecological disasters of the failed Soviet economy have forced countless others to move in search of clean land and water. Traffickers in people are luring thousands into illegal immigration.
Often, migrants' paths cross as populations are exchanged.
"It is a complicated set of movements and causes which have to be appreciated each in their own right in order to formulate appropriate policy responses," said Arthur C. Helton, director of migration programs for the Open Society Institute in New York. "There are no real mechanisms in the region for planning or preparing for migration or refugee emergencies."
Mr. Helton is among those who are critical of what he describes as the limited scope of the Geneva conference, which is likely to include discussion of which principles should apply to the treatment of migrants and refugees but is expected to stop short of any concrete demands for action. Relief officials say that Western Europeans are resisting calls for a broader legal definition of refugees from the region, fearing that this could upset stricter asylum policies now being introduced.
The conference, to be held on Thursday and Friday, is sponsored by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the International Organization for Migration and the human rights division of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Up to 50 countries are expected to send delegations to the conference, which has strong diplomatic and financial support from the United States.
Russia has been asking for an international meeting on displaced people in the Commonwealth of Independent States since 1993. But many Russian officials have been concerned primarily with the fate of ethnic Russians driven from new nations or barred from citizenship. Russia has also sought money for migrants returning to the federation from former republics.
Officials of the High Commissioner for Refugees' office in Geneva say that from its inception, the conference was intended mainly to provide a forum for refugee issues in the Commonwealth of Independent States and as a spur to better analysis of regional population movements that could lead to the adoption of national strategies for dealing with population movements.
Questions of citizenship must be settled by national governments, these officials say.
John Horekens, director of the European bureau of the High Commissioner for Refugees, said in an interview today that the meeting could not solve all the problems of the region, but it could "at least get a dialogue going."
"This will be a long process," he said.

HEADLINE: America's Hot Tourist Spot: The Outlet Mall

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: DALE CITY, Va.

 BODY:
Strolling past the Saks Off Fifth outlet, Dress Barn and a camera store in the vast corridors of the Potomac Mills discount mall, three college students from France smiled with anticipation as they spotted a shop that sold athletic wear.
When they emerged with their purchases, including the New York Yankees baseball caps that were high on their list, one student, Philippe D'Haucourt, said, "Now that we've seen the tourist sights, we can go home." 
 His quip held more than a kernel of truth. Potomac Mills and many other discount outlet centers have become so popular with foreign and American tourists that they are now bigger attractions than the Liberty Bell, the Jefferson Memorial, the Alamo and many other traditional tourist treasures.
Of the 17.2 million shoppers who spent $358 million last year at Potomac Mills, 30 miles south of Washington in Virginia's historic Prince William County, at least 4.5 million were tourists, according to a survey of mall visitors.
The travel industry defines a tourist as someone who travels at least 100 miles or stays in a hotel or motel overnight.
Under a somewhat looser definition, as many as six million of the visitors could be considered tourists, said Patrick McMahon, director of the Virginia Department of Tourism.
The gigantic enclosed mall, with its 225 shops, is far and away the most popular tourist destination in this tourism-rich state -- well ahead of Arlington National Cemetery, with four million total visitors a year; Colonial Williamsburg, with 2.5 million, and Mount Vernon, 10 miles or so distant, at one million. The only attraction in the region that rivals Potomac Mills in drawing tourists is the Air and Space Museum on the Mall in Washington. It draws 8.4 million visitors a year, although many of those are from the surrounding region.
To be sure, many people combine shopping with visits to historic sites, amusement parks, beaches or family and friends. But many just want to shop, planning vacations solely around that passion.
And that is not unique to Virginia. From Maine to Hawaii, bargain hunters flock to discount outlets, turning what was once an obscure corner of retailing transacted in mostly out-of-the-way locales into a booming industry. With sales at the 331 outlet centers in the United States projected to exceed $14 billion this year, up from $6.8 billion at 186 centers in 1990, outlets are the fastest-growing segment of the retail industry -- and, it turns out, one of the fastest-growing of the travel industry as well.
The trend includes Potomac Mills and 10 other discount megamalls that feature not just manufacturers' outlets, but also big discounters like Wal-Mart and Ikea and "off-price" stores like Marshall's that typically offer overstocked brand-name merchandise from a broad range of manufacturers and department stores.
Whatever their names, the outlets draw huge numbers of tourists.
In northeastern Philadelphia the 215-store Franklin Mills outlet, which opened in 1989, drew an estimated 17.8 million visitors last year, including almost 6 million tourists. That is four times the 1.5 million total visitors to the Liberty Bell, for decades the state's top tourist attraction.
In San Marcos, Tex., the estimated 4.2 million tourists last year at two outlet centers combined far exceeded the total of 2.9 million visitors drawn by the Alamo in San Antonio.
And Pigeon Forge, Tenn., a hamlet of fewer than 3,330 people with 200 outlet shops, drew 10 million visitors last year, a million more than visited the Great Smoky Mountains National Park nearby, the nation's most heavily visited destination park.
George Ku Tours in New Castle, Pa., 55 miles north of Pittsburgh, runs three-day shopping tours to the Williamsburg Pottery Factory near Williamsburg, Va., with a stop at Potomac Mills. "We don't stop at Colonial Williamsburg, since this is an all-shopping tour," said Joan George, an owner of the family business. Buses sometimes return so loaded with packages, she added, that the toilet is used as a storeroom.
Even at Niagara Falls, which has two big outlet malls, shopping often takes precedence over falling water. "You'd be surprised how many bus tours come here for shopping," a spokesman for the visitors' bureau, Tom Darro, said, "and couldn't care less about seeing the falls."
The Travel Industry Association of America recently said shopping was the most popular activity of vacationing Americans last year, and Mr. McMahon has an inkling of the reasons. "The only time many people have to shop," he said, "is when they're on vacation."
To keep tourists flowing in, outlet centers participate in package tours with nearby hotels, golf courses and casinos. In Washington the Gray Line tours feature a daily excursion to Potomac Mills, less than 45 minutes away.
Some conventional malls also draw millions of shoppers. But they tend to be in major urban centers, charge full price and cater overwhelmingly to local shoppers.
The Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn., a behemoth with more than 400 stores, 50 restaurants, 9 nightclubs and a roller coaster in a space that could fit seven Yankee Stadiums, is one of a kind. Last year it drew 40 million visitors, including at least 12 million tourists, more than Walt Disney World, the Grand Canyon and Graceland combined.
But outlet centers, even spick-and-span Potomac Mills, are usually no-frills places. And no developer today would dream of picking a spot for one without careful regard for tourists. It was not until about 1988, three years after Potomac Mills had opened in what was a largely wooded area, that tour buses and out-of-state cars made their presence felt.
"That's when we began an all-out push to be included in Virginia and Washington's familiarization tours for tour operators, travel agents and travel writers," said L. Kathy Pelino, director of tour and travel for Potomac Mills. That is also when developers who had not already done so began locating outlet centers with tourists in mind.
Yet for all the glass and chrome of the newer malls, the 300 outlet stores in restored factories and buildings in Reading, Pa., are thriving. Credited with being the first multitenant manufacturers' outlet center, Reading's outlets, which started to open in 1974, attract eight million visitors a year, including millions of day trippers from the Philadelphia region, as well as hundreds of thousands who arrive on 10,000 tour buses.
Although outlet shops have been a godsend for Reading, some tourism officials regard them as a mixed blessing. They provide jobs and tax revenue, yes, but critics say they also contribute to sprawl, traffic jams and one-industry economies.
The economic effects are considerable. Potomac Mills provided $3.4 million in retail sales taxes in the 1995 fiscal year, or 20 percent of Prince William County's total sales tax, along with 2,400 jobs.
But Jerome L. McElroy, a professor of economics at St. Mary's College in Notre Dame, Ind., who has written widely on the economic effect of tourism, said the benefits of outlet malls and shopping centers were often exaggerated.
"They basically deal in merchandise that is marked up, but to which only a small amount of local value is added, unlike, say, dollars spent touring historic grounds," Professor McElroy said. Switching the emphasis from history to shopping, he said, will inevitably change the mix of visitors and risk eroding the character of a state's tourism appeal.
Almost all outlet centers belong to local and state tourism bureaus. Potomac Mills also belongs to Capital Region USA, a cooperative encompassing Virginia, Washington and Maryland that advertises in Europe.
For as the students from France who are visiting here demonstrate, not only American tourists love to shop. Two German exchange students arrived after a two-hour drive, ready to do some serious shopping.
"I have a large shopping list from my roommates for at least 10 pairs of Levis," said Melanie Roehm of Cologne. Her companion, Christel Orth of Frankfurt, said Germany's few outlet stores were so scattered that "you have to travel all over the country to visit them."
A United Airlines advertising campaign in Europe, intended to promote the carrier's hub at Dulles International Airport, features Potomac Mills prominently. In one advertisement asking "Why Washington?" the airline answered by listing Potomac Mills first, ahead of Capitol Hill and the Smithsonian Institution.
"Our foreign passengers love to shop," Milton Perry, a bus driver for the Gray Line tour to Potomac Mills, said. "They come here from all over, and when they go back to Washington they're loaded down."
Last year 5 of the 4,200 tour buses to Franklin Mills in Philadelphia were filled with Kuwaitis. Gurnee Mills in Illinois attracted groups from Ukraine and Tanzania.
Sawgrass Mills near Fort Lauderdale, Fla., which draws an estimated 5.7 million tourists among its 19 million visitors a year, is a magnet for Latin American visitors. Speaking of their free-spending ways, Anne Lipscomb, vice president of marketing for the Mills Corporation, which owns Sawgrass and Potomac Mills, said, "I've never seen so many teen-agers with gold cards in my life."

HEADLINE: Quarrel Imperils Health Care in Haiti

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
Since the mid-1970's, the only source of medical care in Cite Soleil, the biggest slum in the poorest nation of the Western Hemisphere, has been a hospital and clinics operated by a private Haitian organization called the Centers for Development and Health. But that has not necessarily made the group or its director, Dr. Reginald Boulos, popular here.
On the contrary, when Dr. Boulos escorted Tipper Gore, who was visiting Haiti with her husband, Vice President Al Gore, on a tour of the centers last fall, their caravan was stoned. Now, citing death threats against him and his 1,500 employees, Dr. Boulos has closed his 114-bed hospital and three clinics and offered to hand them over to the Haitian Government -- which has, to the consternation of Cite Soleil's residents, rejected the proposal. 
 "I believe that 100 percent of the problem is related not to the quality of the health care we were offering, but to politics," Dr. Boulos said in an interview at the headquarters of his organization, known by its French initials, C.D.S. "Politically, this place is a gold mine: more than 200,000 people living in less than two square miles."
As Dr. Boulos, an American-educated Haitian of Arab descent, sees it, the hostility toward him stems from a widespread perception that he is not a supporter of Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's former President, and the governing Lavalas movement, which Mr. Aristide continues to dominate. The Haitian Government has repeatedly failed to respond to his requests for police protection, he said, "sending a clear signal to me that they see Cite Soleil as their turf and want me out of there."
Not so, replied Dr. Rudolphe Mallebranche, Haiti's Minister of Health. "It was a problem of financing," he maintained. "Dr. Boulos's international funding was drying up."
Asked for their version of events, aid donors acknowledged plans to channel assistance away from the project beginning in July, but said they were doing so at the specific request of the Haitian Government.
Whatever its cause, the dispute has left Cite Soleil's residents, who are among the most destitute people in Haiti, living in squalor without any organized health care. At St. Catherine's Maternity Hospital, for instance, deliveries of babies have ceased altogether and eight Sisters of Charity have been struggling since mid-April to maintain a few basic services for pregnant women and infants, such as vaccines and food.
"We simply could not abandon these people, so of course we decided to stay," said one of the harried nuns, a Spaniard who was willing to disclose only her first name, Sister Milagros. "Too many children were dying. It was terrible."
On one recent morning, the nuns were forced to turn away a young woman who had come with her listless, emaciated infant, its eyes rolling and unfocused, because they did not have the medicine the child needed. Disheartened, the penniless mother sat in the courtyard sobbing, the baby in her arms, until she was given bus fare to get to a municipal infirmary downtown.
Outside the hospital, graffiti proclaiming that "Boulos = Health" have replaced the slogans that once attacked the C.D.S. director as a "zenglendo," or associate of the Tontons Macoute, the paramilitary thugs who flourished under the 30-year Duvalier family dictatorship and its military successors. Patients say they want the group to come back and run the hospital, whose budget is largely underwritten by the United States Agency for International Development, but they seem unsure of how to do that or where to turn for help in the interim.
"Now I've resigned myself to the fact that I'll get skinny and die," said Sonia Leres, 23, an unemployed mother of two who suffers from tuberculosis, along with her 3-year-old daughter, Carola. "If I can't get free X-rays and medicine here anymore, what am I going to do?"
Dr. Mallebranche said that while he is sympathetic to the plight of the nuns and the residents of Cite Soleil, the Haitian Government can do little for them at the moment. "You can understand that the Ministry of Health, which does not have much money, is not prepared for this situation," he explained. "We have to plan for this, to evaluate the situation at the center."
The director of one foreign aid organization that has long supported the Cite Soleil project said the main problem is one of competence. "We're not going to make fools of this Government and ourselves," he said. "We can't turn over implementation to them because they simply can't do it."
Aid donors here said they sent a joint letter to Dr. Mallebranche recently, warning that $42.5 million in international health assistance was languishing in the Government bureaucracy would be sent elsewhere unless the Ministry began dispensing it. "While he wants all the money to go through his desk, he has no capacity to administer anything," complained one donor in an interview.
Community groups that support the Lavalas movement have long been hostile to Dr. Boulos and his organization. During the three brutal years of military dictatorship that preceded Mr. Aristide's restoration to power in October 1994, they accused him of providing information on his clients to the paramilitary thugs who killed hundreds of people in Cite Soleil as well as of supplying jobs and food to some of the most notorious gunmen.
Dr. Boulos admits to trying not to antagonize the military regime and its agents, but said it was "a conscious decision" taken to avoid the shutdown of the hospital and a program that fed 29,000 people. "There were enough human rights groups making noise, and I felt that my duty as a doctor was to provide humanitarian assistance," he said.
After American troops returned Mr. Aristide to power, the level of acrimony diminished somewhat, and Dr. Boulos was even invited to join a government task force on education. But when the episode involving Mrs. Gore was followed by other attacks, he left the country for four months and began to look more favorably on the idea of shifting the focus of his activities to the Haitian countryside.
"That was an incident designed to embarrass me, and it did," Dr. Boulos said. "It achieved its purpose, which was to put me in a difficult situation with my funding agencies."
Even if C.D.S. were asked to return to Cite Soleil, Dr. Boulos added, he would not do so. The group is expanding its activities in the northeast of Haiti, he said, where local officials are grateful for any outside help and political rivalries are less of a factor.
Nevertheless, "my dream is for the Government to succeed in picking up where we left off in Cite Soleil," Dr. Boulos said. "If all of this stays closed, then we have failed too."
