HEADLINE: Charles S. Dennison, 78, Adviser To Governments on Many Issues

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Charles Stuart Dennison, an executive who advised governments from Washington to Senegal on economic development, the environment, science and technology and other policy issues, died last Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 78.
A Santa Fe resident for the past eight years, Mr. Dennison formerly lived in Manhattan and Washington.
He suffered a long illness, his family said. 
 Mr. Dennison's business career grew to reflect his interest in international affairs. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations for nearly 30 years and a strong advocate of private investments in Third World countries.
Born on March 21, 1918, in Manhattan, he studied international relations at Columbia and New York Universities, although he never earned a degree. In 1936, he entered an executive training program at the General Motors Corporation. He then became a junior executive at the United States Steel Export Company.
In World War II he served with the "Screaming Eagles" of the Army's 101st Airborne, where he became a captain.
After the war, as an executive with several companies in the United States and abroad, he traveled to London, Australia, Panama, Senegal and other countries. At the request of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, he set up a large privately owned fertilizer plant in India that helped lessen the country's food shortages.
He was a member of President Lyndon B. Johnson's Science Advisory Committee and, as a Presidential adviser on the world's food supply, worked with the United Nations Environment Program. He was also an executive with the United Nations' Food and Agricultural Organization in Rome, the National Academy of Sciences, the Council of the Americas and the Organization of American States.
He lectured and held seminars at universities and governmental conferences around the world. He was a board member of the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists and contributed articles to the journals Foreign Affairs, Asia and others.
Mr. Dennison is survived by his wife of 45 years, Carol Krueger Dennison; a daughter, Deborah of Santa Fe and a stepdaughter, Laura Hardie of Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A New Way to Measure an Exhausted Bull

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Is the Q ratio signaling that the end is near for this great bull market?
The what? 
 If you're an economist, you didn't ask the second question. The Q ratio, devised by James Tobin, the Yale economist who won a Nobel prize for his work, is a ratio of the total market value of stocks and bonds compared with what it would cost to replace the assets of America's corporations.
There are good data on this since World War II, when the Federal Reserve began calculating the numbers on an annual basis. On average, stocks and bonds sold for about a 30 percent discount to what it would cost to replace the companies' assets.
But now those financial securities sell for at least 70 percent more than the replacement cost. That level has never been seen before, and to some analysts, it is a warning of excessive overvaluation.
Andrew Smithers, a British economist and proprietor of Smithers & Company, a pension consulting firm, is sounding the loudest alarm. "Professor Tobin received a Nobel prize for his work, and the U.S. stock market may thus be said to be making a bet of approximately $3 trillion that he should return his laurels," Mr. Smithers said in a report to clients. "I expect him to be justified in keeping them."
But Mr. Smithers, in an interview, conceded that there was no way to know just when the bubble might burst. The Q ratio, he said, was a good valuation measure, not a way to time the stock market.
Barton Biggs, the chief strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, agrees. "It is an indication that stocks are very risky, because they are very expensively priced," he said.
Mr. Biggs said he had studied the numbers, and the only thing he could come up with to possibly modify them is that they do not take into account the value of franchises and brand names, which perhaps are worth more now than before. Certainly, one could duplicate every asset of the Coca-Cola Company, from bottling plants to office desks, without creating a company as valuable as Coca-Cola if one did not get the right to use the name as well.
Mr. Tobin's work showed that the profits on invested capital, measured by its current value, should return to normal levels eventually, simply because figures well away from normal will produce an investment boom. Eventually, all that investment will create competition, eroding whatever was producing high rates of return.
And what does Mr. Tobin think about all this? He said that he had not seen Mr. Smithers' work but that the current Q ratio did seem to imply that stock prices are higher than they ought to be.
"Another implication is that it ought to generate an investment boom," he said. "You don't have to sell much of your firm to get the money you need for an investment project."
It is conceivable that the current figures are exaggerated because the replacement costs are underestimated. And it is also true that while a lot of companies are selling stock to the public, as would be expected if prices really are ridiculously high, some are also buying stock back and making acquisitions for cash. Neither would seem reasonable if valuations were that extreme.
The figures for the Q ratio are computed annually by the Federal Reserve, with the 1995 figure due out soon. Morgan Stanley estimates it will be about 1.71, and adds that if a figure were to be computed now, taking into account just how much the stock market has risen, it would be around 1.8. That is, assets now sell on Wall Street for about 80 percent more than it costs to make them.
If one assumes that the stock market will eventually fall back to the norm of about 70 percent of replacement value -- or a ratio of 0.70 -- that implies a stock market drop of about 60 percent. That would leave the Dow Jones industrial average at less than 2,500 points.
Mr. Smithers said he had estimated Q values back to the 1920's and had concluded that the stock market was considerably more overvalued now than it was in 1929.
To Mr. Biggs, the Q ratio is a good reason to cut back on American stocks, and substitute foreign ones. To Mr. Smithers, even foreign stocks may not be immune to the consequences of what he thinks will be a huge crash.
A major reason stocks have gone up, of course, is that American investors have done well in stocks and do not see other investments as offering high returns. Real estate has not boomed recently, and interest rates on bonds and bank deposits are far less than where they have been.
That logic, it turns out, has been compelling even to one who might be expected to be especially impressed by Mr. Tobin's Q ratio. What, Mr. Tobin was asked, had he done with his own money?
"I haven't taken it out of the market, if that's what you're asking," he replied, adding that he thought investor psychology was an important consideration. And anyway, he added, "the alternatives don't look all that attractive."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "The Rise of Q" tracks the total market value of stocks and bonds issued by American companies, divided by the replacement cost of corporate assets. Graph runs from 1945 through an estimated 1995. Figures exceeding 1.0 indicate new companies could be built from scratch for less than investors are willing to pay for existing companies. (Source: Federal Reserve; Morgan Stanley) (pg. D6)

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Fall 9.6% As Foreign Demand Weakens

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Orders for American-built industrial tools fell 9.6 percent in April from the month before as foreign demand dipped, a trade group said today.
Last month's orders were tepid compared with orders in March, and represented the first decline since February. Still, orders were up 18.8 percent from a year ago. 
 Machine tool orders declined to $437.60 million in April after rising 14.6 percent, to $484.30 million, in March, the report by the Association for Manufacturing Technology showed. Demand for the year ended in April was 6 percent ahead of the year that ended in April 1995.
If that trend persists, orders for all of 1996 could climb above 1995's record levels, the association said.
"We're pleased to see machine tool orders continuing to outpace 1995 levels," said Albert W. Moore, president of the trade group.
Economists follow orders and shipments of machine tools -- used to shape and assemble metals in products from diesel engines to dishwashers -- to gauge industrial output, consumer demand and business investment.
April's decline in machine tool orders comes amid conflicting signs for the manufacturing sector.
Orders for big-ticket items fell 1.9 percent in April, the third decline in four months, the Commerce Department said on Friday. Yet the durable goods report also showed pockets of strength. Orders for autos, industrial equipment and primary metals rose in April. Indeed, once transportation equipment was excluded, durable goods orders advanced 1.7 percent last month, the Commerce Department said.
In machine tools, domestic customers reduced their orders by seven-tenths of a percent in April while demand from abroad plunged 47.6 percent, the association said.
The drop in exports did not drag down the overall April figure all that much because exports make up only 15 percent of total orders. Indeed, the yearlong trend paints a different picture, with surging exports and domestic demand moderating in line with subdued economic growth in the United States.
By category, orders for metal-cutting tools, like drills, fell seven-tenths of a percent, to $326.8 million, while orders for metal-forming tools, like stamp press machines, dropped 28.6 percent, to $110.8 million last month.
Machine tool shipments rose 6.3 percent in April, to $480.1 million. The backlog of orders, which tracks pent-up demand for tools, fell 1.9 percent, to $2.149 billion.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
For Steel-Wool Maker, Chinese Lessons

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Peter N. Neustadter was drawn to China in the late 1980's, as were so many other American businessmen eager to participate in its booming economy and reap the benefit of cheap Chinese labor. He arranged for a company in the Guangzhou region of China, close to Hong Kong, to manufacture the shards of steel wool that have replaced asbestos fibers in automotive brake pads.
For a while Mr. Neustadter was pleased, and Durawool Inc., his Queens-based company, prospered by selling the Chinese-made material to brake makers in North America and Asia. But now he is embroiled in a legal dispute with a former employee of the Chinese company, who set up a competing business, and Mr. Neustadter faces growing pressure from start-ups there. 
 Earlier this year, a Federal court in Charleston, S.C., issued a preliminary injunction banning the import of the competitive material from China until a trial can be held.
Like the better-known trade battles involving pirated music compact disks and computer software, this case revolves around the vast differences between the United States and China in protecting intellectual property. But it may be even more of a cautionary tale for the typical American business attracted to the siren song of China. And some experts say that such fundamental gaps will produce many more such disputes as the two economies become increasingly reliant on each other.
"There is a cultural difference," said Hans Brechbuhl, managing director of the William Davidson Institute at the University of Michigan Business School. "Americans are very specific, and the details of a contract are the basis for a relationship. The Chinese are the exact opposite. The overall relationship is most important and if something in that relationship changes, they will blow a contract."
Both sides agree on the basic facts. In 1989 Durawool signed a contract with the China Metallurgical Zuhai Sez United Corporation to produce the chopped steel-wool fibers that Durawool would market outside China. A key figure in the deal was Zhang Ye, an English-speaking engineer at Zuhai. Mr. Zhang was deeply involved in establishing the steel-fiber plant and was trained by the American company to operate it efficiently. At Durawool's request, company executives at Zuhai signed an agreement not to disclose information about the production equipment or process. But Mr. Zhang did not sign the papers.
Mr. Zhang left Zuhai in the early 1990's and helped organize a new company, Sunny Steel Wool Ltd., using the same basic machinery and processes as Zuhai. Mr. Neustadter protested what he called infringement on his proprietary knowledge and technology, but agreed to buy some of the Sunny plant's output to control marketing in the West.
Sunny soon sought Durawool's clients, faxing offers of lower prices to brake manufacturers. At that point, Mr. Neustadter rejected a shipment from the company and the two accused each other of breach of contract. Mr. Neustadter, whose company has production plants in South Carolina, China and Ukraine, said the experience has taught him that "signed contracts in China are meaningless."
Nor, he said, is it possible to protect confidential processes in a country where legal patent and copyright protections are routinely violated. "As soon as you get on an airplane, your product is being copied," he said.
But Mr. Zhang, through his American lawyer, insists that he has done nothing wrong.
Some experts contend that Mr. Neustadter was naive in thinking that a confidentiality agreement alone would protect his technology. He did not pay sufficient attention, they say, to keeping talented employees like Mr. Zhang satisfied.
"Many companies are reluctant to educate Chinese employees in the United States for fear they will get a better offer," said Mr. Brechbuhl, whose institute studies nations that are moving from a planned to a market economy. "They need to talk to these individuals and ask them what it takes to make them happy."
Mr. Zhang made little effort to hide what he was doing. After establishing Sunny, he asked Mr. Neustadter to visit his plant and proposed selling chopped fibers to Durawool. "He had duplicated my process and was even using the Durawool name," Mr. Neustadter said.
As a "damage-control" measure, Mr. Neustadter said, he agreed to buy five million pounds from Sunny's factory over several years. "The idea, he said, "was that this fellow would not do any more steel-wool machines and go into another business."
But, Mr. Neustadter said, "nothing went right with the agreement," and Durawool ruptured the relationship for good in 1994 when it refused to accept four shipping containers of Sunny's steel wool.
Mr. Neustadter said his only hope rests with the American legal system, which would at least block Sunny from shipping its product to the United States. "The term Chinese law is an oxymoron," he said. "There is no legal system in China, as we know it. As least courts here can control American ports."
But Fleet Freeman, the American lawyer for Mr. Zhang and Sunny, said Mr. Neustadter had only himself to blame and that Mr. Zhang had not violated any Chinese law.
"Yes, Zuhai signed a confidentiality agreement," Mr. Freeman said. "But does it bind Zhang Ye? According to our consultant, probably not." He said that Chinese law does not allow for blanket protection of processes; each drawing or engineering specification to be protected must be individually marked, which was not done in this case.
Mr. Freeman said Durawool sold at least six more steel-wool machines in China to other companies, and it was the subsequent oversupply of material that drove the price down and hurt Durawool's business, not simply Mr. Zhang's competition.
By inviting Mr. Neustadter to his plant, Mr. Freeman said, Mr. Zhang demonstrated that he thought his operation was legitimate. "The invitation shows that Zhang Ye felt in his own mind he had done nothing wrong," Mr. Freeman said. "Otherwise he would not have extended the invitation." And Durawool's technology, he said, is based on patented German machines, leaving it little meaningful technology to protect.
The ultimate outcome of the dispute is still up in the air. The judge in South Carolina, David C. Norton, issued the preliminary injunction after finding that "there is a strong likelihood" Durawool will prove that it had trade secrets and that Sunny had used those secrets against it. But he also decided that 11 of the 17 charges in Durawool's complaint should be sent back to China for arbitration.
While labor is far cheaper in China -- a well-paid factory worker in the booming economic development zones might make $75 to $90 a month -- Mr. Neustadter said that the main reason to locate there was to draw on local expertise and buy supplies at an attractive price.
"The steel-wool process is pretty automated, so there is not a lot of labor involved," he said. "The Chinese are pretty good at working with iron and steel."
For all his disenchantment with Mr. Zhang, Mr. Neustadter said, the experience has not entirely soured him on doing business in China. The key, he added, is to develop a lasting relationship with a local partner, not simply a contractual deal. "We have a very successful joint venture near Shanghai," he said.

HEADLINE: Making It in New York City

 BODY:
Few postwar trends have devastated New York City more than the collapse of manufacturing, which has hollowed out neighborhoods and eliminated at least 700,000 jobs. In recent years, however, a contrary trend has occurred. Smaller manufacturers, often operated by immigrants, are sprouting everywhere. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is right to try to encourage the trend by promising to cut costs for these new businesses. At the same time, his administration calls for giving big "super stores" access to some areas now set aside exclusively for manufacturing. That approach could also stimulate the economy and widen the choices for consumers.
In the early 1970's, the city tried to keep its manufacturers by barring housing and commercial enterprises from its manufacturing districts. The theory was that competing development in these areas would drive up property values and rents, forcing the manufacturers to shut down or flee. 
 A generation later, it is clear that the city's strategy has failed. It now makes sense to let big stores -- including hardware, housewares, supermarkets and general stores like Kmart -- into the city. Lobbyists for small businesses are opposed, but consumers will welcome the chance to shop in places already popular in the suburbs.
Under the Mayor's plan, stores as large as 200,000 square feet could open in areas now zoned for manufacturing without going through cumbersome approval processes, as long as they are built in areas with adequate transportation. The City Planning Commission argues that more than $3 billion in retail sales are lost because New Yorkers now go to the suburbs to find similar stores. Smaller stores may find the competition difficult, but the record in other communities is that smaller operations can survive if they offer distinctive goods or better service.
Meanwhile, even as the city looks to new uses for manufacturing districts, it is also finding that some of the smaller manufacturers can operate safely in areas now zoned for commercial, retail and residential development. Large garment manufacturers may have fled, but small specialty shops that make purses, ties or other high-quality goods have sprouted to take their place. The city's big bakeries have mostly shut down, but lots of little bakeries have opened. Small operations in the telecommunications, software and computer field have already transformed Manhattan into what some call "silicon alley." Many steps can be taken to encourage even more growth in these areas, such as lifting costly and cumbersome government regulations .
Tax relief might also help these industries, and to that end Mr. Giuliani is offering business and selective sales tax cuts. But can a city already strapped for cash afford these cuts? Some of Mr. Giuliani's other proposals may be more realistic -- improving freight access to Kennedy International Airport, ending the erratic enforcement of traffic and parking restrictions, streamlining the permit process and targeting job-training funds to business sectors that promise growth. As a report by the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University points out, the city must also insure that its schools turn out a skilled work force, that its transportation links are maintained and that it continues to be a magnet for immigrants with an entrepreneurial spirit.
No one knows the long-term trend for the city's economic base, but one of New York's great assets -- its reputation as a place where industrious and creative people want to live and work in close proximity with each other -- will survive only if the city does not take it for granted. With these new initiatives, the city sends a signal that it will fight for its future.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Web Magazine at a Halt And Seeking Readers' Aid

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
The Web Review, one of the best- known of the magazines found only on the Internet, has stopped publishing and has issued an unusual appeal for financing that draws on two models of voluntary contributions.
Bowing to users' hostility to subscription fees on the World Wide Web, the review said that it would consider an alternative system like that of public radio, where some supporters pay and the product is free to all, or like shareware, where users who benefit from a computer program are expected to send payments voluntarily. 
 Pioneers in publishing on the Web are in an economic quandary that is expected to kill many more sites before the computer network becomes a truly mass medium. So many sites are free that only a few with special niches have been able to charge users a fee.
Web Review began last July and was published weekly with a daily update. Known as a Webzine, because it had no paper counterpart, it was one of the major forums on the Web. An issue might contain a lament about the dearth of poetry on the Web, or a rant about the spate of news coverage of pornographic or bomb-building sites.
The magazine said its main audience was Web professionals -- site builders, administrators and programmers who could check for the latest on esoteric topics like virtual reality modeling language or vector-based animation technology.
On May 17, visitors who tapped into the Review's site found a "Dear Reader" letter from the publisher, Dale P. Dougherty, announcing the Webzine's final issue, because advertisers were not covering publishing costs.
The letter said that Web Review would return in June if 5,000 readers would pay $19.95 for a six-month subscription. "How will we know if we don't ask?" the letter said.
"You are voting on the future of the Web and what you will find there," it added. "Web Review is not alone in having these problems."
In an interview from the Review's office in Sebastopol, Calif., Mr. Dougherty said there was only a 40 percent chance that readers would provide enough support for the publication to continue, but he said he remained hopeful.
"Restricted access is an annoyance, if nothing else," he said. "The public radio or shareware model would be a nice way around that. You want the casual users to pick you up, but you have to convert some of them to paying customers."
In a note posted at the Web Review site on Friday, the magazine said it had received 1,000 responses in a week, 700 from readers who said they would pay. The note said some complained the price was too high, and some asserted "they would never pay for information on the Web."
Betty J. Lyter, a senior research analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said a site like Web Review was unlikely to find a paying audience. "People are still site-hopping," she said. "They don't want to tie themselves to one by paying."
Ms. Lyter said Web Review's fate demonstrated the peculiar economics of Internet publishing. "The barriers to entry are relatively few, but the barriers to success are enormous," she said. "A few companies are building brand identities that will be very difficult for other companies to penetrate."
This summer, The Wall Street Journal will begin charging for access to its Web site, and the Microsoft Corporation plans to start Slate, an on-line magazine of politics and culture that will charge a subscription fee.
A satiric article in the April issue of Wired magazine called "The Great Web Wipeout," speculated that such content-rich sites might not prove economically feasible and that the Web would revert to its roots as a global jam session of chat rooms and personal home pages.
The Web Review's parent company, Songline Studios, produces Ferndale, an interactive soap opera. America Online Inc. holds a minority stake in Songline.
Mr. Dougherty said 12 people had worked full time on Web Review. He said the company laid off about 10 of its 25 employees; the rest will work on other electronic publishing projects. The magazine said its archives would remain open at:
http://www.webreview.com.

HEADLINE: Treasury Plans to Auction Bills and Notes

 BODY:
Because of the Memorial Day holiday yesterday, the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills was rescheduled for today. This week the Treasury will also be selling two- and five-year notes on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively.
At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.02 percent and a six-month bill was 5.10 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.02 percent, while the five-year issue was offered at a price to yield 6.40 percent.

HEADLINE: Health Costs Are Growing More Slowly, Report Says

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Health care spending grew more slowly in 1994 than in any year since 1960, the Government reported today.
National health care spending totaled $949.4 billion, or 13.7 percent of total economic output -- the gross domestic product -- in 1994, the Department of Health and Human Services said. The growth in health spending in 1994, 6.4 percent, was "the slowest recorded in more than three decades," it said. 
 Just three years ago, the Congressional Budget Office was estimating that health spending would account for 15 percent of the gross domestic product in 1994.
"It is still too early to state categorically that the long-term surge in health care costs is over," said Katharine R. Levit, an author of the report on health spending. But "indicators for 1995 show little change from the 1993-94 trend."
In an interview, Ms. Levit, an economist at the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, said the trend appeared to be "fairly steady" this year. "We don't expect large changes in the 1995 data," she said.
The department attributed the deceleration of health spending in 1994 to the greater use of managed care and the expectation of Federal action to control health costs. In fact, Congress rejected President Clinton's ambitious health plan and did not pass an alternative.
The new Government data were published today in Health Affairs, a health policy journal sponsored by Project Hope, an international health education organization.
National health spending rose 6.4 percent in 1994 and 7 percent in 1993, compared with 12.9 percent in 1980 and, on average, 11.3 percent a year from 1970 to 1994. Health spending continues to grow faster than the economy as a whole, as measured by gross domestic product, which rose 5.8 percent in 1994, the study said.
The new data are consistent with surveys showing that the cost of employee health benefits in private industry has leveled off. But spending continues to rise at robust rates for Medicare, which provides health care for the elderly and disabled, and Medicaid, for low-income families.
Government programs accounted for 44.3 percent of all health spending in 1994, "the highest level ever recorded," the study said. The figure for 1989 was 40.5 percent.
"This shift occurred because Medicare and Federal Medicaid spending increased more rapidly than private spending did," the study said. The Government's contribution would have appeared even larger if the study had taken account of indirect subsidies like tax breaks for health insurance and for employee health benefits, Ms. Levit and other economists said.
Spending for Medicare benefits increased 11.8 percent in 1994, whereas spending under private health insurance plans rose only 4 percent, the Government said. Republicans have asserted that Medicare ought to follow the example of private employers and make greater use of managed care.
But the authors said the disparity between Medicare and private insurance did not prove that Medicare was less able to control costs. For one thing, they said, the number of Medicare beneficiaries increased 1.8 percent in 1994, to 36.9 million, while the number of people with private health insurance declined by 0.1 percent, to 184 million. "Thus, one would expect Medicare benefits in aggregate to grow more rapidly than private insurance benefits," the article said.
In addition, the article said, Medicare is more likely than private health insurance to cover items like home health care and skilled care in nursing homes, for which outlays have grown rapidly.
After adjusting the numbers to permit meaningful comparisons, the authors found a smaller but still significant difference in the growth of spending for health care financed by Medicare, compared with spending growth for private insurance. Medicare spending rose an average of 5.6 percent for each beneficiary in 1994, while spending increased, on average, by just 3.6 percent for each person covered by private health insurance, the study said.
The authors of the study, Ms. Levit, Helen C. Lazenby and Lekha Sivarajan, work in the office of the actuary at the Federal Health Care Financing Administration.
The article also makes these points:
*Health care spending in 1994 averaged $3,510 a person, up 5.4 percent from $3,331 in 1993. Spending has increased 30.6 percent since 1990.
*Spending for hospital care rose only 4.4 percent in 1994, the third consecutive year in which the increase has slowed. Hospital prices continued to rise, but the use of hospital services for each patient, on average, declined for the first time in more than a decade.
*"Prescription drug price increases measured by the Consumer Price Index tumbled from 10 percent in 1990 to 3.4 percent in 1994," in part because of greater use of generic drugs, mail-order pharmacies and programs to manage the cost of prescription drug benefits.
Spending for home health care rose 13.8 percent in 1994, about three times as fast as spending increases for hospital care and doctors' services, the article said. Medicare and Medicaid financed more than half of all home health care. But the total spending for home care, $26.2 billion, was much less than the amounts spent on hospitals ($338.5 billion) and doctors ($189.4 billion).

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Health Care Spending Slows" shows total spending from 1991 to 1994. (Source: Dept. of Health and Human Services)

HEADLINE: Pro-Western Albanian Chief Claims Victory in Chaotic Election

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania, May 27

 BODY:
In the most chaotic election in Eastern Europe since the fall of Communism, the Western-backed Albanian leader, Dr. Sali Berisha, claimed victory for his party of former Communists today despite concerns by international monitors about fraud and intimidation at the polls.
President Berisha, who had been rewarded by Washington with military and economic aid for his coolheadedness toward the explosive issue of the Albanian population in the Balkans, waged a strongman campaign. 
 He passed a law late last year that barred some prominent opponents from running because of their Communist past even though he was a senior Communist Party official himself. He criticized the opposition party as a "red front," and banned its final campaign rally here.
Toward the end of voting on Sunday, the main opposition party said it was withdrawing from the election before the counting started.
In pulling out of the election, the Socialist Party and its opposition allies said they would not recognize the new Parliament. The move appeared to leave Albania with a likelihood of one-party rule.
Election monitors from the European Union and the United States said they witnessed instances of police intimidation, open ballot boxes and voters' casting more than one ballot. In a district in the capital, the voting was held in the living room of the local leader of Dr. Berisha's Democratic Party.
One election monitor, Fabrizio Migliaccio of Italy, said he was stunned that in seven districts he visited in the seaside town of Durres, "basic violations" of the electoral process were made in front of him. They included more than one person being in the voting booth, unsecured ballot boxes and the stuffing of the boxes with ballots.
But Western officials, dependent in the last four years on Dr. Berisha to preach calm among the Albanians who make up 90 percent of the population of the Serbian province of Kosovo, appeared eager today to give the President the benefit of the doubt.
At a news conference today, Dr. Berisha thanked the West. "We won because we enjoyed the powerful support of our great friends in Europe and the United States," he said.
Western officials said it appeared from independent counting that Dr. Berisha's Democratic Party was a winner of the election anyway. It seemed, they said, that the Democratic Party polled more than 50 percent and the Socialist Party under 25 percent, with smaller parties failing to gain enough for the Socialists to form a coalition.
There was more support for the Democratic Party than expected and less for the Socialists than expected, Western officials said, but they said the voter fraud was not enough to have tipped the scales decisively.

HEADLINE: Japanese Look at the Possibility of a Military Role in Asia

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 27

 BODY:
For half a century, one of the great taboos of public life here has been any discussion of a Japanese military role beyond Japan's shores.
Now the taboo has given way to an open debate, even prompting some calls for a revision of the "peace Constitution" that the United States imposed after World War II. Just as important, for the first time the Government is examining what it would be willing to do if a war broke out elsewhere in Asia, particularly in Korea. 
 Some scholars and diplomats say it is now an open question whether Japan will gradually move toward a more muscular foreign policy, backed by increasingly powerful armed forces. This might take decades, they say, but would eventually transform East Asia by shaping Japan into a military superpower as well as an economic one.
The taboo on security issues has eroded steadily in the last few years, but the crucial breakthrough came with the meeting last month in Tokyo between President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. Mr. Hashimoto pledged that Japan would review the 18-year-old guidelines limiting cooperation with the United States military in a war.
"There is less taboo in Japan in discussing security questions, and that's a good thing," said Sadayuki Hayashi, the Vice Foreign Minister.
The benefits of a review were evident when Mr. Hayashi was asked whether Japanese hospitals would be allowed to treat American soldiers if they were wounded in a nearby war. Mr. Hayashi paused and shrugged.
"I don't know the answer to that," he said. "And there are hundreds of questions like that."
Among the concrete issues that Japan is preparing to resolve with the United States are these: In another Korean war, would American military planes be able to use Japanese civilian airports? Would Japanese military planes or warships be able to pick up refugees in Korea? If Japanese ships or planes were about to be fired on in international waters, would they be allowed to fire back? If an American warship were attacked, would Japan be able to come to its assistance?
One of the obstacles to a larger security role is the sensitivity of Japan's neighbors, particularly China and North and South Korea, all of which have horrific memories of Japanese wartime atrocities.
Even the tiny steps that Japan has taken in the last few years -- such as sending peacekeepers to Cambodia and military relief specialists to Zaire -- have provoked a bit of nervousness in Asia.
Still, ever since the Persian Gulf war of 1991 made clear that international respect comes from joining in security operations and not just paying for them, Japan has become increasingly willing to send troops abroad as part of relief or peacekeeping operations.
Another barrier to a more activist policy is Japan's Constitution, which renounces war "and the threat or use of force as a means of settling international disputes." The United States drafted that language after World War II.
But these days it is Japan that is clinging to its peace Constitution, while the United States is encouraging Japan to play a role in international security. Two years ago, with fears of a war between the West and North Korea growing, the United States informally asked Japan to provide minesweepers in case of a war. Japan responded that it could not, because of the American-drafted Constitution.
Japan's formal position is that the Constitution bars it from exercising the right of "collective self-defense." In other words, it could defend itself if invaded, but could not contribute to an international blockade of North Korea or even intervene to help an American ship under attack in international waters.
Yasuhiro Nakasone, a former Prime Minister who advises Prime Minister Hashimoto on security matters, said he was urging a revision of this interpretation.
"For the time being, I believe we should proceed with changing the interpretation of the Constitution," Mr. Nakasone said. "But in the medium to long term, we should think of revising the Constitution."
For now, Mr. Hashimoto has made clear that he has no plans to move toward collective self-defense, and the United States insists that it is not trying to push Japan in that direction.
"We stay out of that," said Ambassador Walter F. Mondale. "We think that those kinds of debates can be helpful for Japan. But we're proceeding on the basis that the current Constitution and policies will apply."
Still, the idea of scrapping the Constitution may be gaining ground. The largest-circulation newspaper in Japan, Yomiuri Shimbun, a respected mainstream daily, last year published a draft of its proposed new constitution for Japan, and the opposition leader in Parliament, Ichiro Ozawa, has endorsed the idea of constitutional reinterpretation to allow collective self-defense.
The bulwark of opposition to any military role for Japan has been Asahi Shimbun, the second-largest newspaper in Japan and one that caters in particular to liberals and intellectuals. But while the editorial pages still condemn the idea of a broader security role, the news pages, particularly articles written by the newspaper's Washington bureau chief, have embraced the idea.
Likewise, it is no longer so shocking to mention the possibility that Japan might one day arm itself with nuclear weapons. Kiichi Miyazawa, another former Prime Minister, said in an interview that the newly fortified security partnership with America would "forestall the argument inside Japan that we should go nuclear, should be a big military power."
To be sure, the debates for now in Japan are likely to focus not on issues of developing nuclear weapons or even on collective self-defense. Rather, they will concern more mundane matters, like legislation under consideration that would allow Japan to use troop ships to evacuate refugees abroad in a crisis, like a war on the Korean Peninsula.
That proposal is controversial because the ships would be armed. Sending unarmed ships into a war zone might seem foolish, but World War II traumas linger in Japan in the form of a deep anxiety about exerting military force abroad, so many people would rather seem foolish than threatening.

HEADLINE: Nintendo Capitalism: Zapping The Markets;
Fast Electronic Trading Brings Increased Volatility

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
It's 7:29 A.M. high above South LaSalle Street and Patrick Beimford, the chief bond strategist of Zurich Kemper Investments, is poised like an orchestra conductor in front of three electronic screens. He and more than a dozen highly paid young traders and portfolio managers scan intently.
Then, exactly at 7:30, multicolored electronics flash the Government's eagerly awaited tally of consumer prices and retail sales for April -- favorable figures, as it happens, for the bond market that prompt an almost instant flurry of staccato barks and orders. 
 In a twinkling on this Tuesday morning, Mr. Beimford directs the purchase of 3,000 June futures contracts on the 30-year Treasury bond, a transaction involving control of securities worth $300 million and one that is intended to protect the firm against interest rate moves. "We're going from short to neutral," he explained.
Mr. Beimford and his crew are part of a computer-linked, worldwide network of traders and investors whose split-second reactions magnify every smidgen of economic news, from a trade association traffic survey and counts of people newly applying for unemployment benefits to the growth of payrolls and changes in interest-rate policy announced by the Federal Reserve.
This Nintendo capitalism, as the marriage of microchips and mathematics has been dubbed, has led to increasingly volatile markets in recent years, especially for fixed-income securities. And now the longstanding concern about wide swings in the market has broadened into a debate over whether such volatility actually harms or benefits the real economy in which houses are built, wages are paid and college tuitions are financed.
Day after day, the chief raw material for trading-room hyperkinetics is the mundane, detailed reports from the Government intended to facilitate public appraisal of economic performance. But that lofty goal seems overtaken by the split-second decisions of traders caught up in a process of mass psychology.
"You have to try to understand things relative to what people are expecting -- and trade off that, not try to find out the ultimate truth," said John E. Silvia, Zurich Kemper's chief economist. At critical moments he is usually within shouting range of Mr. Beimford and other traders. "This gives an almost existential quality to the market, with perception being reality."
With this mindset, it's probably unavoidable that bond traders act as a herd, often overreacting and discovering in hindsight that they have driven rates too low or too high -- extremes that may have an almost immediate practical effect in an economic world of point-of-sale information systems and just-in-time inventories.
Today's high-tech super-efficient financial markets have "the capability of transmitting mistakes at a far faster pace throughout the financial system in ways that were unknown a generation ago," Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told an audience in Frankfurt earlier this month. He specifically cited the way the currency market punished Mexico for policy errors by battering the peso in late 1994 and early 1995, but his comments seemed to reflect a growing sense among policy makers that they are captives of the market rather than its masters, leaving the Government mostly to provide a final backstop against catastrophe.
"You could say it's really the bond markets that run the country, not the President and not Alan Greenspan," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Chase Regional Bank.
But trading at cyberspeed may hold some advantages. Indeed, many experts argue that it makes possible a greater liquidity of capital worldwide, with long-term benefits outweighing the risks of short-term error. And it serves as an instant referendum on the actions of Government policy makers, forcing them to face up to potentially costly mistakes much faster than before.
"It makes people nervous and it costs some people money," said James E. Annable Jr., chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "But you get efficiency from deep, liquid markets."
Mr. Beimford and his Zurich Kemper colleagues, though presiding over $45 billion of mutual fund assets, actually are among the less frantic players in this intense everyday drama, a process largely removed from outside scrutiny.
The main work of Zurich Kemper's classic "buy side" operation -- as opposed to more feverish "sell side" banks and trading houses -- is to pick bonds and stocks for semi-permanent inclusion in their numerous portfolios, shunning big speculative exposure of their own. In buying the 3,000 Treasury contracts on May 14 after the 30-year bond had spurted nearly three-quarters of a point, or $7.50 for each $1,000, Mr. Beimford unwound half of the firm's hedge against holdings of portfolio tax-exempts.
But even in this comparative island of calm, watching Mr. Beimford and other Zurich Kemper strategists anticipate and respond to the daily parade of Government and other numbers over parts of a recent three-day period point up the ever-tighter relationship between the gauges of economic performance and the market verdicts on them that feed back to the economy.
At a 7:15 A.M. meeting of his fixed-income strategists on the day before the consumer price and retail sales data were released, Mr. Beimford expressed a basically negative long-term view of the bond market, even though he mused that prices might work a bit higher -- and interest rates a bit lower -- in the short term.
He had become progressively less optimistic as prospects vanished over the winter for a balanced-budget agreement and as a report of a ballooning of payroll jobs in February indicated that the economy had skirted recession and thereby dimmed chances for further easing of monetary policy. Finally came the May 2 report that the economy expanded at a unexpectedly robust rate of 2.8 percent during the first quarter.
"That number put a big kink in our entire economic outlook," Mr. Beimford said, prompting a decision to shorten by about half a year the duration -- a refined gauge of average maturity -- of his $34 billion fixed-income portfolio.
And despite the relatively soft Consumer Price Index and retail figures for April, at a 2:30 meeting the Zurich Kemper interest-rate committee raised its target range for the Treasury's 10-year and 30-year bonds by one-quarter of a percentage point.
With its earlier action, Zurich Kemper had contributed a bit to the upward lurch in long-term interest rates that blunted the usual springtime pickup in the real estate market and brought mortgage refinancing to a near halt, an unusually clear example of the market's sway over the economy.
At the same time, the lift that the consumer price and retail sales reports gave the bond market was quickly reflected in a higher stock market, developments greeted by Steven H. Reynolds, Zurich Kemper's chief stock strategist, as a chance to get a better price for the cyclical paper, chemical and steel stocks he has been disposing of recently. "We'll wait a day or two and sell a little stock into that strength," Mr. Reynolds said.
His view is that just as the markets became overly pessimistic about the economy early in the year, they now seem to reflect unwarranted optimism about 1996 growth.
This suggests to Mr. Reynolds and his portfolio managers that stocks are headed moderately higher, buoyed by a drifting down of interest rates, which places them somewhat at odds with the view of Mr. Beimford, the bond chief.
"Portfolio managers have a lot of latitude," observed Mr. Silvia, though he said differences were typically more a matter of timing or emphasis than outright disagreement.
Thus, Gary A. Langbaum, who manages $3.6 billion of stocks and bonds for Zurich Kemper, raised his holdings of shares in banks and other financial services companies, which may be able to fatten their spreads if market rates drift down. He bought $5 million to $8 million worth of each of four issues, saying that if the inflation report had been high he would have bought them later in the week at lower prices.
Similarly, Tracy McCormick Chester, another portfolio manager, confirmed her belief that interest rates have peaked and decided to fill a gap by buying shares of a money-center bank. She's been cashing in profits racked up lately in retail stocks, a strategy seemingly borne out by the report that sales eased three-tenths of 1 percent in April, the first decline this year.
But while stock market gyrations do affect the economy -- though even the October 1987 collapse did not bring on recession -- what really counts is the action taken by bond market people like Mr. Beimford and others who make their living trying to stay one step ahead of what often seems like irrational competition.
"Sometimes I just throw up my hands" because of exaggerated responses to trivial or inconsistent data, said Mickey D. Levy, chief financial economist in New York for Nationsbank, a primary dealer in Treasury securities and an active "sell side" operation with many clients like Zurich Kemper.
But whatever the excessive gyrations in the short run -- and Mr. Levy is dismayed at the recent proliferation of regional statistics and surveys that he says adds to such volatility -- most specialists seem to agree that the high-tech trading serves an important purpose.
Even when traders overshoot, their mistakes can be corrected, so long as the financial system is open enough that homeowners, for example, can jump in as they did when rates tumbled in 1993 and take the occasion to refinance.
Such cases, in fact, suggest that market volatility tends to limit, rather than exaggerate, swings in the economy by shortening the process by which economic actors respond to market signals. That is the way David W. Mullins Jr., a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve who is now an investment manager in Greenwich, Conn., sees it."Feedback mechanisms," he said, "tend to be inherently stabilizing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In today's markets, traders use sophisticated economic models and powerful computers to help them make quick buy and sell decisions based on the latest economic news. The result is that the markets are more volatile, a situation that has been dubbed Nintendo capitalism. (Photo illustration by The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Survey Points To Growth In Job Market

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The job market is expected to improve this summer, led by a pickup in construction industry employment and continued strength in the Midwest, according to a new survey.
The study by Manpower Inc., the nation's leading temporary employment company, found that 27 percent of the businesses surveyed expected to increase employment in the third quarter, up from 26 percent in the second quarter. In the third quarter of 1995, 28 percent intended to expand their work forces. 
 "There is a very early indication in our new figures that an improvement in job formation may be under way," Mitchell S. Fromstein, Manpower's chief executive, said yesterday in a statement.
"While the projected growth is still relatively cautious, we see a quarter-to-quarter increase in activity that was not present a year ago," he said. "It is too early to tell if the growth in the job market can be sustained."
Among the companies surveyed, 7 percent expected staff reductions in the third quarter and 63 percent intended to leave employment at present levels; 3 percent of the companies were undecided.
Nationwide, 40 percent of construction companies planned to increase employment, leading all industries. Next were wholesalers and retailers -- 32 percent plan additions -- followed by producers of durable goods, at 29 percent.
Companies in the Midwest reported the biggest increase in hiring plans. Thirty percent intend to increase employment in the third quarter.
The West is second, with 28 percent, followed by the South with 26 percent and the Northeast at 25 percent.
Manpower based the survey results on telephone interviews conducted with managers at about 16,000 businesses in 484 United States cities.

HEADLINE: Most U.S. and Foreign Markets Take a Holiday

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Asian stock markets were little changed yesterday as holidays in the United States and most of Europe greatly thinned trading.
Japanese stocks fell on light volume as doubts over the immediate outlook for the economy clouded the market. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 98.67 points, or nearly five-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,699.76. 
 But today, Tokyo stocks were revived, with the Nikkei up 244.77 points, or 1.13 percent, to close at 21,944.53. Still, some analysts seemed to be betting that an overall sluggishness would dominate trading.
"A weaker tone will remain in the market for a while, with no active buyers appearing," said Kiyoshi Kimura, general manager of the research department at Societe Generale Securities in Tokyo.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index of 33 leading stocks gained 62.53 points, to 11,081.69, but turnover fell to a low for the year. This morning, the index declined very slightly, easing 4.32 points -- less than one-twentieth of 1 percent -- to stand at 11,077.37.
"Everybody's just waiting for the U.S. to reopen," said Alan Au of PW Asia Brokerage in Hong Kong.
All financial markets in the United States were closed in observance of Memorial Day. In Europe, most markets were also closed for national holidays. Exchanges in Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece and Ireland were among the relatively few open.
Trading was slow in Canadian and Mexican stocks, both closing slightly higher. The Toronto Stock Exchange index of 300 stocks edged up 5.65 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 5,235.50. The main Mexico City index rose 14.05 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 3,327.24.
The exchange rate of the dollar slipped in Tokyo and in limited European trading, then rebounded early today. This morning in Asian trading, the dollar sold for 108.125 Japanese yen, up from 107.75 yen in Milan late yesterday and from 107.80 yen on Friday in New York. The dollar traded at 1.5440 German marks, up from 1.5420 marks both yesterday in Europe and late Friday in New York.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: STRANGER ON THE BLOCK -- A special report.;
At Center of 'Megan's Law' Case, a Man No One Could Reach

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

DATELINE: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
Her name was Megan. Most people do not know his name.
He confessed to strangling and raping her in 1994, the police say. She had just finished first grade. He lived across the street. His is the story of what the country fears. 
 He had pleaded guilty twice before to sexually assaulting small children. In 1981, a judge had labeled him a "compulsive, repetitive sexual offender." Then, after he had served more than seven years for his two crimes, he and two other convicted child molesters quietly moved here, into a neighborhood of split-level homes where people tend their gardens and their children well. Not long afterward, Megan Kanka was killed.
Megan's death has become part of the national psyche. A dozen states have passed laws named for her requiring that communities be notified when sex offenders move in. President Clinton signed a national "Megan's Law" on May 17.
The courts and the public have begun a long debate about whether such laws will work and are constitutional. This spring, the Random House Webster's College Dictionary added "Megan's Law" as a new term in the language.
His name is Jesse K. Timmendequas. He turned 35 last month. He is a slight man with the same dirty blond hair and the same nervous preoccupation with himself that people who knew him as a teen-ager in Piscataway remember.
Mr. Timmendequas (pronounced tim-MEN-duh-qwas) is in jail in Mercer County, N.J., awaiting trial for the killing. Prosecutors will seek the death penalty. He pleaded not guilty. He did not respond to a request for an interview, and his lawyer declined to answer questions for this article.
But public records across New Jersey and interviews with people who knew him and with psychologists, detectives, lawyers, a judge and other professionals who dealt with him fill out a picture as never before. It is a picture of the type of sex offender who defies efforts at rehabilitation, one who, because of Megan's death, has become a catalyst for a national change in the laws.
At a restaurant off the Garden State Parkway one recent afternoon, one of his victims described the bitter memories he left behind. She is a bubbly 22-year-old college student. It has been 15 years since Mr. Timmendequas attacked her.
She described the turmoil she felt when she heard who was accused of killing Megan Kanka.
"I wanted to kill him myself," said the young woman, who spoke on the condition that her name not be used. "They didn't stop him the first time."
She was attacked in 1981 after Mr. Timmendequas lured her into the woods with the promise of firecrackers. Yellowed police records include Mr. Timmendequas's admission that he ran away afterward, thinking he had choked her to death. "After she turned blue, I became scared," he said, according to a police transcript. "I dropped her and I thought she was dead."
The young woman was attacked when she was 7, the same age as Megan Kanka when she was strangled with a leather belt 13 years later. Both girls bit down on their tongues as they struggled for breath.
The stranger in the neighborhood had appeared pleasant, if ineffectual, over the years to people who did not know about his secret thoughts. He helped an elderly man next door move furniture. "He was one of those quiet kids," remembered Mark Ciardi, a classmate in the Piscataway High School class of 1979.
Cases against him stemming from assaults in 1979 and 1981 were routine in the legal system. He benefited from plea bargains in both cases. Because children often make poor witnesses, prosecutors can be reluctant to take molestation cases to trial.
There is no evidence that he benefited from treatment offered him through the years. At one point, he failed to go to counseling even though a judge had ordered him into therapy as the only way to avoid jail. Some who knew what little he would reveal about his thoughts believed there was a danger he would attack children again.
"I didn't think he would kill someone," said Rashmi Skadegaard, who was director of psychology at the Adult Diagnostic and Treatment Center in Avenel, N.J., where Mr. Timmendequas served six years. "But I certainly thought somebody was going to be his victim."
State law-enforcement officials have repeatedly said that, without a notification rule, the state has no role after any sex offender like Mr. Timmendequas completes a sentence.

The First Attack
 
Two Little Girls, And a Stranger
If anyone had been watching at about 4:30 on a fall afternoon in Piscataway in 1979, nothing would have seemed unusual. Two kindergarten girls were playing a few doors down from the modest but neatly kept suburban house where one of them lived. Jesse Timmendequas, 18, rode by on his bicycle.
He later told the police he was heading toward the apartment he shared with his mother, Doris Gorman, and her four other children in a rundown building three blocks away, on William Street in the New Market Pond area. Across William Street from where the girls were playing, a wooded embankment led to a stream.
To the extent that people remember Mr. Timmendequas at all from those days, it is as someone who seemed not to fit in. "Jesse was just there," said a Piscataway school administrator who would only speak with a promise of anonymity. "He occupied a space. Nobody even really knew him."
A few days after Mr. Timmendequas' 1979 arrest, a Piscataway detective, Richard Hand, wrote in a police report, misspelling the suspect's first name: "Jessie to my knowledge is known to hang around with boys much younger than himself, ages 10, 12 and 13 years of age. He has had several problems with the younger boys over in the pond area, New Market Pond, where he has had fights with them and throwing a few of them into the pond."
According to one person who has seen psychological reports prepared after that arrest, Mr. Timmendequas said then that he remembered as traumatic an incident when he was 8: A group of older girls took his clothes away and forced him to walk home through the streets.
That Monday afternoon in October 1979, after he rode up William Street on his bicycle, he persuaded the two 5-year-old girls to go off with him in search of ducks. Mr. Timmendequas, according to the police report, took them by the hand and led them toward the embankment.
At the bottom -- the police report does not say why -- one of the girls broke away and ran for help, leaving him with the other kindergartner.
"When we got down to the bottom of the hill by the brook, I knocked her down and then pulled her pants down," Mr. Timmendequas said in a statement he gave after the police confronted him the next day.
He told the police he just wanted to look at her vagina. But the little girl said he had smelled her. Then, she said, "I started to cry and he put his hand over my mouth."
By then, a neighbor who had been alerted by the other 5-year-old was on her way across William Street. Mr. Timmendequas and the little girl ran back up the hill. "She started to cry," his statement said, "and I ran back up the hill and got my bike and took off towards home."
Later that fall, Mr. Timmendequas pleaded guilty to attempted aggravated sexual assault. Judge John E. Bachman of State Superior Court in Middlesex County concluded that, "While he certainly has mental or psychiatric problems, these seem to be of the type which can be dealt with best in an outpatient setting," and gave Mr. Timmendequas a suspended sentence on the condition that he go for counseling.
Court records show that he did not live up to those terms. Cited for violating the terms of his sentence, he served nine months in the Middlesex County Adult Correctional Center.
 
The Second Attack
 
Out of Jail, Back on the Prowl
By the end of June in 1981, he was out of jail. He had an apartment in Dunellen, not far from Piscataway.
About a quarter-mile from his apartment, there was a patch of woods. At the far edge of the woods was Middlesex Borough's public pool and tennis courts. Even now, neighbors let their children play alone there because it seems safe.
That was where two 7-year-old girls, best friends, were playing the day Jesse Timmendequas came up to them. He asked if they wanted firecrackers for the Fourth of July. Mr. Timmendequas would later tell police he had waited in the area about an hour before he saw the girls, according to a transcript of his statement.
One of the girls panicked, got on a bicycle and went screaming off in search of their mothers. In his statement, Mr. Timmendequas described what happened next with the other child.
"We walked down the trail a little bit and I grabbed her around the throat," he said, "and pulled her off to the side of the woods and when she started to turn blue I let her go and ran and that's it."
An officer asked if he had been aroused. "Yes. A little bit," the transcript quotes him saying.
Mr. Timmendequas, who had just turned 20, said he had been sexually interested in little girls for about a year. An officer asked if he knew what had caused that. "No," was all he answered.
The girl's mother found her unconscious in the woods. The police were called. When Mr. Timmendequas walked out of the woods on the Dunellen side, a police car was waiting. A small stream separated that area from the scene of the assault. Mr. Timmendequas' blue jeans were wet from the knee down.
In the hospital, the doctors concluded no sexual contact had occurred. The girl's father, who sat next to her during the recent interview, said he and his wife have never been able to wipe away the image of their daughter with blue marks on her neck where she had been choked. On her stomach was a black and blue handprint where her attacker had gripped her.
When Megan Kanka was killed all those years later, the father said, he felt he knew what his family had been spared. "As the years go by," he said, "you store it in the back of your mind. When this happened all I could think of was, 'That could have been my daughter.' "
 
In a Program
 
Sitting Silently Through Therapy
For the incident in Middlesex, Mr. Timmendequas was charged with five felonies including kidnapping and attempted murder. But as is often true in such cases, the charges were difficult to prove. The prosecutor, Joyce Munkacsi, said in an interview that the little girl remembered nothing that would establish the sexual aspects of the case. And the girl's parents hoped to avoid a trial.
Mr. Timmendequas "seemed to want some type of assistance," said Ms. Munkacsi, now a judge in Middlesex County.
They bargained. Mr. Timmendequas would plead guilty to attempted sexual contact and attempting to cause serious bodily injury and would be sent to New Jersey's center for sexual offenders at Avenel.
The other charges were dropped. The maximum prison term was 10 years and the judge in the case, C. Judson Hamlin, imposed it, finding that Mr. Timmendequas "constitutes a danger to the public at large and to young children in particular."
Judge Hamlin specified that Mr. Timmendequas should serve the maximum. But as everyone with experience in the New Jersey courts knew then, a 10-year sentence really meant 6 years 8 months with credit for good behavior. Since then, partly as a result of this case, legislators have been under pressure to change laws to make criminals serve more of their sentences.
In an interview, Judge Hamlin said he had no illusions that he could make Mr. Timmendequas less of a risk. "I had no thought there was going to be some magic that was going to happen," he said, "which is why I tried to warehouse him as long as I could."
Avenel's therapeutic approach to sexual offenders has been criticized for years by some officials who say it coddles offenders and does not provide adequate treatment. Supporters say its therapy represents the only chance that some child molesters and rapists who are destined to return to the streets can gain enough insight to control themselves.
But both sides say that all sex-offender treatment programs are particularly frustrated by the many offenders who do not open up to treatment. People who were at Avenel at the time say Mr. Timmendequas never seemed engaged in therapy.
A former inmate testified before a New Jersey legislative task force on Avenel in 1994. Some inmates refuse to go to treatment at all, he said.
"You have other people like Jesse Timmendequas, who will go to a group and sit there," said the inmate, who testified with his identity kept confidential. "They sit there silently, whether it is someone else who has the floor or when the therapist says 'It's your turn to have the floor today.' They kind of muddle their way through."
Edward D. Balyk, a therapist at Avenel, remembered Mr. Timmendequas.
"He was a pouter," Dr. Balyk said. "Then he'd go hide. He spent a lot of time in bed."
 
The Death of Megan
 
Three Molesters Move In Next Door
At Avenel, Mr. Timmendequas met the two other sex offenders with whom he eventually moved to Megan Kanka's street. One was Brian R. Jenin, five years older than Mr. Timmendequas. In one case involving an 11-year-old boy, according to court records, a judge in Burlington County found that Mr. Jenin had "joined the Big Brother organization so he could have access to young boys. So he could sexually molest them."
The other was Joseph F. Cifelli, who was six years older. In 1976, Mr. Cifelli had been charged with carnal abuse and sodomy of a 5-year-old girl. He pleaded guilty to three counts of impairing the morals of a minor.
Mr. Cifelli's and Mr. Jenin's crimes are the types of acts covered by "Megan's Law." Corrections officials in New Jersey say they think both men have stayed out of prison since their release from Avenel, but that since they moved away from the Kanka's block after her slaying, their whereabouts are unknown.
For a time after Mr. Timmendequas was released from Avenel in 1988, he worked at the Montgomery Township Parks Department as a laborer. In 1991 and 1992, he told the police, he and Mr. Jenin lived together in San Diego. Then, they moved into the two-story house with white aluminum siding on Barbara Lee Drive that was diagonally across the street from the Kankas' house. The house belonged to Mr. Cifelli's mother, who was 72 and had Alzheimer's disease.
Mr. Cifelli had lived there as a child and had returned there in 1987 when he was released from Avenel. He and Mr. Timmendequas got jobs in Princeton Township mowing lawns at parks and playgrounds. Mr. Jenin described himself as an unemployed travel agent.
Some of the neighbors knew about Mr. Cifelli's past. But Megan's mother, Maureen Kanka, who had lived here 16 years, said no one told her about it. She had no reason to worry that evening in the summer of 1994 when Megan went out to look for a friend who lived in the house next to Mrs. Cifelli's.
For 23 hours after that, neighbors and police searched. They checked parks and trash bins. They used dogs trained to follow a scent. Mr. Timmendequas helped hand out fliers of the little missing girl.
When the police searched house to house, Mr. Cifelli and Mr. Jenin could prove they had been out doing errands when Megan had disappeared. Mr. Timmendequas seemed nervous, was perspiring heavily and chain smoking, the police wrote in their reports.
As they learned about Mr. Timmendequas' record, they called around New Jersey. From Middlesex Borough, Detective Sgt. Robert F. Schwarz drove south to Hamilton Township. Back in 1981, Patrolman Robert F. Schwarz, new on the force, had arrested the young Jesse Timmendequas who had tried to strangle the little girl in the woods.
At Hamilton Township's police headquarters, Detective Schwarz introduced himself to Mr. Timmendequas, who, he said, seemed relieved to see a familiar face. Within a few hours, Mr. Timmendequas told the police he had killed Megan while raping her. He was afraid she would tell her mother that he had touched her and tried to kiss her, according to portions of his statement.
Mr. Timmendequas agreed to take the police to Mercer County Park, where, he said, he had left Megan's body in a pile of weeds. Detective Schwarz rode with him. As he described the little girl's death in the car, the detective said, there was no moment when he expressed sorrow for her.
"Even then," Detective Schwarz said, "he was only concerned about himself: 'How much time am I going to get?' Everything was about himself." In the back of the patrol car, Mr. Timmendequas lay down so Megan's neighbors would not see him.
Prosecutors have said in court that Mr. Timmendequas got Megan into the house by offering to let her pet his new puppy.
Mrs. Kanka, her husband, Richard, and their two other children no longer have to look at the house where Mr. Timmendequas lived. Through their bay window, they now see a small park that has been built in Megan's memory where the house was.
Mrs. Kanka speaks often around the country, lobbying for the law and warning parents to take care of their children. She has asked for permission to address jurors at Mr. Timmendequas' trial, to ask them to impose the death penalty. "They need to understand," she said, "that people get hurt when something like this happens. And it's not something that goes away. It's not any better now than it was the first day."
Even now, she cannot bring herself to speak his name.

HEADLINE: G.M. to Tap Asian Market, And 2 Nations Bid for Plant

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 27

 BODY:
In Thailand, where the country's bargaining position is strong, the official attitude is studied nonchalance. In the Philippines, where officials are desperate to get into the game, almost anything goes.
The game is auto manufacturing in the world's fastest-growing market, and both countries are bidding for a plum: the first full-scale assembly plant to be built in the region by the General Motors Corporation. 
 The company expects to make a decision next month, and depending on a number of variables, the plant could cost from $500 million to $1 billion, said Andrew Andersz, a G.M. spokesman in Singapore. He declined to offer more specifics but industry analysts said the plant was expected to produce well over 100,000 small cars a year and provide 2,000 or more jobs.
In the Philippines, where the auto industry is young, the plant could generate thousands of additional jobs among subcontractors and suppliers.
The decision on where to put the plant is important for the two countries but also crucial for G.M., which sees Asia as its biggest growth market in the decade ahead. John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said this month that his company planned to capture 10 percent of the Asian market by 2005, up from 5 percent now.
Southeast Asia along with China lies at the core of G.M.'s strategy. Vehicle sales in Southeast Asia increased fivefold from 1980 to 1995, Mr. Smith said, while acknowledging that American auto makers had initially missed an opportunity in this region and that the Japanese had a strong foothold here now. "The Southeast Asian countries are looking for alternatives to Japanese vehicles," he said. "We do have this opportunity to take market share."
At first glance, Thailand is the natural choice. Already a regional center with a growing number of new or planned auto plants, including those of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, its eastern seaboard is turning into a little Detroit.
The competition between Thailand and the Philippines offers a glimpse at the pattern of development in a rapidly industrializing region: growth feeds on growth.
"If G.M. does come, it means Thailand will have really become a car hub in this region," said Chakramon Phasukavanich, deputy secretary general of the Thai Board of Investment. "But even without G.M., we can be a car hub."
John Bonnell, regional director for the market research company Automotive Resources Asia, added: "The G.M. plant would be much bigger for the Philippines than for Thailand. It would transform the picture."
In the Philippines, where the auto industry is negligible, General Motors executives have been met with a hungrier attitude.
"I offered them 50 hectares of low-lying undeveloped area right next to Subic proper," said Richard Gordon, chairman of the Subic Bay Free Port at the former United States naval base 100 miles north of Manila. "They said the land was too soft. So I put them in a chopper and took them to another area. They were pretty amazed at how fast we were handling it. And I offered to develop the area -- power, water, communications and land development -- and I offered it to them rent-free for five years."
The Government is also offering a package of tax breaks, including a tax holiday for the first eight years, duty-free import of machinery, a waiver of local-content rules for car exports and a Government-financed training program for auto workers.
For General Motors, the move is as important as it is for the host nations. If Asian economies continue to grow at close to 8 percent a year, the regional auto market could equal or better that of the United States, at 16 million vehicles a year within the next decade, predicted Victor Sun, a regional auto analyst for Peregrine Brokerage Ltd. in Hong Kong.
G.M. defines the market as extending from Japan and South Korea in the north to New Zealand in the south, but excluding the Indian subcontinent. The company currently has plants in Indonesia and Taiwan that assemble about 20,000 vehicles a year for domestic markets.
Outside Japan and South Korea, Thailand has emerged as the region's leading auto maker, producing 580,000 vehicles last year, including 330,000 pickup trucks, which makes it the second-largest producer of pickups after the United States. By the end of the century, Thailand aims to be producing one million vehicles a year, Mr. Chakramon said.
This translates into a broad base of hundreds of automotive component manufacturers, a major attraction in contrast to the Philippines, where the industry is mostly limited to transmissions and some other components.
"What Thailand is really offering is that there is already an automotive component infrastructure here," said Richard Stampfle, president of the Lear Seating (Thailand) Company. "You don't need to build one. You can go out and buy your parts."
His company, a unit of the Lear Corporation of Southfield, Mich., is one of the component manufacturers ready and waiting for General Motors in Thailand.
This growing manufacturing presence here, along with the network of roads and ports, continues to attract still more factories. In addition to most of the major Japanese manufacturers, Chrysler recently began producing and marketing its Jeep Cherokee here and Ford, together with the Mazda Motor Corporation of Japan, is building a factory to produce compact pickup trucks.
With these advantages, Thailand is wooing General Motors primarily with the package of incentives it offers to all companies that choose rural areas away from the congested capital of Bangkok.
The package includes tax exemptions on export earnings for the first eight years, followed by a 50 percent tax reduction for the next five years, as well as an exemption from tariffs on machinery imports for the first two years.
At the request of General Motors, Thailand has also agreed in principle to finance a $15 million automotive training institute as long as it is open to other manufacturers, Mr. Chakramon said.
In its greatest concession, Thailand has acceded to a request by the company that it lift a 54 percent local-content requirement for all auto makers by July 1998, 18 months ahead of a deadline for such a move set by the World Trade Organization.
"That means we are really trying to please General Motors," Mr. Chakramon said. Although the shortened deadline would apply to all manufacturers, he said, it is a concession Thailand has in the past refused to other companies, which meant they had to invest in local production lines for parts and components.
He said Thailand had declined to match the offer by the Philippines of rent-free land, adding, "We don't have free public land to give away."
And he said Thailand had also turned down a request by General Motors for an exemption from the nation's 20 percent import tariff on components because of a need to protect local manufacturers.
"We have a couple of hundred auto parts makers in the country and we have to give them some protection," he said. "We have agreed to abolish the local-content requirement and if we slash the duty tariff as well, I think they will be in trouble."
